DOC.HEAD: French Speakers From U.S. Seek To Promote Language Back Home
DOC.TEXT: Paris is the venue for many strategy sessions dedicated to the defense and promotion of the French language, but this one had a distinctively American accent. There was Virgil Benoit of Red Lake Falls, Minn., who noted that the motto on his state flag was ``L'Etoile du Nord'' - the Northern Star. There was Randolph Lineham, a lawyer from Long Beach, Calif., whose ancestors emigrated in 1870 when Prussia annexed the Alsace region. And there was Floyd Satterlee of Indianapolis with no French connection other than a love of the language and culture. They were among 45 delegates from 20 states, representing the estimated 1.5 million French-speaking U.S. citizens, who gathered in Paris last week to assess the prospects for the language of Voltaire in the land of french toast and french fries. The best-known French-speakers in the United States are likely Louisiana's nearly 600,000 Cajuns. But there are French-speaking communities from Maine to the Pacific, conference delegates said. Lineham said speaking French has been considered chic in certain California circles for a long time. The Francophone community there continues to grow with the arrival of immigrants from the former French colonies of Cambodia and Vietnam. More than half the delegates in Paris were professors. Normand Beaupre, a university teacher and writer from Biddeford, Maine, still remembers when Franco-Americans were called ``the Chinese of the East'' because many of them worked in New England textile mills. ``We were told, `Speak American,''' he said. Beaupre, 55, says it's no longer a liability to be a French-speaking American. ``I have my own identity.'' he said. ``I am not a Quebecer, nor a Frenchman, nor a Cajun. I am a Franco-American.'' The 1980 census registered 13 million Americans of French origin. The first French arrived at the end of the 16th century, and France lost its last territory in the present-day U.S. with the Louisiana Purchase in 1803. The three-day meeting was organized by a French association formed 13 years ago to strengthen ties with French-speaking Americans. The French Foreign Ministry and Paris mayor's office provided part of the funding. At the close of the conference, delegates voted to seek improved teaching of French at U.S. schools, promote French-oriented local festivals and push for a greater availability of TV programs and written material in French. ``After the second generation, the French language is very often lost by the children,'' Beaupre said. ``We need a new strategy, and this is to link with the international Francophone movement rather than staying alone in each state.''

DOC.HEAD: For a Man Of Firsts, Will It Be No. 9?
DOC.TEXT: Lech Walesa has had a lot of firsts - the latest being becoming Poland's first popularly elected president - but now it looks like a No. 9 is in store. Already the parents of eight, the 47-year-old Walesa and his wife, Danuta, 41, are reported to be expecting another child. According to Monday's Sztandar Mlodych newspaper, Solidarity headquarters was abuzz Sunday night with more than word of Walesa's landslide victory. The newspaper said that during the victory celebration, ``headquarters staff couldn't resist talking about children ... the `First Lady,' although it is not visible yet, is in the third month of her pregnancy.'' The report could not be confirmed independently. Aides in Gdansk declined to speak about it. The youngest of the Walesa children, Brygida, was born in 1985. The eldest, Bogdan, is 20 and was married in September.

DOC.HEAD: If War Comes, Women Soldiers Will Die: Is America Ready?
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Diane Evans' parents had four sons and two daughters. It was Diane who went to war. ``No place in Vietnam was safe,'' the former Army nurse recalls. ``We were in a combat zone and we were subject to attack.'' It saddens her that two decades later, America still is coming to grips with the prospect that women may die in war alongside men. If there is a war in the Persian Gulf, for the first time in history American women may be injured or killed in significant numbers. The Pentagon won't say how many women serve among the 240,000 U.S. troops in the gulf, only that they comprise somewhat less of the gulf contingent than their 11 percent share of the overall U.S. military. Images of women soldiers feature prominently in news reports from Saudi Arabia. And the role played by women has expanded, allowing them to serve in a whole range of support positions that were off limits in days past. Many argue that makes them more vulnerable if fighting breaks out. ``Although women don't fill combat positions, the roles that they are serving in will expose them to hostile fire,'' said Meredith Neizer, head of the Defense Advisory Committee on Women in the Service. No one is sure how the nation would respond to female casualties. ``After all we've said about how far women have come, Americans are not ready to have their women go out there and get maimed and killed in combat,'' said Bill Taylor of the Center for Strategic and International Studies. Taylor said the number of women killed or injured in a gulf war probably would be low because women don't serve in tank and armored infantry units. But even the possibility of casualties among women is generating debate about the expanding role of women in the military and the accompanying risks. ``There's been a wakeup call on what wartime military duty might entail,'' said Martin Binkin, a military analyst with the Brookings Institution. There's less discussion about scrapping the military's ban on women in combat jobs, he said. Women are barred by law from serving on combat sips and planes in the Navy, Air Force and Marines. The Army bars them from serving in combat-related fields such as infantry, tank and some artillery units. But women serve in many of the support and supply units that could be caught in battle. Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo., is pushing legislation to require a four-year test to see how women would perform in combat-related jobs. She argues that excluding women from combat jobs doesn't insulate them from danger but it does deny them career advancement opportunities. Women, she says, often handle the communications for maneuvers, and communications centers are considered prime targets for attack. ``Women would be the first hit in a strike,'' Schroeder said. She rejects arguments that Americans aren't ready to see women wounded or killed. Female police officers face life-threatening dangers daily, she notes. And a few women ``came home in body bags'' from both World War II and Vietnam, she said. Eight women nurses and more than 58,000 men died in Vietnam. More than 200 women and more than 400,000 men died in World War II. Retired Air Force Brig. Gen. Wilma Vaught, president of the Women in the Military Service of America Foundation, believes the public has overcome any special qualms about the wartime loss of women vs. men. ``We've progressed far from where we were,'' she said. ``People don't want their women killed any more than they want their men killed. They'd like for them all to live.'' And yet, Binkin cautions, ``you still have many people with traditional views that war is not a place for women.'' The question of women in combat is ``a very emotional issue and it could very well be reopened'' by the gulf operation, he said. Some critics believe the public has been conditioned to accept the expanding role of women in the military and the risk they could die in war. ``We've become numbed to a point,'' said Brian Mitchell, author of ``The Weak Link,'' a book critical of the ``feminization'' of the military. ``We've had enough propaganda about how great this is that women can go over there and fight and die like men,'' he said. ``The American public has been conditioned ... to think that this is just the way things are nowadays.'' A New York Times-CBS News poll taken in January 1990, after military women served ably in the U.S. invasion of Panama, found that seven of 10 Americans thought women should be allowed to serve in combat units if they wished. Opinion could quickly shift if hostilities result in images of women returning to U.S. soil in caskets, Binkin said. ``If we get into a combat situation that brings home the point of what war is all about, you might get different answers,'' he said. For Diane Evans, the Army nurse who served in Vietnam, the key to accepting the risks that women face in today's military lies in acknowledging their contributions in past conflicts. She directs the Vietnam Women's Memorial Project. ``We could have casualties in the gulf even before we have a memorial built to women who died in the last war,'' Ms. Evans said. ``We want the women who go off to the next one to know they will not be forgotten.''

DOC.HEAD: Justice or Quotas? Political Parties Wrestle With a Hot Issue
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The next presidential campaign will likely feature a fiery debate over affirmative action. But one party will call it simple justice, the other will label it unfair quotas and voters will have to decide whom to believe. Sen. Jesse Helms rode to re-election in North Carolina after accusing his black challenger, Democrat Harvey Gantt, of supporting racial quotas. And while some denounced the tactic, others detected a way to bolster the identity and electoral strength of the Republican Party. ``Helms came from 13 points behind to win comfortably, I think solely on this issue,'' said GOP consultant Roger Stone. ``It is the kind of cutting social issue that conservatives need to hold onto the White House.'' A number of recent developments suggest voters may be hearing a lot more about affirmative action and racial quotas between now and November 1992: -Democratic congressional leaders have renewed their pledge to once again pass a civil rights bill that President Bush branded a quota bill and vetoed in the last Congress. -Virginia Gov. Doug Wilder, the only Democrat blatantly testing the 1992 presidential waters, blasted Bush's characterization of the bill and said it gave Helms phony ammunition. ``I know what racial quotas are; I have experienced them firsthand,'' Wilder, who is black, said in a letter to Bush. -William Bennett, the new Republican Party chairman, defended Helms' use of the quota issue and said he was ready to debate affirmative action if the Democrats bring it up. ``Most Americans are troubled'' by racial preference programs, he said. -Rep. Richard Gephardt, the House Democratic leader, chided Bennett for his remarks in a speech last week and charged that ``ideologues on the right are following a new trail of racial resentment and recrimination'' blazed by Louisiana state legislator David Duke. -Disaffected Democrats at a conservative forum predicted doom for their party unless more moderate voices are heard. ``Until we give up fear and discuss these issues rationally and logically, we are going to continue to lose,'' said former New York Mayor Ed Koch. Prominent Democrats say their party has a sound position but others have distorted it. ``I don't know what there is to redefine,'' said party chairman Ron Brown, who is black. ``The Democratic Party and its chairman in particular vehemently oppose quotas. We vehemently oppose anything that could lead to reverse discrimination. The legislation that the Democratic Congress sent forward to the president was not a quota bill. It was supported by a number of conservative Republicans.'' But the Democrats - including Gantt himself - acknowledge that they haven't communicated well with voters, many of whom equate affirmative action with quotas. As Stone noted, ``Harvey Gantt ran up and down North Carolina saying he wasn't for quotas, but nobody believed him.'' Working against the Democrats is a feeling among some voters that the civil rights agenda of the 1960s has been fulfilled - that affirmative action was supposed to be temporary and small-scale and has outlived its time. But Gantt said hundreds of years of discrimination cannot be remedied in two decades. ``That's not even one generation,'' he said. ``We need to do it, and we need to remove the stigma that we're going to discriminate against whites or we're going to promote blacks who aren't qualified. None of that is true.'' Many Democrats maintain the heart of the matter is economics. They say Republicans want to divert attention from the recession, and the whole idea of affirmative action is more threatening now because jobs are scarce. ``This issue is about a shrinking economic pie and people thinking someone's going to give their slice to somebody else,'' said Democratic strategist Mike McCurry. ``You have to recast the debate to show the Republicans are trying to peddle fear instead of a plan to get the economy going. And you have to have an answer for the working person who fears for his job,'' he added. ``You have to say, `my plan is to develop a red-hot economy so we all have jobs.''' Republican analyst Doug Bailey thinks his party, too, should look at the big picture. He said it would be ``a big political mistake'' to lean heavily on affirmative action to fill the void left by the end of the Cold War and the splintering of the GOP on abortion and taxes. ``It turns off a large corps of moderate voters, Northern suburban voters who have supported the Republican party in the past,'' Bailey said. ``They will not want to see a party intentionally choose an issue, even though it may have some merit, which divides people on racial lines.'' However, Stone said the theme would appeal to a group that is equally if not more important to the party - blue-collar ``Reagan Democrats.'' And he maintained it could be pursued without the GOP appearing to be insensitive or divisive. ``You can use other issues to illustrate your desire for economic growth in the minority community,'' Stone said. ``Go out and campaign against quotas but for enterprise zones and greater financial assistance for minority education.'' But the Democrats firmly believe they hold the higher ground on civil rights and can persuade voters of that. Foreshadowing the rhetoric to come, Wilder has accused Bush of failing to provide moral leadership and Brown called his veto of the civil rights bill a disgrace. ``He had an important choice to make,'' the party chairman said, ``and he chose the politics of Jesse Helms and David Duke rather than the politics of Martin Luther King and Abraham Lincoln.''

DOC.HEAD: Huge Trust Agency Selling Off Much of East Germany
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The world's largest corporation has inherited most of what once was East Germany, with instructions to sell it off or close it down. Detlev Rohwedder, the chairman, is running the sale of the century - converting the state companies of former East Germany to private enterprise - and says he wants to do it with consideration for the people who might be hurt. He is from West Germany, but a native of Thuringia, one of Germany's five new eastern states. ``I think it's great to be asked by my government to be part of the effort,'' Rohwedder said after agreeing in early November to take a full four-year term as chairman of Treuhand. The incorporated agency, whose name means Trust, was established by the East German government last spring when it still was trying to preserve state enterprises. Westerners moved into the management later and Rohwedder became chairman in August. Treuhand's mandate is to sell as much as possible to private owners and deliver the proceeds to the national treasury. It is empowered to close inefficient operations or divide large ones and sell or close the parts separately. It has ordered all the former East German enterprises to submit balance sheets for analysis. Rohwedder, a 58-year-old lawyer, had long experience in the West German government and was credited with the rescue from near-bankruptcy of the Hoesch steel company. His trust corporation is responsible for 4.5 million to 6 million employees and owns 60 percent of eastern Germany's forests, 35 percent of the arable land, factories, housing and other real estate. It will take until next spring to count the employees and estimate what the assets are worth, Rohwedder said. By mid-November, the trust said, it had taken in 1.5 billion marks ($1 billion) from the sale of state companies. Although the East German economy was considered in bad shape, its output in 1989 was estimated at the equivalent of 290 billion West German marks ($187 billion). Real estate will be especially difficult to sell. Some of it was seized from people living in West Germany or Jews who fled the Nazis, many of whom have filed claims for restitution that may be in the courts for years. Wolf Schoede, spokesman for Treuhand, said it was ``the largest corporation in the world, and it has no precedent and there will be no successor.'' Most commentators say Chancellor Helmut Kohl could not have found a person with better qualifications than Rohwedder to run it, but Treuhand has taken a lot of criticism in its short life. In its Nov. 12 issue, the weekly magazine Spiegel declared that Rohwedder was unapproachable and had ``quickly shown the door'' to Heinz Ruhnau, head of the national airline Lufthansa, who wanted to buy the East German airline Interflug. Foreign companies say Treuhand is almost impossible to contact its procedures are not clear and it favors German investors. Tom Sommerlatte, vice president in Germany of the U.S.-based consulting firm Arthur D. Little, said he had contracts with 12 East German companies that wanted to form ventures with foreign firms. ``We have tried very hard to talk to Treuhand and convince them of solutions we have found,'' Sommerlatte said. ``Sometimes, they didn't even receive us; we couldn't get an appointment.'' When the point was raised during a meeting with foreign journalists, Rohwedder sighed and said: ``They probably were the 2,087th call we had that day. We have a small number of people here, too few to accommodate the questions.'' Treuhand's staff doubled in October to about 500 and will grow to 1,200-1,500 by the middle of 1991, Rohwedder said. It has offices in 15 cities of eastern Germany and headquarters on the Alexanderplatz, the center of East Berlin. Its attitude is to favor entrepreneurs and foster competition, the chairman said. That, he added, was why he backed away from Lufthansa's attempt to lock up almost all domestic German air traffic by buying Interflug. The unpleasant side of the job is to close companies whose products won't sell in Western markets. Rohwedder said he had heard criticism that Treuhand was too slow in shutting some factories and explained his approach this way: ``We could make unemployment very fast, and it would take a long time to get back to work. We have to work with love for the people.'' He denied favoring German applicants over foreigners. ``German economic policy is to be open to the outside world,'' he said. ``It stiffens competition, makes people work harder and benefits the consumer.'' Rohwedder acknowledge that Germans have the inside track because many West German companies had good business ties with East Germany. About 90 percent of the first 200 deals were with German firms. ``The game is played in Germany, so it's only natural the Germans play the greatest role,'' he said. Foreign hotel chains were interested in building in many places, he said, but that brought up the awkward problem of land ownership: ``We don't know if we own this corner in East Berlin or a Jewish family that was expelled in 1938.'' In Dresden, 130 miles south of Berlin, a long street of grimy factories contains two examples of Treuhand's work. Pentacon, a company that made Praktica cameras without regard for costs to show that East Germany could build an internationally accepted product, is closing and about 5,000 people will be out of work. Cigarettes, however, are a thriving business. Philip Morris bought the Dresden factories of the old East German tobacco company and is turning out 50 million cigarettes a day. It has guaranteed the jobs of all 945 workers through 1992, increased production 30 percent and raised wages $100 a month to an average $1,050, still less than half what the company pays its workers in western Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Daily News Strike: Labor's Last Stand?
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: It involves just one newspaper and fewer than 2,500 workers. But to organized labor, which has stumbled from one debacle to another in the last decade, the Daily News strike has the feel of a last stand. ``These days, every strike like this one seems to be about the survival of the union movement,'' said James Green, professor of labor studies at the University of Massachusetts-Boston. ``Union people ask themselves, `If we lose another one, why are unorganized workers going to join a union?''' And they ask themselves: If we can't win in New York, where can we win? ``New York City is so damn important to the American union movement,'' said AFL-CIO spokesman Rex Hardesty in Washington. ``Like they say, everything else is Hoboken.'' With about 40 percent of its work force organized, New York is one of the few big cities that can still pass for a union town. The News strike began Oct. 25 after a paper handler who was working while seated refused a supervisor's order to stand up, saying he needed to sit down because of a physical disability. When other workers walked out in sympathy, the company hired permanent replacements. Within 24 hours, nine unions were on strike. Since then management has been more successful at producing a newspaper than distributing it. Most newsstand dealers refuse to sell the News, usually because of striker appeals, threats or outright violence. Circulation has dropped from a million-plus to about 500,000. And many leading advertisers have pulled out, including department stores such as Macy's and Alexander's. The News battle comes at a crucial period in U.S. labor history. Union members, a majority of the work force 40 years ago, now account for less than 20 percent. The last decade was marked by a series of embarrassing defeats or costly standoffs. Against this background, the News dispute is variously described as labor's Alamo, or its Waterloo. ``Certain strikes rise to national attention and become symbolic strikes,'' says Ronald Filippelli, editor of an encyclopedia on labor strife. ``They become much more important than the number of people involved.'' Local strike leaders have welcomed the attention. Juan Gonzales, a News columnist, calls the strike ``a decisive battle between labor and management in the United States. ... The labor movement is drawing a line in the sand. This trend of breaking unions is going to stop here.'' The AFL-CIO has four staffers working in New York and gave the News unions $100,000 for an advertising and reader boycott campaign directed by Samuel McKnight, a veteran labor lawyer from Michigan. At a rally Nov. 14 outside the Daily News building, leaders of some of the nation's top unions promised the strikers about $300,000, and local unions have pledged $2 million. If national interest has raised the stakes in the strike, some wonder if it might also influence the way the strike is conducted. When management hires replacement workers - once a relatively rare tactic, albeit a legal one - unions are reacting with unusual bitterness, according to Filippelli. In labor disputes such as those at the Daily News, Eastern and Greyhound, ``a message is being sent to unionized employers that unions might be willing to take a company down if replacement workers are used,'' he said. Ester Fuchs, a Barnard College professor who specializes in urban politics, questions such tactics. ``Because of the boycott, the unions are going to be blamed, rightfully or wrongfully, if the paper closes,'' she said. She also wonders if unions should focus national attention on this particular strike: ``If they lose under these circumstances, people will ask how they can win anywhere else. If they win, it's not a cue for anyone elsewhere, because the conditions in New York are so special.'' Strike organizers challenge that assessment. McKnight, the labor lawyer, said strikes are won by hurting the employer economically. Said Filippelli: ``The (boycott) is aimed at getting a settlement, and I don't think anyone wants to drive the News out of business.'' Indeed, the AFL-CIO's Hardesty said the strike can showcase labor's ability to work with management. He points to the New York Post, a rival tabloid where unions made extensive wage-and-hour concessions earlier this year. ``We'd like to say to employers, `We know we can go down with you. We'd like to go up with you,''' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Nations That Team Up Against Iraq Get a Little Something in Return
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Egypt gets to write off billions of dollars in debt. Syria gains more control over Lebanon. China lands a $50 million loan. The Soviet Union wins help restructuring its economy. Nations that have joined the U.S.-led effort against Iraq - by sending troops to the gulf or agreeing to abstain in a key United Nations vote - are getting a little something in return. And those who haven't may find it a little more difficult to get expected aid from the United States and other countries. In the world of diplomacy, there is nothing unusual about a little exchange of favors, which diplomats call ``quid pro quo.'' But analysts say Iraq's invasion of Kuwait is pushing international politicking to new extremes, including high-level U.S. contacts with nations it has accused of supporting terrorism: Syria, Cuba and soon, Iraq itself. ``Altruism and principle do not always make the world go 'round,'' said Michael Mandelbaum, East-West studies director for the Council on Foreign Relations. ``Expecting something for your support is normal, predictable, understandable behavior in diplomacy and politics.'' It's difficult to draw a direct link between cooperation in the gulf and increased aid. Some of the benefits, such as Egyptian debt relief and help for the Soviets, may have come anyway. But maybe not so expeditiously. And not all of the aid is coming from the United States. But Washington's attitude toward a country can make a difference. For example, the Bush administration called on other wealthy countries to help Jordan only after King Hussein said he would apply full sanctions against neighboring Iraq. And after Yemen voted against a U.S.-sponsored resolution authorizing the use of force against Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, the State Department began reviewing American aid to that country. A department source who spoke only on condition of anonymity said Yemen's chance of getting $30 million was now ``not as strong as it might have been.'' About two-dozen nations are sending troops, ships, planes or other support for the military buildup against Saddam's million-member army. Other countries have balked at sending troops - Germany and Japan cite prohibitions in their constitutions - but are helping those who do and those who suffer most. That also helps keep the fragile alliance together. The U.S. force in the Persian Gulf is expected to reach 400,000 soldiers in the next few weeks. The second-largest force, 144,500 troops, is from the area most directly threatened by Iraq's occupation of Kuwait, the Gulf Cooperation Council nations of Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, Oman, United Arab Emirates, Qatar and the exiled Kuwaiti regime. Egypt has pledged 20,000 soldiers, along with tanks and heavy artillery. Syria, which borders Iraq to the west, has 6,500 soldiers in Saudi Arabia and a 15,000-member armored division is to be added. For spearheading Arab support, Egypt is being rewarded in Washington with a write-off of $6.7 billion in loans used to buy arms from the United States. Even before Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, U.S. officials were looking for a way to relieve Egypt's financial burden. But Egypt's cooperation helped sell the debt-forgiveness plan to Congress. Pakistan has pledged to send 5,000 troops to the Persian Gulf and another 5,000 serve as advisers with the Saudi military. Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and the Kuwaiti regime are lending about $500 million to Pakistan to help compensate for oil imports cut off by the gulf crisis, according to Kuwaiti officials. Analysts agree that the Soviet Union has made clear it wants some economic assistance for its support of the Saudi-U.S. position. ``It's an important signal that the Soviets voted for the United Nations sanctions against Iraq,'' said Jim Phillips, an analyst for the conservative Heritage Foundation. ``I think they expect food aid. It's a hazy quid pro quo, but the Soviets are counting on U.S. goodwill down the line.'' The Soviets so far have committed only warships but indicate they would send ground forces under a U.N. command. In return, Saudi Arabia and other Arab nations aligned against Iraq reportedly are putting together a multibillion-dollar loan package for Moscow. Other countries sending troops include Britain, with 30,000; France, with 13,000; Morocco, with 1,200; and Bangladesh, with 2,000. The support from some nations has been bare bones and clearly aimed more at showing the flag in an international operation and warming relations with the United States than seriously aiding the military effort. Italy, the Netherlands, Spain, Australia, Argentina, Canada, Greece, Denmark, Norway, and Portugal all have sent ships to the gulf, but have stopped short of committing significant ground forces. New Zealand, which has been at odds with Washington since the Wellington government banned nuclear-power submarines in 1984, pledged two planes and a medical team. Other countries receiving or looking for more U.S. aid also are kicking in token support. Czechoslovakia is sending a 200-man army unit and Poland a military field hospital. The Philippines is putting together a medical team. For China, it was enough just not to say no. During backstage negotiations leading up to the Security Council's vote allowing military action, the Asian Development Bank granted China a $50 million agricultural loan. It was the first loan by the U.S.-influenced bank to Beijing since the June 1989 crackdown on student demonstrators. China, which could have stopped the resolution with its veto, abstained when the council voted the day after the loan was announced. Then Chinese Foreign Minister Qian Qichen was welcomed in Washington for meetings with Bush and his aides, ending an 18-month ban on high-level contacts with China. Chinese officials denied that they used the U.N. veto power to gain political favors, and bank officials refused to comment on whether the loan was linked to the U.N. resolution.

DOC.HEAD: Boat People: Is Forced Repatriation The Only Way Out?
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs repoprt.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto HK2 Dec. 9.
DOC.TEXT: A year after police put 51 Vietnamese on a plane to Hanoi in the only forced repatriation of boat people, pressure is mounting to resume the controversial policy. British colonial officials say forced repatriation eventually will be seen as the only way to clear Hong Kong's squalid camps of tens of thousands of refugees, whatever the international outcry that accompanies it. If Hong Kong resumes the policy, United Nations officials predict other countries in the region will follow suit, returning more than 100,000 Vietnamese who crowd camps throughout Asia. Once back in Vietnam, no one can protect the would-be refugees from persecution. The United Nations, which monitors boat people who return voluntarily, says it can do nothing to help those who are forced to return because it opposes the policy. Early next year, the government will consider lifting a moratorium imposed on mandatory repatriation, said Clinton Leeks, Hong Kong's refugee coordinator. ``It's really our only option,'' he said in an interview. Leeks said Western governments are not taking enough of the genuine refugees and the number of boat people deemed to be non-refugees, or ``economic migrants,'' is growing. Human rights lawyers say they look to the United States, the sole remaining Western country actively opposed to forcing Vietnamese home, as a last line of defense. ``The U.S. is the only thing that stands between the boat people and prison planes or prison ships back to Vietnam,'' said David J. Clark, a law professor at the University of Hong Kong who has studied the boat people problem. American officials insist that U.S. opposition to forced repatriation remains staunch, but analysts agree that Washington's policy is linked to its refusal to normalize relations with Vietnam. If Vietnam helps organize elections in Cambodia and participates in settling the Cambodian civil war, U.S. diplomats say, the United States may recognize Hanoi by 1992. ``The next day, look for forced repatriation,'' a U.S. official said on condition of anonymity. In the camps of tin huts, concrete and watchtowers, the prospects are depressing to Hong Kong's 52,171 boat people. ``We'd rather die that go back to Vietnam,'' reads a sign stuck on a chain-link fence at Whitehead Detention Center, the biggest of Hong Kong's 15 camps. A year-end report by a Western consulate predicted riots and bloodshed in the camps if the Dec. 12, 1989, forced repatriation is repeated. ``The Americans should know what kind of resistance the people from North Vietnam are capable of mounting,'' a police official said. A U.N. official who works in the camps said he believes the Vietnamese know they are fighting a losing battle. Forced repatriation could become unnecessary, he said, if the Vietnamese realize they have no place to go but home. U.N. officials have begun telling the refugees since October they should return home, a radical break with previous policy. Since the Vietnam War ended in 1975, more than 1.5 million Vietnamese have fled since the Vietnam war ended in April 1975. The United States has accepted almost 1 million Indochinese refugees, about three times the total of the next three countries - Australia, Canada and France. As a place of first refuge, Hong Kong has borne the brunt of the exodus, 162,479 arrivals since 1979, but the numbers are declining. Only 6,201 boat people have arrived so far this year, compared with 34,114 in 1989. Resettlements rose to 7,152, a 50 percent increase from 1989. Hope for a solution increased in September when Vietnam, the United Nations and Britain signed an agreement creating a new category of boat people, those ``who do not oppose'' repatriation, to supplement voluntary repatriation. Interest in the new category appears low, however. Only 23 Vietnamese were in the first group to return Dec. 1, although 111 had signed up. Interest in the voluntary program also is lagging. Although the total number of Vietnamese in Hong Kong declined by several thousand over the last year, the decrease has been among boat people who already had been granted refugee status and a chance to settle in the West. People who await screening on their qualifications as refugees, plus those who flunked the process, have increased from 43,702 in 1989 to 43,949 as of Dec. 3. Also, 2,684 babies were born in the camps, giving the boat people one of the highest birth rates in the world. ``These increases are intolerable,'' Leeks said. ``What happens if there's another mass exodus next year?''

DOC.HEAD: Drought Points Up Another Israeli-Palestinian Conflict
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Israel has stopped pumping water from the Sea of Galilee and the River Jordan has become a dirty, brown stream. Palestinians often are lucky to get a drip when they turn on the faucet. Israel is suffering a drought, which in the Middle East means much more than not being able to sprinkle the lawn. Water is another of the region's many crises, extending beyond Israel to Turkey, Syria, Jordan and Iraq. Water is inseparable from Israel's conflict with the Arabs, and especially the Palestinians in the occupied territories. Agriculture minister Rafael Eitan has run full-page newspaper ads warning Israelis their country would lose nearly 60 percent of its water if it gave up the occupied West Bank. ``Water is an extremely scarce resource in Israel,'' the ads say. ``In fact, it is in many ways the limiting factor on the country's future development.'' As thousands of Soviet immigrants pour in monthly, with 1 million expected by the end of 1992, everyone fears a shortage. Palestinians see Israel's handling of water as another attempt to drive them from the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. ``Water is a final solution to the Palestinian problem,'' said Saeb Erakat, a professor of political science at An-Najah University in the West Bank. ``Denying Palestinians water means `Get out.'' Erakat turned on the tap at his home in Jericho, an oasis city since ancient times. A few drops trickled out and he said: ``No water, no life.'' Eitan calls Israel's dwindling water sources ``a potential catastrophe.'' On Nov. 25, Israel stopped pumping water from the Sea of Galilee, which supplies about a quarter of its drinking water. The sea had dropped to within two inches of the level where more pumping could turn it into a salt lake. Reports say the country's underground water also is near the danger level. Predictions are for a late, plentiful rainfall this winter, but November ended without significant rainfall. A group of rabbis even held a special prayer for rain. The Gaza Strip has more serious problems than the West Bank or Israel. Open sewers in crowded refugee camps drain into its only water source, an aquifer nearly destroyed by overuse. Israel already pumping water in for the few thousand Jewish settlers and 750,000 Arabs in Gaza. In the long run, Eitan talks of importing water from Turkey or Eastern Europe and building desalination plants. The reserve army general leads the right-wing Tsomet Party, which wants to make the occupied lands part of Israel. ``Giving up control of the West Bank is basically giving up control of the entire water system,'' said Martin Sherman, one of his advisers. Water from an underground mountain reservoir that straddles the West Bank and Israel now is divided 80-20 in Israel's favor. The government says this is justified under international law, based on population figures before Israel captured the territory in the 1967 Middle East war. One-quarter of all Israel's water comes from the reservoir. The ad placed by Eitan's ministry said another aquifer that provides one-third of the supply would would be affected if a Palestinian state was created in the West Bank. Erakat said 30 percent less arable land is irrigated now than before 1967, reducing the economic output of the West Bank by more than 25 percent. Shehadeh H. Dajani, manager of the Arab Development Society in Jericho, used a large map on the wall of his office to point out land that was irrigated before the occupation. ``This is something they have gained after 1967, and they don't only control the land, but our water from heaven,'' Dajani said. Israel has denied taking water that should go to Palestinians. According to government statistics, Israelis use twice as much water per person as Palestinians. A government conservation campaign has had little effect and farmers have stymied efforts to raise the subsidized price of water for agriculture. As the crisis gets worse, Sherman said, the government will have to decide who gets water and how much. Left-wing legislator Dedi Zucker said water is the deciding factor in the Palestinian-Israel conflict. ``It will either force us to cooperate with one another or to kill one another by thirst,'' he said. Neighboring Jordan and Syria have water disputes with Israel. ``I would tell the world, if you want to limit the tension in the Middle East, don't send tanks and don't confuse us with fruitless talks,'' Eitan said. ``Send water and that will cool down the Middle East.'' In Oja, a village outside Jericho, Mubarak al-Nujoum pointed to fields overgrown with brush and blamed his water shortage on a nearby Jewish settlement that even has a swimming pool. He said more than half his 25-acre farm, which supports an extended family of 17 people, no longer is irrigated. He still raises tomatoes, cucumbers and corn, but has stopped growing bananas because they need too much water. Al-Nujoum threw a pebble into an irrigation pond, which he said was only one-third its normal depth. ``These whirls of water are the rings of war here,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Danes Reluctantly Prepare for Another Election
DOC.TEXT: The Danes, who claim the world's record in parliamentary elections, reluctantly vote again Wednesday, and the hottest issue seems to be who provoked the unwanted balloting. Conservative Prime Minister Poul Schlueter blames an economic dispute with the opposition for forcing his election call. Even he reflects the country's lack of enthusiasm for its 20th general parliamentary vote in 45 years. Shlueter says he wants to ``get it over with as soon as possible.'' Denmark has one of the world's most fractured democracies. It has not had a majority government since 1971, longer than any other pluralistic system. Schlueter, whose center-right coalition controls just 67 seats in the 179-seat parliament, has called four elections since 1982. The latest campaign lacks the trappings seen in those held most other countries. There are no mass rallies in the streets. The size and placement of campaign posters is severely restricted by law. Paid political spots are not accepted on state radio or on the two public TV channels. Yet turnout among Denmark's 3.9-million electorate, averaging 85 percent since 1945, is among the world's best. Thirteen parties ranging from Marxists to anti-tax crusaders are competing for the vote. With just 2 percent of the vote needed for representation, many gain seats - and have emerged as kingmakers between the evenly balanced main parties. Political scientist Steen Sauerberg says many Danish follow ``the liberal ideal of giving the little guy a chance, too.'' Another reason for the frequent votes, he says, is because there are no fixed terms for parliamentarians, although there is a four-year maximum. Schlueter, whose coalition includes the Liberals and Social Liberals, called the vote to settle a minor dispute with the main opposition Social Democrats on economic policy and taxes. Both sides wanted a 6 percent cut at the top of the progressive tax scale. But the Social Democrats opposed financing it with reductions in social benefits. Unlike in the neighboring Scandinavian countries of Sweden and Norway, the two main political blocs in Denmark have remained evenly balanced. Neither the left nor right has managed to get a working majority, said Sauerberg. This allows the small parties often to hold the balance of power in the parliament, he added. But Danish politics, despite its surface chaos, remains surprisingly stable. The voters tend to stay loyal to their party, and support for the parties swings only a few percentage points after each election, said Sauerberg. All 13 parties get equal time on TV to present their political platforms regardless of their current strength. They also participate in a series of debates among all the parties at once. The basic flaw in the current campaigns, says Sauerberg, is that the politicians spend more time speculating openly about possible coalitions than they do discussing the traditional issues of employment, taxes and welfare. So why do the Danes keep voting? ``Simply because of the Danes' sense of duty towards society and the fact that voter registration is automatic - you get a card in the mail,'' Sauerberg said.

DOC.HEAD: Desert Shield Prompts Troops To Look For More Coverage
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: With thousands of troops deployed for Operation Desert Shield, many are looking to increase their life insurance coverage before they go. That has proven difficult. In the same way casualty companies won't write hurricane coverage when a storm has formed, many life insurance companies are inserting war exclusion provisions in new policies. ``They say if you are killed in a war, the policy is no good,'' said I.C. Russell of the South Carolina Insurance Department. The department has received calls from concerned servicemen and women, but ``there's no mandate by law that says any insurance company must write you a policy if they don't want to,'' Russell said. The Washington-based American Council of Life Insurance has no specific numbers on how many companies are putting in exclusions. ``But it seems many companies are issuing the war exclusion clauses for military who have been called to the Persian Gulf,'' said spokeswoman Diane Coffey. The council is a trade group representing about 600 companies nationwide. Coffey said policies issued after Aug. 2, when Iraq invaded Kuwait, could include clauses ``that would stipulate the full policy would not be paid if death occurred as a result of war in the Persian Gulf.'' Policies issued earlier, without the exclusion, can't be amended to exclude deaths in a Gulf war, she said. Coffey urged military personnel to shop around because ``basically each insurance company decides.'' One insurance company with mostly military customers is the United Services Automobile Association, based in San Antonio. Of the company's 2 million policyholders, about 95 percent are active duty officers. The company's new policies don't have war exclusions, but they do limit the amount of new coverage, said spokesman John Walmsley. Officers from lieutenant through captain may buy new or additional coverage up to a maximum of $250,000, he said. Higher ranks may buy new or additional coverage up to a maximum $350,000. For enlisted personnel, the cap is $10,000. ``We frankly felt the escalating tensions in the Middle East needed a prudent business decision,'' Walmsley said. Business has increased since the crisis began, Walmsley said, but he couldn't say exactly how much. All troops, including reservists called to active duty, may get coverage through the Servicemen's Group Life Insurance program administered by the federal government. The government contracts with private companies for the coverage, said Betty Nahdil, an administrator in the Benefits Directors Office of the Veterans Administration. More than 99 percent of service personnel buy the coverage, which provides a death benefit of $50,000. ``Any military operation not withstanding, they can get this coverage,'' she said. ``The fact that we are in the Gulf is not increasing the number of policies we are issuing except among the reservists who are offered the opportunity.'' She said 44 claims have been paid for troops killed in accidents since the Gulf buildup began. Fifty soldiers have died since the deployment began.

DOC.HEAD: Gun Ban Divides Public Housing Residents
LaserPhoto RM2
DOC.TEXT: A wave of fatal shootings, numerous burglaries and drug trafficking have persuaded some people to hold onto their weapons despite a ban on firearms in Richmond's public housing. ``I'd rather be safe than sorry,'' said Sondra Davis, 30, who lives with her 11- and 12-year-old daughters in the Hillside Court housing project. U.S. District Judge Richard L. Williams ruled Dec. 3 that the gun ban inserted into leases by the city housing authority in October was ``part of a good-faith effort to improve the safety and quality of life in public housing.'' The ruling marked the first time a judge has upheld a gun ban in public housing in the United States, according to the National Rifle Association. A Chicago ban on guns in public housing has not been challenged in court. Ms. Davis said she won't be deterred by the rule, under which violators can be evicted. ``Instead of dying or one of my kids getting hurt, I'd just have to find another place to live,'' she said. ``I'm not selling drugs. I'm just keeping a gun in my house for my protection.'' The Richmond Tenants Organization had challenged the ban as an unreasonable lease restriction that made the city's 14,000 public housing residents second-class citizens. Alma Barlow, president of the tenants group, said her group has not decided whether to appeal. Some residents of the city's 4,500 public housing units said the ban is a good idea if it helps reduce crime. They said they often hear shooting at night and have either been burglarized or seen people breaking into homes. ``It's all right with me,'' said Lena Austin, 55, as she hung laundry outside her Hillside Court home. ``They need to really buckle down.'' ``It will probably stop more killing around here,'' said LaToya James, 18, who lives in the Blackwell complex. About a third of Richmond's record 111 slayings this year occurred in the seven housing projects, said Officer Stephen V. York, who compiles crime statistics for the Police Department. Many of Richmond's slayings were drug-related. Richmond had 98 slayings in all of 1989. Nearly 300 burglaries have been reported this year in public housing, York said. ``I'm scared to go out,'' said William Loney, 70, of Hillside Court. He said he was thinking about getting a gun that he keeps at a relative's house. ``I'll probably do it anyway because if they say I can't keep guns they're responsible for my life.''

DOC.HEAD: German Automaker Wins Takeover
DOC.TEXT: In a major Western investment in Eastern Europe, the German auto manufacturer Volkswagen has won the bidding war to take over the prized Czechoslovak carmaker Skoda. Officials did not say how much money Volkswagen AG was prepared to invest in Skoda. News reports have put the figure at up to more than $5 billion. Petr Pithart, premier of the Czech republic, said Volkswagen beat out a French-Swedish consortium of Renault and AB Volvo for the deal announced Sunday. He said Volkswagen made a better financial offer, was strong in the European market and provided better assurances for Skoda's 16,000 workers. Skoda is considered one of the best auto manufacturers in Eastern Europe. It had a manufacturing tradition predating communism and used its own designs instead of Western retreads. Its cars have a relatively good reputation for reliability. Auto manufacturing is one of the few areas in which Western industrial firms have shown a keen interest in expanding into the formerly Communist countries of Eastern Europe. Volkswagen is to take an initial share of 25 percent to 33 percent in the Czechoslovak automaker and gradually increase control, Pithart said. Newspapers have said Volkswagen pledged to keep the Skoda name and not to lay off employees.

DOC.HEAD: AMs Separates moved on Arenas as a0630, Alexander as a0733.
DOC.TEXT: Reinaldo Arenas, a novelist who spent several years in prison in Fidel Castro's Cuba and was suffering from AIDS, died here Friday, and police said it appeared to be a suicide. He was 47. There were no obvious wounds when his body was found in his Manhattan apartment, but a note was found and investigators speculated he had overdosed on drugs, said Sgt. Ed Burns, a police spokesman. As a teen-ager, Arenas joined Castro's revolution, and later worked as a researcher in the Jose Marti National Library. Arenas said he was branded a social misfit in Cuba because of his homosexuality, spent time in a labor camp, and was imprisoned from 1974 to 1976 for being a counterrevolutionary. His novel ``Singing From the Well'' won the Prix Medici in France for the best foreign novel of 1969. He wrote the poem ``El Central'' while in the labor camp, and his second novel, ``Hallucinations,'' was never published in Cuba. He escaped to the United States in 1980. ``Hallucinations'' was reprinted in in 1987 as ``The Ill-Fated Peregrinations of Fray Sergando.'' Other works include ``The Graveyard of the Angels,'' and ``Farewell to the Sea.''

John Alexander, a tenor with the Metropolitan Opera for 27 years, died Saturday of a heart attack at age 67. Alexander collapsed Saturday evening at the Temple Theater in his hometown of Meridian and was pronounced dead at Jeff Anderson Regional Medical Center. He was among a group of local artists on the program to perform at a fund-raising event that evening. Alexander recently retired after 27 years as a tenor with New York's Metropolitan Opera. He was the first American-born tenor to establish a reputation for interpretation of 19th-century bel canto roles, a style of singing that is characterized by brilliant vocal display and purity of tone and most often associated with Italian artists.

DOC.HEAD: Pollution, Industry Blamed for Sharp Climb in Cancer Rates
DOC.TEXT: Cancer death rates in industrialized nations are rising faster than aging and smoking might account for, heightening suspicion that pollution and other environmental dangers are at fault, scientists say. Cancer causes about 2.3 million of the 11 million deaths annually in industrialized nations, according to one of an international set of reports collected and published by the New York Academy of Sciences. When lung cancer - most often caused by smoking - is excluded, the cancer death rate among men in industrialized nations has risen 9 percent since 1950, the report said. Cancer death rates for women have risen in some countries and fallen in others, it said. ``Cancer is increasing in industrial countries above and beyond that due to cigarette smoking or aging alone,'' said Devra Lee Davis, an editor of a collection of studies and a researcher at the National Academy of Sciences in Washington. ``The combination of air pollution and industrial activity is obviously a very important factor.'' Brain cancer is among the most rapidly increasing, Davis said, especially among people over 65. In some cases, the rate in the industrial world has increased more than six-fold in those over age 75, she said. Such cancer has also increased among young people, although at a lower rate, she said. Research shows that in the United States, the rate of lung cancer deaths among nonsmoking women is now higher than the total lung cancer death rate in women 30 years ago, she said. That could reflect exposure to second-hand cigarette smoke as well as to radon, asbestos and air pollution, Davis said. According to National Cancer Institute figures, the lung cancer death rate among all American women in 1955 was 5.1 deaths per 100,000 women. Davis and her collaborators calculated that the death rate in women nonsmokers by 1985 was 6.1 per 100,000. Sharp increases are also occurring in a blood cancer called multiple myeloma and the dangerous skin cancer called melanoma, Davis said. The rates are climbing in many industrial nations, including the United States. In Italy, Cesare Maltoni and colleagues at the Bologna Institute of Oncology found that cancer causes nearly 40 percent of all deaths in the Bologna area, and the rate continues to climb. That's double the rate for the rest of the country. Bologna is in the most industrialized part of Italy. ``The changes are so great over such a short time in so many countries in men and women that we need to look carefully for their causes,'' Davis said. ``These could be very important as clues for prevention.'' Although the studies emphasize occupational and environmental exposures, smoking remains one of the greatest causes of cancer, Davis said. In many industrial countries smoking is responsible for 40 percent of all cancer deaths in men and 30 percent in women, the studies show. Smoking kills an estimted 3 million people each year around the world, and if current trends continue that will climb to more than 10 million by 2020, Davis said. The combined population of the industrialized countries studied is about 1.2 billion. The studies are collected in ``Trends in Cancer Mortality in Industrial Countries,'' which will be released this week. Although the increases in cancer are clear, the causes are not, Davis said. Links to benzene, PCBs and other environmental carcinogens are being considered. Among other possible factors, she said, are: a genetic predisposition to cancer; lifestyle, including drinking and smoking; the consumption of anti-cancer foods like fresh fruits and vegetables; exposure to X-rays and infectious agents, and a variety of occupational hazards.

DOC.HEAD: New Budget Rules Block Major Boosts in Domestic Spending
DOC.TEXT: As residents of little Middletown, N.Y., brace for a slowing economy, agencies serving the poor in the Hudson River Valley community expect more and more people will need help to pay fuel bills, rent and even find shelter. But they don't expect to get the money they'll need from the federal government. ``There will be people wanting services we just won't be able to accommodate,'' Charles Darden, executive director of Middletown's Regional Economic Community Action Program, lamented recently. With the end of the Cold War last year and before the U.S. involvement in the Persian Gulf, some lawmakers argued that excess money from a slimmed-down Pentagon - the so-called peace dividend - should be used to expand domestic programs. Instead, the money will be used mostly to chip away at the federal deficit. And strict budget procedures written by Congress and President Bush will keep it that way for at least three years. Advocates of these priorities and the new rules say they are necessary to trim the budget deficit, which is expected to reach at least a record $320 billion in fiscal 1991, which began Oct. 1. ``If we don't deal with the deficit, we won't be able to deal with any of our other priorities,'' said House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., an architect of the five-year budget package. Robert Greenstein, executive director of the Center for Budget and Policy Priorities, which lobbies for low-income programs in Washington, criticized the plan. ``The problem is not only do we not invest more in domestic programs, but we don't even give ourselves over the next three years the ability to debate the issue,'' he said. As part of this fall's big budget deal, congressional leaders and the White House set firm ceilings for each of the next three years for three separate categories of spending: defense and domestic programs and foreign affairs. Money can't be transferred from one category to another. Defense spending will be reduced from $297 billion this year to $296 billion in 1992 - not including the costs of U.S. operations in the Middle East, which will be counted separately. Although that seemingly is a $1 billion decrease, it is $9 billion less than the military would need to keep up with inflation next year, according to preliminary estimates by the non-partisan Congressional Budget Office. During that same time, spending on domestic initiatives - excluding benefit programs like Social Security - will be allowed to rise from $198 billion to $210 billion. But that will be $4 billion less than those programs would need to stay even with inflation, CBO says. Foreign affairs spending will change little from its current level of $20 billion. This means two things. First of all, when the ever-rising cost of living is factored in, there will be less money to go around for domestic spending next year. Secondly, the money cut from the Pentagon's budget is not being spent - it's being used to reduce the deficit. Some officials say that after a decade in which domestic programs grew little if at all - and considering U.S. involvement in the Persian Gulf - the added domestic spending is relatively generous. ``I'm not saying we're satisfied,'' said Marsha Simon, legislative director for Families USA, an advocacy group for the poor. ``But given the constraints and the past history, I don't think we could be expected to have done better.'' Others go even farther, arguing that now is the time to repay the government's past-due bills. ``We went into debt building up our military defenses and winning the Cold War,'' said Rep. Bill Frenzel, R-Minn., outgoing ranking Republican on the House Budget Committee. ``The first thing we have to do is pay back some of that debt we got into.'' Even some liberals who were involved in this year's budget talks say that because of the confrontation with Iraq, it was impossible to strike a deal pouring more money into domestic programs. ``The defense savings aren't as substantial as they should have been,'' said Sen. James Sasser, D-Tenn., chairman of the Senate Budget Committee. ``But it was very difficult to deliver a peace dividend in the face of a threat of war.'' The three spending categories will merge in 1994, meaning that domestic programs will be able to grow at the expense of the military. But until then, advocates of stronger domestic initiatives are girding for tough competition for federal dollars among themselves. ``It will precipitate infighting among allies,'' said Middletown's Darden. ``It will be very stressful.''

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0430; inserts Bjt designator.
Baker, Shevardnadze Try to Wrap Up Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III chose his hometown to try to wrap up a nuclear weapons reduction treaty with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, but it may take more than relaxed Texas hospitality to get the job done. Between trips to the Johnson Space Center and other diversions today and Tuesday, Baker and Shevardnadze will review the conclusions of their negotiating teams and see whether they can agree on a handful of remaining issues on the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty. The toughest is verification - ways to make sure neither side cheats on terms of the treaty, which will provide for an overall reduction of about 30 percent in U.S. and Soviet long-range bombers, missiles and submarines. ``I have no doubt that our talks here in Houston will be productive and that we will continue to tackle some difficult issues in a constructive spirit,'' Baker said Sunday. Shevardnadze, in a brief statement, said in Russian, ``It seems we have a lot of work ahead of us.'' Noting that the United States and the Soviet Union have cooperated in some space ventures, the foreign minister remarked: ``I hope we will further solidify our cooperation on earth.'' Hardly anyone is still predicting the treaty will be ready to be signed at a Moscow summit meeting next month. ``It seems that every time you solve three issues, there are three more that soar up,'' Jack Mendelsohn, the deputy director of the private Arms Control Association, remarked Friday in Washington. The treaty has been in negotiation since 1982. The major elements are in place. But some complex problems stand in the way of completing the accord, such as procedures for exchanging information about arsenals and how to monitor mobile missiles. ``We don't expect the treaty to be wrapped up in Houston,'' said a U.S. official who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``Still, we hope for completion early next year.'' President Bush had hoped he could sign the treaty on a visit to Moscow in January. His summit meeting with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev will be delayed until the accord is ready. Recently, U.S. and Soviet negotiators made major headway by reaching tentative agreement on three key issues. They sidetracked a dispute over the Soviet Backfire bomber, decided some banned U.S. weapons could be turned over to Britain and imposed restrictions on the launch and payload weight of the Soviets' SS-18 missiles. But apart from monitoring arrangements, several other issues are unsettled. These include the kind of testing information to be exchanged and whether the Soviets can inspect U.S. B-2 bombers. The Soviets sent negotiator Alexei Obukhov and other experts to Washington for talks beginning last Friday with a U.S. group headed by under secretary of state Reginald Bartholomew. The idea was to try to pave the way for Baker and Shevardnadze by clearing up some of the technicalities. The two teams also will be in Houston, hip-deep in details, while Baker and Shevardnadze talk about the Persian Gulf crisis and other regional disputes and make a visit to the Johnson Space Center. NASA technicians will try to arrange a phone patch to astronauts on a shuttle mission so Baker and Shevardnadze can talk to them. The Soviet foreign minister also will inspect a mockup of the space shuttle. On Wednesday, they will fly back to Washington where Shevardnadze will meet with Bush at the White House. If the treaty is ready that could produce announcement of a summit date. But U.S. officials are skeptical the two sides can get that far by Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Up In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 23,784.67, up 262.18 points, or 1.11 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Relatives of Gander Crash Victims Accuse Government of Coverup
DOC.TEXT: Your son and 247 other American soldiers are killed in a plane crash in Gander, Newfoundland, while flying home from duty in the Middle East. You seek solace from the U.S. government and you look to Canada for answers about why he died. Instead: -Some Canadian investigators suggest the plane might have been bombed. -Others say ice on the wings caused the crash. -The U.S. government rules out a terrorist connection, even though it fails to conduct a thorough investigation because the air disaster occurred outside the United States. Five years after one of the worst military aviation tragedies in history, many families of the victims in the Gander crash believe the Reagan and Bush administrations are covering up a terrorist act. ``They treated them just like they were a herd of cattle that went to slaughter,'' says James Godsey, of Newport News, Va., whose brother was on the Gander plane. Invitations sent by the families to the White House to attend a memorial service have gone unanswered. Pleas to Congress were met with opposition. ``Show me the smoking gun,'' one congressional aide said when a family member tried to interest him in delving into the crash. Seconds before the plane went down on Dec. 12, 1985, eyewitnesses reported seeing a bright light as if the plane was on fire. Islamic Jihad, a terrorist group with ties to Iran, claimed responsibility for the downing of the DC-8. Days before the disaster, White House aide Oliver North confided to his superiors that Islamic Jihad might retaliate because Iran was unhapy with a secret shipment of antiaircraft missiles sent by the Reagan administration. Congress ``let them get by in Iran-Contra'' and now they ``roll over and play dead'' on the Gander crash, complained Connie Farmer of Hartsville, S.C., who lost a son in the tragedy. She said her youngest son, Aaron, is a ``gung-ho'' Army private deployed as part of Operation Desert Shield. He plans to hold a memorial service for his brother, Kyle, Dec. 12 in Saudi Arabia with some members of the 101st Airborne Division. The troops on the Gander flight were from the 101st. Miami-based Arrow Air operated the plane that carried the soldiers to their deaths in Gander. The same company shipped goods to the Contras for North's secret resupply network. ``At first, I thought my son died because the government let him ride home on a piece of junk that was an accident waiting to happen,'' said Dr. Doug Phillips of St. Petersburg, Fla., a pathologist. Then Phillips found out that many of the bodies in the Gander crash contained high levels of carbon monoxide, suggesting the plane was on fire before it hit the ground. Phillips and his wife asked the Canadian government to open a judicial inquiry and they also sought an inquest into the deaths in the province of Newfoundland. Their requests were turned down. The families of the Gander victims finally got someone in Congress to listen. Rep. William Hughes, D-N.J., called a two-day hearing of his House Judiciary subcommittee on crime to examine the U.S. response to the Gander crash. During the hearings last week, the Army, the National Transportation Safety Board, the FBI and the State Department emphasized one point: the Canadian government was responsible for looking into the Gander crash. The families have a right to expect more than that from the U.S. government, Hughes' subcommittee admonished the agency representatives. ``I have thought from day one that the plane was bombed,'' said Godsey, whose late brother was assigned to special operations in the Army and trained for rapid deployment and hostage rescues. ``I wonder how much taxpayers' money it's going to cost to cover up this air crash?'' Godsey asked. Linda Tatnall, of Hudson, Mass., had a brother aboard the Gander plane. ``I think the government owes us more than a botched investigation,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Spot and Homeless Owner Won't Bow Wow Out of Fight for Pit Bull's Life
DOC.TEXT: Behind the gray bars of doggie death row sits a pit bull named Spot, tried and convicted of biting people, but granted a stay of execution while his homeless owner appeals. Spot, 85 pounds of muscle, fur and nervous energy, was found guilty of biting two people in a late-night scuffle under a fig tree where owner Ed Mannon sometimes sleeps. Spot was impounded and sentenced to die unless Mannon gives the dog a proper home with a fence - something Mannon says he can't even give himself. ``This wouldn't happen if I had a house,'' said Mannon, 38, homeless for 10 years. ``I don't know how to be nice about this anymore. This is just one of the many interruptions the city has made into my life.'' Police see it as a public safety matter and say Spot earlier bit another man. ``I think it's a little bit ludicrous,'' said police spokesman Lt. Richard Glaus. ``We're not in the dog killing business, per se. We do have an obligation to maintain public safety. This guy habitually keeps his dog not even on a leash.'' Spot was sent to the pound after a midnight clash in March in an area between the freeway and the train tracks where the city's homeless gather. Two people were bitten but not seriously hurt. Mannon contends they were attacked after they tried to steal a radio and one of 12 puppies fathered by Spot. The puppies' mother, Tina, another pit bull, did some of the biting, but Spot got all the blame, Mannon claims. Tina does not belong to Mannon. Mannon bought Spot for $100 in 1987 and say the dog protects him from street thugs and once helped him beat a marijuana rap by eating the evidence. At a hearing, a police lieutenant heard anti-Spot testimony from fellow officers and animal-control authorities. Mannon's defense included character witnesses and a videotape of him playing with Spot at the county kennel. The lieutenant decided Spot should be killed or kept at the pound permanently unless he is kept in a fenced yard or on a leash. Mannon appealed to Superior Court. He called the proper-home option a thinly veiled effort to deny homeless people the right to own dogs. The court upheld the ruling but granted a stay of execution while the case is under appeal. Will Hastings, an attorney with the non-profit Legal Defense Center, took over Spot's case, which is now before the state appeals court. ``Ed would not have been in this situation and neither would the dog if Ed had not been homeless,'' said Hastings.

DOC.HEAD: Tired Bush Stays Home
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Lead prospects uncertain; Bush meets with Lansbergis at 2 p.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: President Bush did something unusual Sunday night. He stayed home. An exhausted Bush, just back from his third foreign trip in as many weeks, shelved plans to attend a ``Christmas in Washington'' gala at the Pension Building. A spokesman, John Herrick, said Bush was ``a little exhausted'' after spending much of the afternoon playing tennis. Bush returned Saturday night from a week-long journey through five South American countries. Bush was expected to resume a full schedule today, including meetings with President Vytautas Lansbergis of Lithuania, a group of black college presidents and Defense Secretary Dick Cheney. Tonight he and wife Barbara are hosting a Christmas ball for members of Congress, the first of eight holiday parties this week and next at the presidential mansion. Bush looked tired Sunday morning when he went out to St. John's Episcopal Church. Bush heard a sermon likening Jesse Jackson to John the Baptist and admonishing people to heed Jackson's calls for racial justice and equality. The Rev. James C. Holmes said people should heed Jackson, the District of Columbia's new ``shadow'' senator, when he talks about ``the need to turn the racism in our country to justice.'' ``God has always used imperfect messengers,'' said Holmes, an assistant pastor. ``If we focus on the imperfections, then we block out the message.'' The rector, the Rev. John C. Harper, gave thanks for the release of the hostages in Iraq and Kuwait, and prayed for Bush, the American troops in the Persian Gulf and ``those who pay counsel to the peace of the world.''

DOC.HEAD: Politics, Economy on Agenda at GOP Governors Meeting
DOC.TEXT: Republican governors were conferring with their party's incoming national chairman and with top White House aides today, looking at the political problems and issues that await the GOP in the buildup toward the 1992 presidential campaign. Vice President Dan Quayle was to wrap up the first day of their annual conference, addressing the governors and then meeting with them privately. White House chief of staff John H. Sununu flew in Sunday to spend the evening with the governors and returned to Washington. His deputy, Andrew Card, was on hand for today's meetings. Sununu is a former New Hampshire governor and his wife, Nancy, is on the staff of the Republican Governors Association. Twelve Republican governors, three governors-elect, and one Republican who faces a runoff election were attending the two-day meeting. J. Fife Symington of Arizona won a narrow edge in the Nov. 6 election, but didn't get a clear majority. He and Democrat Terry Goddard will settle their race on Feb. 26. For William J. Bennett, President Bush's choice to become chairman of the Republican National Committee, the conference was a debut of sorts - his first formal outing in the new political role. He is to succeed the ailing Lee Atwater, suffering from a brain tumor, and due to move to the largely honorary position of general chairman when the national committee elects its leaders next month. The governors also were to hear from Secretary of the Interior Manuel Lujan, William Reilly, administrator of the Environmental Protection Administration, and Secretary of Housing and Urban Development Jack Kemp. On Tuesday, party officials and pollsters appear at the final conference session to discuss the November elections and the Republican outlook for the future.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Natural Gas Explosion Hits Army Post; 10 Reported Hurt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf pvs and SUBS grafs 15-16, bgng `Four adults ...' with two grafs to CORRECT to three adults and two children in critical condition.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NA1, LaserColor NA3
DOC.TEXT: A natural gas explosion ripped through a housing complex at the Fort Benjamin Harrison Army post on Sunday night, injuring at least 10 people, officials said. There were no immediate reports of deaths at the post, which serves as a processing center for soldiers en route to the Persian Gulf. At least three adults and two children were in critical condition, a hospital official said. Dogs were brought to search the rubble for anyone who might have been killed, but the dogs were later called off for fear of another blast, authorities said. The explosion, in a housing area for enlisted personnel, destroyed a four-family housing unit and damaged another unit, said post spokesman Maj. Ronald Downing. Downing, who previously had reported 11 people were injured, said a later count reduced that to 10. The cause of the blast was under investigation, he said. Downing said fire authorities had been called earlier in the evening to investigate a natural gas leak. The evacuation of the complex had been planned but the explosion at about 9:15 p.m. occurred before it could be carried out, he said. About 210 people living in the Harrison Village complex were evacuated after the blast, he said. Hundreds of firefighters, police, military and emergency personnel were on the scene late Sunday. Large plumes of black smoke curled from the fort area, on the northeastern edge of Indianapolis. Authorities said callers reported the blast could be felt more than a mile from the site. Rubble was strewn over a four-block-square area. State Trooper Anthony Blackburn said he arrived within five minutes of the blast. ``Insulation was coming down like snow when we got here. One apartment was engulfed n flames and the other building was in flames,'' he said. Joan Adams said military police began to go door to door about 7 p.m., telling residents that a gas leak had been found and would be fixed. ``He told us there was no danger for us to stay there,'' she said, but the family decided to leave anyway. Two hours later, an explosion occurred. Three adults and two children, ages 4 and 9, were taken to Wishard Hospital in critical condition, said hospital spokesman Tim Johnson. Four adults were taken to Hawley Army Community Hospital at the post suffering from smoke inhalation. At least one other person was admitted to another hospital.

DOC.HEAD: Shares Close Higher Down, Dollar Lower
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with closing Nikkei, dollar. Picks up 9th pvs, `In the ...'
DOC.TEXT: Share prices made up early losses to close higher Monday in Tokyo, while the dollar declined against the Japanese yen. The dollar closed at 130.55 yen, down 1.62 yen from Friday's finish at 132.17 yen. The currency opened at 130.70 yen and ranged between 130.30 yen and 130.93 yen. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average gained 262.18 points, or 1.11 percent, ending the day at 23,784.67. The index, a 969.39-point winner on Friday, was 42.47 points lower at the end of the morning session. Traders said the index's afternoon recovery was helped by the stability of the yen and government bonds as well as forecasts for lower U.S. interest rates. They said the Nikkei's morning slide was due to profit-taking following earlier gains. In the currency market, the dollar remained lower because of concerns that the U.S. Federal Reserve Board may further cut interest rates before the end of the year, dealers said. Lower interest rates make the dollar less attractive. Market players also lost interest in the U.S. currency because of optimism about the chance for a peaceful solution in the Persian Gulf following Iraq's announcement it is releasing all foreigners. The dollar usually is bought heavily in times of international tension such as the gulf crisis.

DOC.HEAD: No Flies On This Forensic Entomologist
DOC.TEXT: Flies and maggots can tell investigators when people died and whether they took drugs. They can also help solve cases involving the living. M. Lee Goff, a University of Hawaii entomologist who runs a Honolulu company called Forensic Entomology Enterprises, said police usually call him to help figure out how long someone's been dead. But last summer he got a different question: How long had a baby - barely alive and covered with bruises and maggots - been left near a Hawaii lake? ``She was quiet enough that flies had been attracted.
