Initially, they were attracted to the feces in her diapers,'' Goff said in New Orleans last week at a conference of the Entomological Society of America. Based on the maggots' size and other factors, the insect expert estimated the baby had been there 27 hours. He testified at the trial of the child's mother, Sharon Klafta, 32, who was convicted of attempted murder in September for leaving 16-month-old Heathe near the lake in April. The child now lives in a foster home and the mother is in prison. More and more, Goff said, forensic entomologists are called to testify about abuse to the living as well as about decomposition of the dead. Goff estimated there are about a dozen forensic entomologists nationwide. ``Some of my colleagues have been showing neglect of the elderly,'' he said. ``The nursing home will say, `Yes, we clean and bathe them regularly,' but the maggots have been sitting there and developing for five or six days.'' Their testimony is based on expertise on the life cycles and eating habits of insects that feed on still bodies. There are about 230 such insects in Hawaii, and nearly twice as many in the mainland United States, he said. Goff's job gets harder - but not impossible - the longer a person has been dead, he said. He recalled a case in which he examined bones and dirt from a child's grave. Judging from the beetles, larval skins and mites in the dirt, Goff estimated the child died 52 days earlier. ``When the suspect confessed, it turned out to be the morning 53 days before we were there,'' he said. Drug cases are especially challenging, he said. When asked to find out how long a cocaine user had been dead, he had to do some experimenting. ``I really didn't know if cocaine in the tissues would affect the development of the flies. I began raising flies on tissue diffused with cocaine,'' he said. Flies and their eggs grew at a normal rate, he said. But once the maggots began feeding, they growth rate rapidly increased until they changed into flies. He also learned that maggots feeding on a cocaine or heroin user retain the drug. ``As a body decomposes, it becomes very difficult to detect drugs,'' he said. ``The maggots pick up the drug and store it. You can analyze the maggot and show the drug was in the body.''

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Paula Abdul was banged up but was not seriously hurt in a three-car accident involving her Jaguar. The pop singer was treated Sunday at Medical Center of North Hollywood after complaining of pains in her head, neck and upper body, authorities said. Miss Abdul rear-ended a car, which then rammed a third car, said police Sgt. Al Zardeneta. No charges were immediately filed. ``We don't know how it happened,'' Zardeneta said. ``There are two options - either she was speeding or she was following too closely.'' The other drivers complained of sore necks but were not taken to the hospital, he said. Miss Abdul's 1989 debut album, ``Forever Your Girl,'' spawned the hits ``Straight Up,'' ``Cold Hearted'' and ``The Way You Love Me.'' She also choreographed the films ``Coming to America'' and ``The Running Man'' and won an Emmy for her choreography on television's ``The Tracey Ullman Show.'' --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Frank Sinatra is going home for his 75th birthday. Ol' Blue Eyes returns on Tuesday, the eve of his birthday, to an arena near his New Jersey hometown of Hoboken to begin a yearlong world tour. He plans to fulfill a lifetime dream of performing in the Soviet Union and possibly China. As Sinatra grows older - his light baritone has gotten deeper and richer - he exudes vitality. Still, Sinatra may be thinking about his age. During a toast on an upcoming TV special, he lifts his glass and says, ``May you all live to be 400 years old, and may the last voice you hear be mine.'' After kicking off his Diamond Jubilee World Tour at the Meadowlands' Brendan Byrne Arena, Sinatra will gather with his family at a hotel for a private birthday celebration. --- RADNOR, Pa. (AP) - One more crack about her producers and Delta Burke might have to kiss ``Designing Women'' goodbye. Linda Bloodworth-Thomason, a producer of the CBS show, said in next week's TV Guide she has almost lost patience with Ms. Burke, who has complained for months that she doesn't get enough recognition and respect on the set. ``She seems to be continuing to escalate the situation to a point where a choice has to be made - and a choice will be made,'' Bloodworth-Thomason said. The feud has caught co-star Dixie Carter in the middle because she considered both women close friends. In the end, she took Bloodworth-Thomason's side, accusing Burke of attacking the producer. ``There were things that happened and things that were imagined and distorted,'' Carter said. ``People need to see the forest for the trees.'' --- NEW YORK (AP) - Lena Olin of the new film ``Havana'' says love scenes can be tricky, but Robert Redford was a charm. ``He was sweet,'' Olin, 35, said in the Dec. 17 issue of People. The Swedish-born actress plays a political activist who has a love affair with a gambler played by Redford in the movie, set during the Cuban revolution. ``Actually those scenes were saved until we had shot for quite a while, because usually it's good that you get some kind of intimacy with the person,'' she said. ``I mean, I could've done it the first day since he is the way he is, but it's even nicer when you get to know how sweet he is.'' Olin starred in ``The Unbearable Lightness of Being'' and won an Oscar nomination for her role in ``Enemies: A Love Story.'' --- RADNOR, Pa. (AP) - It's been 24 years since Dolly Parton and her husband, Carl Dean, have appeared together on stage, and that's the way he wants it. Her Dec. 21 Christmas special on ABC, ``Dolly Parton ... Christmas at Home,'' will include her mother, father, six brothers, five sisters, about a dozen aunts and uncles and 15 or so nieces and nephews - but not her husband. ``He's very shy, and not the least bit interested in show business,'' she said in next week's TV Guide. They last appeared together in 1966, the year they were married, when Ms. Parton had to attend a music awards ceremony in Los Angeles. ``Carl rented a tuxedo for the night, and I won an award for best song of the year,'' she said. ``But when we got home, he said `Dolly, I think you're terrific and talented, and I wish you the best, but don't ever ask me to anything like that again.''' Dean doesn't accompany Ms. Parton on the road, preferring to remain in Nashville, where he owns an asphalt-paving business.

DOC.HEAD: Former Guerrillas Win Elections in Colombia
LaserPhoto NY19
DOC.TEXT: Voters have given a former guerrilla army the largest bloc in an assembly that will rewrite the country's constitution, dealing a resounding defeat to Colombia's traditional parties. As if to punctuate its insistence that leftists can do better at the polls than in the jungle, the army on Sunday raided the headquarters of a recalcitrant rebel group, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia. The attack south of Bogota claimed the lives of 11 soldiers and as many as 40 rebels, the army said. ``Violent groups have lost their argument to persevere in their practices of hate,'' President Cesar Gaviria said in a televised speech Sunday night. The voting capped a bizarre 12 months in South American politics. Last December, Brazil elected little-known businessman Fernando Collor de Mello as its president. In June, Peru selected Alberto Fujimori, a virtually unknown agronomist, as its president. Only about 30 percent of the roughly 12 million eligible voters went to the polls on Sunday, elections officials said. While the overall composition of the 70-member Constituent Assembly will be conservative-to-moderate, the results marked a remarkable turnabout for the leftist April 19th Movement, known as M-19, which laid down its arms in March. With 83 percent of the vote counted, M-19 had 27 percent of the vote and should control 20 seats, political analysts said. The governing Liberal Party garnered around 26 percent of the vote. A right-wing splinter group of the Conservative Party, the National Salvation Party, won 16 percent of the vote, while the traditional Conservative Party captured around 10 percent. The rest of the vote was spread among smaller parties. The assembly is empowered to reform a 104-year-old constitution that has been inadequate to handle vast political- and drug-related violence and extortion, government corruption and desperate poverty. Expected changes include revamping the battered courts, adding safeguards to curb corruption, and establishing new civil rights for prisoners. Colombia's powerful cocaine cartels are widely believed to have donated money to assembly candidates, although little hard evidence surfaced. Candidates rarely mentioned the government's 15-month-old war on drug traffickers. Colombia has been dominated throughout its 160-year history by the Liberals and the Conservatives.But Sunday, the voters showed more faith in M-19 chief Antonio Navarro Wolf, a 41-year-old engineer more accustomed to kidnapping businessmen and hijacking airliners than making campaign speeches. Yet the M-19 victory was oddly characteristic of a group always better at capturing the imagination than capturing territory in war. The group takes its name from the date of an allegedly rigged 1970 presidential election. Its inaugural act in 1974 was to steal the sword of Simon Bolivar, the hero of Latin American independence. In 1980, the rebels raided a dinner party and held the U.S. ambassador and other diplomats captive for weeks. Political violence has claimed about 75,000 lives in Colombia since the late 1960s. Drug traffickers killed about 550 people over the past year, including three candidates in last May's presidential elections, as they tried to force the government to stop extraditing cocaine smugglers to the United States. Many candidates, including Navarro, were unable to take their campaigns to the streets for fear of being killed.

DOC.HEAD: Cheering Crowd Celebrates Return of Hostages
With PM-Gulf-Iraq, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A former hostage from Iraq shouted ``Oh my God!'' as he saw his infant son for the first time, and the two men who won the release of 21 Americans flown here were cheered, kissed and given roses. The hostages who arrived in Houston on Sunday were part of a group that Iraq's Saddam Hussein decided to let go one day before he announced the blanket release of all Western hostages. Some of those hostages arrived Sunday in Frankfurt, Germany, and Americans among them were to arrive today at Andrews Air Force Base, outside Washington. Family members in Houston mobbed former Treasury Secretary John Connally and oil executive Oscar Wyatt, who secured their loved ones' release. Three U.S. Embassy employees and seven family members also were aboard the Boeing 707 operated by Wyatt's Coastal Corp. that arrived before dawn at Ellington Air Field. ``Oh my God!'' shouted Jim Vine of Pasadena, Calif., as he rushed to throw his arms around his wife, Donna, and son Evan, whom he had never seen before. The baby was born Sept. 6, about a month after Iraq invaded Kuwait. Lynda Parker screamed for several minutes when she saw her husband, Bobby Gene Parker of Vidor, descending the plane. She dropped to her knees and embraced Parker, who lost about 40 pounds while he was kept at a military base 25 miles north of Baghdad. ``Four and a half months - it's been a long time coming,'' Parker said as he greeted about 40 friends and relatives. ``What did I miss the most? My family and I've got them all right here.'' Parker, who worked for Kuwait Drilling Co., said he read a lot and spent his time listening to Voice of America and BBC radio. ``There was never enough food,'' he said. ``I just hope everyone will be home for Christmas.'' Parker's 25-year-old son, Ryan, interrupted a news conference by Connally and Wyatt to give each man a rose. ``This is a very, very small token of appreciation for everything you've done,'' he said, his voice cracking. ``You've brought my daddy home.'' He then led a crowd of about 200 relatives and family members in three cheers for the men. Connally and Wyatt met with Saddam for about 45 minutes to secure the hostages' release. Three Britons and an American living in England also were freed. They left the plane in Shannon, Ireland, during a refueling stop. Connally and Wyatt donated 15 tons of medical supplies, valued at $500,000, to Fellowship on Reconciliation, an Iraqi humanitarian group in Amman, Jordan. ``Mr. Wyatt said that if indeed there's an armed conflict, the presence of a few hundred hostages would not in any way deter the armed conflict,'' Connally said. Most of the former hostages, who looked gaunt and tired, said they generally were treated well. All complained about food shortages. ``I lost some weight,'' said Allen Lawson of Huntsville, Texas. ``But as far as being mistreated, no I was not mistreated. I know we sometimes got more food than the Iraqi citizens.'' Jackie Nelson, wife of former hostage Bill Nelson of Los Angeles, kissed Wyatt and Connally on the cheek and said, ``God bless you. I can't thank you enough. We're so grateful.'' The oilmen, exhausted from the 18-hour flight, were moved to tears. ``That's why we went,'' Wyatt said later. ``God Bless America. There's nothing like it,'' said Nelson, who was held at a munitions plant 37 miles south of Baghdad. ``These people are marvelous. They have done things our government can't do and won't do.''

DOC.HEAD: City Government Overhaul Fails in Dallas
DOC.TEXT: Voter defeat of a government overhaul designed to help minorities get elected to City Council means a federal judge is free to impose a new setup on the city. Residents on Saturday rejected by 369 votes a measure under which 14 council members would be elected from districts and the mayor would be elected from the city as a whole. The vote was 45,255 in favor and 45,624 against. Under the current system, instituted in 1975, eight members are elected from districts and three others, including the mayor, are elected from the city at large. With the plan's defeat, U.S. District Judge Jerry Buchmeyer could institute the same plan or a similar one and call a City Council election in May. Mayor Annette Strauss said the judge indicated he could rule as early as January. Supporters said the plan would have helped ease racial inequities that make it difficult for minorities to get elected. Opponents said the system would have resegregated Dallas. They backed a plan calling for 10 candidates to be elected by district, four by larger districts, or regions, and the mayor by the city as a whole. The referendum was part of the settlement of a 1988 lawsuit brought by Roy Williams and Marvin Crenshaw, blacks who failed in their at-large council bids. They charged that the election system made it difficult for minorities to win office. Black and Hispanic leaders nationwide have long charged that at-large elections dilute minority voting strength. Crenshaw said he was confident the judicial system would not fail supporters of the 14-1 plan. ``And I think Judge Buchmeyer is going to take that stake and drive it through the vampire's heart,'' he said. Al Gonzalez, chairman of the 14-1 for Dallas Committee, blamed the referendum's failure on poor turnout among minorities. ``I was shocked,'' he said. ``You can make a lot of excuses, it was Saturday, if it was pouring, whatever. We should have got that vote out. The minority community has nobody to blame but themselves.''

DOC.HEAD: Former Panamanian Denies Leaking Phone Tapes
DOC.TEXT: A political opponent of Manuel Noriega who helped U.S. drug agents decipher tapes of the former dictator's phone calls from jail denied leaking the tapes to CNN. The FBI believes Jose Blandon, a former intelligence officer and diplomat under Noriega, may have been the source of the leak, The Miami Herald and The Washington Post reported this weekend, citing unidentified sources. However, Blandon said the FBI investigation into who gave CNN the tapes it has broadcast over the past month should focus instead on U.S. officials who may want to keep Noriega's drug trafficking trial from going forward and embarrassing agencies that worked with Noriega before his downfall, the Post reported Sunday. ``Somebody in the government was leaking them,'' Blandon told the Post. He said that Drug Enforcement Administration agents were present whenever he had access to the tapes and that he was allowed to take notes only. Blandon said he spent five full days in May and June reviewing 22 of the tapes at the DEA in Miami before describing their contents to a large group of DEA agents. The U.S. attorney's office in Miami has maintained that prosecutors in the Noriega trial have not been exposed to tapes of privileged conversations between Noriega and his attorneys. However, Blandon said Assistant U.S. Attorney Michael P. Sullivan visited him at his Miami hotel room after the DEA review and asked for a briefing on the tapes. ``I mentioned everything,'' Blandon told the Post, including a conversation in which Noriega and defense attorney Frank Rubino discussed how to deal with Luis del Cid, a former Noriega aide who has pleaded guilty and promised to testify against his former boss. ``I discussed this with Sullivan.'' After he returned home that weekend, Blandon said, he received a call from a DEA agent saying the agency urgently wanted a memorandum describing the content of the calls ``because Sullivan was asking for that.'' Blandon said he faxed a six-page memorandum to the DEA on a machine that was seized by FBI agents during a search of his home in Houston on Thursday. In court documents filed Friday, prosecutors said a DEA agent reviewed the memorandum and determined that while it spoke of a call between Noriega and his attorney, this was not a privileged attorney-client conversation. Noriega's defense has asked U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler to dismiss the drug case, alleging the government's taping of his phone calls violated his right to attorney-client confidentiality. The judge has yet to rule. Noriega is accused of taking $4.6 million in bribes to protect the cocaine trade passing through Panama to the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Daughters of King, Malcolm X, Split Over King Holiday
DOC.TEXT: The daughters of Martin Luther King Jr. and Malcolm X, echoing their fathers' split over tactics, divided over whether to take part in a play in Arizona following the state's failure to enact a King holiday. Yolanda King, a 34-year-old actress, withdrew from the performance Sunday of ``Stepping Into Tomorrow'' at the University of Arizona. Attallah Shabazz, daughter of the Black Muslim leader, kept her commitment. The play was performed as scheduled, with a understudy taking Ms. King's role. A statement read on Ms. King's behalf before the show said she felt her presence ``could and would be misconstrued.'' ``I believe that the greater good would be served by my support of this boycott,'' she said. The women's split recalled their fathers.' King, who was assassinated in 1968, said civil rights should be achieved through non-violence. Malcolm X, who was shot to death in 1965, defended the use of violence. Both women are founding directors of Nucleus, a performing arts group that has taken the show nationwide for more than 10 years. Arizona voters on Nov. 6 defeated two propositions to establish a paid King holiday. Since then, numerous conventions and other events have canceled. The National Football League threatened to withdraw the 1993 Super Bowl from Tempe. The Tucson appearance was booked months before the election. Ms. King said in the statement that she initially felt her appearance ``would have a positive effect'' toward resolving the holiday issue and would also ``inspire young Arizonans who believe in my father's vision.'' But it ``became increasingly apparent to me that my presence in Arizona could and would be misconstrued by some to be contrary to the goals and tactics of the proponents of the King holiday,'' she said. Ms. Shabazz said she took part because there are different ways to fight for a cause. ``Some write letters, some hug people, some protest,'' she said. ``If Ms. King thought that we were slapping the cause in the face then we wouldn't be here,'' Ms. Shabazz said. ``She thinks physically, as a King descendant, that she should not be here.'' The show combines music, comedy and drama, using a high school reunion as the setting to examine such problems as teen pregnancy, drugs, suicide and peer pressure.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Plunges, Stocks Rebound
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell sharply against the yen for the second consecutive trading day today, while share prices rebounded from early losses. The dollar closed at 130.55 yen, down 1.62 yen from last Friday's 132.17-yen finish. It opened at 130.70 yen and ranged between 130.30 yen and 130.93 yen. The dollar had fallen 1.88 yen on Friday. Spot trading totaled $9.55 billion, up slightly from Friday's $9.33 billion. Dealers said the dollar's low opening today followed worse-than-expected U.S. jobless figures reported Friday as well as the U.S. Federal Reserve Board's quarter-point cut in the federal funds rate. Lower interest rates tend to make a currency less attractive to investors. The dollar's decline slowed later as ``investors could not figure out which way they should push the dollar,'' said Naohiko Yasuda, a dealer with the Bank of Tokyo. On the stock exchange, the 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average gained 262.18 points, or 1.11 percent, closing at 23,784.67. The index has risen nearly 2,000 points since Wednesday. It gained 969.39 points on Friday alone, but fell 42.47 points in this morning trading before turning up again. The afternoon recovery was helped by the stability of the yen and government bonds as well as forecasts for lower U.S. interest rates, traders said. The jobless figures announced Friday renewed concerns about a slowdown in the U.S. economy, said a trader with Nomura Securities Co., speaking on condition of anonymity. ``The market is expecting a U.S. discount rate cut to come by the end of this year,'' he said. ``Although trading was volatile because of position adjustments, the market has been regaining stability gradually,'' he added. The Nomura trader said buying by investment trusts and foreign brokerages helped the index's recovery in the afternoon. About 400 million shares changed hands on the first section, down from Friday's 590 million. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds rose to 87.72 points from Friday's 87.31-point close. Their yield fell to 7.120 percent from 7.210 percent.

DOC.HEAD: USA Today Says it Will Launch Clothing Line
DOC.TEXT: Move over, Georgio Armani. There's a new fashion designer in town, and its name is USA Today. ``The Nation's Newspaper'' announced Sunday that it will launch an apparel line under the ``USA Today'' brand name. The clothes: men's and women's casual sportswear, ``designed in accordance with the newspaper's upbeat, colorful, graphic style.'' A brief read on the plans: - USA Today clothing will be available at national department store chains, sporting goods stores and other outlets. - Schlaifer Nance and Co. will develop and market the line. - Distribution is slated for spring 1992. Says Thomas J. Farrell, vice president and general manager of USA Today: ``Our goal is to create a natural extension of the USA Today brand name to meet the interests of both our readers and advertisers.''

DOC.HEAD: Pump Prices Remain Stable Despite Federal Gas Tax
DOC.TEXT: The price of gasoline at the pump has barely increased over the past three weeks despite the new nickel-a-gallon federal tax, an industry analyst says. The average price of a gallon of gas was $1.4606 on Dec. 7, up .08 cents from Nov. 16, according to Trilby Lundberg's national survey of 13,600 gasoline stations. Lundberg noted Sunday that prices did not jump despite the 5-cent tax imposed Dec. 1. ``Crude oil prices have been softening for several weeks, therefore gas suppliers were passing through lower crude oil costs,'' she said. She also cited lessening fear of war in the Persian Gulf, reports of increased oil supply, lower demand for gas at this time of year and price competition between gas stations.

DOC.HEAD: Small Town, Black Neighbors at Odds Over Martin Luther King Holiday
DOC.TEXT: When the mayor of this small, overwhelmingly white town said there weren't enough blacks to justify a Martin Luther King holiday, he was faced with a minority that wasn't so silent. Blacks in neighboring Kankakee boycotted Bradley businesses. Now, merchants are worried and village officials are offering an apology and a holiday. But the holiay would leave village offices open, and blacks say that is not enough. ``I think they are sincere and we are making progress,'' said the Rev. William Copeland, a leader in Kankakee's black community. ``But we're not there yet.'' Bradley Mayor Kenneth Hayes may not have realized just how close Kankakee was when he rejected the idea of a holiday on King's birthday, which falls on Jan. 15 but is being observed on Jan. 21. ``Martin Luther King was a great man for the black people. ... We have five or six blacks in Bradley. Why should we close down services for the other 11,995?'' he told the Kankakee Daily Journal. Just across the town line, some 10,000 blacks live in Kankakee, a city 50 miles south of Chicago with a population of about 32,000. Some of them shop in Bradley. At least 2,000 people - black and white - have pledged not to cross that line in protest against the mayor's remarks, Copeland said. Bradley leaders met with Copeland and other black ministers Thursday. They offered an unsigned pology from Hayes, hospitalized in Chicago for lung surgery, and a resolution proclaiming a King holiday but leaving village offices open. ``They're saying they'll celebrate on paper but it will be business as usual in Bradley,'' said Copeland. ``We want a real holiday, we want the mayor to sign the apology, and we want a pledge from them to work for fair housing and affirmative action.'' Bradley village board member Howard Duchene said Hayes would sign the apology when he recovered. But he said the village may not be able to afford a paid holiday for King's birthday. Meanwhile, black leaders say a black-oriented fashion show has moved from Bradley to Kankakee, and blacks have returned Christmas gifts bought in Bradley and canceled group shopping trips there. ``If blacks feel strongly that they were offended, they should stand up for what they believe, but it's not our fault and I wish they wouldn't punish us,'' said Mark Viers, manager of NRM Music in Bradley's new shopping mall. ``The mayor doesn't speak for all of us.'' Some residents line up with the mayor. ``I cannot believe that in this day and age in a country whose citizens are supposed to be free to choose, I am being told which persons' lives to glorify,'' David Albers of Bradley wrote to the Kankakee Daily Journal.

DOC.HEAD: First Japanese in Space Returns With Craving for Beer, Smoke
DOC.TEXT: After eight days as the first journalist in space, Toyohiro Akiyama safely touched down today with down-to-Earth cravings for beer, good food and a smoke. ``It seems like I came back as a mass of desire,'' Akiyama, 48, said after emerging from the Soyuz space capsule that landed on the frozen tundra in Kazakstan, the Soviet republic in Central Asia. Akiyama, a news director for the Tokyo Broadcasting System, was the first Japanese in space. He returned with cosmonauts Gennady Manakov and Gennady Strekalov, who were concluding a four-month stay aboard the Mir space station. TBS paid the Soviets $12 million for Akiyama's rocket fare and spent an additional $25 million on the project. As soon as Akiyama emerged from the capsule, waving and smiling, he was mobbed by TBS reporters who had raced to the landing site to beam live to Japan his first words back on terra firma. ``Yes, it's very beautiful,'' he said when asked how it felt to be back on Earth. TBS then arranged for Akiyama to say a few words to his wife, Kyoko, who had watched the landing from the company's Tokyo studios. ``I'm back,'' said Akiyama, wrapped in a parka and with his space helmet still in place. ``I worried a bit,'' replied his wife. ``Did the kids do all right on their exams?'' he asked. ``Why ask such things now?'' she shot back. ``I want to eat something good.'' ``I've prepared it,'' his wife reassured him. The saturation coverage by TBS of Akiyama's mission reached a crescendo with today's all-day live broadcast of the landing, which came at about 3:05 p.m. local time. TBS had rented four helicopters with cameras mounted underneath to cover two possible landing sites. When a reporter from one of the helicopters first spotted the capsule plummeting to Earth, he repeatedly yelled in tones of near hysteria, ``I see it. I see it. It's there. It's there.'' Reporters were at the landing site less than 10 minutes after touchdown, and repeatedly mentioned how charred the capsule looked. When asked by an anchorman whethe the capsule was still hot, a journalist at the scene touched the side and reported back: ``I can't tell because I have gloves on.'' Akiyama's odyssey in space began Dec. 2 with liftoff from the Baikonur Cosmodrome, about 1,300 miles east of Moscow. He and two Soviet cosmonauts linked up with the space station Mir on Tuesday. TBS, which sent Akiyama into space as part of the company's 40th anniversary celebrations, aired exclusive live broadcasts from their astro-reporter each night that won strong ratings. In those reports, Akiyama explained how it felt to be weightless and to be space sick, which he described as being akin to a hangover. He expressed concerns about global pollution he viewed from orbit, and even recited Japanese haiku poetry. Akiyama also took six Japanese tree frogs into space for experiments on how they adapt to the weightless environment. TBS said videotape of these experiments may be shown later. Taking along a paying passenger was an important step in the Soviets' effort to commercialize their space program, and Akiyama's trip has been a relentlessly commercial affair. Japanese corporate sponsors, including a diaper maker and a toothpaste company, had their logos and names plastered on the rocket that launched Akiyama into space. TBS expects to lose $7.4 million on the project, even after accounting for advertising revenues and proceeds from documentaries and lectures by Akiyama.

DOC.HEAD: 25 Die In Factional Violence As Peace Talks Continue
DOC.TEXT: Police said today that 25 people died in black factional fighting as President F.W. de Klerk and African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela continued efforts to end political unrest. Police reported scattered clashes over the weekend, with the worst violence in the Johannesburg black township of Tokoza, where 13 people were killed. Eleven men were hacked and shot to death in the township, another man was ``necklaced'' with a burning tire and a six-year-old girl was gunned down, police said. Dozens of people died in Tokoza last week in clashes. De Klerk and Mandela issued a statement late Sunday revealing they had been holding secret talks on halting the violence that has claimed about 1,000 lives in the Johannesburg area since August. The statement said the two leaders had met several times in recent weeks, including a secret meeting Saturday. The statement said significant progress had been made, but gave no details. It said urgent follow-up steps would be taken. The statement said the major problem to be resolved involved the ANC's suspension of its armed struggle against the white-led government, agreed to at a meeting in Pretoria Aug. 6. The government has accused the ANC of violating the agreement by continuing to recruit and train members for armed struggle. The ANC contends it never agreed to end preparations for possible future armed struggle. The ANC suspended its largely ineffective armed struggle as aconcession in the talks aimed at ending apartheid and setting up full-scale negotiations on a new constitution. The ANC has repeatedly accused government security forces of instigating the violence between black groups. Much of the violence has pitted ANC partisans against the mostly Zulu Inkatha Freedom Party. In other developments, Inkatha called at its annual congress for an end to economic sanctions against South Africa and urged all black political groups to unite to end factional fighting. A party resolution passed Sunday urged all black groups to ensure a quick start to talks with the government. ``All scrutiny and all analysis will show that the process of reform is irreversible, that apartheid is totally doomed and that all that remains is finally to finish dismembering it and throwing its pieces away,'' the Inkatha congress said. The congress called for the United Nations and the European Community to adopt ``a rigorous timetable'' for ending sanctions ``as effectively and expeditiously as possible.'' Inkatha supporters and ANC backers have waged virtual warfare in Natal province for five years, killing more than 5,000 people. The fighting spread in August to the Johannesburg area, where some 1,000 people have died. The Pan Africanist Congress, the most militant of the main black opposition groups, concluded its first congress inside South Africa in 31 years on Sunday by rejecting negotiations with the government on a new constitution.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Gulf Buildup May Cost Additional $20 Billion
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon may have to ask Congress for up to $20 billion more to cover the Persian Gulf buildup, The New York Times reported today. The costs of the operation have risen sharply because of plans to add up to 200,000 troops to the U.S. forces already in the region, the newspaper said. U.S. officials said the request reflects an estimate that the Persian Gulf operation could cost as much as $31 billion, the Times said. It said that contributions from American allies might offset less than half of that amount. Despite the unknowns, such as what the precise cost will be and how much allies will contribute, a senior Pentagon official quoted by the Times said Congress may be asked to allot $16 billion to $20 billion more when lawmakers reassemble in January. Before the Nov. 8 decision to add troops to those already in the Persian Gulf, it was estimated Congress would have to allot about $5 billion during the fiscal year that began Oct. 1. The anticipated 1991 costs of the deployment will have no impact on the budget agreement struck last fall. The agreement omitted expenses for the gulf operation because they could not be calculated. There was no immediate indication of whether the additional costs would be covered through higher taxes or through borrowing, the Times said.

DOC.HEAD: Dry, Mild Weather Across Much of Nation; Rain in Northwest
DOC.TEXT: Unseasonably mild and dry weather prevailed across much of the nation today, although rain fell across the Pacific Northwest. Temperatures dipped to below freezing in the Deep South, but reached the 30s and 40s in most of the rest the nation. Portions of the Rocky Mountain states and the extreme northern tier of the Plains and Great Lakes had temperatures below 30 degrees. Birmingham, Ala., was 31 degrees early today, the same as Bismarck, N.D. High pressure in the Plains was expected to bring record warmth, with temperatures about 25 degrees above their season norm. Temperatures will drop 10-15 degrees in the upper Midwest, after record high temperatures Sunday. Flurries are possible in the northern mountains of New England, along the southern shorelines of lakes Erie and Ontario, and the mountains of Idaho and Montana. A cold front will sweep across New England today, ushering in a blast of winterlike temperatures. The nation's high on Sunday was 87 degrees at Camp Pendleton, Calif. DOC.HEAD: Former Vermont Governor Deane Davis Dies
DOC.TEXT: Former Gov. Deane C. Davis, who pushed through legislation to protect Vermont's environment, has died at age 90. The two-term Republican, who served from 1969 to 1973, died Saturday at Central Vermont Hospital in Berlin of complications from gall bladder surgery. The scion of a farming family, Davis, a lawyer, had neither served in the Legislature nor held statewide elective office when he ran for governor in 1968. In 1970, Davis had one of the most successful legislative sessions ever enjoyed by a Vermont governor. Legislators enacted a pioneering law that controlled major development projects by establishing how they would be evaluated; an innovative water quality law, and legislation restructuring the government into superagencies. In April 1970, Davis presided over Vermont's first Green-up Day, a project to clean up the state. More than 70,000 people helped remove 4,000 truckloads of trash from interstate highways. At age 9, Davis became a member of the first Boy Scout troop in America. In 1940, he served as general counsel for the National Life Insurance Co. in Montpelier. Ten years later he became president of the company, which he helped build into one of the biggest firms in the nation. In retirement, he wrote two books of Vermont humor. His memoirs are scheduled to be published in the spring. Davis' first wife, Corrine, died of cancer. In 1952, he married Marjorie Smith Conzelman. Davis is survived by his wife;, a son; a daughter, and a sister. A funeral is scheduled for Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Army Replaces Ershad Loyalists
DOC.TEXT: The army has replaced three senior officers loyal to ousted President Hussain Muhammad Ershad, and mayors appointed by the former president also will be replaced, sources said today. Ershad, a former general who seized power in 1982, bowed to public pressure last week and handed over power to a caretaker government led by Supreme Court Chief Justice Shahabuddin Ahmed. Shahabuddin has appointed nine advisers to preside over the affairs of state while he prepares parliamentary elections to be held early next year. Sources close to Ershad's government said the army had replaced Maj. Gen. Mohammad Ashraf Hossain and Brig. Nasiruddin Ahmed, the two senior intelligence officers, along with Gen. Abdus Salam, the quartermaster-general. The intelligence officers were part of Ershad's crisis team, which met almost daily during the seven-week campaign of street demonstrations and strikes organized to press for his ouster, the sources said. They said all three men had been appointed officers ``on special assignment,'' presumably positions without power. There was no official confirmation of the command changes. The Morning Sun newspaper reported that the caretaker government had also removed Saiful Bari, chairman under Ershad of state-run radio and television, and Mosarraf Hossain, secretary of the industries ministry. Shahabuddin's advisory council met for the first time Sunday and moved to replace the mayors of Dhaka, Chittagong, Rajshahi and Khulna, and the chairmen of 61 of the country's 64 district councils, according to an announcement published today in major newspapers. Only Bangladesh's four largest cities have mayors. The rest of the country of 110 million to 120 million people is divided into administrative districts. The popularly elected chairmen of three districts in the Chittagong Hill Tracts will keep their jobs. The other chairmen were appointed by the president. The English-language Morning Sun said Ershad was seeking possible political asylum in the United States, Britain, Australia or Pakistan. U.S., Australian and Pakistani diplomats denied any knowledge of such a request. British diplomats could not be located for comment because their embassy was closed today. Ershad was secluded Sunday at his home in Dhaka's cantonment, home to senior military officers. Several other members of his government were in hiding, fearing attacks if they appear in public. The former president's opponents are divided over whether to let Ershad leave the country or to prosecute him, as is demanded by the students who sparked the campaign that led to his demise.

DOC.HEAD: Thirty-Two Rhodes Scholars Announced, Including Five From Harvard
DOC.TEXT: A football captain who wants to build an inner-city school is among 32 Rhodes Scholars chosen to study at Oxford University in England for two years. The 1991 U.S. Rhodes scholars announced Sunday were chosen during meetings held nationwide Wednesday and Saturday, said David Alexander, the American secretary of the Rhodes Scholarship Trust based at Pomona College in Claremont. The winners include a Baptist minister, a student fluent in four languages, four English majors, five political science majors and two pre-med students. Several scholars said they planned careers in education. Darcy D. Prather, an inside linebacker at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said Sunday his eventual goal is to start a school in Chicago or St. Louis that would ``address deficiencies of students in science and engineering.'' Prather will study politics, philosophy and economics at Oxford. Harvard University had five scholars, Yale had four, and Williams College and the U.S. Air Force Academy each had two. The new scholars include 27 men and five women. Women have been eligible for the scholarships since 1976, and 157 have participated in the program. Among the qualities sought in Rhodes scholars are proven intellectual and academic excellence, integrity, respect for others, ability to lead and to use talents fully, and sports prowess. Applicants must be single and between the ages of 18 and 24. ``It's renewing to be among so many candidates this year who care about education and teaching,'' said Goodwin Liu, a biological sciences major at Stanford University and a tennis instructor. Liu plans to study human sciences at Oxford. The University of Virginia's Brad Ronnell Braxton is a religious studies major who is already a licensed Baptist minister. He plans a career in the ministry and college teaching. Sabina Alkire, who majored in sociology at the University of Illinois, worked in Pakistan, India and Guatemala. She speaks Spanish, Hindi and Urdu and plans to study theology at Oxford. Carl D. Marci, a pre-med student at Columbia University, conducted a study last year for an AIDS support group that delivers hot meals to people with acquired immune deficiency syndrome. He plans to major in public health. The Rhodes scholarships were established in 1902 by the estate of Cecil Rhodes, a British philanthropist and colonialist, who had hoped they would contribute to world understanding and peace. Scholarship winners have educational fees and living expenses paid. Former Rhodes scholars include Sen. Bill Bradley, D-N.J., entertainer Kris Kristofferson, former Los Angeles Rams quarterback Pat Haden and U.S. Supreme Court Justice David Souter.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Falls, Gold Mixed
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell in European trading today. Gold was mixed. Dealers said the lessening of tensions in the Persian Gulf after news that Iraq and the United States would negotiate was hurting the dollar, seen as a safe haven in times of international tension. In Tokyo, the dollar fell 1.62 yen to a closing 130.55 yen. Later in London, it was quoted at 130.55 yen. DOC.HEAD: Defiant Hostages Say They Would Have Welcomed the Bombs
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Lorin Hubbard says he felt no fear as he waited for American bombs to fall on the Iraqi ammunition plant where he was held as a human shield. ``We were hoping they'd blow the place up,'' the angry, tired Boeing aircraft executive said as he trudged through the Frankfurt airport, a free man after four and a half months as a vulnerable pawn. Hubbard, 66, was among scores of Westerners taken hostage by the Iraqis and designated human shields, dispatched to areas the Iraqis considered vulnerable to a U.S. attack. He said he and his wife, who had lived in Kuwait City for more than five years, were picked up in Kuwait City by Iraqi troops shortly after the Persian Gulf nation invaded the tiny emirate. He and about 40 other foreigners were taken to Baghdad ``in an unair-conditioned bus in the heat of the day, babies and everything.'' He said they were farmed out to other locations, and that he and his wife were held in an office at a munitions plant about 40 miles west of Baghdad. The composition of the nationalities he was with changed with the diplomatic overtures made by various countries. ``They'd take the French out, then they'd bring somebody else in, then they'd take the Germans out,'' said Hubbard, who is from Seattle. ``We had no idea when we'd get out,'' he said. ``Nobody knew where we were, as far as I know.'' Asked if he felt in danger to a U.S. attack on the ammo factory, Hubbard said: ``I want to see them make a hole in the ground at that place,'' he said. ``We were hoping they would. I hope they blow it up.'' Many other former hostages expressed rage when their ordeal finally ended. Several who managed to avoid detection in Kuwait said they were aided by an organized underground of Kuwaiti citizens. Don Latham, an engineer from Albuquerque, N.M., said he worked with a Kuwaiti resistance that called itself ``The Guardians.'' ``The last thing I saw was a Kuwaiti family that had given refuge to an American citizen,'' he said. ``They (the Iraqis) killed seven members of the family.'' He said he photographed the body of a 12-year-old boy. ``Those murdering bastards,'' he said. Latham, 51, said that he went underground with his 70-year-old stepfather, who had come to visit him just two days before the invasion. ``Several families put us up,'' he said. ``The resistance is not totally violent. They're much more concerned with taking care of the people, getting food, not just to the Kuwaitis, but anybody.'' Ernest Alexander, originally from Media, Penn., ran a law firm in Kuwait and also spent the time since the invasion in hiding, aided by the Kuwaiti underground, he said. He said he believes Kuwaitis would welcome a U.S. military effort. ``They all do to every man to every woman to every child, even if it means they're all under a rain of bombs,'' said Alexander, 39. ``It was very demoralizing to find (Americans) suggesting that sanctions ought to go on for a year, 18 months.'' Pete Dooley arrived in Kuwait in February to run a string of restaurants for his company. He said he hid in his apartment during the siege. ``They came to the door, but I didn't answer,'' said the 40-year-old resident of Hopkinsville, Ky. He said Kuwaitis and some Palestinians helped him get around. ``Very many people have left,'' he said. ``Everybody that could leave is gone.'' He said he was looking forward to going home. ``My mother is going to bake me a meat loaf,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Jailed Reporter Released, Still Refusing To Answer Questions
DOC.TEXT: A newspaper reporter was free today after spending two days in jail for refusing to answer questions about interviews she conducted with a man on trial for murder. Libby Averyt, 26, of the Corpus Christi Caller-Times was freed Sunday after prosecutors agreed to allow District Judge Eric Brown dissolve contempt charges against her, the newspaper reported. Brown had ordered Ms. Averyt jailed Thursday on contempt charges after she invoked the First Amendment and similar provisions of the Texas Constitution after refusing to answer 12 questions about conversations she had with Jermarr Arnold. She was jailed Friday. Averyt and the newspaper's attorney, Jorge Rangel, maintained that journalists should not be compelled to reveal information obtained from news sources if that information was not published. Arnold stands trial for the 1983 slaying of 21-year-old jewelry store clerk Christina Sanchez. The trial is scheduled to begin Wednesday. At a meeting Sunday with prosecutors and the judge, Rangel said, ``I told everyone present that Libby was not going to change her mind and was not going to answer the questions.'' He urged that she be freed since, he argued, further jail time would not change the situation. Rangel said Ms. Averyt is still under subpoena for Arnold's murder trial. If called to testify, Ms. Averyt said, ``I'm not going to answer any questions about unpublished material.'' ``Libby made a very strong statement, that she was willing to go to jail on behalf of a principle,'' said Larry Rose, executive editor of the Caller-Times. ``I believe it sends a statement that news reporters are not going to let themselves become investigative arms of the state.'' Ms. Averyt said among the first things she planned to do after getting out of jail was ``to take a hot bubble bath and talk to my husband.''

DOC.HEAD: Astronomer Waxes Poetic Over Columbia's Star-Crossed Mission
With PM-Space Shuttle, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Astronomer Bill Blair has been waxing poetic over Columbia's star-crossed mission for months, much to his colleagues' delight. The research scientist at Johns Hopkins University started giving songs and poems a shuttle twist long before fuel leaks halted the mission's fourth countdown in September. He is part of the team managing the university's ultraviolet telescope aboard the shuttle. One of his first efforts at fine-tuning songs was with ``Fifty Ways To Leave Your Lover.'' He wrote four or five versions of the song - all called ``Fifty Ways To Lose Your Pointings'' - based on problems simulated during training that came true after launch. Another lyric, happily, was not so prescient: ``We'll be launched by Christmas, but only in our dreams.'' ``Since we got launched by Christmas, I never fleshed that one out the rest of the way,'' he said, laughing. Other team members have come up with occasional lyrics about the mission, which was delayed by fuel leaks for months before the Dec. 2 launch and has been hampered by technical problems since. But Blair, 37, goes that one further. ``It's just been sort of a joke,'' he said. ``Rather than just saying one phrase from a song at the dinner table and we all laugh about it, I sit down and do a whole song.'' His latest effort - ``The Night Before Astro'' - was beamed up to the astronauts on Columbia during a science briefing late Saturday night. The poem is filled with acronyms decipherable only by space-savvy types. A sample: ``In the POCC back in Huntsville we sat and we waited ``Although more than one veteran's mood was quite jaded. ``The countdown went smoothly, the APUs worked. ``The SRBs fired, it lurched and it jerked. ``It cleared the launch tower, we hooted and whistled. ``And away they all flew on the back of that missile.'' Blair said he came up with the idea for the holiday poem after he arrived at Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville, Ala., just prior to last week's launch. Marshall houses the Payload Operations Control Center - POCC, pronounced pock. ``I was working the night shift, and little phrases of it kept going through my head, usually at two in the afternoon when I was supposed to be asleep,'' Blair said. ``I just got inspired enough to finish it.'' Blair said he wanted to include personal notes about the astronauts in the poem, ``but I just ran out of gas.'' Blair currently is altering the lyrics of ``Deck the Halls.'' ``I keep trying to stop. I should be sleeping, not doing this on my off-shift time,'' he said early Sunday evening before reporting to work. ``I'm working on `Deck the halls with plots of data.' I haven't gotten the rest of it yet, but I'm working on it. We're delighted to be getting some data, believe me. It's taken a long time.''

DOC.HEAD: Actress Joan Bennett Dead At 80
DOC.TEXT: Actress Joan Bennett, who played opposite Katharine Hepburn in ``Little Women'' and was Elizabeth Taylor's mother in ``Father of the Bride,'' has died at age 80. Miss Bennett died Friday night at White Plains Hospital after suffering a heart attack at her home in Scarsdale north of New York City, said her husband, David Wilde. ``I don't think much of most of the films I made,'' she said in 1986. ``But being a movie star was something I liked very much.'' Among her 75 film credits are the 1933 classic ``Little Women,'' in which she played one of the sisters, as did Miss Hepburn. In Vincente Minnelli's 1950 comedy ``Father of the Bride,'' Miss Bennett played a nurturing mother, shedding the husky-voiced presence she had developed for Fritz Lang's thriller films. Miss Bennett's film credits also include ``For Heaven's Sake,'' and ``Desire in the Dust.'' In 1951, she was the protagonist in a Hollywood scandal when her then-husband, producer Walter Wanger, shot and wounded her agent, Jennings Lang, in a Los Angeles parking lot. Wanger suspected Lang of having an affair with Miss Bennett. The actress, born in Fort Lee, N.J., made her 1928 debut in the Broadway play ``Jarnegan.'' Miss Bennett appeared on stage in ``Stage Door,'' ``Pleasure of His Company,'' ``Fallen Angels'' and ``Butterflies are Free.'' In 1978, she acted in the TV movie ``Suddenly Love,'' followed by ``A House Possessed'' in 1980 and ``Divorce Wars'' in 1981. She also played Elizabeth Collins in the gothic soap opera ``Dark Shadows.'' The serial, which ran from 1966 to 1971, attracted a cult following and gave her a new generation of fans. Miss Bennett was first married when she was 16 and had four husbands. In addition to Wilde, she is survived by four daughters, Shelley Wanger and Stephanie Guest, both of New York City; Diana Anderson of Los Angeles; and Melinda Bena of Chappaqua, N.Y. She will be cremated and buried in Old Lyme, Conn., Wilde said.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Accepts Nobel Peace Prize In Absentia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: The other prizes are to be awarded later today in Stockholm. The first announcement is scheduled for about 11 a.m. EST.
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev accepted the 1990 Nobel Peace Prize in absentia today. He said problems in his homeland prevented him from coming to the awards ceremony. ``I do not regard the the 1990 Nobel Peace Prize as an award to me personally, but as a recognition of what we call perestroika and innovative political thinking, which is of vital significance for human destinies all over the world,'' Gorbachev said in a message from Moscow. In an acceptance speech read by his envoy, Anatoly Kovalyov, Gorbachev promised to continue the process of openness and reform. Kovalyov said the prize's $715,000 cash award probably would be donated to worthy causes. Nobel prizes in physics, chemistry, literature, medicine and economics were to be awarded later today in Stockholm, Sweden. The Norwegian Nobel Committee said the 71st Peace Prize recognized Gorbachev's international efforts, more than his domestic policies. But committee leader Gidske Anderson said at the Oslo City Hall ceremony that she hoped the award would be seen as ``a helping hand in an hour of need'' as Gorbachev and the Soviet people cope with the restructing of their economy and government. ``This transformation is inevitably a painful porcess, involving great sacrifice,'' she said. Norway's royalty, government leaders and roughly 900 guests applauded as Anderson presented the Peace Prize medal and diploma to Gorbachev's stand-in. Gorbachev had hoped to attend the ceremony in person, but last month said problems at home required his attention ``hour by hour.'' Demonstrators in Moscow protested the award Sunday and today, blaming Gorbachev for ethnic and political violence in his own country. Gorbachev, quoting the 18th Century German philospher Immanuel Kant, said in his acceptance speech: ``Kant prophesized that mankind would one day be faced with a dilemma: either to be joined in a true union of nations or to perish in a war of annihilation ending in the extinction of the human race. ``Now, as we move from the second to the third millennium, the clock has struck the moment of truth,'' Gorbachev wrote. The year 1990 represents a turning point, he said. ``It marks the end of the unnatural division of Europe. Germany has been reunited. We have begun to resolutely tear down the material foundations of a military, political and ideological confrontation.'' An unofficial translation of Gorbachev's two-page statement said the Peace Prize recognized that perestroika and reform no longer belong to Soviets alone. ``They are the property of the whole of mankind and are an inseparable part of its destiny, and of a safe, peaceful future,'' the text said. Gorbachev thanked Norway, and the West, for supporting the Soviet Union's struggle to adopt greater openness and freer markets - a struggle that has unleashed anger, protests and frustation in his own country due to shortages of food and products. But Anderson said the 1990 award very much reflected the wishes of Alfred Nobel, the Swedish inventor of dynamite who endowed the Nobel prizes in his 1896 will. ``Nobel wanted the prize to be awarded to someone who had worked to promote `fraternity between nations' ... to someone who actively promoted a reduction in `standing armies' and worked for the `holding of peace congresses,''' she said in her prepared remarks. Gorbachev is the the third eastern European who has not received his prize in person since 1975. ``The award this year ... is an historic event not least because of some of the previous awards made by our committee,'' Anderson said. She said the 1975 award to Soviet human rights champion Andrei Sakharov and the 1983 award to Poland's Lech Walesa were greeted ``with cool hostility in the Soviet Union and Poland.'' Neither laurate was able to attend the ceremony, and their governments rejected everything the committee stood for, she said. Now the Soviet president has accepted the same award.

DOC.HEAD: Americans Headed Home
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines a0503, a0485. Minor editing for transition. Adds Folsom's hometown, age, in 9th graf.
DOC.TEXT: More than 150 Americans, some looking gaunt and weary after more than four months as hostages in Iraq and Kuwait, flew to the United States today aboard a chartered jetliner. Four Canadians and 152 Americans left Frankfurt on a Pan Am plane headed for Andrews Air Force Base near Washington, U.S. consular officials said. Hamburgers and champagne were among the provisions on the jet. The flight left Frankfurt at 2:26 p.m. About 13 hours earlier, an Iraqi Airways airliner delivered the former captives, about two dozen other Americans and 101 Britons to Frankfurt airport. Some of the Americans who arrived in Germany from Iraq after midnight Sunday were to return to the United States on later flights. The former hostages said they had a scare as the 747 descended into Frankfurt from Baghdad. The plane began to shudder as it approached the runway, and the landing was aborted. No explanation was given, but the second landing attempt was uneventful. After a few hours sleep, the Americans - some of whom lost up to 40 pounds during their captivity - awoke to a huge breakfast of ham and eggs, bacon, corn flakes and hash browns. ``I wallowed in the ham,'' said former ``human shield'' Chris Folsom, 51, of Doylestown, Pa. Two of the men who had been hiding in Kuwait planned to fly directly home to Albuquerque, N.M., to bypass the hostage homecoming as a protest against the administration's handling of their release, a relative said. Ruth Kho said her father, Eugene Hughes, and his stepson Donald Latham ``have some hard feelings toward the United States government.'' ``The Voice of America didn't broadcast that they could come out of hiding,'' she said. As a result the men took a chance in coming to the airport in Kuwait City, where they were forced to wait in the desert for eight hours before being flown out Sunday, she said. Iraq's parliament on Friday approved a decree by President Saddam Hussein to release the estimated 8,000 American, European and Japanese citizens who had been forbidden from leaving Kuwait and Iraq. U.S. officials said they planned to charter another flight from Baghdad in three or four days to evacuate the rest of the estimated 750 Americans in Iraq and Kuwait. The flight to Frankfurt included about 80 Americans who had been stranded in Kuwait for more than four months following the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion. They told of hiding in crawl spaces with little to eat, of an underground resistance that helped foreigners, and of brutal treatment meted out to Kuwaitis by the occupying army. ``Kuwait City no longer exists. It's dead,'' said Latham, 51, an engineer. Latham, who lived in Kuwait City for five years, said his 70-year-old stepfather had come to visit him two days before the Iraqi invasion. ``We've been in hiding ever since. We've been working with the Kuwaiti resistance,'' he said. He said there is an organized underground called ``The Guardians,'' who set up a food distribution network and a system to help underground foreigners. ``They are not so much concerned with killing Iraqis as with taking care of the people,'' Latham said. Thomas Kreuzman, 38, of Holiday, Fla., said he spent 23 days hiding in an air-conditioning duct with his dog. They lived on dry spaghetti and sneaked out at night for water, he said. Randal Warren, 49, a construction worker from Charleston, Mo., described hiding out on the top floor of an apartment house, keeping the curtains closed the entire time and wearing no shoes to hold down the noise. A Palestinian and a Turkish friend brought supplies about every two weeks, Warren said. ``This is the first time I have had shoes on in over three months.'' The freed hostages also included so-called ``human shields'' who had been kept at strategic locations in Iraq. Robert Vinton, of Santa Fe, N.M. said he was held south of Baghdad at an oil refinery. He said he was picked up Aug. 18 on a Baghdad street. ``It was like a gulag,'' the 58-year-old Vinton said. He was held with up to eight other foreigners at a time, he said, though he added: ``We were mostly left alone.'' Joseph Lammerding, 35, of Sacramento, Calif., said that after visiting his parents he plans to return to the gulf to help push the Iraqis out of Kuwait. Lammerding, who spent four months in hiding in Kuwait, said the Iraqis brutally retaliated against Kuwaitis who were trying to offer resistance and protect foreigners. ``Sometimes they would shoot one member of a family. Sometimes the entire family. They raped and plundered, literally,'' said Lammerding, who described himself as an adviser to the Kuwaiti military who had lived in the emirate since 1983. But the hostage crisis wasn't hell for everyone. David Dorrington, 43, said he spent most of the crisis hidden with five other Britons in a villa in Kuwait. ``Our basic living conditions were embarrassingly rather good. We had very good help from our Filipino maid who supplied us with everything and was absolutely magic,'' he said. But three weeks ago, Dorrington said, he was arrested and taken to Baghdad. A Dutchman who flew to Rome early today said he was not mistreated, although he was unable to leave Baghdad. Unlike many American and British hostages, the Dutch weren't forced to serve as ``human shields.'' ``Circumstances in Baghdad were fairly normal ... We were able to go shopping, get food and move around freely,'' Mario Punte said in Amsterdam, where he arrived from Rome.

DOC.HEAD: Capital Quiet After Police Used Clubs to Disperse Protesters
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with diplomats' description of the clash, capital reported quiet today. Changes byline. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Club-wielding police fought student demonstrators the Albanian capital who staged a rare show of public defiance against the Communist government, but diplomats said there were no new clashes today. A diplomat reached by telephone in Tirana said there were injuries and arrests in Sunday's clash, but he did not know how many. The diplomat said without citing a source that more demonstrations had been planned for today, but by noon there were no street gatherings, nor any sign of an increased police presence. Talks between students and the government, reportedly opened after Sunday's protest, may have eased the tensions. First word of the clash in Tirana came in an unusually frank dispatch from the government-controlled news agency ATA. It appeared to be the first instance in which ATA was the first to report a confrontation between police and demonstrators in the isolationist Balkan country. The agency even indicated, without providing specifics, that the students who took to the streets were critical of Communist authorities. It said the students were angry about a power outage that left their dormitories without heat and light, and that demonstrators had tried to exploit dissatisfaction over the lack of heat for ``political ends.'' The students ``provoked the order forces and acted contrary to the law,'' the agency reported. ``Security forces were forced to interfere in order to disperse them.'' ATA said negotiations subsequently began between student representatives and the minister of education, and that a government commission was being formed to adopt ``measures to stabilize the situation'' and address the students' demands. The four-paragraph ATA dispatch did not say how many students or police were involved, did not elaborate on what demands the protesters had and contained no other substantive details. One diplomat said ``a great many students'' took part in the demonstration near the university but a ``strong'' police force encircled the area, then attacked the protesters with clubs. ``There certainly were injuries because fights occurred when the police attacked the students,'' the diplomat said. Diplomats reported no sign of any special police or military state of alert in Tirana today. ``Here on our street, where there are several embassies, we are holding normal consular hours with people coming to see us,'' one diplomat said. ``The usual guards have not been increased.'' The diplomats all spoke on condition of anonymity. The fact that the incident was reported by the official news agency was in line with recent moves to slowly open Albania to the outside world and ease controls on the country's 3.2 million citizens. Albanian leaders have, however, rejected multiparty democracy of the kind that has replaced orthodox Marxist rule in other East European countries. In preparation for elections next year, the Communist-controlled Parliament last month approved a law that would allow independent candidates to run in secret-ballot elections. However, the law guarantees that only candidates who are not overt anti-Communists can run. Strict control of the economy is being loosened and limited, and some private enterprise is now encouraged. The government also has eased regulations that had prevented all but a few Albanians from going abroad.

DOC.HEAD: Havel Asks For Broader, Temporary Powers to Save Country
DOC.TEXT: President Vaclav Havel asked Parliament today for broader, temporary powers to keep the country from breaking apart. In an emergency speech, he said Czechoslovakia's future is being threatened by a dispute over a division of powers between the federal government, the Czech republic and the Slovak republic, where nationalism has risen rapidly. ``I am very sorry I had to go this far,'' the playwright-turned-president said in the nationally televised speech. ``I am doing this to fulfill the expectations of millions of citizens who ... entrusted this position to me and believe I will help save our federation.'' ``Our state is not this time threatened from the outside, as so many times in the past, but from the inside,'' he said. ``We are threatening it ourselves with ou low political culture, lack of democratic consciousness and mututal understanding ... our lack of experience and personal bad qualities.'' Havel did not immediately say what powers he wants. He said they would be included in a bill to be presented soon to Parliament, and he urged that it be considered immediately. He said the powers would be in effect until a new constitution is adopted, sometime within the next 18 months. Havel also proposed that Parliament immediately set up a constitutional court and pass a law permitting national referenda as last resorts to settle political disputes. Under Czechoslovakia's current constitution, Havel is empowered to sign treaties, command the armed forces, appoint the federal government, summon and dissolve parliament, sign its laws, grant amnesties or other legal pardons and declare war. He is also allowed to assume extra powers granted by special law. Havel has been content for much of his nearly one year as president to be a moral force in politics. But his tough speech today before Parliament indicated that separatist threats from the Slovak republic had forced him to act. He singled out the premier of the Slovak republic, Vladimir Meciar, for criticism. Slovak leaders have been quoted as saying that if the federal parliament insists on amending a draft agreement dividing powers among the federal government and the republics, they will declare the sovereignty of Slovak law on their territory. Parliament plans Tuesday to debate a law dividing powers among the federal government and the two republics. The Czech and Slovak parliaments differ over control of oil and gas pipelines, taxation and budget questions, postal services, control over policy toward ethnic minorities, and chairmanship of the national bank. Havel said a declaration of Slovak sovereignty was clearly unconstitutional, and said that whatever decision Parliament makes is legally binding ``on all institutions and all people.'' Otherwise, ``the thin ice of our constitution will be broken and our state would inevitably fall into legal chaos,'' he said. He warned that if Czechoslovakia, formed from two parts of the former Austro-Hungarian Empire in 1918, broke in two, neither part could guarantee the inviolability of its borders, and chances for economic reform would end. Western leaders repeatedly have warned Czechoslovakia that its internal instability is one of the greatest threats to aid and investment. Czechoslovakia needs large amounts of both to throw off the vestiges of four decades of communism. Government economic policy calls for rapid privatization of the state-run economy, beginning next year.

DOC.HEAD: Socialists Lead Serbian Vote; Opposition Cries Fraud
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE with early official returns, Tanjug report; Picks up 7th graf, `A runoff ...'; SUBS 14th graf, `...' to conform.
DOC.TEXT: The former Communists and their hard-line President Slobodan Milosevic led in early election returns today in Serbia. Opposition leaders accused them of widespread vote-rigging. First official results from just five of the republic's 250 voting districts showed Milosevic with more than 66 percent of the overall vote for president. His main challenger, populist Vuk Draskovic, had about 19 percent. Socialists also led the opposition for parliament in the five districts, said Caslav Ignjatovic, chairman of the republic's electoral commission. He estimated turnout at 80 percent. Officials of the opposition Democratic Party said no firm results were known in Sunday's elections, Serbia's first free multiparty elections since 1938. But they reported indications from around Yugoslavia's largest republic gave an expected lead to Milosevic and his Socialists, the renamed Communists. The state news agency Tanjug said the Socialists had won nearly 80 of Parliament's 250 seats, according to its unofficial survey of 140 districts. A victory for Milosevic and his party is thought likely to deepen Yugoslavia's regional strife, which threatens to break the country apart. A runoff vote will be held Dec. 23 for the presidency or any of the 250 Serbian Parliament seats in which no single candidate wins 50 percent. Republic-wide elections were also held Sunday in Montenegro, where Communists took an early lead, according to unofficial returns reported by the official news agency Tanjug. Tanjug said the Communist candidate for Montenegro's presidency, Momir Bulatovic, appeared likely to win without having to face a runoff. The Marxist leaders of Serbia and Montenegro are pitted against the Western-leaning republics of Slovenia and Croatia in the Yugoslav power struggle. At stake is whether the volatile Balkan country stays together as a federal republic, dissolves into a confederacy or collapses with member states becoming completely independent. Center-right coalitions ousted the Communists in Slovenia and Croatia in regional elections earlier this year, and advocate greater democracy and implementation of market-based economic reform on the federal level. Milosevic, the charismatic Soclialist leader of Serbia, has refused to acknowledge the possibility of a federal break-up or to negotiate with the western republics. Draskovic, of the Serbian Renewal Movement, has said he would negotiate with Croatia and Slovenia. The voting was marred by charges of ballot-rigging and widespread irregularities at the Serbian republic's 9,500 polling stations. Electoral Commission Chairman Caslav Ignjatovic said he was investigating the claims. Draskovic said the Socialists distributed campaign leaflets at polling stations Sunday and that pro-government media also ignored a ban on campaigning that was to have extended two days before the election. Opposition leaders also claimed the Socialists stopped registering deaths in Serbia in April in a plan to rig the election using phantom votes. ``Communists ... are capable of doing anything to stay in power,'' Draskovic said. Both Draskovic and Milosevic stressed their support for tight Serbian control over the formerly autonomous province of Kosovo, in the southern area of Serbia. The ethnic Albanian majority in Kosovo boycotted Sunday's elections to protest the Serbian government's decision over the summer to strip them of self-rule and close Albanian newspapers. The divisions among Serbians, Croats and Slovenes, as well as the Kosovo-Serbia conflict, reflect the Babel of ethnic and political forces vying for power in Yugoslavia. The Central Intelligence Agency predicted recently that the country could be torn apart within 18 months.

DOC.HEAD: Tass Denies Rumors That Gorbachev Will Quit Party Post
DOC.TEXT: Rumors that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev will step down as Communist Party chief are ``totally unfounded,'' the state-run news agency Tass said today. Gorbachev opened a plenary session of the party's Central Committee in the Kremlin, convened to discuss the party's position on a draft Union Treaty and tasks of party organizations, Tass said. ``Although the Communist Party has become an opposition party in many republics after the last elections, it remains the only truly national political force,'' Tass said. ``This gives Gorbachev a chance to preserve the union and at the same time to give new meaning to `sovereignty of union republics,''' the news agency said. ``Therefore, rumors that Gorbachev may resign as party leader at this plenary meeting are totally unfounded.'' Tass did not say where the rumors came from. The rumors echoed previous speculation that Gorbachev would eventually step down as party chief, continuing to wield power in his strengthened job as president. Gorbachev has been attempting to transfer to the government much of the Communist Party's once all-powerful control over the country. Tass said the Central Committee would discuss the new Union Treaty draft and preparations for the nation's fourth Congress of People's Deputies, scheduled to open Dec. 17. According to the Tass report, the Central Committee might make changes in the Politburo following changes in the party leadership at the republican level in Byelorussia and Georgia. ``Despite a change in the balance of political forces in the country, much depends on the result's of today's plenum,'' Tass said. The Union Treaty under discussion by the Central Committee defines the relationship between the Kremlin and the 15 Soviet republics. The proposed treaty, Gorbachev's plan for saving the union from collapse, has also been sent to the legislatures of the Soviet Union and the republics for approval. However, six republics have already said they will not sign the document, which would give them virtual control over all affairs except defense. The draft treaty represents the central government's attempt to preserve the union and appease secession movments by the republics and smaller regions while creating a uniform, market-oriented economic system. The Central Committee meeting was closed to the public and reporters.

DOC.HEAD: Excerpts from Gorbachev's Peace Prize Acceptance Speech
With PM-Nobel Prizes
DOC.TEXT: Here is a partial text of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's speech accepting the 1990 Nobel Peace Prize on Monday. The English translation was supplied by the Nobel Committee: ... The prize has been awarded since the beginning of this century. The disasters and tragedies of this period, which have not managed to subdue man's optimism and unflagging belief in human reason, have given the Peace Prize the unique aura associated with it today. Immanuel ant prophesied that mankind would one day be faced with a dilemma: either to be joined in a true union of nations or to perish in a war of annihilation ending in the extinction of the human race. Now, as we move from the second to the third millennium, the clock has struck the moment of truth. In this respect the year 1990 represents a turning point. It marks the end of the unnatural division of Europe. Germany has been reunited. We have begun resolutely to tear down the material foundations of a military, political and ideological confrontation. But there are some very grave threats that have not been eliminated: the potential for conflict and the primitive instincts that allow it, aggressive intentions and totalitarian traditions. I would like to assure you that the leadership of the U.S.S.R. is doing and will continue to do everything in its power to ensure that future developments in Europe and the world as a whole are based on openness, mutual trust, international law and universal values. The recent meeting in Paris of heads of state and government from the European nations, the United States and Canada, embodying all the best elements in international movements such as the Helsinki Process, has established the framework for a Europe based on the rule of law, stability, good relations between neighboring countries and humane attitudes. It is my hope that such a Europe will be understood and accepted by nations and governments in other parts of the world as an example of universal security and genuine cooperation. ... The Nobel Peace Prize for 1990 confirms that perestroika and innovative political thinking no longer belong only to us, the people of the Soviet Union. They are the property of the whole of mankind and are an inseparable part of its destiny and of a safe and peaceful future. We are deeply grateful to Norway and other members of the international community who have shown such understanding and who, through their conduct in international issues and in their relations with the Soviet Union, have shown their solidarity as we proceed with our perestroika and their sympathy as we struggle to resolve our problems. If we all took this as our point of departure, mankind would have no cause to regret the loss of a unique opportunity for reason and the logic of peace to prevail over that of war and alienation. ...

DOC.HEAD: Noisy, But Peaceful Protest At St. Patrick's Cathedral
