DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of demonstrators opposed to the Roman Catholic Church's stand on abortion and AIDS education protested outside St. Patrick's Cathedral, but obeyed a court order not to disrupt Mass. Sunday's rowdy but peaceful demonstration came a year after the pandemonium in which 113 activists were arrested. On Dec. 10, 1989, about 4,500 protesters gathered to dispute the church's teachings. Forty-three were arrested for chanting, lying down and chaining themselves to pews during the service. Seventy more were arrested outside. This time, four people were arrested - six blocks from the cathedral - when the throng sat briefly in the street on Fifth Avenue, blocking traffic. Some 25 members of the AIDS Coalition to Unleash Power and Women's Health Action and Mobilization walked out of the cathedral during Cardinal John O'Connor's homily, but services were not disrupted, said police Sgt. Robert Ahearn. Outside the church, about 350 protesters marched in a half-block-long circle for two hours, shrieking, blowing whistles, pounding tambourines and drums, and chanting, ``Teach safe sex. Just say no is not enough.'' O'Connor said from the pulpit that he should be allowed to exercise his right to disseminate church teachings. Afterward, he asked worshipers to ``react with love'' to any demonstrators they encountered outside, said spokesman Joe Zwilling. The Archdiocese of New York was prepared for the anniversary of last year's disturbance. On Friday, it got a court order allowing protesters to pray inside the church, but not to disrupt services. About 450 police officers were deployed, some wearing riot gear. The church, which holds 2,800 people, was closed after the Mass began. The two groups say O'Connor and the Catholic Church are obstructing the dissemination of safe sex information and advocating ``atred and violence'' against homosexuals and abortion rights supporters. ``Lives are at stake,'' said a lawyer for the AIDS group, William Dobbs. ``There are people who are sick today because of the cardinal's policies.'' The U.S. Catholic bishops have said the public distribution of condoms could lead to promiscuous sexual behavior, and that abstinence outside of marriage is the ``only morally correct and medically sure way'' to prevent AIDS. Assistant Police Chief Thomas Walsh called the protest ``very peaceful, very nice.'' ``They have the right to do what they want, as long as they behave like perfect ladies and gentlemen - and they did,'' said worshiper Mary Hayhurst of Dracut, Mass. Six of last year's demonstrators were convicted last month of criminal trespass, disorderly conduct, resisting arrest and other offenses. They will be sentenced in January.

DOC.HEAD: Metropolitan Opera Singer Dies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Quin in penultimate graf is cq
DOC.TEXT: John Alexander, a former Metropolitan Opera tenor and professor of music at the University of Cincinnati, died after a performance in his hometown of Meridian, Miss. He was 67. Alexander suffered a heart attack Saturday shortly after finishing a performance of ``Nessum Dorma'' from ``Turandot.'' He died later Saturday at Anderson Hospital in Meridian. He had been in Meridian, the city where he was born, for a gala benefit for the restoration of the community's 100-year-old opera house. ``Everyone here is amazed at the poetic-ness of his death,'' said his son-in-law, David Staples of Chicago. ``He was doing a major performance for the first time in three years. He was with his friends from the world of opera and was back in Mississippi, which he loved and where he always wanted to be buried, in his family's plot.'' Alexander began his career in Cincinnati as a student at the old Cincinnati Conservatory of Music. His debut was the lead in ``Faust'' at the Cincinnati Summer Opera at the Zoo in 1950. He had a long career at the New York City Opera and the Metropolitan Opera, where he sang for 25 years. He was known for his Moaart roles, including Belmonte in ``The Abduction from the Seraglio'' and Ferrando in ``Cosi Fan Tutte.'' He was acclaimed at both New York houses as Bacchus is Strauss's ``Ariadne auf Naxos.'' Alexander had two heart bypass operations in the 1970s, but continued to perform at the Metropolitan until 1987. He still taught opera and voice at the conservatory, now part of the University of Cincinnati, and gave occasional performances. He lived with his wife, Sue, in suburban Cincinnati. ``He was always interested in young people,'' Mrs. Alexander said. ``He was an unselfish, outgoing and loving person, and always the tenor.'' Italo Tajo, retired chairman of the conservatory's opera department, said Alexander's death will be a loss to the music world. ``He was a great asset to any theater because he was always ready for anything,'' Tajo said. Alexander had sung leading roles in more than 50 operas. He was on the board of trustees of the Cincinnati Opera Company. In addition to his wife, survivors include a daughter, Cindy Staples of Chicago; a sister, Ann Quin of Jackson, Miss.; and two grandchildren. Funeral services are scheduled Tuesday in Meridian.

DOC.HEAD: Court Refuses to Postpone Los Angeles Election
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today refused to postpone a Jan. 22 election under a redistricting plan designed to help elect an Hispanic to the Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors for the first time in 115 years. The court rejected an emergency request by board members, who said the plan ordered by a federal judge is unlawful. The justices, oowever, took no action on a formal appeal by board members still pending before the high court. The five-member board, controlled by conservatives, was accused by Hispanics in 1988 of violating their rights by drawing districts after the 1980 census that allegedly diluted Hispanic voting strength. The lawsuit against the board said the district lines violated constitutional rights assuring equal protection for all and a 1982 federal voting rights law. The law forbids not only intentional discrimination but also any practice that has the effect of weakening the voting strength of minorities. U.S. District Judge David V. Kenyon declared the former district plan unconstitutional. He carved out a new district in which Hispanics account for an estimated 51 percent of the registered voters and 71 percent of the population. Kenyon ruled that when the board redrew districts after the 1980 census, members fragmented the Hispanic vote in an effort to help their own re-election chances. The number of Hispanics living in what constitutes the district created by Kenyon has increased dramatically in the last decade. The board member now representing the new district is retiring. The county has a population of about 8.5 million people, and the board of supervisors has considerable power over such matters as planning and development. The Bush administration sided with Hispanic rights groups in urging the Supreme Court not to disturb Kenyon's ruling, which was upheld last month by the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. The cases are Los Angeles County vs. Garza, 90-849, A-422.

DOC.HEAD: Court Asks Administration Views on Civil War Era Law
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today asked the Bush administration for its views on whether a Civil War era law enacted primarily to protect freed slaves bans racially discriminatory firings. The justices said they want to hear from Justice Department lawyers about a ruling that the manufacturer of Buster Brown shoes was guilty of illegal racial bias when it fired a white supervisor at a Missouri warehouse. The court is not expected to say whether it will review the case until hearing from the government lawyers, which could take months. Kenneth Hicks worked for the Brown Shoe Company for 34 years. His assignment when fired in 1982 had been as evening shift foreman at a warehouse in Benton, Mo. The company, in trimming its workforce, dismissed Hicks while keeping another supervisor, Alvin Chester, who is black. Hicks said he was fired because of his race, even though he had more seniority than Chester. Hicks testified that when he asked a boss at the warehouse if race was behind the firing, the boss smirked and said, ``You said that, not me.'' Hicks also cited evidence that the company had an affirmative action plan aimed at promoting more blacks to supervisory jobs. Company officials said they chose to retain Chester because he had more experience and was better qualified for the specific job both men were doing. A federal jury ordered the company to pay Hicks $10,000 in punitive damages, and the 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in April awarded him nearly $21,000 more in attorney fees and other legal costs. The appeals court said a civil rights law enacted in 1866 forbids racially discriminatory firings. The law was the focus of a highly publicized Supreme Court ruling in 1989. The justices said the law does not ban on-the-job racial harassment. But they upheld a 1976 ruling that the law does permit lawsuits against private individuals or companies accused of bias in the making and enforcing of contracts. Left unanswered was whether the law specifically applies to racially biased firings. The 8th Circuit court said last year's high court ruling is unclear, adding, ``We simply decline ... to overrule the clear and undisputed precedent of this circuit.'' The appeals court, with jurisdiction in seven Midwestern states, said firing ``is fundamentally different from racial harassment or discrimination in the terms or conditions of employment. Discriminatory discharge goes to the very existence and nature of the employment contract.'' The states in the 8th Circuit are Arkansas, Iowa, Minnesota, Missouri, Nebraska, North Dakota and South Dakota. The case is Brown Group Inc. vs. Hicks, 90-324.

DOC.HEAD: Bethlehem Under Curfew, Soldier Buried
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTs 4th graf to say it is two weeks before Christmas, sted three.
DOC.TEXT: Israeli soldiers enforced a rare curfew in Bethlehem today, and the town's Palestinian mayor condemned a bombing that killed an Israeli soldier and wounded two others the day before. Elsewhere in the occupied lands, scattered clashes broke out today between soldiers and stone-throwing youths and at least 12 Palestinians were wounded by army gunfire, including a 14-year-old boy who was shot in the head, Arab reports said. The army said it was checking the reports. Two weeks before Christmas, the West Bank town of Bethlehem, the site of Christ's birth, looked like a virtual ghost town as soldiers manned roadblocks, closed stores and ordered all Palestinians indoors, Arab reports said. In the port city of Haifa, comrades and relatives buried paratrooper Guy Friedman, 19, the soldier killed in Sunday's pipe-bomb explosion on the Jerusalem-Bethlehem highway. No one claimed responsibility for the attack. In Bethlehem, photographers said about half a dozen tourist buses, incluing one with a group from Denver, arrived under military escort and visited the Church of Nativity, built at the spot where tradition says Christ was born. The army imposed the curfew in Bethlehem Sunday. Arab reporters said the curfew was the first in Bethlehem since Nov. 15, 1988, when there was an army clampdown in all the occupied lands to prevent celebrations and demonstrations when the Palestine Liberation Organization in Algiers declared national independence. Most refugee camps in the West Bank remained under curfew today, but the army lifted curfews elsewhere in the occupied territories. The curfews were imposed Thursday to prevent violence over the weekend, marking the third anniversary of the uprising against Israeli occupation of lands seized in the 1967 Middle East war. Bethlehem Mayor Elias Freij condemned Sunday's violence. ``What is depressing and increasing tension is the absence of any prospect of peaceful dialogue,'' he said. After the bombing, angry residents of the Jewish settlement of Beit Haggai in the West Bank blocked a main road calling for harsher army action against Palestinian activists, army radio said. Settler leader Aharon Dom said the bombing should prompt the government to deport Palestinian leaders. ``The Arabs must know that every additional cycle of terror will bring them to being uprooted from this land. And this uprooting means that there will be no return,'' Dom told army radio. Army Chief of Staff Lt. Gen. Dan Shomron visited the site of the bombing and said it did not constitute a shift to a more violent phase of the Palestinian uprising. ``But if we are also looking at the background of radicalization here in the field, in the context of what is happening in the world - including the (Persian) Gulf - we cannot but take into consideration the possibility of a change,'' he told Israel radio.

DOC.HEAD: Prime Minister Revamping Cabinet
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Chatichai Choonhavan has pledged to form a new government that excludes a minister blamed for the rift between his administration and the army, news reports said today. Chatichai was renamed prime minister Sunday, less than 24 hours after resigning in an apparent maneuver to revamp his Cabinet, which had been strongly criticized by the military. The military had insisted he dismiss several democratically installed Cabinet members and it made unspecified threats. Chatichai resigned knowing his reinstatement was likely and would let him refashion the Cabinet. Government spokesman Suvit Yodmani said Chatichai was discussing the new Cabinet with members of his coalition and it might be two days before it is announced. The Nation newspaper quoted Chatichai as saying his new government would not include Deputy Minister of Education Chalerm Yumbamrung, who has clashed with military chiefs several times this year. ``There is nothing to worry about. The military will be satisfied with the new government,'' he was quoted as saying. Chatichai last reshuffled his Cabinet in November and broke a promise he had made to the military to drop Chalerm then. Chalerm was demoted to the education ministry slot but remained in the Cabinet. The military has in recent years voiced support for Thailand's fledgling democracy after decades of intervention. But it has tried to maintain a position as watchdog over state and society and its leaders have frequently made political pronouncements.

DOC.HEAD: Southwestern Bell Among Buyers of Mexican Phone Monopoly
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS name to Southwestern Bell in 1st graf and in 11th graf, beginning ``Southwestern Bell....
DOC.TEXT: An international group that includes St. Louis-based Southwestern Bell has won a controlling interest in Mexico's telephone monopoly, one of the largest concerns being sold in a privatization drive. The Finance Ministry on Sunday announced the winning $1.76 billion bid of the consortium, which is led by Mexico's Grupo Carso and also includes France Cable & Radio. The group will get 20.4 percent of the company, which is trying to modernize and expand an aging system that now serves 4.1 million customers in this rapidly growing country of some 84 million people. The government holds more than $4 billion worth of shares in Telmex, which is valued at roughly $8 billion. It plans to sell the remainder of its shares, most of them non-voting issues, on national and international stock markets. In separate agreements signed earlier Sunday, the government agreed to finance sale of 4.4 percent of the company to its workers over an eight-year period. By the end of this year, Mexico will have sold all but 25 of the 404 state companies it owned in 1982, the government-owned Notimex news agency reported Sunday. President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, who took office in late 1988, has pushed privatization ss a way to help draw foreign and expatriate local capital into the country to fuel modernization of industry. Grupo Carso is the lead partner under government insistence that the company remain under Mexican control. The stipulation meant to mollify nationalists with bitter memories of foreign exploitation in the past. Grupo Carso is led by Carlos Slim, an adviser to the president. The company owns store chains such as Aurrera and Superama, Vips restaurants and the famed Sanborns restaurant-luxury store chain, as well as interests in paper companies, hotels and a stock brokerage. Southwestern Bell, one of the regional companies spun off from American Telephone & Telegraph in 1984, has sales of more than $8.9 billion a year. The French partner is a unit of France Telecom, with sales of more than $20 billion yearly. Finance ministry officials said the sale was meant to ``radically improve'' phone service, expand the system, strengthen research and development efforts, guarantee the rights of the workers and to guarantee majority Mexican control. Telmex had already launched a three-year modernization program to help make it more attractive to buyers. In September, the company signed $300 million worth of contracts with a group led by American Telephone & Telegraph for a new optic-fiber cable network and terminals.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Says Iraq Hostage Release Shouldn't Raise Hopes for Peace
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; edits thruout to tighten; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Saddam Hussein's release of foreign hostages in Iraq and Kuwait should not raise hopes for a peaceful resolution of the Persian Gulf crisis, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said today. Cheney said the release of hostages was ``obviously very good news'' for the hostages and their families, but it did not mean Iraq is backing away from its armed occupation of Kuwait. ``The illegal, immoral, illicit act of Saddam Hussein in holding hundreds of American hostages against their will for several months appears to be coming to an end,'' Cheney said in remarks to a defense industry group. ``But I don't believe Saddam Hussein deserves any credit for stopping a practice that obviously is abhorrent to the civilized world. He has to rank as one of the world's all-time hostage-takers,'' Cheney said. Iraq has continued to send reinforcements to Kuwait and southern Iraq, Cheney said. ``In these past few days as he has released hostages he has simultaneously continued to build up his deployments in Kuwait, to enhance his fortifications and to add additional forces to the regions,'' Cheney said. ``He has given us absolutely no indication whatsoever of any intention'' of complying with U.N. resolutions requiring the Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait and the restoration of the Kuwaiti monarchy by Jan. 15. Cheney's remarks appeared aimed at counteracting any positive public reaction in the United States to the arrival home of hostages held in Iraq and Kuwait since the Aug. 2 invasion. Cheney's comments followed those of other top-level Bush administration officials who said the United States wants international controls over Iraq's nuclear weapons and other sophisticated arms once the current crisis is resolved. In spelling out the administration's reasons for committing a quarter of a million American troops to the gulf and threatening to use them against Iraq, Cheney particularly stressed the economic interests at stake. ``There is no naysaying the fact that one of the major concerns we have is the very real possibility that should Saddam Hussein succeed in his aggression, should he be allowed to keep Kuwait, that he would be in a position to directly control over 20 percent of the world's proven oil reserve,'' Cheney said. The defense secretary also said a longstanding U.S. commitment to preserving the independence of Saudi Arabia and other gulf states is ``at the heart of this.'' Secretary of State James A. Baker III and National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft spelled out the American vision of the Persian Gulf's military future Sunday. Baker said Kuwait's bargaining position would be aided by ``security arrangements'' aimed at bridling Iraq's superior military might and its ``weapons of mass destruction.'' ``That's not something we get to until after he withdraws,'' Baker said on ABC-TV's ``This Week With David Brinkley.''. Scowcroft, on NBC's ``Meet the Press,'' said, ``What we would want to see is his weapons of mass destruction programs or his nuclear, biological and chemical programs under strict international supervision, so that he cannot develop that kind of capability.'' They also demanded that Baker's anticipated meeting with Iraqi President Saddam Hussein be held by Jan. 3. The Iraqi leader has offered to meet Baker in Baghdad on Jan. 12 - three days before a United Nations deadline for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait or face eviction by military force. Iraq's U.N. ambassador, Abdul Amir Al-Anbari, would not rule out a Saddam-Baker session by Jan. 3. But he said that if fighting erupts, American losses in one day could surpass total U.S. casualties during the Vietnam war, when more than 55,000 Americans died. ``That means any war would make really that region of the world simply hell, and perhaps also the rest of the globe into a ... crisis which I don't know whether we will recover from it or not,'' Al-Anbari said on the NBC program. Baker said that when he meets with Saddam, he will not agree to an Iraqi withdrawal in exchange for giving Iraq a small, oil-producing region of Kuwait because ``to say anything else would be to reward an aggressor.'' But Baker said that if Iraq withdraws completely from Kuwait, the two neighbors could negotiate to settle remaining differences. Iraq is demanding a sea lane to the Persian Gulf and has accused Kuwait of plundering an oil field the two nations share along their common border. Al-Anbari said his country might accept a security arrangement that covered the entire Persian Gulf region. ``But if it is just against Iraq, singling out Iraq, it is just simply not acceptable,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Congratulates Walesa on Election
DOC.TEXT: President Bush has written a letter to Lech Walesa to congratulate him on his election as president of Poland, the White House said today. ``The president noted that this electoral process was an important afirmation of the strengthening of democracy and freedom in Poland,'' said presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. Fitzwater said Bush wrote the congratulatory letter on Sunday night. ``He congratulated Mr. Walesa on his leadership and courage, which has been displayed over many years. The president assured him that the United States stands by Poland and we'll do all we can to support this new democracy,'' Fitzwater said. The Solidarity leader was elected by a landslide in Poland's first popular presidential vote.

DOC.HEAD: Man Burns Self To Death, Criticizes U.S. Role in Mideast
DOC.TEXT: A man who doused himself with fuel and then set himself ablaze left fliers describing his suicide as a protest of U.S. policies in the Persian Gulf, authorities said. Timothy T. Brown, 48, a knife-sharpener who served his customers from his van, burned to death Sunday morning on the steps of a deserted cannery in this rural Delta community about 40 miles southeast of Sacramento. Investigators said Brown apparently splashed the liquid on himself, then stood or knelt over a pail filled with the fuel as he ignited it. His van, parked about 100 yards away, had a stack of one-page letters on the side window next to a sign that said, ``Take One.'' ``I, Tim Brown, Vietnam veteran, declare that my act of self-immolation is a direct protest of American war policy in the Middle East. America do not go to war. ... America, do not repeat the mistake of Vietnam.'' Brown also left copies of the letter on the windshields of neighbors' cars. Bob Brian, an investigator with the Sacramento County coroner's office, said Brown's fiery death ignited a blaze at the cannery that firefighters extinguished. Brian's office confirmed that Brown's death was a suicide. Brown was a familiar figure in the rustic Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta, a lush network of levees, rivers and sloughs and small towns about 50 miles east of San Francisco. His knife-sharpening business served restaurants and other customers on a regular route between San Francisco and the Delta. He lived on a houseboat, neighbors said, and had recently completed installing new plumbing, carpeting and a water heater. ``He just seemed like a regular kind of guy,'' said Jim Willis, owner of a liquor store patronized by Brown.

DOC.HEAD: Walesa Glides To Easy Victory, Promises Economic Renewal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with report that Tyminski will not be allowed to leave the country pending investigation of slander charges. Pick up 6th graf pvs, ```I am...'; edits thereafter to TRIM
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos GDA64, NY10,15
DOC.TEXT: Elected by a landslide in Poland's first popular presidential vote, Lech Walesa got right to work today on his pledge to build this young democracy into an economically sound ``pillar of peace.'' Walesa, who led the decade-long struggle that ended authoritarian Communist rule, acknowledged that ``terribly difficult tasks'' lie ahead as he attempts to complete the painful transition to a market-based economy. ``I want to work because there is a lot of work to be done,'' the former shipyard electrician told reporters at his Gdansk headquarters after defeating emigre businessman Stanislaw Tyminski in Sunday's runoff. Prosecutors today ordered that Tyminski be barred from leaving Poland while an investigation continues into allegations he slandered the government during his campaign, state television reported. Tyminski was ordered last week to appear this month for questioning before a prosecutor in southern Poland. The general prosecutor in Warsaw said steps must be taken to assure he will answer the summons, the television report said. A slander case was opened against Tyminski, who has Canadian and Peruvian as well as Polish citizenships, after he said last month that Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki betrayed the nation by causing hardship and chaos with his economic reforms. He accused the prime minister of economic ``treason.'' Meanwhile, Parliament Speaker Mikolaj Kozakiewicz said today that Walesa's swearing-in before the National Assembly will take place about Dec. 21. The date depends on when the Supreme Court completes its review of the election. The president-elect went to work today in a new government car with three police vehicles in escort. Later, he made a sentimental pilgrimage to the former Lenin shipyard, his former workplace and birthplace of Solidarity. Walesa told workers he wouldn't forget that he once wore overalls. ``I am going to return here often,'' he said. The Solidarity chief's margin of victory was 74 percent to 25 percent for Tyminski, according to full unofficial results released today by the national election commission. It said Walesa received 10.6 million votes to 3.7 million votes for his opponent. Two bitter and divisive rounds of voting strained the nation, splintering the Solidarity movement a year after Poland ousted the Communists and embarked on the most ambitious economic reform plan in Eastern Europe. Walesa said he would decide by Wednesday which of seven possible candidates to select to succeed Mazowiecki. The former Walesa ally was eliminated by Tyminski in the Nov. 25 first round of presidential voting. In a taped address to the nation Sunday night, Walesa repeated his campaign theme of speeding up the dismantling of Communist-collectived industries and encouraging private enterprise. ``In Poland there is enough work for everyone. We must change and modernize much,'' he said. ``Europe will appreciate us for this. An economically developed Poland will be one of the pillars of peace and calm in Europe, whereas a poor Poland will meet a wall of disapproval at all borders.'' ``I hope to be a good sheriff - determined, strong and effective,'' Walesa told a news conference earlier. Some Mazowiecki supporters have accused the vocational school graduate of demagoguery and promising more than he could possibly deliver. Walesa sipped champagne for the TV cameras and gave an awkward but affectionate kiss to his wife Danuta at the insistence of photographers. Newspaper editor Adam Michnik, a Mazowiecki ally who has bitterly accused Walesa of demagogic tendencies, promised ``loyal'' opposition. Writing today in his paper, Gazeta Wyborcza, Michnik described Walesa as an ``outstanding politician'' who had to decide which course he would pursue as president: ``The rhetoric of promises, the principles of courtly rule, the philosophy of decrees and the `ax,' or realism, responsibility, respect for pluralism and the philosophy of the state of law?'' Turnout in Sunday's vote was about 53 percent, compared to about 60 percent in the first round. Tyminski's best showing was among rural voters - where he obtained about 35 percent. The challenger who returned to Poland in September after 21 years in Peru and Canada had promised prosperity in a month, finding support in people frustrated by economic hardship and rising unemployment. ``There are many people in Poland for whom it is really bad,'' Walesa said. ``We must ... make Poland such that those doubters quickly join us, because we need them.'' Tyminski declined to concede defeat immediately, saying voters had been intimidated by Walesa's camp. Journalists noticed no signs of irregularities. The feud between Walesa and Mazowiecki split the Solidarity movement, but after the first round of voting Walesa won the backing of the Roman Catholic Church and virtually all political and social organizations. For Walesa, 47, the presidency culminates an astonishing personal voyage: from the middle child of a dirt-poor peasant family to Belweder Palace, seat of Polish presidents. His union offices are just steps from the shipyard where Walesa leaped into history as the charismatic leader of nationwide strikes that shook the Communist firmament in August 1980. Outgoing President Wojciech Jaruzelski, the general and former Communist leader who interned Walesa under martial law nine years ago this month, was among the first to send congratulations. On Tuesday, Walesa is to travel - like Polish kings before him - to the Jasna Gora monastery in Czestochowa to pledge fealty to the nation in front of the painting of the Black Madonna, Poland's most revered icon.

DOC.HEAD: Ballets Russes Art Director Dead At 86
DOC.TEXT: Boris Kochno, artistic director to Sergei Diaghilev and his ``Ballets Russes,'' died at a Paris hospital during the weekend, friends said today. He was 86. There was no information immediately available on the cause of death. His death also was announced by Radio France. A choreographer, librettist and lighting specialist, Kochno was artistic director to Diaghilev from 1922-29 and was responsible for bringing Igor Stravinsky to the world of ballet. Born in Moscow in 1904, Kochno was best known for ballets danced by Diaghilev's famed ``Ballets Russes'' troupe, including ``Les Facheux,'' ``Zephire et Flore'' and ``Les Matelots.'' After Diaghilev's death in 1929, Kochno took over the company and moved it to Monte Carlo where in 1933 he founded, along with George Balanchine, another troupe, Les Ballets. But it was short-lived. After World War II, he created the Ballets des Champs-Elysees and wrote many librettos including ``Les Forains,'' (1945) choreographed by Roland Petit.

DOC.HEAD: Court to Decide Prison-Suit Issue in Connecticut Case
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether prison inmates sometimes are entitled to jury trials when suing prison officials over alleged mistreatment. The justices said it will hear an appeal by John J. McCarthy, who accused officials at a state prison in Somers, Conn., of violating his rights when they removed him from his cell in 1983. He said officials used excessive force in using tear gas to get him out of his cell. He also alleged that they planted a knife in his cell as a pretext for removing him. McCarthy initially agreed to have a federal magistrate decide his case but later changed his mind. U.S. District Judge Jose A. Cabranes ruled that McCarthy had given up his right to a jury trial and assigned the case to Magistrate F. Owen Eagan. The magistrate, after conducting eight days of hearings at the prison in 1988, recommended that Cabranes rule in favor of the prison officials, and the judge agreed. The 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the judge's ruling. The appeals court said Cabranes acted properly in rejecting McCarthy's request to have a jury decide the case against the officials. Federal law authorizes federal judges to assign to magistrates cases in which prisoners say their rights are violated by conditions of confinement. The judge can designate a magistrate even if the officials and prisoners object. The Supreme Court said it will decide whether the same rule applies when a prisoner alleges ``a specific episode of allegedly unconstitutional conduct rather than continuing prison conditions.'' The case is McCarthy vs. Bronson, 90-5635.

DOC.HEAD: Limoges China, Dirt Bathrooms - Hostages Tell Varied Tales of Captivity
DOC.TEXT: Some Americans told tales of deprivation at the hands of the Iraqis, but Dave Lammel said Monday he spent his time in Kuwait in a royal palace where he ate off Limoges china and drank from crystal glasses. ``I had the irony of living in these ungodly opulent conditions,'' he said. ``It was bizarre. It was like a Fellini movie.'' But the 42-year-old from Orinda, Calif., was no less a hostage of Saddam Hussein than Terrence Dupuis, 53, who had to stomach rotten food and a hole in the ground for a toilet. Both recounted their days in captivity after a night enjoying what was for Dupuis the luxury of a comfortable bed at a hotel in Frankfurt, where they arrived after midnight Sunday on a flight from Baghdad. On Monday morning, more than 150 hostages and family members, most of them American, had a breakfast feast of real scrambled eggs, bacon, hash browns, orange juice and coffee. Lammel, an engineering consultant for Chevron Corp. who arrived in Kuwait July 10 on a business trip, was part of a group of Westerners rounded up after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion. Instead of being taken to an arms depot to serve as human shields, Lammel and the others were kept in a Kuwaiti royal family palace inside a military compound just south of Kuwait City. Lammel, who lost 10 pounds in captivity, said he drank from gold-rimmed crystal glasses and had a floor-to-ceiling marbled bathroom at his disposal. But he expressed bitterness about being held hostage and about the destruction of Kuwait. He also was upset about those soldiers who already had died in Operation Desert Shield. ``I'd like to express my extreme sympathy to the families of American soldiers who lost their lives. I feel their sacrifice has been what brought me out alive,'' Lammel said. ``They died protecting me.'' Dupuis, a native of Massachusetts who was returning to his wife in Toronto, spent his time as one of Saddam's ``human shields'' in two military camps, the last one for 12 weeks. Aside from the food, the worst part was the lack of decent toilet facilities, he said. Tom Kreuzman, gaunt and tired from his four months of hiding in Kuwait, quietly recalled his passage to freedom Monday. But he could not share the euphoria of the other 155 people who flew to the United States from Frankfurt later in the day. Kreuzman, a 38-year-old native of Holiday, Fla., spent 23 days alone in a ceiling duct with his Scottish terrier, Chu Chu, who got lost in the rush at Baghdad airport on Sunday. ``It's a tragedy,'' said the former U.S. Air Force serviceman who worked for the Kuwaiti Defense Ministry as a technician on their Hawk missile system. ``She made it that far. She went through a lot with me over there.'' Kreuzman also said he felt guilty and hadn't wanted to leave behind the Kuwaitis who had helped him hide from Iraqi authorities. He said they feared the world would forget about them once all the hostages were out. Kreuzman pledged to return to Saudi Arabia as soon as possible to help Kuwaiti soldiers there ``behind the line.'' ``They didn't invade Kuwait, they raped it,'' he said of the occupying Iraqi forces. Despite dprivation, fear and the constant threat of war, Bruce McKinnon was another animal lover who had turned down an earlier opportunity to flee Kuwait because the flight couldn't accommodate his two small dogs. ``One is 15 years old. And I promised him I would get him out of Kuwait,'' said McKinnon, 44, a native of Frankfort, Mich.

DOC.HEAD: Teddy Kollek: Defending Jerusalem Against `Silly Things'
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Teddy Kollek's pet word for the day was ``silly'' - mild by the standards of the blunt-talking Jerusalem mayor. A Cabinet minister making his home in the Moslem Quarter: ``silly.'' A pledge by Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir to build yet another Jewish housing project in Arab east Jerusalem: ``silly.'' His own decision to run for mayor 25 years ago: ``the silliest.'' Teddy Kollek will be 80 in May, and is showing no inclination toward imminent retirement. Up at dawn, at work until near midnight, he gives new meaning to the word ``indefatigable.'' His bustling frame and thick hair haven't changed in years. He is one of the world's best-known mayors, with an office full of teddy bears sent by admirers. The Oct. 8 blood bath on the Temple Mount has plunged Jerusalem into its worst crisis in 23 years, but it hasn't dimmed Kollek's enthusiasm for the city. After the killing of at least 17 Palestinians by police confronting a stone-throwing mob, Kollek sounded angry and self-critical. In an interview with the Maariv newspaper, he railed at the government for failing to treat the Arabs as equals, and at himself for not doing enough for them. ``For the Jews, I did something. But for the (Arab) east? Nothing. Enough blah-blah! What have I done? Schools? Nothing. Sidewalks? Nothing. Cultural centers? Nothing,'' he stormed. But later, in an interview at his City Hall office, he seemed calmer. ``I think it will take a long time until it gets back to where it was,'' he said. ``It was a very traumatic event.'' But he saw signs that the dust was settling. Arabs who boycotted the municipality immediately after the shootings were trickling back looking for help with their problems, he said. He pointed to small gestures - Arabs who spotted a bomb and called the police; Arabs who rescued a Jewish family from a mob. He wants to give them medals for public service, but the Arabs, he says, fear the publicity. The Palestinian vengeance attacks that followed the Temple Mount killings began with three Jews knifed to death in Jerusalem. Although the stabbings spread around the country, it was Jerusalem's image that took the worst beating. Tourists, both foreign and Israeli, have stayed away in droves. Shlomo Lahat, mayor of Tel Aviv, came here with 1,400 schoolchildren the other day as part of ``Jerusalem - especially now,'' a campaign to demonstrate solidarity with the city. ``I am a Jerusalemite,'' declared Lahat, borrowing from the late John F. Kennedy's celebrated phrase ``Ich bin ein Berliner.'' ``I'm very moved, even though that usually doesn't happen to me,'' Kollek replied. ``People are afraid of coming to Jerusalem these days. ... It's no secret.'' In an Israel increasingly drawn to mystic nationalism, Kollek remains a convinced pragmatist, a throwback to the ``deeds, not words'' philosophy of his mentor, David Ben-Gurion. The realist in Kollek tells him that managing a city of Jews and Arabs in the cockpit of the Mideast conflict requires a hard head and a feel for compromise. Hence he has little patience for rhetoric. ``You have to work with tweezers,'' he says. ``You can't do anything with grand declarations. ... I can do lots of little things that together amount to something. I think this is the only way.'' He blames many of Jerusalem's problems on ``heavy-handed government'' and an Israeli tendency ``to approach every problem with an open mouth.'' But he faults the foreign media for treating Jerusalem as though it was the only city in the world with communal strife. ``I was terribly encouraged by a silly affair - by the fight between Montreal and the Mohawks about a golf course,'' he remarked. ``It's ridiculous, right?'' Kollek lists various concessions made by Israel after it captured Jerusalem from the attacking Jordanian army in 1967: a semi-free Arabic press, a choice of Israeli or Jordanian citizenship, Arab curricula in schools and Moslem control of access to their holy places. The trouble, he says, is that these are now taken for granted. Another problem may be that not all Israelis are blessed - or cursed - with Kollek's ability to see both sides of the problem. ``We can't put ourselves into the shoes of other people,'' he said. ``Either we are unable to or we don't want to.''

DOC.HEAD: A Drink Is A Drink Is A Drink For Utah's Desert Wildlife
LaserPhoto SK1
With AM-Space Shuttle, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Some of the mule deer and antelope in Utah's desert are surviving thanks to space technology. Hercules Corp. has donated more than 100 surplus casings for solid fuel rockets to the state Division of Wildlife Resources since 1978 for a program aimed at supplying water to animals in otherwise inhospitable areas. The casings serve as tanks, nick-named ``guzzlers,'' to capture and store rain water in areas that receive only 6 to 8 inches of precipitation a year. They attract wildlife to areas that otherwise might be avoided, said Jay Roberson, upland game program coordinator for the division. ``They've opened up millions of acres,'' he said. The rocket casings are buried on public land, beneath a funnel or catch basin that captures rain. A pipe or hose feeds the stored water to a trough through a valve that opens when animals drink. The state still has to pay for other materials and install the guzzlers, but officials say the tanks generally are the most costly part. The price can exceed $10,000. ``The state has saved over $400,000 by using the cases instead of buying new materials,'' said biologist Dean Mitchell. In the past, Hercules had to cut up surplus rocket motor casings and send them to a landfill, said company engineer Richard Cloward, who also is vice president of the Utah Wildlife Leadership Coalition. ``It's crazy to spend money to cut those things up just to facilitate burying them,'' he said. John Waugman, environmental engineer at Hercules, said the huge casings generally are made of fiberglass, graphite or Kevlar, a material used in bulletproof vests. They're usually stronger than steel. ``It doesn't deteriorate,'' Cloward said. ``It will be there long after you and I are gone,'' added Waugman. Hercules produces rocket motors for the Defense Department and the space program, including the Titan and Titan IV, Delta II, Trident II, the Midgetman small intercontinental ballistic missile and Pegasus. Waugman said the donated casings were never filled with rocket fuel. He and Cloward also said Hercules has run tests to ensure that nothing from the tanks gets into the water or leaches into the ground. Roberson is unable to document whether the tanks have been responsible for increased populations of animals, but his general impression is that the range has more animals because there is more water. ``That's our belief and that's our observation,'' he said. ``We believe it enough that we are willing to continue maintaining the guzzlers.'' ``There are the skeptics who say `show me the data,''' Roberson said. ``But when we say how much money it would take to do the study ... you could put in a lot of water to research that.''

DOC.HEAD: Troops Can Be Blue But Still Have Decent Christmas, Psychologist Says
DOC.TEXT: The only thing white about Christmas here is the desert sand. Families and loved ones are far away for the American military personnel deployed in Operation Desert Shield. Outward Christmas displays are barred so as not to offend the Islamic sensibilities of the Saudi Arabians. Twinkling lights don't go with military tents. It's enough to give the toughest troops the Christmas blues. But a psychologist says Desert Shield won't be completely barren of holiday cheer. ``There will be kind of a blue haze over everything. It's kind of a funk,'' said Capt. Frank Mullins, 54, of Mobile, Ala., a psychologist at the U.S. Navy's Fleet No. 5 Hospital. ``But the average person will find a lot of solace being among friends, sharing Christmas dinne, singing a couple of carols,'' he said. What helps people get through the holidays are personal things sent from home: a card, a trinket, a snapshot, Christmas music, yule decorations, Mullins said. Army Maj. Doug Bidle of Chicago received a candy cane house complete with fake snow and an artificial tree from his wife. Navy Petty Officer Diane Escobar of Austin, Texas, has a nativity scene, and a paratrooper in the Army's 82nd Airborne Division was mailed the artificial tree his father had in Vietnam. ``The troops here should try to have as normal a Christmas as they can, with as many customs and rituals as they can get from home,'' Mullins said. ``People are upset, don't get me wrong. If you don't feel upset, maybe there's something wrong with you,'' he said. ``They may get depressed. They may cry a little bit. But they'll be fine the next day. ``We don't expect to be overflowing with psychiatric casualties on Christmas Day.'' What's also absent in Saudi Arabia is spiked eggnog and alcoholic spirits because liquor is banned in Saudi Arabia. But Mullins said the absence of booze, a depressant, is one of the reasons why the mood of the troops has been so good despite the desert life, scorpions, vipers, isolation and harsh living conditions. ``I'll be the first to say I'm glad there's no alcohol,'' he said. ``What it does is cut down on the mental health business. We've had surprisingly little business.'' ``The truth of the matter is the mental health of many of troops is going to improve,'' Mullins said. ``They can cope with normal developmental pressures without alcohol. ``They're going to find they can engage in more adult behavior and operate in their environment more realistically.'' Most of the problems troops have sought help for are personal ones: the Dear John letters, the death of a loved one back home, the first child born while a serviceman is on desert duty. The military recognizes that stress, fatigue and anxiety can be daily enemies than can dull the fighting edge of young service members. ``The kids we're seeing are not bitching about living in the sand,'' Mullins said. ``The harshness of the living conditions since we've been here has not been that big a problem. ``How many times have you heard that morale is good when people are bitching? When people get too depressed to bitch, you've got problems. They withdraw socially, go into themselves.'' What's important is the coping skills that people develop from the hardships, the psychologist said. ``For a lot of young men here, this may be the major growth experience in their lives,'' Mullins said. ``Don't forget, World War II was that way for the people who're now 60 years old.''

DOC.HEAD: Space Panel Recommends Limits On Shuttle Flights
DOC.TEXT: A top-level review of the nation's space program recommended today that space shuttle flights be confined only to those that require human involvement and that the proposed space station be redesigned from top to bottom. A committee of experts said some of the concerns expressed about the National Aeronautics and Space Administration are ``deserved and occasionally even self-inflicted.'' Their report was released after Vice President Dan Quayle and NASA administrator Richard Truly were briefed on its contents. The 12-member committee, which has been studying the space program for four months, was headed by Norman R. Augustine, chairman and chief executive officer of the Martin Marietta Corp. NASA has received heavy criticism this year, particularly after shuttles were grounded for five months by leaks and by the inability of the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope to see the universe as sharply as advertised. The committee was asked whether some new form of management structure was called for, but it said ``changes of such sweeping scope are inappropriate.'' ``In spite of imperfections, by far the greatest body of space expertise in any single organization in the world resides within NASA,'' the report said. ``Briefly stated, the committee believes that NASA, and only NASA, realistically possesses the essential critical mass of knowledge and expertise upon which the nation's civil space program can be sustained.'' The committee said NASA should start immediately to phase out some of its missions on the space shuttle and transfer them to a new, unmanned launch vehicle that would be developed. The report said the civil space program is overly dependent on the shuttle for access to space and warned that statistically ``we are likely to lose another space shuttle in the next several years.'' It said, therefore, that the shuttle should be used only for those missions where human involvement is necessary. ``The committee believes in hindsight that it was, for example, inappropriate in the case of Challenger to risk the lives of seven astronauts and nearly one-fourth of NASA's launch assets to place in orbit a communications satellite,'' the report said. Quayle called the report a tremendous effort and said the committee will be reconvened in six months to assess what progress has been made. Truly said ``NASA and I intend to take each of these recommendations most seriously.'' There was no immediate response from NASA. Most of the top officials of the space agency met with the vice president. NASA and Quayle, who is head of the National Space Council, have been at odds over the future of the program and the committee was set up to respond to those concerns. The committee recommended that the priorities of the space program be shifted to place primary emphasis on science. It also recommended that the space station be redesigned to lessen complexity and reduce cost - ``taking whatever time may be required to do this thoroughly and innovatively.'' The first construction flight for the station has been scheduled for 1995, but Congress has balked at the cost of the station and ordered NASA to cut back. The committee included former NASA administrator Thomas Paine, former Air Force Secretary Edward C. (Pete) Aldridge Jr., and former astronaut Joseph Allen. It offered to meet again in six months, if NASA wants.

DOC.HEAD: Former West German Spy Presumed Dead Turns Up Alive
DOC.TEXT: A onetime spy for former West Germany who disappeared into East Germany eight years ago and was declared dead has surfaced alive and well, German authorities said Monday. Hans-Juergen Foerster, spokesman for the federal prosecutor's office in Karlsruhe, said officials were investigating whether the agent had given up state secrets while working for West Germany's intelligence service. The prosecutor's office did not identify the 48-year-old man by name or say where he was staying. It was not clear whether he could be prosecuted. He worked for the Office of the Defense of the Constitution, as West Germany's secret service was called. The agency has the same name in united Germany. The man disappeared eight years ago, but the statute of limitations for simple intelligence activities is five years. However, for more serious allegations such as treason, he could still be charged.

DOC.HEAD: Construction Nearly Complete; Presidential Library Opening in a Year
DOC.TEXT: Former President Reagan frequently travels these days to a Southern California hilltop to scrutinize finishing touches on the nation's largest presidential library. ``He thought maybe the oak trees were getting too much water, but otherwise he's pleased. He takes a real interest in his library,'' said Charles H. Jeloian, director of the Ronald Reagan Presidential Foundation. Reagan also was concerned about the flowering pear trees on a library patio, but they came through the shock of transplanting and were healthy by fall. ``He spends all afternoon here. He knows this place like the back of his hand,'' said Jelloian. The 153,000-square-foot, Spanish-style library sits on a knoll 45 miles northwest of Los Angeles, a convenient stop between Reagan's Bel-Air home and his Santa Barbara ranch. Ground-breaking was held Nov. 21, 1988. The Ronald Reagan Presidential Library is on schedule and within its $40 million budget. The structure should be completed by Reagan's 80th birthday on Feb. 6 and a dedication ceremony will be next November. The 100-acre site is impressive, with views of mountains and the Pacific Ocean across open fields of brush, beavertail cactus and wildflowers. Visitors enter large wrought-iron gates into a patio featuring a fountain. A red-tile roof protects the adobe-look walls. Straight ahead, on the second floor, are offices for Reagan and his wife. ``The president can walk out on the balcony and wave to visitors,'' said Jelloian. More than 250,000 visitors are expected annually. Plasterers, painters and carpet layers now swarm over the building, which will feature an archives section, gift shop, two theaters, space for 30,000 gifts presented during Reagan's White House years and a replica of the Oval Office. The library will be the repository for an expected 62 million papers, exceeding President Nixon's 44 million. When the library opens, the non-profit foundation will turn it over to the National Archives and Records Administration, which will run the Reagan library with a staff of about 22 people and an annual budget of $1.5 million. At the ground-breaking, Reagan said he hoped historians and scholars would ``judge our efforts well.''

DOC.HEAD: Six Killed, 11 Injured in Minivan Accident
DOC.TEXT: VILLIERS, South Africa (AP) A minivan taxi and a truck collided, killing six people and seriously injuring 11, police said on Monday. The accident occurred Sunday night in this community 60 miles south of Johannesburg, the government-run South African Broadcasting Corp. reported. It said two men and four women were killed and that the 11 injured were in critical condition at a hospital in Frankfort, south of Villiers. It have no further details. Minivan taxis are the main public transportation for South African blacks and often operate overcrowded. They frequently are involved in accidents.

DOC.HEAD: Casino Robbed of $83,000
DOC.TEXT: Four masked men held up a casino in the eastern city of Pilsen early Monday and escaped with $83,000, the CTK news agency said. There were about 40 players at the casino when the robbery occurred at 1:15 a.m., the state news agency said. Police said the robbers struck some of the players on the head with their guns but that none was seriously injured. The tourist industry is booming in Czechoslovakia, and six casinos have opened.

DOC.HEAD: Explosion at Army Base Kills Child, Injures 17
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 graf to CORRECT time of blast to 9:30 sted 8:30; UPDATE with official saying building where leak found was being evacuated, not one that blew up; add that coroner said positive identification pending but others saying it is missing 5-year-old. Picks up 8th graf pvs, `The post...'. SUBS 12-13th grafs, bgng `Adams, whose...', with 4 grafs to add detail on evacuation effort. Picks up penultimate graf.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NA2
DOC.TEXT: A natural gas explosion rocked an apartment complex at an Army base, killing a 5-year-old girl and injuring 17 residents and rescuers, authorities said. The girl's remains were discovered in the rubble of the building at 9:30 a.m. today, about 12 hours after it blew up, officials at Fort Benjamin Harrison said. The blast occurred hours after fire authorities arrived to investigate a gas leak at another building in the complex. That building was being evacuated when the blast hit several hundred feet away, authorities said. The explosion, in a housing area for enlisted personnel, destroyed a four-family housing unit and damaged another unit, said post spokesman Maj. Ronald Downing. ``The fire engines were trying to get in and we were trying to get out. It was total chaos,'' said Joan Adams, a resident of the complex. She described people running through streets in their pajamas, carrying children. At least 17 residents and firefighters were injured. By midday today, three people were still listed in critical condition, one of them a 4-year-old girl, authorities said. Marion County Deputy Coroner Charles W. Green said he could not conclusively identify the dead child until after dental records were checked. But base officials said there was little doubt it was the 5-year-old girl who had been reported missing earlier. Firefighters and police called off their search through the smoldering rubble after the body was found. The girl's identity was not released. Other members of her family were among the injured, Downing said. The post on the edge of town serves as a processing center for soldiers en route to the Persian Gulf, although none of those soldiers stayed in the affected area. Fire authorities had been called in about 5:45 p.m., or 3{ hours before the blast, after people reported smelling gas, Downing said. He said officials had planned to evacuate the 240-unit Harrison Village complex before the explosion. Harley said authorities turned the gas off at one housing unit where they thought the leak was occurring. But a nearby unit, where the gas had not been turned off, blew up, he said. Some residents complained that they were not adequately warned. Adams, whose husband is a sergeant, said that about two hours before the explosion, military police began telling residents that a gas leak had been found elsewhere in the complex and would be fixed. ``He told us there was no danger for us to stay there,'' she said. Her family had planned to leave anyway, because the complex was without heat and hot water, but the explosion happened before they did so, she said. Lt. Col. Bill Carey, provost marshal, said the building where the leak was detected was evacuated as a precaution, but ``we didn't feel the whole area needed to be evacuated.'' However, the blast occurred in another building about 800 to 1,000 feet away, he said, adding that ``prior to the explosion, we had not been to this building.'' The blast was felt more than two miles away. Wood and other debris were scattered where a two-story building once stood. Rubble was strewn over four blocks. About 210 families were evacuated after the explosion. ``Insulation was coming down like snow when we got here. One apartment was engulfed in flames and the other building was in flames,'' said State Trooper Anthony Blackburn.

DOC.HEAD: Private Trash Haulers Strike in NYC; Garbage Begins Piling Up
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs with detail from situation this morning. Picks up 7th graf pvs, `Jim Grossman...'.
DOC.TEXT: Garbage bags began mounding on streets outside fast-food establishments today as garbage collectors struck the private carting companies that pick up trash from 250,000 businesses. No emergencies were reported on the first morning of missed pickups, but the city Sanitation Department was ready to collect garbage at any business sites where health or fire hazards were certified. A 2,100-member Teamsters local called the strike Sunday after union members rejected a second contract offer. Picket lines went up Sunday night. The haulers pick up 10,000 tons of garbage daily from restaurants, factories and other businesses, as well as construction sites. The strike affects 475 carting companies with total operations worth more than $1 billion a year. Collections of residential garbage, the province of the Sanitation Department, was not affected by the strike. The walkout began officially Sunday night and the union said this morning it was largely effective, but some trucks were making pickups in the Bronx. ``They went out with management people and with scabs, and they have a lot of police protection,'' said Bernard Adelstein, secretary-treasurer of Teamsters Local 813. The union represents collectors in New York City and adjoining suburban counties. Adelstein said no decision had been made yet on whether the walkout will be spread to those counties, Westchester and Putnam. He said there was no chance of a strike on Long Island, where contracts run to 1992. This morning, little garbage was visible on such main midtown thoroughfares as Broadway and Sixth Avenue, but accumulations began appearing at curbside and against buildings on the side streets. At one spot, between two high turnover restaurants on 48th Street at Broadway and Seventh Avenue, the black plastic garbage bags narrowed the passageway for pedestrians. Jim Grossman, a spokesman for the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association, which represents 7,000 municipal garbage collectors, said the union will not pick up the businesses' trash without the city declaring a health emergency. Such a declaration would obligate the union to pick up the trash, he said. But he said, ``It's wintertime and the garbage can sit outside a long time before it creates a health problem.'' The union's last strike was in the winter of 1981 and lasted 17 days. The city declared a health emergency the day before it was settled. The Teamsters rejected the first contract offer Dec. 2 but postponed their strike deadline by one week at the request of Mayor David Dinkins. The union demanded a three-year contract with 8 percent wage increases each year - about $60 a week - and improved pension and welfare benefits, said secretary-treasurer Bernard Adelstein. Workers earn about $40,000 a year. The offer rejected Dec. 2 called for no pay increase the first year, $25 a week in the second and $35 a week in the third. The proposal rejected Sunday offered slightly more, union officials said. The old contract expired Nov. 30. No negotiations were scheduled.

DOC.HEAD: Wealthy Israeli Convicted of 22 ``Bikerbank'' Robberies
DOC.TEXT: A Tel Aviv court on Monday convicted a wealthy socialite of a string of 22 armed bank robberies in which the gunman became almost a cult figure with the nickname ``Bikerbank.'' The three-judge panel of the Tel Aviv District Court set a sentencing hearing for Feb. 11 for Roni Leibovitz, the national news agency Itim reported. The robberies stretched over nearly two years because police were unable to find a clue to the identity of the robber, whose trademark was escaping on a motorcycle after firing a shot into the bank ceiling. Liebovitz, 37, was arrested on Oct. 18 and later confessed to the robberies, in which he took $175,500. Israeli newspapers and the state-run television devoted much time and space to reporting the robberies and speculating on the identity of the suspect. But Liebovitz failed to live up to the media's romantic image of a tall, handsome robber - possibly a war hero gone wrong. Instead, the robber turned out to be the son of a wealthy family whose lavish livestyle led him into debt, according to news reports. The reports said Leibovitz's family founded a food and soap factory called Etz Hazait, or Olive Tree, and has U.S. interests that do hundreds of millions of dollars in business annually. The family was said to have paid back the money to the banks. In arguing for a lenient sentence, defense lawyer Uri Slonim said Leibovitz had admitted to the crimes and never shot anyone during the robberies, Itim reported.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Singer Bobby Helms says he was unsure about mixing rock 'n' roll and Christmas, but his ``Jingle Bell Rock'' has become a holiday classic. ``It's made itself a part of Christmas,'' said Helms, who recorded the song in 1957. While many other holiday songs are mellow renditions dreaming of a white Christmas or chestnuts roasting on an open fire, ``Jingle Bell Rock'' is a snappy number that catches the excitement of the year. ``It lifts people up,'' he said in a recent interview. Helms said that the song - written by Joe Beal and Jim Boothe - was the first to tie in Christmas with rock 'n' roll, which was just emerging in 1957. ``I wasn't sure about putting rock 'n' roll into Christmas,'' says Helms, 53, who lives in Martinsville, Ind. ``But it's just one of those songs. You never know.'' Besides ``Jingle Bell Rock,'' Helms had two other hit records: ``My Special Angel'' and ``Fraulein.'' His recording career continued through the 1950s and 1960s. He later got into the nightclub business and also sponsored music festivals. --- ASPEN, Colo. (AP) - Two of the most talked about women in Hollywood - Oprah Winfrey and Cher - agree they like themselves just the way they are. A crowd of fans showed up at the Wheeler Opera House over the weekend to see Cher and Winfrey discuss Cher's new movie, ``Mermaids,'' and a variety of other topics during a taping of The Oprah Winfrey Show. The segment is scheduled to air Friday. A second, more intimate interview with Cher, taped at her Aspen home, will be televised Dec. 31. Cher said she moved to Aspen recently because excessive media exposure forced her to seek privacy. The singer-actress said she was ``tired of having to defend my actions.'' Winfrey said she admires Cher's confidence and announced that she is trying to confront her own reality. Winfrey gained attention two years ago when she lost 67 pounds on a crash diet. She has since regained most of the weight and has no plans to diet again. ``I believed I was going to be among the 2 percent'' who don't regain weight after dieting, she said. ``It pains me to say it, but I was wrong. I recently said to the universe `OK take me, come on.' I'm ready.'' --- BRUSSELS, Belgium (AP) - The Princess of Wales visited a factory and two charitable organizations Monday amid tight police security following last week's arrest of three terrorist suspects. Hundreds of police were on hand to protect Lady Diana, the wife of Prince Charles, one week after three Irish Republican Army suspects were captured with guns and ammunition in Antwerp, 30 miles away. The three Irish citizens were charged with illegal weapon possession. Police said it was not known if the three had planned to attack the princess. The princess visited the Johnson Matthey PLC precious metals factory, and opened the Brussels office of HelpAge International, which is linked to the British charity organization ``Help the Aged,'' of which she is patron. She also visited Belgian Queen Fabiola's children hospital. --- TULSA, Okla. (AP) - Country music singer Roy Clark joined more than 2,000 motorcyclists who collected about $20,000 worth of toys that the Salvation Army will distribute next week. Riders were required to bring a new, unwrapped toy for a child 14 years or younger during the 11th annual Motorcycle Toy Run. Clark, who has been riding a motorcycle since 1949, said he brought a football for a boy and a doll for a girl. ``I thought I'd be different,'' he said. The run was sponsored by A Brotherhood Aiming Toward Education, a motorcycle rights group. Organizers say the amount of toys collected Sunday was the most ever. One rider had 33 toys strapped to his motorcycle, some wore Santa Claus suits and three couples got married in front of the toy pile at the Oklahoma National Guard Armory.

DOC.HEAD: Saudis Fear If Saddam Keeps His Army He'll Be Arab Champion
DOC.TEXT: If Saddam Hussein's forces are left intact after he is forced out of Kuwait, he will claim the late Gamal Abdel Nasser's mantle as the champion of the Arab world, Saudis fear. Saudi officials, speaking Monday on condition of anonymity, echoed the concern voiced a day earlier by U.S. Secretary of State James Baker III. Baker said that even a peaceful solution to the Gulf crisis would be followed by continued pressure on Saddam to curb his military power. ``He can't keep his military. He'll be a hero. He'll make Nasser in 1956 look like Mickey Mouse,'' said one Saudi source. Nasser, the populist Egyptian president who died in 1970, became an idol in the Arab world after standing up to the French and British forces backing Israel in the 1956 attempt to reverse his nationalization of the Suez Canal. He used his pan-Arab nationalism to appeal to public opinion across North Africa and the Middle East, destablizing many pro-Western governments in the process. His memory remains a potent force in the Arab world today. The Saudis see history repeating itself in Saddam's vast military arsenal and political ambitions. Saddam has the biggest and most powerful army in the Arab world, with a million troops, a missile armory and other weapons of mass destruction. Most officials expect he will find a way to extricate himselffrom Iraq before being attacked by the 26-nation alliance that began deploying troops to Saudi Arabia soon after Kuwait was invaded Aug. 2. But even after a retreat, Saddam will ``say he stood up not just to the United States, but to the whole world,'' a Saudi source said. The future threat would be both political and military. Saddam's invasion of Kuwait, an emirate disliked by poor Arabs for its vast oil wealth and limited rights for foreign workers, struck a popular chord in many parts of the Arab world. It added to his claim of achieving a victory against Iran, a traditional Arab enemy, in the 1980-88 war, despite having gained nothing in the end. ``They just love this white stallion stuff, Saladin and all that,'' said an Asian diplomat, referring to the Arab general who in 1187 recaptured Jerusalem from the European crusaders. Saddam, who likens himself to the Kurdish Saladin, is often shown on Iraqi television heroically mounted on a white charger. ``Arabs will say, `he's tough, he can solve our problems, let's follow him','' the diplomat added. Saddam has already tried to capitalize on that image with his attempt to link his withdrawal to an Israeli pullout from the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. ``Occupying another Arab land and torturing Arabs does not give hope that the Palestinians can be liberated,'' said a senior Saudi diplomat. The Saudis are concerned that what Saddam does not gain through charisma he can achieve through the threat of force, especially if he develops nuclear weapons within the next few years. They don't want U.N. economic sanctions against Iraq eases unless Iraq reduces the size and power of his military, or at least makes U.N.-backed guarantees not to use its arms again on fellow Arabs. ``We can't just stop at the withdrawal. The Iraqi army has to be reduced to a degree that it won't threaten us,'' said the senior diplomat. The Saudis, despite buying billions of dollars' worth of advanced weaponry over the last decade, found themselves hopelessly unable to combat Saddam when he invaded Kuwait. The Saudis have embarked on a crash expansion of their military and are buying weapons worth billions of dollars. But analysts say that even when that program is completed, they will still not be able to defend themselves without outside help.
DOC.HEAD: END
Court to Decide News Media Confidentiality Issue in Minneapolis Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts grafs 17-18, In the confidentiality, with reaction.
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether news media organizations enjoy any constitutional protection against being sued over broken promises of confidentiality. The justices said they will consider reinstating a $200,000 award against Minnesota's two largest newspapers won by a news source whose identity was not kept confidential. The award had been thrown out by the Minnesota Supreme Court. Public relations man Dan Cohen initially won a $700,000 award against the Star Tribune of Minneapolis-St. Paul and the St. Paul Pioneer Press Dispatch. A state appeals court ruled that a promise of confidentiality given to Cohen by a reporter with each newspaper amounted to an oral contract, but cut the award to $200,000. Cohen's victory was overturned completely by the state Supreme Court last July. In other action the court: - Gave federal judges more power to decide lawsuits stemming from labor disputes. The court unanimously reinstated a suit by two workers fired by a Michigan company, Ring Screw Works. The workers sued after losing grievances against the company. Justice John Paul Stevens, writing for the court, said the federal Labor Relations Management Act gives judges authority to rule in such cases unless the collective bargaining agreement between a union and management expressly forbids it. - Agreed to judge the validity of federal guidelines for sentencing people convicted of trafficking in the hallucinogenic drug LSD. The justices said they will decide whether the sentencing guidelines, now based on the weight of the LSD and its ``carrier,'' must instead be based on the number of doses confiscated. - Asked the Bush administration for its views on whether a Civil War era law enacted primarily to protect freed slaves bans racially discriminatory firings. The justices said they want to hear from Justice Department lawyers about a ruling that the manufacturer of Buster Brown shoes was guilty of illegal racial bias when it fired a white supervisor at a Missouri warehouse. - Agreed to decide whether prison inmates sometimes are entitled to jury trials when suing prison officials over alleged mistreatment. The justices said they will hear an appeal by John J. McCarthy, who accused officials at a state prison in Somers, Conn., of violating is rights when they removed him from his cell in 1983. - Refused to postpone a Jan. 22 election under a redistricting plan designed to help elect an Hispanic to the Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors for the first time in 115 years. The court rejected an emergency request by board members, who said the plan ordered by a federal judge is unlawful. In the confidentiality case, Cohen's attorney, Elliot Rothenberg, expressed pleasure at the Supreme Court's decision to take it up. ``The major issue will be, to what extent does the First Amendment of the Constitution apply to contract law,'' he said. ``Does it give newspapers the right to dishonor promises or violate (oral) contracts with confidential sources?'' Attorneys for the newspapers said they had not seen the court's order and could not immediately comment on it. The controversy stems from a revelation during the 1982 Minnesota political campaign that Marlene Johnson, a Democratic Farm Labor candidate for lieutenant governor, once had been arrested and charged with shoplifting. Cohen, who was associated with the campaign of Wheelock Whitney, the Independent-Republican candidate for governor, provided the information on the condition he not be identified as the source. Reporters for the two papers gave that assurance, but their editors ordered that Cohen's name be published because, they said, the public should be told that the information came from someone linked to Whitney's campaign. The same day he was named as the source in the newspaper stories about Johnson, Cohen was fired from his advertising agency job. In voting 4-2 to throw out Cohen's ensuing lawsuit against the newspapers, the state Supreme Court drew a distinction between moral and legal obligations. It said promises of confidentiality did not amount to oral contracts. ``To impose a contract theory on this arrangement puts an unwarranted legal rigidity on a special ethical relationship,'' the state court said. The state court also rejected arguments that Cohen was entitled to collect monetary damages under a more general legal theory governing broken promises. ``Enforcement of the promise of confidentiality under (such a) theory would violate defendants' First Amendment rights,'' the state court said. The Constitution's First Amendment guarantees freedom of the press. Minnesota's highest court added: ``There may be instances where a confidential source would be entitled to a remedy ... when the state's interest in enforcing the promise to the source outweighs First Amendment considerations, but this is not such a case.'' The two dissenting state court justices called the ruling ``a sad day in the history of a responsible press in America.'' In the appeal acted on today, lawyers for Cohen argued, ``This court has not before accorded media organizations a constitutional privilege to break promises or contracts with others or to be immune from generally applicable laws. No one, including the news media, should be above the law.'' Lawyers for the two newspapers urged the justices to reject Cohen's appeal. The case is Cohen vs. Cowles Media Co., 90-634.

DOC.HEAD: ABC Adds Daytime and Kid Shows to Sports Chief's Chores
DOC.TEXT: ABC Sports president Dennis Swanson got two additional duties Monday: running the network's children's and daytime programming. The move was part of a restructuring that followed the removal of Michael Brockman as president of ABC's daytime, children's and late-night entertainment. ABC assigned the late-night duties to Philip R. Beuth, a senior vice president at the ABC Television Network Group, said the group president, John B. Sias. Beuth also will continue overseeing the top-rated ``Good Morning America.'' Sias called Brockman's replacements ``two widely experienced broadcasters who have demonstrated their keen ability to provide excellent and successful entertainment programming in difficult and competitive environments.'' Brockman has attributed his departure to philosophical differences with management. Brockman, who only had been on the job since April 1989, previously held the same jobs at CBS, where he oversaw creation of ``The Pat Sajak Show,'' a late-night ratings bomb that was quickly canceled.

DOC.HEAD: Hostages Leaving; Iraq Insists It Will Keep Kuwait
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf pvs ``In the hostage ...'' with two grafs to update with two more planes carrying hostages leaving Baghdad.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY8, BX1, HT2
DOC.TEXT: The first wave of American hostages freed under Saddam Hussein's blanket release headed home today. But even as it relented and released foreign captives, Iraq declared it would not compromise ``one iota'' over Kuwait. U.S. consular officials in Germany said 152 Americans and four Canadians left Frankfurt on a Pan Am flight headed for Andrews Air Force Base near Washington. Provisions aboard included hamburgers and champagne. While expressing relief at the freeing of the hostages, the Bush administration wants nothing less than Iraq's total withdrawal from Kuwait. But the Baghdad government's information minister, Latif Jassim, said today any talk of an Iraqi withdrawal from the emirate was ``nothing but dreams and wishful thinking.'' ``Kuwait is for Iraqi, whether in the past, present or future,'' Jassim said in a statement carried by the official Iraqi News Agency. ``We will not compromise one iota on Kuwaiti territory, its waters or the money and investment of the buried Al-Sabah dynasty,'' he said, referring to Kuwait's deposed ruling family. The Bush administration is urging a meeting between President Saddam and James A. Baker III by Jan. 3 so Iraq would have time to pull out by Jan. 15, the deadline set in the U.N. resolution authorizing force to drive Iraq from Kuwait. In the hostage exodus, an Iraqi Airlines jet left Baghdad for London today carrying 384 Westerners, including 277 Britons and some Americans. The exact number of Americans on the British-chartered flight was not immediately known. Fourteen other Westerners - a Canadian, seven Irishmen, five Britons and a Dutchman - flew to Amman, Jordan, earlier today aboard a scheduled Iraqi Airways flight.
