The Americans who left Frankfurt today were among about 175 former captives who had arrived a day earlier from Baghdad aboard a U.S.-chartered Iraqi Airways jet. Some spoke of hiding barefoot in Kuwait City apartments, others of being held captive in ``gulags'' at strategic sites around Iraq. The flight from Baghdad also included 101 former British hostages, who were flown this morning from Frankfurt to London, where they were greeted by jubilant relatives and government officials. ``I feel euphoric,'' said one of the freed British captives, 45-year-old Harvey May. U.S. officials said they planned to charter another flight in three or four days to evacuate the rest of the estimated 750 Americans in Iraq and Kuwait. Twenty-one former American hostages landed in Houston on Sunday. They left Baghdad on Saturday aboard a jet chartered by former Treasury Secretary John Connally, who was in Iraq on a private mission to free hostages. About 8,000 Westerners had been prevented from leaving Iraq and Kuwait since Iraq overran Kuwait on Aug. 2, including about 600 who were held at strategic sites to guard against a feared attack by U.S-led forces. Saddam announced Thursday that they could all go home. The move came a week after the U.N. Security Council approved the use-of-force resolution, which President Bush followed up by inviting Iraq to exchange envoys in an effort to avoid war. Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz plans to visit Washington for a meeting with Bush, possibly on Dec. 17. Baker's trip to Baghdad would follow some time later, but Iraqi and U.S. officials have yet to agree on a date. Baker said that if Saddam does not agree to a meeting by Jan. 3, it will show the Iraqi leader is not serious about averting war. A meeting Jan. 12, as proposed by Baghdad, would not give Iraq enough time to withdraw from its oil-rich neighbor before the Jan. 15 deadline, Baker said. The Iraqi ambassador to the United Nations, Abdul Amir Al-Anbari, said the meeting might be scheduled earlier. Speaking on NBC-TV's ``Meet the Press,'' he said the disagreement over scheduling was ``a minute one.'' British and Arab newspapers reported Sunday that Iraq had redrawn its border with Kuwait in possible preparation for a partial pullout from Kuwait. The reports, in the Observer of London and the Al-Khaleej daily in Abu Dhabi, said Saddam's aim was to keep the entire Rumailah oilfield and two islands, Warba and Bubiyan, which would give it open access to the Persian Gulf. The oilfield, which lies chiefly in Iraq, extends two miles into Kuwait and Saddam accused Kuwait of overexploiting it before he invaded. The weekly Observer, citing unidentified Arab sources in Washington, said ``most Arab governments expect Iraq to withdraw from the rest of Kuwait in late January'' but completion of a new border fence around Rumailah's southern time indicates an even earlier withdrawal. Baker said that in his meeting with Saddam he would not agree to give Iraq all of Rumailah because ``to say anything else would be to reward an aggressor.'' Baker predicted the public would support using force even if Iraq demanded only a small part of Kuwait because Americans would want to stand up against ``international outlaws like this man.'' The United States has 250,000 troops in the gulf and plans to build that force up to 400,000 by mid-January. The anti-Iraq coalition includes an estimated 100,000 troops from other nations.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Vic Fazio is House Democrats' Mr. Fix-it
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS 17th graf to attribute quote to Foley, sted O'Neill
DOC.TEXT: He's been called the Mayor of Capitol Hill. The Democrats' Mr. Goodwrench. Mr. Fix-it. The Prince of Perks. They're all appropriate descriptions of Rep. Vic Fazio of California, Congress' point man when it comes to securing pay raises and financing incumbents' built-in advantages over their challengers. And he's sick of them. ``It is not a very clear picture of me. It's very one-dimensional. My interests have been much broader,'' he complains. Breaking loose, Fazio has parlayed the points he scored as Mr. Inside for a shot at Mr. Outside, a chance to become a national mover in the Democratic Party. House Democratic colleagues last week elected him chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee. He'll represent their interests as the party goes into the crucial 1992 elections. Many secure, senior Democrats are expected to retire as congressional district boundaries are redrawn to comply with the new census data. It's a job that will require an instinct for issues, a mastery of demographic detail and a knack for emptying the wallets of campaign contributors. Anyone who believes Fazio was given that job just because he helped secure members a big pay raise last year would be wrong. They'd also be wrong if they thought that had nothing to do with it. The fact is that Democrats see Fazio as a jockey who can ride any horse to victory, even the ugly ones. And sometimes he seems to ride more than one at a time. In 12 years in the House, Fazio, 48, has never limited himself to the insider tasks for which he is known. He's done everything from fighting for cutbacks in the MX missile system, to securing tougher environmental rules for offshore oil drilling, to winning $2.8 billion in earthquake aid for his state after the 1989 San Francisco-area disaster. At the same time, he set up a political action committee to help fellow Democrats win re-election and has headed Impact 2000, the party's effort to prepare for the upcoming redistricting. In the shakeup that followed the resignation of former Speaker Jim Wright, D-Texas, Fazio a few years ago stepped onto the track that has now led him to the DCCC chairmanship. He became vice chairman of the House Democratic Caucus and is keeping that job, the first time the Democrats have put one person in two leadership posts. If he's been labeled Mr. Inside, it's his own fault. As chairman of the Legislative Branch subcommittee, Fazio is responsible for day-to-day budgeting of the institution. He's done the job better than many might think prudent, all the while waiting impatiently, finger-tapping impatiently, for the day he can dump that committee chairmanship for a better one. It's as if he can't find enough things to do. Speaker Thomas S. Foley said of Fazio: ``If I had a machine to clone him, I would do it. He is the most effective member of Congress I ever met.'' Republicans are equally impressed, if less complimentary. House Minority Whip Newt Gingrich, R-Ga., once called him ``a nice, clean machine politician,'' the Democrats' ``consigliere,'' the term used for a trusted counselor in the Mafia. For now, Fazio is counseling unity for his party. On the Persian Gulf, he sees little room for partisan advantage and worries that Democratic doubts could ``reassert that image of the Democratic party as appeasers.'' On the slumping economy, he believes the traditional Democratic answer of jobs programs is ``passe.'' And, true to form, he's not afraid to talk about the nitty-gritty. ``It's going to be a very, very bad year for fundraising for the House,'' he said, with House members competing for a ``theoretically finite amount of money'' with Democratic Senate and presidential candidates. He expects he'll need ``to find 60 to 75 new candidates of real quality ... people who can win'' the open seats created by retirements and the redistricting. Fazio says he considers his national party efforts ``totally really apart from the legislative branch-related activities. It's really two different worlds and they don't overlap very much.'' They do in one way. The Democrats are counting on him to do the dirty work, to be their Mr. Fix-it. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Steven Komarow covers Congress for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Milosevic, Communists Headed For Victory In Serbia
DOC.TEXT: Serbia's ruling Communists and their hard-line President Slobodan Milosevic were headed Monday for an election victory that could split Yugoslavia apart. As official returns trickled in from Serbia's first free ballot since 1938, the renamed Socialists and Milosevic took a commanding lead over their main challengers, the center-right nationalist Serbian Renewal Movement. A victory for Milosevic and his party is almost certain to deepen the rift between Serbia and the pro-Western republics of Croatia and Slovenia, where center-right parties ousted Communists in spring elections. The opposition charged the Communists with widespread vote-rigging. International observers said they believed Sunday's election was essentially fair, but indicated Communist domination of Serbia's media made for a biased campaign. In Montenegro, Communists were already celebrating what they claimed to be an overwhelming victory over 10 opposition parties, according to unofficial returns reported by the state Tanjug news agency. Tanjug said the Communist candidate for Montenegro's presidency, Momir Bulatovic, appeared as likely as Milosevic to win outright without being forced into a runoff. A runoff vote will be held Dec. 23 for any of the 250 parliament seats in Serbia or 125 seats in Montenegro in constituencies where no single candidate wins 50 percent. ``All I can say is they are leading and leading well,'' Jova Vukelic, spokesman for the Serbian Democratic Party, said of Milosevic's Socialists. Vukelic said he based his comment on partial results reaching his party. Tanjug said the Socialists had won nearly 80 seats in the Serbian parliament, according to an unofficial survey of 140 out of 250 districts. ``Initial results indicate that the Communists will have at least a 60 percent majority over the opposition in parliament,'' said Dragan Veselinov, president of the opposition Peasant's Party. ``We should be happy if they win only 60 percent. I'm afraid they could win by an even higher margin,'' said Vojislav Kostunica of the Democratic Party. The outcome of the vote in Serbia is likely to decide whether this volatile Balkan country stays together or breaks up. The newly elected governments in Slovenia and Croatia advocate greater democracy and have threatened to secede if Yugoslavia's federation of six republics does not transform into a loose confederation of near-independent states. Milosevic has refused to acknowledge the possibility of a federal break-up or to negotiate with the western republics. His main rival for president, Vuk Draskovic of the Serbian Renewal Movement, has said he would negotiate with Croatia and Slovenia. Electoral Commission Chairman Caslav Ignjatovic said he was investigating claims of ballot-rigging and widespread irregularities at the Serbian republic's 9,500 polling stations. Draskovic said the Socialists distributed campaign leaflets at polling stations Sunday and that pro-government media also ignored a ban on campaigning 48 hours before the election. Opposition leaders also claimed the Socialists stopped registering deaths in Serbia in April and rigged the election, using phantom votes. ``In terms of procedures at individual voting places, the elections passed fairly well,'' said Robert Hand, an official of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, which monitored the Serbian elections. ``Our main concern is what happened before the elections,'' Hand said. He said the group was unhappy with the limited opposition access to the Communist-controlled media during the campaign. Serbia's state-controlled media claimed the opposition parties were pro-Western enemies of the republic whose victory could lead to civil war with other Yugoslav regions. The divisions among Serbs, Croats and Slovenes reflect the babel of ethnic and political forces vying for power in Yugoslavia. The U.S. Central Intelligence Agency predicted recently that the country could be torn apart within 18 months and said civil war was possible.

DOC.HEAD: Former Public Enemy No. 1 Killed by Police
DOC.TEXT: Police killed a man once considered France's public enemy No. 1 during a robbery attempt at the home of an elderly widow, officials said Monday. A policeman was wounded in the abdomen in the exchange of gunfire Sunday night, and Jean-Charles Willoquet, 46, was killed by a bullet to the head, officials said. Willoquet was granted early release last year from a prison term imposed after he was convicted of attempted murder and hostage taking during a 1975 escape. On Sunday, he and an accomplice entered the Normandy home of Rosa Kahn, 81, representing themselves as policemen investigating a band of thieves, police said. A young girl called police after hearing cries from Mrs. Kahn, who was beaten. In the ensuing gunfire, Willoquet died, the policeman was wounded and Willoquet's accomplice escaped in a car. Willoquet was first arrested in 1968, when police said he was working by day as a hair stylist and burglarizing chateaux in the Loire Valley in his free time. He was sentenced to five years in prison, with three years suspended. He was arrested again in 1974 in Paris in connection with 11 armed attacks and a dozen racketeering charges. During his trial in 1975, he earned a reputation as public enemy No. 1 by escaping from the Palais de Justice with the aid of his wife, who entered the hearing room disguised in the black robe of a French lawyer. She took out a grenade and passed her husband a pistol. Willoquet took the judge and his assistant hostage and fled, wounding two gendarmes. He was captured a year later, months after his wife was apprehended. He was sentenced to serve two concurrent 20-year terms and was freed after 14 years. He wrote a book, ``Anything To Be Free,'' while serving time.

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court to Consider Media Source Protection Case
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court said Monday it will decide whether news organizations enjoy some constitutional protection against being sued for breaking promises to keep a source's identity a secret. The court voted to consider reinstating a $200,000 award against Minnesota's two largest newspapers. It was won, and then lost, by a news source whose identity was not kept confidential. The award had been thrown out by the Minnesota Supreme Court. Before beginning a four-week holiday recess, the court also: -Ruled unanimously in a Michigan case that workers may sue their employers after losing union grievance complaints. The decision reversed a federal appeals court ruling that a labor strike is a union's only recourse when its workers lose grievances. -Agreed to judge in a Wisconsin case the validity of federal guidelines for sentencing people convicted of trafficking in the hallucinogenic drug LSD. -Refused to postpone a Jan. 22 election under a redistricting plan designed to help elect the first Hispanic in 115 years to the Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors. -Asked the Bush administration, in a case from Missouri, for its views on the scope of a key civil rights law forbidding racially discriminatory firings. In the dispute over confidential sources, public relations man Dan Cohen initially won a $700,000 award against the Star Tribune of Minneapolis-St. Paul and the St. Paul Pioneer Press Dispatch. A state appeals court reduced the award to $200,000. During the 1982 Minnesota political campaign, Cohen told reporters for the two papers that Marlene Johnson, a Democratic Farm Labor candidate for lieutenant governor, once had been arrested and charged with shoplifting. Cohen, who was associated with the campaign of Wheelock Whitney, the Independent-Republican candidate for governor, provided the information on the condition he not be identified as the source. Reporters for the two papers gave that assurance, but their editors ordered that Cohen's name be published. The same day he was named as the source in the newspaper stories about Johnson, Cohen was fired from his advertising agency job. In voting 4-2 to throw out Cohen's ensuing lawsuit against the newspapers, the state Supreme Court rejected arguments that Cohen was entitled to collect monetary damages for the broken promise. ``Enforcement of the promise of confidentiality under (such a) theory would violate defendants' First Amendment rights,'' the state court said. The Constitution's First Amendment guarantees freedom of the press. The two dissenting state court justices called the ruling ``a sad day in the history of a responsible press in America.'' Cohen's lawyer, Elliot Rothenberg, said he was pleased by Monday's court action. He said the justices must decide whether the First Amendment gives news organizations ``the right to dishonor promises or violate (oral) contracts with confidential sources.'' The Minnesota Supreme Court, however, ruled that the promise of confidentiality made to Cohen did not amount to an oral contract. ``I'm very surprised the justices agreed to review this case. Most of the scenarios are pretty terrible,'' said Jane Kirtley of the Washington-based Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press. ``The case really is about journalistic ethics, not legally cognizable issues.'' If the justices reverse the Minnesota court's ruling and fail to make an an exception for reporters ordered by courts to divulge their sources, she said, ``reporters will face the choice of revealing a source and getting sued or not revealing a source and going to jail.'' Ms. Kirtley said the practical impact might not be great if the Minnesota court's ruling were reversed in a decision that made clear reporters could not be sued when forced by court order to reveal a source. ``But such a ruling would be significant as another chink out of the First Amendment armor,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Court Says Judges Have Broad Powers in Labor-Management Disputes
With AM-Scotus Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court ruled Monday that a federal law designed to promote labor peace gives federal judges broad power to resolve disputes between employers and their workers. Voting 9-0, the justices revived a lawsuit by two workers who said they were fired unjustly by Ring Screw Works in Michigan. The workers sued after losing grievances against the company. Writing for the court, Justice John Paul Stevens said the federal Labor Relations Management Act empowers judges to decide such suits unless the collective bargaining agreement between workers and their employers expressly forbids it. ``There is a strong presumption that favors access to a neutral forum for the peaceful resolution of disputes,'' Stevens said. A contract that gives unions the right to strike and management the right to impose a lockout over deadlocked grievances does not automatically strip federal judges of authority to rule in those disputes, he said. The courts are barred from acting only if both sides in the disputes ``expressly agree to resort to economic warfare rather than to mediation, arbitration or judicial review,'' Stevens said. Arthur Groves was fired by Ring Screw Works for allegedly excessive unexcused absences from work. Bobby Evans was dismissed for allegedly falsifying company records. Both men denied the charges but lost grievance complaints against the company. They then sued the company for firing them without due cause in violation of the Labor Relations Management Act. The United Automobile Workers Union joined the lawsuits on the side of the workers. The 6th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals last year upheld a ruling by a federal judge who threw out the suits. The appeals court said the UAW contract with Ring Screw Works implies that a strike is the union's only recourse when workers lose grievances. Union members voted against striking after Groves and Evans lost their grievances. The appeals court said the workers would be permitted to sue only if they accused the union of breaching its duty to represent them fairly, and the fired workers made no such claim.

DOC.HEAD: 12 Killed in European Storm
DOC.TEXT: Much of Europe dug out Monday from a heavy snowfall that snarled traffic and left thousands without electricity. At least 12 people were killed and nine were missing in the Continent's first storm of the winter season. Snow fell in France, Spain, Italy, Switzerland, Germany and Austria. In southern Europe, heavy rains flooded Venice and forced the suspension of ferry services. Torrential rains fell on the French Riviera. Police in Nice said two French people were killed Sunday night along the French-Italian border when bad weather sent rocks falling onto their car. Police in Britain, where snow turned to rain and sleet Monday, said 10 people were killed. Five mountain climbers were missing in northern Spain, where small towns were cut off by the heavy snow. Seven major highway mountain passes were closed in the provinces of Burgos, Cantabria, Leon and Soria. A Spanish Air Force helicopter and a merchant marine tug searched off the northern Spanish coast for four people on a French yacht missing in the Bay of Biscay. Roads were closed in the central Portugal Serra de Estrela range. Southeastern and central France were hit by heavy snowfall. The main highway between Lyon and Grenoble was inaccessible, with traffic rerouted to a small, one-lane highway. The Mount Blanc tunnel through the Alps was closed. In Switzerland, snow closed roads and delayed train and bus traffic. The Zermatt ski resort reported 3 feet of snow in 24 hours. In Austria, avalanche danger closed many roads in parts of East Tyrol and western Carinthia. In northern Tyrol, ice on the Inntal highway caused a 21-car pileup. Police said several people were injured. German police reported numerous accidents on the southern German autobahns because of heavy snow. Drivers were advised to use chains on alpine roads. Schools in Turin were closed as northern Italy dug out from its first pre-Christmas snow since 1964. Snow fell Sunday on Mount Vesuvius and the island of Ischia in the Bay of Naples, where heavy winds halted ferry traffic. Wind-driven seas flooded Venice. By daybreak Monday, 40 percent of the city was flooded, including low-lying St. Mark's Square. Train travel was disrupted as British Rail tried to clear snow-covered lines. British Rail said it had only two snowplow locomotives for 10,000 miles of track. It was considered a waste of money to buy more when the country did not have heavy snow every winter, the state-run network said. Six people were expected to appear before magistrates Monday in Coventry, England, where looters stole jewelry, clothes and stereos while police car patrols were halted by snow. Later, officers were sent out on foot.

DOC.HEAD: NTSB Chairman Presses States to Lift Licenses of Drunken Drivers
DOC.TEXT: A top federal safety official called Monday for a national campaign to persuade 21 remaining states to pass laws to immediately confiscate the licenses of drivers who fail or refuse drunken-driving tests. James L. Kolstad, chairman of the National Transportation Safety Board, told a meeting of the National Commission on Drunk Driving that license confiscation is a ``simple, direct and inexpensive'' way to attack a problem blamed for 60 deaths a day or nearly 22,000 fatalities a year. Such laws already have been passed by 29 states and the District of Columbia, and Kolstad said they have resulted in substantial decreases of drunken driving. Kolstad noted that the deaths of eight persons in the collision of two Northwest Airlines passenger jets at Detroit Metropolitan Airport a week ago ``flashed across the TV screens and the front pages of our newspapers.'' ``And almost immediately the calls for corrective action to prevent that kind of accident from happening again were heard,'' he said. He said that while the response was understandable and correct, ``it is disappointing that society does not get equally concerned when transportation deaths occur on our nation's roads and highways.'' ``Drunk driving is one of the leading causes of death in our country today and it is totally preventable,'' Kolstad said. Kolstad noted that a recent safety board study found that a third of fatally injured truck drivers tested positive for alcohol or drugs. ``Four out of five of these drivers had a history of substance abuse before their fatal accidents,'' he said. Kolstad's proposal, recently listed as one of the safety board's ``most-wanted'' safety changes, would require the immediate confiscation of a license if a driver either fails a sobriety test or refuses to take one. Under the program, a driver is given a temporary license and given the option of an administrative hearing. ``That hearing establishes only one basic fact: did the driver indeed fail the test or refuse to take it?'' Kolstad said. ``If the answer is `yes,' the driver's license is revoked on the spot. ``The driver may still face criminal charges later, but the important result is that they are taken off the road in very short order,'' he said. ``There are no appeals, no dilatory tactics, no mitigating circumstances, no plea bargaining, no pre-trial diversion. The drunk driver is taken off the road. ``This approach works and it works well,'' he said, adding that it deters not only drivers found drunk behind the wheel but also those who have not been caught but who will fear losing their driving privileges. Kolstad urged a lobbying campaign ``to convince legislators and governors of the common sense necessity'' of administrative license revocation laws. According to the Safety Board, the 21 states which have not passed such laws are: Alabama, Arkansas, Georgia, Idaho, Kentucky, Massachusetts, Michigan, Montana, Nebraska, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New York, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, South Carolina, South Dakota, Tennessee, Texas, Virginia, and Washington.

DOC.HEAD: High Court May Test Job Rights Under Old Anti-Bias Law
With AM-Scotus Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court indicated interest Monday in an important civil rights issue - whether a Civil War-era law enacted primarily to protect freed slaves bans racially discriminatory firings. The justices asked the Bush administration for its views on the issue, urging Justice Department lawyers to comment on a ruling that the manufacturer of Buster Brown shoes was guilty of illegal racial bias when it fired a white supervisor at a Missouri warehouse. After hearing from the government lawyers, which could be months away, the court will decide whether it wants to hear the case. Kenneth Hicks, a white foreman with the Brown Shoe Company, was fired in 1982 after 34 years with the firm. The company, in trimming its work force, dismissed Hicks while keeping another supervisor, Alvin Chester, who is black. Hicks said he was fired because of his race, even though he had more seniority than Chester. The shoe company asked the high court to overturn rulings in favor of Hicks, who was awarded $10,000 in punitive damages and nearly $21,000 more in attorney fees. The Supreme Court, in a highly publicized ruling in 1989 on the Civil War-era law, left unanswered whether the act specifically applies to racially biased firings. The law at issue was enacted in 1866 and provides that ``all persons ... shall have the same right...to make and enforce contracts ... and to the full and equal benefit of all laws ... enjoyed by white citizens.'' The 1964 Civil Rights law offers similar protection. But the older statute authorizes broader remedies, particularly punitive damages. In another civil rights case Monday the court refused to postpone a Jan. 22 election under a redistricting plan designed to help elect a Hispanic to the Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors for the first time in 115 years. The court rejected an emergency request by board members, who said the plan ordered by a federal judge is unlawful. But the justices took no action on a formal appeal by board members still pending before the high court. The five-member board was accused by Hispanics in 1988 of violating their rights by drawing districts after the 1980 census that allegedly diluted Hispanic voting strength. U.S. District Judge David V. Kenyon declared the former district plan unconstitutional and carved out a new district in which Hispanics account for an estimated 51 percent of the registered voters and 71 percent of the population. The Bush administration sided with Hispanic rights groups in urging the Supreme Court not to disturb Kenyon's ruling, which was upheld last month by the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals.

DOC.HEAD: President-Elect Walesa Returns To Shipyard Where His Battle Began
LaserPhoto GDA50
DOC.TEXT: President-elect Lech Walesa returned to his old shipyard Monday and appealed for help in building a new government. Prosecutors said his defeated challenger must remain in Poland to answer slander charges. Walesa spent the day wrapping up Solidarity duties, one day after his landslide victory over businessman Stanislaw Tyminski in Poland's first popular presidential election. Union leaders began selecting a new chairman. They also began preparing for free spring parliamentary elections, when Solidarity may form a political wing, and planning for the expected exodus of activists to the government in Warsaw. ``I have to think as the president,'' said Walesa, touring offices in the Baltic seaside town of Sopot, where he will work when not at Belweder Palace in Warsaw. Challenger Stanislaw Tyminski, apparently conceding defeat, sent Walesa a two-sentence telegram wishing him success. ``I hope you will not make a lot of mistakes and you can create conditions for normal life in a strong, independent Poland,'' he said. Walesa will be sworn in to a five-year term as president about Dec. 21, barring protests of the vote, parliament Speaker Mikolaj Kozakiewicz said. Walesa received 74.25 percent of the vote to Tyminski's 25.75 percent, according to national election commission results. About 14.2 million people voted. Turnout was put at 53 percent, compared with 60 percent during the first round of voting Nov. 25. Walesa took time for two emotional tributes. He visited the department where he fixed electric carts when the Gdansk Shipyard was still named for Lenin. On Tuesday he was to travel - like Poland's kings - to pay homage before the Black Madonna icon at Jasna Gora monastery in Czestochowa, Poland's holiest shrine. At the shipyard, where he led his first strike almost exactly 20 years ago during December 1970 food riots, the 47-year-old Walesa asked his old foreman and co-workers to ``be my support.'' ``I am going to return here often and I am going to do everything for you,'' he told workers. ``I know where I have this white shirt from and I know that my overalls here were the same as yours, sometimes even dirtier.'' Walesa carried every province, according to unofficial results. Tyminski did best in rural areas, where farmers are discontented with economic reforms that nolonger guarantee a minimum price for their products but have not dismantled the purchasing monopolies. ``There are many people in Poland for whom it is really bad,'' Walesa said. ``We must ... make Poland such that those doubters quickly join us.'' Walesa is under pressure to chart quickly policies that will continue Poland's painful course toward a market economy while answering the dissatisfaction of Tyminski's sizable minority. He has promised by Wednesday to pick among the candidates he is considering for prime minister. Tyminski suggested Sunday night he might challenge the returns, but election officials reported no contact with him. He vowed to remain active in Polish politics. ``Even if there are difficulties, I am now the second person in Poland. That is our victory,'' he said. A local prosecutor in southern Poland lodged the slander case against Tyminski after he accused Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki of treason by creating economic chaos. Tyminski defeated Mazowiecki in the first round of presidential voting. Walesa said Tyminski ought to account for unsubstantiated allegations, but added that for now: ``It is a government matter.'' A Dec. 7 order summoned Tyminski for questioning before the prosecutor in Nowy Sacz, and the general prosecutor in Warsaw confirmed to the PAP news agency that steps were taken ``ensuring Tyminski's presence in the country until the hearing.'' After questioning, it will be determined if Tyminski must stay in Poland until a verdict on the slander case, the ministry said. PAP quoted sources as saying Tyminski and his wife, whose children are in Toronto, had booked airline tickets Wednesday to Canada. Tyminski has Canadian, Peruvian and Polish citizenships. Meanwhile, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev was among the first to wish Walesa success: ``History and life prove convincingly the need to develop cooperation and interaction between our states and peoples,'' Tass said. Among others congratulating him were President Bush, outgoing President Wojciech Jaruzelski, who interned Walesa after declaring martial law nine years ago Thursday, and Mazowiecki, who resigned after his defeat.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Cites Plight of Kuwaitis in Human Rights Proclamation
DOC.TEXT: President Bush emphasized the plight of the people of Kuwait as he signed a Human Rights Day proclamation on Monday. Despite progress in some countries, ``millions of men, women and children around the world continue to be denied the freedom to live, work and worship as they wish,'' the president said. ``Nowhere is that situation more tragic and more urgent today than in Kuwait,'' Bush told an audience of 150. ``We must speak out and stand up for the Kuwaiti people, a people whose very nation is now in the grasp of a tyrant unmoved by human decency,'' said Bush. ``The eyewitness accounts that I have heard from Kuwaiti citizens are a catalog of human misery: looting, torture, rape, summary execution, acts of unspeakable cruelty. What has happened to Kuwait is more than an invasion. It is a systematic assault on the soul of a nation.'' The document proclaimed Monday as Human Rights Day and urged Americans to observe this week as Human Rights Week. The president, joined by former Chief Justice Warren Burger, also designated this Saturday as Bill of Rights Day. Burger heads a commission that is coordinating events marking the 200th anniversary of the Bill of Rights, the first 10 amendments to the Constitution.

DOC.HEAD: Godfather III Star Deplores Latino Label
DOC.NOTE: For release at 6 p.m. EST, time set by source
DOC.TEXT: Compliment him on his hairy chest. Compliment him on his natty wardrobe. But don't call ``Godfather III'' star Andy Garcia a ``Hispanic heartthrob.'' ``There's nothing that I cherish more than my culture and what I am,'' Garcia says in January's Glamour magazine. ``But to call me the great Hispanic actor is ridiculous; it's racism. They don't call Dustin Hoffman the great Jewish-American actor.'' Garcia's family fled Cuba for Miami in 1961 when he was 5. Garcia, 34, who plays Vincent Mancini, the illegitimate son of Sonny Corleone in the latest ``Godfather'' movie, says his Cuban heritage is ``the source of my strength.'' But it also caused him to get boxed into Latino roles during his 13-year career, which included parts in ``The Untouchables,'' ``Internal Affairs'' and ``Black Rain.'' Though his fame is increasing, Garcia's ego apparently is not. Told he looks handsome in the tuxedo he wears in the movie, Garcia bowed his head and told the interviewer: ``Vincent thanks you.'' Told the interviewer also was fond of his ``glorious chest,'' the actor replied: ``I can't take responsibility for the chest. It's a genetic thing.''

DOC.HEAD: Electrician President Returns to Shipyard, Greets Old Workmates
With AM-Poland, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Keeping his oft-repeated election promise that he would work relentessly, President-elect Lech Walesa clocked in at Solidarity headquarters just after 9 a.m. Monday - only hours after his landslide victory. Walesa used his first full day as president-elect to touch base with union supporters, make a nostalgic visit to his former workplace and consult with advisers on government appointments. Arriving in a new Volvo escorted by three police cars, Walesa promised ecstatic supporters waiting there to ``always return to my union roots.'' The headquarters is just steps from the Gdansk Shipyard where it all began. He said he would make a pilgrimage Tuesday to the Black Madonna of Czestochowa in southern Poland - the icon whose image he wears on his left lapel - in thanks for his election victory. Then he went on to the shipyard where time and again h defied the former Communist government. ``I remember that I came from the shipyard and I came from there without a tie and a suit,'' he said surrounded by former workmates. As he walked through the shipyard one of the workers called out: ``Neither you nor Tyminski are fit for the presidency.'' ``You've always been like that. You haven't changed a bit,'' came Walesa's reply, flippant as he often is when talking to the workers who have provided the backbone of his electorate. He went on to the department where he fixed electrical carts while still at the shipyard, to be greeted by his old foreman. ``I knew it would happen some day,'' his former boss said. ``You have to come and help me now,'' Walesa replied. ``I am going to return here often and I am going to do everything for you to live better,'' he told those who had stood alongside him so often in the past. ``I know where I have this white shirt from and I know that my overalls here were the same as yours, sometimes even dirtier,'' he said. Frequently during his campaign Walesa claimed he did not want to be president, but had to be in order to rescue Poland during the difficult times that lie ahead. ``I will ... return here and ask you (for advice), and I will do it for you and not for myself.'' ``This is what we hope for,'' a worker said. ``All people at the top should follow you and work for the nation and not for themselves,'' another added. ``But he's our president, don't worry,'' another answered. Earlier, speaking at Solidarity headquarters, Walesa said: ``The union will get strengthened. I will help the union very much, remembering that here are my roots.''

DOC.HEAD: Dispute Over Blind Minister's Guide Dog Resolved
DOC.TEXT: A blind clergyman can return to the pulpit after a 10-week absence now that he's won permission to have his guide dog in church. The decision was announced at Sunday's service at Mount Zion AME church. The Rev. Le Roy Singleton, an associate pastor, was sitting in the fourth row with his wife, Emma, and his guide dog, Digby. Singleton's vision had been failing for years because of glaucoma and diabetes. He got the German shepherd-collie mixed breed in September, but he said the Rev. Ellsworth Coleman, the church's pastor, told him the dog was not welcome in the church. Singleton, who had been sitting in the pulpit, moved to the back pews with the dog, saying he did not want to cause any problems in the church. He also stopped performing ministerial duties. Singleton blamed a church member, whom he did not identify, for causing the dispute. ``This person caused the dissension, saying that when Reverend Singleton gets back with his dog, you won't even be able to shake his hand and you won't even be able to get close to talk to him or this dog will chew you up. ... This is not an attack dog,'' Singleton said. The dispute ended Saturday after a meeting between Singleton and Coleman and the decision was announced the next day. ``I'm allowed to come in church and I'm allowed to sit where I want to sit and that's all I wanted from the beginning,'' Singleton, 62, told the congregation. ``There will be times when I will be asked to preach again and that's solely up to him (Coleman),'' Singleton said. ``We stand now united together,'' Coleman said. Earlene A. Hughes, president of the Delaware affiliate of the National Federation of the Blind, said she believes the issue is resolved. ``The public needs to be more aware that blind persons are capable of leading normal and productive lives as much as their sighted partners and I hope that this will be an educational experience for the people of Delaware,'' Hughes said. The federation became involved because it wanted to make sure Singleton was not a victim of discrimination.

DOC.HEAD: Premier Says Communists Ready To Decide Economic Strategy
DOC.TEXT: Premier Li Peng said Monday the Communist Party Central Committee is finally ready to decide on the economic strategy that will guide China into the 21st century. ``I believe the time for convening that meeting is now completely ripe and I am sure that we can achieve the expected results,'' Li said at the airport before leaving on a 10-day tour of Southeast Asia. He will visit Laos, becoming the first Chinese premier to do so, as well as the Philippines, Sri Lanka and the first stop, Malaysia. The 175-member party Central Committee generally meets in the early autumn. It was expected to do so this year to approve new Five- and Ten-Year Plans for the economy to take effect on Jan. 1, when the old plans expire. But intense backstage wrangling over the pace of economic reform and development priorities has stalled the drafting of plans. Li said the Central Committee will meet at the end of December, but did not give a specific date. He said the economic plans will be the only agenda item, dispelling rumors that several ministerial changes also will be discussed. The act of convening a Central Committee meeting indicates that some basic agreement on economic policy has been reached. The Chinese traditionally try to avoid open debate at such meetings and keep arguments to informal settings. Officials have been arguing about a host of issues, including how much control the central government should have over the economy, how much revenue provinces should give the center and whether state-set prices should be raised or freed from control. The economic arguments cloak a struggle over ideology and power. China's power broker of the past decade, senior leader Deng Xiaoping, has lost prestige since endorsing the army attack on pro-democracy demonstrators last year, and his public appearances and statements are rarer than ever. Li, asked at the airport if Deng still has final say over important matters, answered ambiguously. ``We have successfully established a new generation of leadership with Comrade Jiang Zemin as the nucleus,'' he said, referring to the party general secretary. ``This new leadership is entirely capaable of being responsible for all affairs within China. Naturally, the thinking and writings of Comrade Deng Xiaoping ... still have a positive influence on us and are still useful to us.'' He added that Deng, 86, is in good health. Unofficial reports say Deng has suffered from cancer for several years, and rumors have circulated recently that his health has become much worse. He has not been seen in public since July and has turned down requests for meetings by several prominent foreign visitors. Li also was asked if foreign observers will be allowed to attend trials of prominent activists jailed since last year's crushed democracy movement. The premier said only that the cases would be handled ``according to legal procedures,'' and that government policy was ``very lenient.'' About a dozen leading participants in the democracy movement were formally charged or had court hearings in the past month. Trial dates have not been announced. Trials in China are not open to the general public and foreigners are rarely allowed to attend.

DOC.HEAD: Immigrant Finds Brother Who Survived Holocaust, 51 Years Later
DOC.TEXT: Half a century after fleeing to the Soviet Union from Nazi-occupied in Poland, Yaacov Eichel immigrated to Israel and was reunited with a younger brother who survived the Holocaust without Eichel knowing. ``I'm in seventh heaven,'' a beaming Eichel, 66, said in Yiddish on Israel television Monday. ``It is so surprising and dreamlike ... difficult to describe in words,'' said brother Mordechai, 59, from northern Israel, who Hebraized his family name to Allon. Eichel came from Tashkent three months ago. He said he went to the Yad Vashem Holocaust Memorial in Jerusalem after years of unsuccessful attempts to track his family's whereabouts in the Soviet Union and Poland. That's where he found a list of what happened to the Eichel family that Allon filed in 1955 after he came to Israel. A Yad Vashem archivist was able to locate Allon, and the two brothers met this week in the West Bank settlement of Maale Adumim, the Yedioth Ahronoth newspaper said. Allon said his brother fled their home in Warsaw in 1939 shortly after the Germans invaded Poland. ``Mom saw there was a danger and he was already old enough so she told him, run away and rescue yourself,'' Allon said. Eichel made it to an uncle's home in Tashkent and had some contact with his family through letters until the Germans besieged the Soviets. ``Since then I knew nothing of what happened to him,'' Allon said. He said his parents and two other brothers were shoved with the rest of the city's Jews into the Warsaw Ghetto. All but Allon either died in Nazi death camps and or were shot dead by the Nazis in Warsaw. He had managed to find shelter with Jewish partisans in Warsaw until the Russian Army liberated the city in 1945.

DOC.HEAD: T-Bill Rates Fall to Lowest Level in Two Years
DOC.TEXT: Interest rates on short-term Treasury securities fell in Monday's auction to their lowest level in more than two years. The Treasury Department sold $10.1 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 6.86 percent, down from 7.06 percent last week. Another $10 billion was sold in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 6.74 percent, down from 6.96 percent last week. The rates were the lowest since three-month bills sold for 6.76 percent on July 18, 1988, and six-month bills averaged 6.71 percent on July 5, 1988. The new discount rates understate the actual return to investors - 7.08 percent for three-month bills with a $10,000 bill selling for $9,826.60 and 7.07 percent for a six-month bill selling for $9,659.30. In a separate report, the Federal Reserve said Monday that the average yield for one-year Treasury bills, the most popular index for making changes in adjustable rate mortgages, fell to 7.24 percent last week from 7.30 percent the previous week.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
FDA Approves New Contraceptive
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration today approved the first major new contraceptive in three decades - an implant that protects women against pregnancy for up to five years. The device, called Norplant, consists of six matchstick-sized silicone rubber capsules containing a hormone that is released slowly over time. The capsules are implanted in the upper arm of a woman in a minor surgical procedure that requires only local anesthesia. Fertility is restored when the capsules are removed. The device is more than 99 percent effective, meaning that for every 100 women who use it, at most one will become pregnant, says the New York-based Population Council, which developed Norplant. It will be marketed by Wyeth-Ayerst Laboratories of Philadelphia. The device has been approved in 16 countries, where half a million women have used it, according to the council. Many family planning experts consider Norplant to be the biggest advance in birth control since oral contraceptives and the intrauterine device, or IUD, were approved in the early 1960s. Norplant contains nothing new. The hormone, a synthetic progestin, has been used safely for years, council officials say. Wyeth-Ayerst has not released price information for the product.

DOC.HEAD: Hayes Wants Tombstone to Reflect Triumphs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to CLARIFY by changing `said' to `heard'
DOC.TEXT: Actress Helen Hayes, who isn't bashful about her success on the stage and screen, says she wants her tombstone to reflect her triumphs. Miss Hayes, 90, told the Hollywood Women's Press Club she wants to take her epitaph from a line in a play she did about Queen Victoria. In the play, a rough-looking man breaks through police lines at Victoria's 90th birthday celebration and shouts, ``Go it, old girl. You've done well.'' ``I've always meant, since I (heard) that line, to have it put on my tombstone,'' Miss Hayes said. Miss Hayes made the remark at the press club's Golden Apple luncheon Sunday. She and actor Dennis Weaver received Louella O. Parsons Awards, given in recognition to performers who project outstanding images in the entertainment industry. ``I can't imagine why someone who was so briefly in film should receive it, but I'm happy, and I'm not humble about it,'' Miss Hayes said of the award. ``I feel proud as a lord and 10 feet tall.'' Patrick Swayze and Whoopi Goldberg, two stars of the hit film ``Ghost,'' received Golden Apples as the male and female star of the year. The group's Sour Apple trophy went to Zsa Zsa Gabor.

DOC.HEAD: Pakistan Completes Census; Population Could Double By 2020
DOC.TEXT: Pakistan completed a nationwide census on Monday, and analysts say the new right-wing government has little time to find a way to cope with the nation's soaring birthrate. Conservative estimates put Pakistan's current population at about 120 million, almost 40 million more than in 1980. At that rate, family planning experts say, the population will double by the year 2020. This was the first census in a decade in Pakistan, one of the world's fastest-growing countries. Census takers had been going from tents to dried-mud houses to palatial mansions since Nov. 22. By the time the results are released in about six months, hundreds of thousands of children will have been born. The burgeoning population threatens to devour the country's already meager resources. Pakistan, a predominantly Moslem nation, produces a child every eight seconds. Observers say that kind of growth could lead to economic collapse. ``If they don't deal with this soon, they'll be facing a disaster in five to 10 years. It's a nightmare that nobody wants,'' said one Western diplomat, who asked not to be identified. Pakistan's birthrate stands at 3.2 percent, well ahead of the 2 percent in India, its neighbor to the east. So far, there is little evidence the new government is eager to embark on an ambitious family planning program. The Social Services ministry, responsible for encouraging small families in Pakistan, is headed by a fundamentalist Moslem, Saddar Niazi, who boasts of being one of 15 children. He said the pressure for family planning is a holdover from the liberal secularism of former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto, who was ousted Aug. 6 on charges of corruption and ineffectiveness, and overwhelmingly defeated in national elections three months later. Most Pakistani women have an average of six to seven children, the highest fertility rate in Asia, and only 11 percent of couples of childbearing age use contraceptives. Most rural women are veiled at puberty and bartered into marriage as early as 15. Most women have at least four living children by the time they turn 30. Almost as many would have died at childbirth or before the age of five. Proponents of family planning struggle against conservative views of Islamic clerics. When women consider birth control, they are often chastised for defying what is called God's grand design. The National Institute of Population Studies has warned that even if Pakistan became a nation of two-child families, the population would grow to 160 million in the next several decades. Just to keep the current standard of living, ``we must double all our infrastructure, hospitals, schools, housing, food production, water resources and factories,'' said spokesman Mohammad Sheikh. Pakistan's infrastructure is dilapidated. Health care is inadequate and available only in the cities and towns. Khurshed Ahmed, a senator and member of the ultra-orthodox Jamaat-i-Islami, or Party of God, said there was no need for family planning. Education and affluence would check population growth, he said. But Pakistan is desperately short of schools. More than 52 percent of Pakistan's budget is spent on defense and a meager 4 percent on education. Less than 17 percent of the population as a whole can read or write, and the percentage is far smaller for women.

DOC.HEAD: Former Customs Commissioner Testifies in Defense of DeConcini
DOC.NOTE: EDs: To update with afternoon testimony, Inserts grafs 12-15, Later a former. Should stand for PMs.
DOC.TEXT: A former customs commissioner testified in defense of Sen. Dennis DeConcini today, telling the Senate Ethics Committee that intervention with government agencies is proper and not limited by ethical standards. ``Whatever approach a senator took, so long as it was not unlawful, was acceptable to me,'' said William von Raab, commissioner of the U.S. Customs Service during the Reagan administration. But von Raab also acknowledged he had never faced pressure from senators under the same circumstances DeConcini and other senators are accused of applying. ``There were massive interventions'' by members of Congress seeking changes in regulations or waivers for specific constituents when he was in office, he said. ``It was standard operating procedure,'' von Raab, a Republican, told DeConcini's lawyer, James Hamilton. Von Raab testified during the 15th day of the ethic panel's hearings into allegations that DeConcini, D-Ariz., and four other senators improperly intervened with S&L regulators on behalf of Charles H. Keating Jr., who contributed $1.3 million to their campaigns and favored causes. Von Raab said that not only was it common for members of Congress to meet privately with regulators on behalf of constituents, it also was common for them to do so even when regulators had referred the case to the Justice Department for criminal investigation. But under cross-examination by the committee's special counsel, Robert S. Bennett, he said he had no direct knowledge of the senators' efforts for Keating - and that he hadn't faced the same kind of intervention the senators are accused of applying. DeConcini faces accusations by witnesses that he tried to negotiate a deal on behalf of Keating's Lincoln Savings and Loan and continued to press regulators after being told of potential criminal activity at the thrift. Von Raab said he sometimes refused to make changes DeConcini wanted, and in one case DeConcini's position was upheld in the courts. ``Sen. DeConcini was always firm, resolute, but always fair,'' he said. Later, a former tax accountant for Keating's company, American Continental Corp., testified about flights Sen. John McCain, R-Ariz., and his family took on the company's aircraft. David Stevens estimated the value of the flights by McCain, his wife Cindy, their child and a babysitter, going back to 1984, at $16,870.46. McCain repaid two of the flights at the time and more in 1989, when the Internal Revenue Service examined the company's books. Stevens said in a letter to the committee that he ``never saw any evidence that he (McCain) originally inended to reimburse for the costs of his wife and babysitter.'' But he said under questioning he did not know McCain's intent and regretted the conclusions in his letter. Stevens said that after he wrote offering his testimony, DeConcini called to request he sign an affidavit. In their call, he said, DeConcini complained that McCain had received more favorable treatment than he had from ethics investigator and wanted Stevens' testimony to show that only a one-sided case had been presented. Other witnesses testified in DeConcini's defense, describing help he provided for law enforcement, drug-treatment projects and disabled veterans. They said he acted without regard to campaign contributions. ``I could not imagine how he could have done anything more,'' said Rod Mullin, who runs an assistance program for the poor. Evidence presented so far has been particularly damaging for the two senators seen as in the worst trouble, Democrats Alan Cranston of California and DeConcini. None of the senators could have liked the description that witness William K. Black offered last week of their April 1987 meeting with federal regulators. The senators were told of Lincoln S&L's reckless and potentially criminal practices. ``This is an institution that is probably the worst institution in America,'' Black recounted. ``And instead of trying to help bring it under control, five U.S. senators were pushing us in the opposite direction. It was startlingly the wrong direction.'' The other three senators are Democrats John Glenn of Ohio and Donald Riegle of Michigan and Republican John McCain of Arizona. All sides are awaiting the testimony of James Grogan, a former top aide and lobbyist for Keating. He has been given limited immunity from prosecution for his testimony, which will be given in private Dec. 17 and in public later. Federal regulators, and even one of DeConcini's own aides, have described him as pressing on to help his friend and contributor, Keating, despite strong warnings. Laurie A. Sedlmayr, DeConcini's aide on banking issues, testified she didn't like Keating and warned her boss that it would be a ``political mistake'' to go to a critical April 2, 1987, meeting on Lincoln that four of the senators held with top regulator Edwin J. Gray. DeConcini ``thanked me for my suggestion and said he was going to go ahead anyway,'' she said. Gray, the former Reagan administration thrift regulator, repeated his allegations that DeConcini offered a deal in that April 2 meeting. The meeting itself was improper, he said, because he felt pressured by the senators on behalf of one institution. Michael Patriarca and Black, both San Francisco-based regulators, described DeConcini as offering a deal on Lincoln and said none of the other senators dissented or distanced themselves from the offer. Black contended that pressure from the senators led to the Federal Home Loan Bank Board's May 1988 decision to ease off new regulatory controls proposed for Lincoln. The bank board revised its hard-line policy after Cranston aide Carolyn Jordan called to express displeasure. Her call had been set in motion by a call from Grogan, Keating's lobbyist, complaining about the bank board's action. The result of the board's change was that the eventual takeover of Lincoln was delayed and the cost of the taxpayers' bailout of insured deposits was increased, Black said. And, he said, it meant Lincoln was able to sell more uninsured junk bonds to people - many of them elderly - who became victims of Lincoln's collapse. Keating faces fraud charges in California stemming from the sale of those junk bonds.

DOC.HEAD: President Asks for Broad Powers to Keep Country Together
DOC.TEXT: President Vaclav Havel appealed to Parliament on Monday for new powers to keep Czechoslovakia from splitting in two as it wrestles with vestiges of Communist rule. The former dissident and playwright, who became president in Czechoslovakia's revolution last year, has preferred to govern with moral authority. But he said he was forced to act because a dispute over division of powers between the federal government and the Czech and Slovak republics threatens the country's future. ``I am very sorry I had to go this far,'' Havel said in an emergency speech, broadcast live on national TV. ``I am doing this to fulfill the expectations of millions of citizens who ... entrusted this position to me and believe I will help save our federation.'' Slovak leaders are said to be ready to declare the sovereignty of their laws on Slovak territory unless the federal Parliament approves a division of powers that they find acceptable. The state news agency CTK quoted Deputy Premier Pavel Rychetsky as saying Havel should be given power to ask for a non-partisan government of experts in times of crisis, to rule by decree if Parliament has been dissolved and to veto legislation. Havel currently has the power to sign treaties, command the armed forces, appoint the federal government, summon and dissolve parliament, sign its laws, grant amnesties or other legal pardons and declare war. His extraordinary powers, if granted, would be in effect until a new constitution is approved. That is to take place in the next 18 months. Initial Slovak reaction to Havel's speech ranged from no comment from top leaders to criticism from Christian Democrats, one of three members of the governing coalition in Slovakia. ``I disagree with strengthening the presidential position to delegate law-making powers to the president,'' said Jan Petrik, the executive secretary of the Christian Democratic Movement. ``I cannot agree with the concentration of uncontrollable power in the hands of the president,'' Petrik said in the Slovak capital, Bratislava. The CTK news agency quoted Slovak deputy Anton Andras as saying, ``I consider the proposal to give broader powers to the president unfortunate and unsuitable. We have had this before.'' Andras, until recently Slovak interior minister, was alluding to the authoritarian Communist rule. Czechoslovakia formally became a federation in 1968. But hard-line Communist rule meant Slovaks felt controlled by Prague, the Czech and federal capital. Czechs meanwhile resented the allocation of half the country's resources to just one third of its people, the approximately 5 million Slovaks. Czechoslovakia is embarking on an ambitious reform program in which the state-owned economy will be turned over to private hands. But Western leaders repeatedly have warned that political instability will hamper the foreign investment and aid that the economy badly needs. A law dividing powers among the federal government and the two republics was to be debated by Parliament on Tuesday, when Havel was scheduled to leave on a visit to Spain and Portugal. The bill on presidential powers was to be debated later. That leaves the issue of strong new presidential powers hanging over deputies while they discuss dividing government functions. The Czech and Slovak parliaments differ over control of oil and gas pipelines, taxation and budget questions, postal services, control over policy toward ethnic minorities and chairmanship of the national bank. An agreement forged last month between the Czech, Slovak and federal governments keeps foreign policy, defense, general economic and monetary policy under federal control. To prolonged applause from Parliament, Havel stressed that sovereignty of Slovak law on Slovak territory would be unconstitutional. The federal Parliament's decisions should be binding ``on all institutions and on all people,'' he said. Otherwise, ``the thin ice of our constitution will be broken and our state would inevitably fall into legal chaos,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Congressional Report Critical of Mail Standard Change
DOC.TEXT: The Postal Service should rescind a decision to reduce delivery standards for some mail, a report prepared for Congress said Monday. The post office cut back some overnight delivery areas in July, saying the changes would save money and improve efficiency. The agency said the changes would slow delivery of only about 5 percent of first-class mail. The change could slow delivery of as many as 4.3 billion pieces of mail over a year, according to the General Accounting Office report ``Just Say Slow.'' In 1989, the post office carried 85.8 billion pieces of first-class mail. Five percent of that would be 4.3 billion. The report charged that the Postal Service implemented the change without demonstrating that it would lead to any improvement for the public. ``Our investigation indicates that many customers - especially those in rural America - will suffer because of the new standards,'' Rep. Bob Wise, D-W. Va., said in a statement. Wise is chairman of the government information subcommittee of the House Government Operations Committee, which released the report. The independent Postal Rate Commission has also criticized the change in delivery standards. The changes primarily affect areas where mail standards had called for overnight or second-day delivery, but the post office had performed poorly in meeting those goals. In general, for example, a pair of cities with relatively low volume might have been shifted from overnight to second-day delivery or from second to third-day delivery in the change. Postal officials had no immediate response to the report.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela To Tour Troubled Townships
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela has accepted an invitation to join political, business and church leaders on a tour of violence-plagued black townships, the African National Congress said Monday. There was no word on whether rival Inkatha leader Mangosuthu Buthelezi would take part in Wednesday's tour organized by the anti-apartheid South African Council of Churches. Buthelezi said Sunday he had not received an invitation. Police said 27 people died in violence throughout the country over the weekend and on Monday, including 13 in the Tokoza township south of Johannesburg. Wednesday's tour would include a stop in Tokoza. Two Inkatha supporters were shot to death and eight seriously wounded early Monday when a taxi they were riding in was ambushed by gunfire in eastern Natal Province, the independent South African Press Association reported. The report said the unidentified attackers used AK-47 assault rifles. An Inkatha official on Monday accused police of instigating attacks on Inkatha members in Tokoza over the weekend. There was no immediate government response, but police and the government have repeatedly denied similar charges by the ANC. Mandela and President F.W. de Klerk announced Sunday they had held secret meetings in the last week to discuss the violence. The brief joint statement said progress had been made and further talks would be held, but it provided no details of other steps to be taken. Supporters of the Zulu-dominated Inkatha Freedom Party have been fighting Xhosas and other blacks loyal to the ANC for five years in Natal, leaving more than 5,000 people dead. The virtual warfare spread to townships near Johannesburg in August, killing about 1,000 people. Both Mandela and Buthelezi have called for the violence to end, but their supporters have continued fighting. Buthelezi has called for a one-on-one meeting with Mandela, saying they are the only leaders with the power to halt the violence. But the ANC has rejected the idea. It blames Buthelezi for instigating the violence in a bid to gain legitimacy outside of Natal, the traditional Zulu homeland. Mandela attended a summit of black leaders convened last month by Anglican Archbishop Desmond Tutu, but Buthelezi turned down the invitation. He said such a meeting would waste time unless the ANC and Inkatha first cleared up their differences. A meeting between the leadership of the two black opposition groups, including Mandela and Buthelezi, also had been planned, but was postponed indefinitely. The ANC said scheduling problems caused the postponement. On Sunday, an Inkatha congress called for the ANC to work with other anti-apartheid groups in seeking an end to violence and a quick start of negotiations with the white-led government on ending apartheid. De Klerk has pledged to end apartheid and negotiate a new constitution with all parties that would give political power to the black majority. The ANC and the government have held peace talks since May on setting up the full-scale negotiations, expected to begin next year. But the violence has strained relations between them, with the ANC repeatedly accusing security forces of fueling the violence and siding with Inkatha. An official of the militant Pan Africanist Congress said Monday his group and the ANC would meet soon to discuss forming a unified front to fight apartheid. But the PAC on Sunday rejected an invitation to join the planned negotiations with the government on a new constitution, saying only a freely elected constituent assembly had the power to draft a constitution.

DOC.HEAD: N.Y. Democrat Forms Group to Back Hard Line in Gulf Crisis
With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Stephen Solarz on Monday announced the formation of a diverse group of government, academic and labor leaders that will seek to push President Bush to take a harder line in the Persian Gulf crisis. The liberal New York Democrat, who has acknowledged worries that his party may suffer long-term political damage if it is seen as being too soft on Iraq, said he hoped to counter congressional critics who say Bush seems too eager to use military force against Saddam Hussein. The group, the Committee for Peace and Security in the Gulf, issued a statement endorsing the threat of military force as an essential part of a strategy that also includes economic sanctions and diplomatic isolation. It also sought to focus attention on Saddam's arsenal of conventional, chemical and biological weapons, and on his efforts to build a nuclear bomb. In addition to forcing Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait, ``We believe that we must also find ways to remove Saddam Hussein's capacity to wage aggression,'' the group said. The threat requires that Iraq's weapons of mass destruction ``be verifiably dismantled, or if necessary destroyed,'' it said. A Solarz spokesman, Bob Hathaway, said while the administration has spoken vaguely of a need for ``security in the region'' once the immediate crisis is resolved, the committee ``thinks it's necessary for the administration to go further by directly confronting this issue.'' The committee hopes to take out newspaper ads and hold seminars in Washington and around the country on topics like military options in the gulf and the usefulness of economic sanctions. It also hopes to sponsor speaking tours for group members. The group includes figures as diverse as former Democratic Party political director Ann Lewis and Reagan administration Pentagon official Richard Perle, its two co-directors. In addition to Solarz, the group includes senators Richard Lugar, R-Ind., and John McCain, R-Ariz., and Reps. Tom Lantos, D-Calif.; Dave McCurdy, D-Okla.; John Murtha, D-Pa., and Robert Torricelli, D-N.J. ``It's a tribute to Saddam Hussein's power to bring people together,'' joked Perle, who said Solarz began forming the group about six weeks ago. ``We were concerned about where things were headed,'' said Perle, who now is a scholar at the American Enterprise Institute, a conservative think tank.

DOC.HEAD: Declaration Drafted to End Superpower Involvement in Afghanistan
DOC.TEXT: A declaration providing a face-saving superpower exit from the Afghanistan conflict has been drafted by U.S. and Soviet officials and could be released this week, diplomatic sources said Monday. The three-point document is deliberately vague and would let the Afghans decide how to settle the 12-year-old war, said the sources, speaking on condition of anonymity. The declaration falls far short of bringing an end to the conflict, they said. But pressure has been increasing for both sides to clear Afghanistan from the superpower agenda before the Jan. 15 deadline for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. The document could be released during the current talks between Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze in Houston, the sources said. Washington's special envoy to the Afghan resistance, Peter Tomsen, was expected in Pakistan on Tuesday. He was prepared to explain any superpower announcement to the Afghan guerrillas, who have been trying since 1978 to overthrow the Soviet-supported government in Kabul, the sources said. ``We anticipate an announcement,'' one diplomat said, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``It's been in the cards for some time. It may or may not happen this time. We're poised but it could be another false alarm.'' The announcement had been expected during last month's Baker-Shevardnadze talks in Geneva but was delayed by differences over how to cut off weapons to both warring sides, they said. The Soviet Union sent about 115,000 troops into Afghanistan in December 1979 to prop up successive Communist governments trying to impose radical reforms on the largely rural Moslem population. After the Red Army's pullout in February 1989, Moscow continued to pour an estimated $2 billion to $3 billion annually in weapons and supplies to support troops loyal to President Najibullah. Western diplomats and guerrilla leaders once confidently measured the survival of Najibullah's government in weeks and months. But the guerrillas were unable to switch from their hit-and-run tactics to conventional warfare and were rendered helpless against the well-equipped and well-trained Afghan air force. Within months of the Soviet withdrawal, the anticipated guerrilla victory became a costly military stalemate that failed to produce a clear victory for either side. With the guerrillas controlling the countryside and Najibullah's troops holding the cities, the superpowers began searching for diplomatic formulas to extricate themselves from a war that has left more than 1.5 million people dead and sent nearly 6 million Afghans into exile in Pakistan and Iran. Diplomatic sources say the draft declaration is purposely vague and advocates no concrete peace plan for the Afghans, fiercely independent tribal people who throughout history have resisted, often violently, the tutelage of outsiders.

DOC.HEAD: The Gang That Couldn't Stay Put
DOC.TEXT: When the social club run by hard-boiled reputed mobster Venero ``Benny Eggs'' Mangano was evicted, the mob's cobblers resisted any urge to fit the landlord for concrete shoes. Instead, the Greenwich Village neighborhood was covered with posters, banners and petitions in an unsuccessful campaign to ``Keep the Club.'' Non-violence failed to sway landlord Martin Herzog, a brave and thrifty soul who claims an art gallery or boutique will pay $3,500 a month for the storefront that Mangano rented for $250. ``I've known Benny Eggs and the rest of those guys for 25 years,'' Herzog said. ``I'm not afraid of them. I'm only afraid of God.'' Law enforcers describe Mangano, a short, bald 69-year-old, as No. 2 man in the Genovese crime family, the nation's second largest. The nameless club at 101 Thompson St. was frequented by old men from the neighborhood, who would chat, play cards or sip a drink at the tables inside. When the weather was warm, they'd hang out on the sidewalk. No one claims all or even most of them were criminals, and their presence comforted residents worried about street crime. Benny Eggs also met business associates at the club, but in recent years he had done most of his talking while strolling around the block, said a federal prosecutor who spoke on condition he not be identified. Before the eviction, posters appeared around the neighborhood. ``So far we have been able to keep hard drugs off the street. When we move, the drug dealers and criminals will know,'' they warned. ``Keep the Club!'' proclaimed a banner unfurled from a fire escape on the front of the building. Several young occupants of the apartments above the club, people who did not grow up in the neighborhood but valued the club as a hedge against crime, carried petitions door to door and collected hundreds of signatures. After the eviction took effect the end of October, a new set of posters appeared: ``Mr. Herzog promised we could stay as long as he controlled the building. Now he's evicted us. Call his lawyer and tell him you will not patronize any new business here.'' Herzog says that when he purchased the building four years ago he shook hands with Mangano and told him to expect a rent increase. He says he began eviction proceedings when Mangano refused to pay more. For Benny Eggs, the struggle over the club became academic. He was arrested earlier this year with seven co-defendants on charges of conspiring to rig bids on city window replacement contracts. Pending his trial, he is confined to his home with an electronic monitor to verify his presence. Initially, Mangano was allowed to spend weekends at the seashore, but a judge revoked that privilege after his accuser's wife found a bomb in the front seat of her car. Tony Dapolito, whose family has run an Italian bakery in the neighborhood of the club for 70 years, says many law-abiding citizens were sad to see it go. ``People felt they threw those poor old men out,'' he said. ``With the club, they had a place to go. The nearest senior center is 10 blocks away, and the K of C (Knights of Columbus) is five blocks.'' ``These clubs used to be all over the city, and they're what made the streets safe,'' he added. ``I'm not condoning all of them, but most of them were pretty decent places.'' Herzog does not share his nostalgia. ``This area's been a slum long enough,'' he said. He called Benny Eggs and company ``parasites,'' and asked: ``Why don't they go play pinochle in their rent-controlled apartments?''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Has `Touch of the Flu'
DOC.TEXT: President Bush kept a full schedule Monday despite being slowed by what he called ``a touch of the flu.'' Bush, who spent last week in South America, told reporters that he ``shouldn't have played tennis yesterday. Got out there and did that and then - WHAM!'' Asked what the connection was between flu and tennis, Bush replied: ``Well, I don't know. I think I was tired.'' Bush skipped a Christmas gala Sunday night, but he was to be the host of a Monday night ball at the White House for members of Congress.

DOC.HEAD: Head of Co-Op Lending Program Says Some Borrowers Are In Trouble
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The head of the federal agency that has loaned billions of dollars to America's rural electric cooperatives acknowledged Monday that some of the borrowers are having trouble repaying their low-interest loans. Gary C. Byrne, who has headed the Rural Electrification Administration since March, also said the agency's lending program must be tightened to make it more responsible. ``We have some difficult credit situations,'' Byrne told a small group of reporters in his first meeting with the press. However, he added, ``I'm reasonably confident that we're through the worst of the credit problems.'' Eight rural electric cooperatives currently are in default on $2.3 billion in loans from the REA; four of the eight are in Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization. The eight also owe $1.25 billion to private creditors. Only a few of the nation's nearly 1,000 electric co-ops are in serious trouble, but the money problems have made some experts fearful of the REA's financial health. Nearly all the co-ops nationwide have received low-interest federal loans or federal guarantees for bank loans. The financial troubles gripping some electric co-ops and their potential impact on the federal loan program were disclosed in an article by The Associated Press. Byrne, the first banker to be appointed REA administrator, said the outlook for co-ops will depend on the health of the economy and on the weather. If the economy is weak or the weather is warmer than usual this winter, he said, demand for electricity - and consequently the co-ops' revenue - would decrease. Byrne said the REA has adopted a strategy that includes steering financially healthy co-ops toward the private market for their loans and weaning them away from federal aid. The agency plans to reduce the number of low-interest loans it grants and replace them with loan guarantees. In addition, he said, the REA needs to revise its lending policies to better distinguish between the co-ops with the greatest financial need and those less in need of federal funds. The new approach ``does assure the American taxpayers that if the money is loaned out, that money will be returned,'' Byrne said.
