The rural electrification program, set up in the mid-1930s, radically changed U.S. agriculture by providing the cheap electric power that enabled farmers to modernize. But critics complain that the program no longer serves a useful purpose and is a waste of taxpayers' money. The Bush administration, looking for ways to reduce the swelling federal budget deficit, has mounted a quiet attack on the REA subsidies. The Office of Management and Budget, in a recent memo to the Energy Department, proposed phasing out all REA subsidies over ten years. ``I think we're going to be battling for funds over the next several years,'' Byrne said. ``You keep the program strong by making the program financially responsible.'' The biggest losses have been posted by big cooperatives that generate their own electricity. Most of the smaller co-ops - which are members of the generating co-ops and only distribute electricity - are in sound financial shape. The REA has proposed new administrative rules that would, among other things, require the smaller distribution co-ops to guarantee loans made to their parent cooperatives. Byrne, who was appointed by President Bush to a 10-year term, formerly was chairman of the Bank of Alex Brown in Sacramento, Calif. Prior to his appointment, REA administrators had come from a farming or ranching background.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev: Party Should Say `Sovereign,' Not `Socialist' in U.S.S.R
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail Gorbachev told Communist Party leaders Monday they have nothing to fear from his Union Treaty proposal to drop the word ``socialist'' from the country's name and replace it with ``sovereign.'' The treaty plan contains ``strong expressions of the ideas and principles we connect with socialism - its humanistic, democratic nature,'' Gorbachev assured the party's embattled Central Committee during a closed-door session. Gorbachev, who is also head of the the Communist Party, urged party leaders to create a ``strong political desire for the preservation and renewal of the union.'' ``What is profitable for separatists is absolutely fatal for the majority of workers,'' Gorbachev said. The party meeting was closed to journalists, and a text of his speech was carried later by the state news agency Tass. Several of the 15 republics already have dropped ``Soviet Socialist'' from their names as a rejection of decades of Soviet communism. Last week, hard-line members of the national legislature demanded Gorbachev suspend steps toward democratic reforms as a way to hold the union together. They suggested Gorbachev be replaced if he does not take action. Some European leaders also have expressed fears that civil strife could send millions of Soviets fleeing across international borders. Gorbachev's draft treaty, which would replace a 1922 document, envisions changing the country's name from ``Union of Soviet Socialist Republics'' to ``Union of Sovereign Soviet Republics.'' Gorbachev said his proposal is a government document, not the statement of a political party. ``Will there be a union of strong sovereign states or a crumbling symbolic formation?'' Gorbachev asked the policy-making Central Committee, leaders of the 17 million-member party that has been steadily losing members and authority. The draft treaty never mentions the words ``socialism'' or ``communism.'' It divides powers between the central government and the republics, and says ``economic development strategy'' will be determined jointly. It would give more economic power to the republics, while retaining Kremlin control over the military, foreign policy, transportation, energy and other key industries. Six republics already have said they will not sign and demanded Kremlin endorsement of their sovereignty declarations. All the Soviet republics except Kirgizia in central Asia have declared some form of autonomy or independence. Lawmakers in Kirgizia had sovereignty on their agenda as they opened a session Monday. Kirgizia's legislative speaker, Absamat Masaliev, resigned Monday in order to concentrate on duties as a Communist Party official, Tass reported. It was unclear whether Masaliev's resignation was connected to the republic's sovereignty debate. In Moscow, Gorbachev also blasted the ``war of laws'' in which national and republic lawmakers have passed conflicting legislation, paralyzing the economy. He has said the treaty is needed to stave off economic collapse. ``If patches of land, divided by customs barriers, independent currencies or even border guards form in place of an all-union market, vast opportunities will be lost,'' he said. Gorbachev reiterated his insistence that no republic can secede without a referendum. Gorbachev also rejected proposals to adopt new constitutions in each republic before signing the Union Treaty. He said inter-republic agreements are acceptable only if they do not supplant the Union Treaty. Nearly a dozen such bilateral treaties have been signed. Earlier Monday, Tass said rumors that Gorbachev will step down as Communist Party chief are ``totally unfounded.'' Such rumors have been circulating for a year.

DOC.HEAD: White House Christmas: 47 Trees, Mistletoe, and Gingerbread Millie
DOC.TEXT: A beaming Barbara Bush showed off the White House Christmas decorations Monday, from a towering tree garlanded with Nutcracker dolls and ballet slippers to a gingerbread house guarded by a miniature Millie. ``It's ravishing,'' exclaimed the first lady as she led a preview tour of the White House, brimming with garlands, bows, poinsettias, 47 trees, 54,000 lights and even a sprig of mistletoe above the Grand Staircase. An estimated 100,000 visitors will troop through the mansion to view the finery over the holiday season. President Bush complained Monday of having ``a touch of the flu,'' but he was host of a congressional ball for 700 guests Monday night. The Bushes planned seven other Christmas parties over the next 10 days. Mrs. Bush had seen most of the decorations as they went up over the weekend, with the help of 40 volunteers from the florist industry and White House staff. Several grandchildren helped pelt the trees with artificial snow. But she got her first glimpse of White House Executive Chef Hans Raffert's gingerbread house, dressed up as the witch's cottage from Hansel and Gretel. The wayward children are in the front yard, along with the witch, a snowman and, stretched out in front of her own doghouse, Millie. ``It's just beautiful, Hans. Absolutely spectacular,'' Mrs. Bush told the chef, who has created gingerbread houses each Christmas for the past 21 years. ``Prettier than ever.'' The Nutcracker ballet provided the theme this year, with the official 18{-foot high Fraser fir tree in the Blue Room festooned with porcelain dolls and beaded ballet slippers. Mrs. Bush credited the White House staff with the handiwork, including doll's costumes made from scratch. Giant toy soldiers are posted along the room's walls. ``Everybody in the White House had a part - the carpenters, the electricians, everybody,'' she said, including a plumber who constructed a castle from plastic pipes. An 18th century Italian wood and terra cotta nativity scene is prominently displayed in the East Room, as it has been every Christmas since 1967. Mrs. Bush also gave reporters a glimpse of the Bush's personal Christmas tree, upstairs in their private quarters in the Yellow Oval Room. The tree, a 16-foot Fraser fir, overlooks the Truman Balcony in the center of the mansion. It is filled with the family's own decorations, including a crocheted snowman that she and her eldest son, George, made years ago. Mrs. Bush also spotted a wooden rabbit nestled in grass, the last survivor from a set of 10 that her mother gave her in 1945, the year they were married. The first lady said there was only one thing that she or the president wanted this Christmas: ``Peace.'' Asked about Pentagon restrictions on Christmas celebrations for the U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia, Mrs. Bush said, ``It's too bad. But you know, when in Rome, I guess you have to do what the Romans do.'' But she said nothing can stop them from celebrating the holiday in their hearts. Pressed on what other gifts would be under the Bush tree, the first lady said, ``I have way too much in life, as does George Bush.'' But she said, ``I'm giving him something he needs.'' The Bushes will spend Christmas at Camp David, the presidential retreat in Maryland, with their children and grandchildren.

DOC.HEAD: Reputed Mob Chief Says Government Bugs Violated First Amendment
DOC.TEXT: The reputed chief of organized crime in New England claims the First Amendment right of free speech and association should bar the government from using tapes of a purported Mafia induction ceremony. Raymond J. ``Junior'' Patriarca does not admit that the Mafia or La Cosa Nostra exists. But if it does, he argues, a secret induction ceremony is ``clearly protected ... by the First Amendment from governmental intrusion.'' Patriarca, 46, of Lincoln, outlined his defense in pretrial motions filed last week in U.S. District Court in Boston, The Providence Journal-Bulletin reported Monday. He noted that the amendment applies to the Ku Klux Klan and the Nazi Party, which are ``far more heinous yet unquestionably protected organizations.'' He is trying to block introduction of six hours of tape recordings that agents made of a meeting on Oct. 29, 1989, at a house in Medford, Mass. The government alleges that at the meeting four new members took a blood oath to kill anyone who violated the organization's secrecy. Patriarca has been in prison since his March indictment on charges of racketeering, conspiracy and interstate travel in aid of racketeering. He is accused of organized crime violations along with 21 other alleged members and associates of the purported Patriarca crime family in Massachusetts, Connecticut and Rhode Island. Until Patriarca submitted numerous court motions last week seeking to quash the charges and the evidence, there had been speculation he was trying to work out a plea agreement. He also challenged the warrant that allowed the bugging of the meeting, and says the tapes should not be used against him because the government didn't mention him as a target of the bugging in the warrant. Floyd Abrams, a noted First Amendment attorney from New York, said Patriarca's argument ``is not without its charm.'' But he said the right of speech and association never had been allowed to shield criminal conduct. ``It is one thing for him to argue, `There is no Cosa Nostra and if it exists, I'm not in it,' and it's another to say if it exists it's just a private social club,'' Abrams said. Vincent Blasi, a professor of First Amendment law at Columbia University, agreed that the constitutional protection doesn't apply when the government has a reasonable basis to believe that intercepted conversations will reveal crimes. The government has until Dec. 31 to respond.

DOC.HEAD: Couple Operates Retirement Farm for Horses
DOC.TEXT: A stable of played-out polo ponies, run-down racehorses and pleasure steeds too old for fun have found a patch of heaven at Mill Creek Farm, where they are never ridden, saddled or worked. The 24 horses now living on the farm literally have been put out to pasture. All they have to do as long as they live is to eat from ample supplies of forage and grain and socialize with each other. ``We feel like there is a need for a place like this,'' said Peter Gregory, who operates the Retirement Home for Horses Inc. near this community northwest of Gainesville in northern Florida. Many horse owners cannot or do not want to keep their horses after the animals get older and they end up being destroyed, Gregory said. He and his wife, Mary, take in horses from people and institutions who have heard about them from word of mouth. They rely on voluntary contributions, but pay much of the the minimum $40-a-month cost of caring for each horse themselves. ``In a small way, we are trying to make up for the things that have happened to them,'' he said. The Gregorys took on the work in their own retirement, buying the 140 acres of rolling pasture and woodland about seven years ago. They formed a nonprofit corporation with tax-exempt, charitable-institution status that they hope will enable the farm to take in horses for years to come.

DOC.HEAD: Grand Jury This Week May Take Up 1963 Slaying of Civil Rights Leader
DOC.TEXT: A grand jury meets this week and may decide whether a suspect should again face charges in the 1963 ambush slaying of civil rights leader Medgar Evers. ``All I can say is there is speculation the case will be presented'' the week of Dec. 10, Myrlie Evers, widow of Medgar Evers, said in a recent telephone interview with reporters from her home in Los Angeles. She said she hoped to be in Mississippi in case she is needed to testify. District Attorney Ed Peters declined to comment when asked if the Byron De La Beckwith case would be considered by the Hinds County jury. Evers was field secretary of the Mississippi NAACP when he was shot to death June 12, 1963, in the driveway of his Jackson home. Authorities said a high-powered rifle bearing Beckwith's fingerprint was found nearby. Beckwith, at the time a Greenwood fertilizer salesman, said the weapon had been stolen. Two all-white juries were unable to reach verdicts in February and April 1964 and mistrials were declared. The murder charge was dismissed against Beckwith in 1969. Beckwith, 70, who now lives in Signal Mountain, Tenn., remains an ardent segregationist but says he is innocent. ``It's amazing they'd wait 27 years to convene a grand jury,'' he said last week. Assistant District Attorney Bobby DeLaughter confirmed that he has spent the past 14 months investigating the Evers slaying. Initially the investigation centered on possible jury tampering after published reports that the old state Sovereignty Commission, a now-defunct segregation watchdog agency, collected information about potential jurors in Beckwith's second trial. A different grand jury met in December 1989 but found no evidence of jury tampering. That panel asked for more investigation into the prospects of reopening a murder prosecution, DeLaughter said.

DOC.HEAD: 19th Game Postponed after Kasparov Wins 18th Game, Takes Lead
DOC.TEXT: The 19th game of the world chess championship was postponed Monday for two days at the request of Anatoly Karpov, who trails reigning champion Garry Kasparov 9.5-8.5 in the series. With Karpov's loss Sunday to Kasparov, who moved ahead of Karpov for the third time in the championship match, only a maximum of six games remain to be played. The first player to gain 12.5 points (victories count for a point, ties for a half-point) wins the championship and $1.7 million of a $3 million purse. In the event of a tie, Kasparov retains his title. The series began Oct. 8 in New York and Kasparov won the second and 16th games, with Karpov evening the score with wins in the seventh and 17th games. All the other games have been draws. The first 12 games in the series were played in New York. The 13th game started in Lyon on Nov. 24.

DOC.HEAD: Czech Bud Stops Flowing in Strike Over Trademark Beer
DOC.TEXT: The only thing brewing at the original Budweiser on Monday was trouble. Beer stopped flowing when the Czech braumeisters went on strike Monday in a brew-haha over merging with the makers of America's version of the famous fermented beverage. Budvar brewery in the southern Bohemian town of Ceske Budejovice, known as Budweis in German, has brewed its namesake beer since it was founded in the 19th century. Early in this century, Bavarian-born Adolphus Busch acquired the rights to sell ``Budweiser'' in North America. Budvar maintained the trademark rights for Europe, with exports on the Continent worth $8 million in 1989. Now, after a failed attempt under Communist rule in 1988, attempts are under way to reunite the two Budweisers. Anheuser Busch tried and failed two years ago to establish a joint venture with Budvar, offering a $2 million investment. The attempt created a wave of protest among Budweis consumers around Ceske Budejovice, 100 miles south of Prague. The local newspaper, Jihoceska Pravda (South Bohemian Truth), quoted beer drinkers at the time as saying they would rather die than see an agreement with a company whose beer is ``a weak imitation of the original product.'' ``You'll never see our beer in cans, we use them (cans) oor sauerkraut only,'' an irritated young businessman reportedly said then. But Budvar seems ready for American investment now that Communist rule has been overturned and the economy opened up to rapid privatization. Budvar is to become an independent state-run shareholding company in January, with the Finance Ministry overseeing its gradual privatization. Once that happens, Budvar, as the largest of state-controlled breweries, is the most likely candidate for an eventual merger with Anheuser-Busch. Budvar's approximately 300 workers seem to favor the Bud reunion. They walked out Monday to press state management into speeding up talks on a merger with the American company and guaranteeing jobs. ``This strike is an extreme solution, which damages the brewery,'' Josef Tolar, the brewery's acting manager, told the state news agency CTK after the stoppage was announced. ``We were left with no alternative,'' he added. The workers say management of state breweries in south Bohemia is slowing talks with demands for compensation for its past investments in Budvar. Antonin Kratochvile, general manager of the brewery chain, known as Jihoceske Pivovary, said Budvar has agreed to pay his group 160 million crowns ($6.5 million). He refused to comment on American participation in the deal, saying only it was millions rather than billions of dollars. Other details of an eventual merger have not been made public. Nor were details available on how much beer Budvar brews daily.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Moving to Send Food, Other Aid to Soviet Union
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Reworks top, subbing 2 grafs for top graf pvs
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration indicated Monday that an aid package to help the Soviet Union get through the winter could be forthcoming, suggesting it wants to reward Moscow for help in the Persian Gulf. Officials said the aid could include emergency food and medical supplies as well as trade benefits. Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said President Bush may grant trade concessions even if the Soviets do not pass a liberalized emigration law, which the United States has long said must precede concessions. Fitzwater cited the severity of Soviet economic problems and a desire to reward Moscow for its political help in the Persian Gulf. In Houston, Secretary of State James A. Baker III gave the clearest sign yet that the administration was prepared to help the Soviet Union with food and other supplies. ``As far as humanitarian assistance, medical assistance, food and that sort of thing, I know the president will be forthcoming with respect to trying to help,'' Baker said after Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze specifically requested food aid. Fitzwater said the president was considering waiving the Jackson-Vanik law, which has imposed severe restrictions on Soviet trade with the United States since 1974, mainly because of its repression of Jews. Earlier this year, administration efforts to liberalize trade with Moscow were slowed by the Soviet crackdown on independence movements in Lithuania and other Baltic republics. Bush met Monday with Lithuanian President Vytautas Lansbergis. Even as the United States considers aiding the Soviet economy, the Kremlin is threatening Lithuania with ``economic catastrophe,'' Lansbergis told reporters after the session. He likened the plight of Lithuania to Iraqi-occupied Kuwait and said he appealed to Bush to ``take an active policy'' if Moscow escalates its pressure against the breakaway state. Afterwards, Fitzwater said Bush relayed to Lansbergis that there was no change in U.S. support for self-determination for all three Baltic republics. ``The president said the United States has never recognized the forcible incorporation of the Baltic states into the U.S.S.R. and assured President Lansbergis that this policy would not change,'' Fitzwater said. Lansbergis indicated heand Bush did not discuss what the United States might do if it provided food aid to the Soviet Union, and Moscow in turn denied food to the rebellious republics. Under pressure from Congress, Bush said in June at his summit with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev that further trade liberalization - including granting Moscow most-favored-nation status - would be delayed until the Soviet legislature passes a law liberalizing emigration policies. That law has not been passed. ``We are considering going ahead with waiver of Jackson-Vanik without passage of the law,'' said Fitzwater. Asked why, the spokesman said that the Soviets had largely liberalized their emigration policies toward Jews and other minorities. He also cited ``what appears to be a very serious need in terms of their economy and in terms of their ability to get food supplies'' and noted ``their cooperation in the Persian Gulf, their strong support of us in that area.'' In Houston, Shevardnadze asked specifically for food relief as he and Baker opened two days of talks that focused on resolving the remaining differences on a strategic nuclear weapons treaty Bush and Gorbachev hope to sign in Moscow next month. Shevardnadze, posing for pictures with Baker, told reporters, ``We would appreciate, if possible, some food supplies. ... That is the most acute problem.'' He added that the Soviets would also like to receive from the United States ``efficient economic cooperation.'' Baker said Bush is considering helping the Soviets as they try to make a difficult transition in their economic system. ``The United States would want to be of assistance in ways that we can be,'' Baker said. But the Jackson-Vanik curbs remain the biggest obstacles to giving the Soviet Union access to U.S. markets and banks. The law, named after the late Sen. Henry Jackson of Washington and former Rep. Charles Vanik of Ohio, was enacted to try to force the Soviets to allow Jews and other minorities to emigrate. Under Gorbachev Jewish emigration has hit a record. Bush is weighing his options on whether to waive the Jackson-Vanik law, Fitzwater said, indicating that a decision might be made by the end of the week. White House officials said that the issue of waiving the Jackson-Vanik restrictions was separate from any emergency package that might be assembled. Bush will meet with Shevardnadze at the White House on Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: US Praises Angola Constitution Plans
DOC.TEXT: The State Department praised plans by Angola's Marxist-stye ruling party to allow a multiparty system and said Monday that elections should be called as soon as possible. The ruling Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola voted Sunday to revise the constitution and allow democracy before the end of March. The party, known by its Portuguese acronym MPLA, also called for free-market economic reforms and recommended legislation to guarantee rights of expression, religion and association, and freedom of the press. ``We are encouraged by the MPLA party decision to move toward amending the constitution to allow for the creation of other political parties in Angola,'' said State Department spokesman Richard Boucher. A 15-year civil war between the Soviet-backed government and U.S.-aided rebels has killed 340,000 people, according government estimates. Cuban forces backing the government have been reduced from about 50,000 to 10,000 this year as a result of peace talks. The government and rebels are to meet for a sixth round of peace talks in January in Portugal. Boucher urged the government of President Jose Eduardo Dos Santos rapidly to permit a multiparty system in which the U.S.-backed rebels and other groups would be given the right to form and operate as political parties. Jonas Savimbi, leader of the rebel National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, known as UNITA, said last week that he would agree to a cease-fire if the ruling party approved a multiparty system and elections. Boucher said the MPLA move does not change U.S. aid plans. The United States has been aiding the rebels and has said it would not stop helping UNITA until the government guarantees them a role in a multiparty society.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Lawmaker Sentenced to 12 Years in Prison for Corruption
DOC.TEXT: A former high-ranking state senator was sentenced Monday to 12 years in federal prison for corruption uncovered in an FBI sting in which he sold influence for campaign contributions. Paul Carpenter stood silently when U.S. District Judge Edward Garcia sentenced him, declining an offer to speak. Carpenter, a silver-haired 62-year-old Democrat from suburban Los Angeles, was convicted in September of racketeering, extortion and conspiracy. The charges followed an undercover operation at the state capital. In the sting, an FBI agent posing as a businessman paid Carpenter $20,000 in campaign contributions to get a bill through the Legislature. At Carpenter's trial, other instances were cited of his shaking down lobbyists for campaign money. Carpenter, who must surrender to authorities by Jan. 7, was also ordered to repay $20,000 he received from an FBI undercover agent in the sting operation. ``It's a case of proven acceptance of bribery money and extortion of money in the form of political contributions,'' said the judge, who called the evidence against Carpenter ``overwhelming.'' The judge also observed that the former lawmaker felt no remorse. He said Carpenter's punishment was intended to deter others. Carpenter will be eligible for parole in four years. Carpenter's attorney, Gerard Hinckley, said he would appeal the sentence. A former Senate Democratic Caucus chairman, Carpenter was for several years one of that body's top fundraisers. After 12 years in the Senate, he was elected in 1986 to the Board of Equalization. His sentencing removes Carpenter from the powerful state tax board. Carpenter was the second elected state official snagged in the five-year FBI probe. Joseph Montoya was still a state senator when he was convicted in February of racketeering, extortion and money laundering. He is serving a 6{-year prison sentence. The investigation is continuing. So far four other people have pleaded guilty to charges that flowed from it - two former legislative aides and two former county law enforcers. Another two former legislative aides are awaiting trial. Most of the charges against Carpenter related to his dealings with John Brennan, an FBI agent who posed as Alabama businessman Jack Gordon. The agent paid Carpenter $20,000 in campaign contributions as a payoff for Carpenter's help in getting a bill through the Senate to finance a fictitious shrimp business. Carpenter said he told an aide he wouldn't take the money unless he was assured that he wouldn't have to do anything in return. However, the next day, in a tape-recorded conversation with Brennan, Carpenter promised to serve as the bill's problem-solver and to ``stroke'' the state treasurer to remove opposition to the measure. The bill was approved by the Legislature but vetoed by Gov. George Deukmejian, who was tipped off to the FBI investigation.

DOC.HEAD: Official Warns Against Attempts to Trim Army Budget Plan
DOC.TEXT: President Violeta Chamorro will veto any cut in her proposed defense budget rather than risk a backlash from the Sandinista-led army, a top government aide said Monday. Minister of the Presidency Antonio Lucayo said Mrs. Chamorro will not allow the $78.6 million budget plan to be ``mutilated in such a way as to endanger that security.'' Mrs. Chamorro's 1991 spending proposal allocates 16 percent of the $499 million national budget to the armed forces. It is a sharp decline from defense budgets under her Sandinista predecessors, who battled U.S.-backed Contra rebels for about 10 years. But National Assembly is split over the proposal, and many deputies Mrs. Chamorro's coalition demand even bigger cuts. The 39 Sandinista deputies in the 92-member assembly have said they approve of Mrs. Chamorro's proposal. Under Mrs. Chamorro's 8-month-old government, the armed forces has been trimmed from 100,000 troops to about 28,000. The National Assembly is scheduled to begin debate on the budget Tuesday. The military is one of the most sensitive issues confronting Mrs. Chamorro, who left the armed forces and police in Sandinista hands. The move assured a peaceful change of governments but enraged much of the conservative United National Opposition coalition that backed her candidacy. Her UNO critics say Mrs. Chamorro is at the mercy of the Sandinista armed forces and police. The assembly must vote on a budget by Dec. 15 and send it to Mrs. Chamorro. By law, the 1991 budget must be approved by midnight on Dec. 20.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Sees Lithuanian President, Calls for Peaceful Settlement With Soviets
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Monday told Lithuania's president he hopes the Soviet Union will work with the leaders of independence-minded Baltic republics without resorting to threats or force. In the first meeting between a U.S. president and the head of state of tiny Lithuania, Bush and Vytautas Landbergis discussed negotiations with Moscow in pursuit of Lithuania's recognition as a sovereign state. While the Kremlin has suspended its economic blockade of Lithuania pending the outcome of independence talks, there is ``still definitely tension in the situation,'' said Bush spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. Landbergis, speaking to reporters immediately after his talk with Bush in the Oval Office, said his republic ``is being attacked today by the Kremlin through various means, including threats and intimidation.'' ``We are being threatened with economic catastrophe; we are being threatened with military action against us,'' Landbergis said. ``Therefore, the purpose of my visit today to the White House was to ask for some sort of political protection from the United States.'' He said he received no firm promise from Bush that the United States would provide such protection. But shortly after the meeting, Fitzwater issued a statement reviewing the subjects discussed and reiterating U.S. refusal to recognize the Kremlin's absorption of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia into the Soviet Union a half century ago. ``The president stressed that the U.S. wanted a peaceful solution to the problem between the Baltic states and the U.S.S.R. and hoped the Soviet government would work constructively with Baltic leaders, without resorting to threats, intimidation or the use of force,'' the statement said.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Urged to Focus on Science, Not Spectaculars
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with Truly comments, subbing 2 grafs for 6th pvs, Richard Truly
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Space Shuttle Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A high-level committee said Monday that NASA must focus on science - and not on flashy, futuristic projects - both on the space shuttle and on the proposed space station ``if it is not merely to drift through the decade ahead.'' The space science program ``ranks above space stations, aerospace planes, manned missions to the planets, and many other major pursuits which often receive greater visibility,'' said the government's Advisory Committee on the Future of the U.S. Space Program. It said NASA was trying to do too much and allowing too little margin for the unexpected, leading to frequent revamping of major programs. The agency should concentrate on two major undertakings: studying Earth's environment from space in a ``Mission to Planet Earth'' and exploring space in a ``Mission from Planet Earth.'' The committee said the space shuttle should be flown only when astronaut skills are needed and that no new shuttles should be built after the Endeavour, now under construction, is completed. Instead, the committee recommends that a new unmanned heavy-lift launch vehicle be developed and used for all but missions requiring human presence. ``Now it's our challenge,'' said Vice President Dan Quayle, head of the National Space Council, after he was briefed by the committee. ``This report will give our space program a needed shot in the arm.'' Richard Truly, the NASA administrator, said he has invited the committee and its chairman to meet with the agency's senior managers ``so we can deal with the recommendations in the report.'' But overall, he said, he sees no major change in NASA's pace of science programs. He took issue with allowing the shuttle production line to close after Endeavour. ``We should not give up the ability to build one if for any reason we need to build another one,'' Truly said. Sen. Al Gore, D-Tenn., chairman of the Senate science subcommittee, praised the report as ``a reasoned view of the space program'' and said it will form the basis of a congressional review in the next session. NASA assembled the outside review at the request of the Bush administration after a spate of embarrassments that included grounding of the shuttle fleet because of leaks on Columbia and Atlantis and a flaw in grinding the Hubble Space Telescope's mirror. Repairs were made, and Columbia, the leakiest of the shuttles, was returning to Earth at 12:51 a.m. EST Tuesday in California after a nine-day flight. Atlantis flew last month. ``NASA is neither as troubled as some suggest nor as good as it will have to be to carry out the program we have recommended,'' Norman Augustine, chairman of the 12-member committee told a news conference. But he said the agency was at a crossroads. The committee's report said ``a focus must be given to this program now if it is not merely to drift through the decade ahead. Although there is no particular timetable that can in good conscience be assigned to this pursuit, it nonetheless sorely needs agreement as to direction.'' Augustine is chairman and chief executive officer of the Martin Marietta Corporation, a major rocket builder. He said he did not participate in discussions of a new heavy-lift vehicle. Other members of the committee included Edward C. Aldridge Jr., former secretary of the Air Force, Joseph P. Allen, former astronaut; Edward P. Boland, a former congressman whose committee oversaw NASA spending, and Thomas O. Paine, NASA administrator during the Apollo moon flight era. The space agency already has moved toward a commitment to science projects. It stopped delivering commercial satellites to orbit after the Challenger disaster in 1986 and last month conducted its last secret Pentagon mission, although it still has three unclassified Defense Department cargoes. The committee said the civil space program is overly dependent on the shuttle for access to space but said it should not be used for satellite deliveries, which can be carried out on unmanned rockets. ``It's a mistake to risk seven people and one-fourth of our shuttles to place a commercial communications satellite into space,'' Augustine said. The committee said a subject not often mentioned is the statistical probability that ``we are likely to lose another space shuttle in the next several years, probably before the planned space station is completely established on orbit.'' The report did not mince words about the space station, which had been planned for the mid-'90s but has run into major financing and other snags. ``We do not believe that the space station Freedom, as we now know it, can be justified solely on the basis of the non-biological science it can perform,'' the committee said. Instead its objectives should be only two: primarily, life sciences and secondarily, microgravity experimentation. ``We believe the space station Freedom can be simplified, reduced in cost, and constructed on a more evolutionary, modular basis that enables end-to-end testing of most systems prior to launch,'' the report said. The committee sought to deflect suggestions that an agency other than NASA should be in charge of space activities, saying ``NASA and only NASA'' has the knowledge and expertise to sustain the country's space program.

DOC.HEAD: Authorities Say No PCB Risk in Flooded Subdivision
DOC.TEXT: Federal regulators on Monday lifted an evacuation order imposed on a flooded subdivision after cancer-causing PCBs were discovered in the oily floodwater. The decision allowed residents forced from 120 homes near the Little Calumet River to return to assess flood damage and gather personal belongings. Six inches of rain late last month left the 420-home Wicker Park Manor subdivision under five feet of water. Polychlorinated biphenyls, once used as insulators in electrical transformers, were banned by the federal government in the 1970s. The main east-west street through the subdivision became a dividing line Wednesday after the Environmental Protection Agency detected double the acceptable safe limit of PCBs in the floodwater. Residents living north of the street were banned from returning to their homes, while other residents were granted access. The source of the PCBs is not known. The entire subdivision was closed Friday while EPA testers broadened the scope of their sampling to areas south of the street. A growing number of residents were permitted to return through Sunday as followup tests showed no detectable levels of PCBs in homes, heating oil, soil or debris, said EPA spokesman Philip Schuette. The negative test results suggest the EPA may have trouble finding the origin of the contamination, he said. Frank DeAtley, emergency coordinator for the Highland town council, said local officials accepted the EPA recommendation to allow access to homes despite not knowing where the PCBs came from. ``I'm sure we'll all feel better if we know what the source was. Likewise, you have to move on when you can.'' The White House has issued a disaster declaration making Lake County flood victims eligible for low-cost federal loans for rebuilding.

DOC.HEAD: Fetal Alcohol Syndrome Often Ignored, Acute Among Indians, Panel Told
DOC.TEXT: Doctors and government agencies are looking the other way while alcoholic women, including a disproportionate number of Indians, give birth to thousands of children with debilitating handicaps, a Senate committee was told Monday. Many doctors fail to confront women who drink during pregnancy and aren't trained to diagnose and treat children afflicted with the resulting birth defects, said parents and experts in testimony to the Senate Finance subcommittee on Social Security and family policy. About 5,000 babies are born each year with fetal alcohol syndrome, a cause of mental retardation, and 35,000 more suffer from less severe effects of a mother's drinking, according to the National Council on Alcoholism and Drug Dependence. The problem is particularly acute on Indian reservations, where the rate of fetal alcohol syndrome is seven times the national average, said Sen. Tom Daschle, D-S.D. One of every four children on the Pine Ridge Reservation in South Dakota is born with the malady, Daschle said. Fetal alcohol syndrome could create ``a continual underclass in our society who can't function,'' said Michael Dorris, a Dartmouth University professor who adopted three children with alcohol-caused birth defects. ``In this great land of plenty, many babies are born exposed to such high levels of alcohol and drugs before birth that they die or are born intoxicated,'' said Jeaneen Grey Eagle, director of a Pine Ridge treatment program. ``They are doomed to spend the rest of their life with birth defects and or mental retardation,'' she said. Doctors on the reservation shy away from diagnosing children with the diseases or confronting their mothers during pregnancy because of social stigmas, Grey Eagle said. She told of one baby so intoxicated at birth that she passed out, adding that her mother, who had no prenatal care, was drunk when she arrived at the hospital. The problem is most common among poor Indians and blacks, but a Maryland woman who grew up in a upper middle class home in suburban Washington told the committee she gave birth to a severely handicapped daughter and had two other babies die before seeking treatment for alcoholism. ``I never meant to harm my children,'' said Kathleen Tavenner of Emmitsburg, Md. ``It was ignorance ... that harmed my child.'' She had been a client of several welfare programs while abusing alcohol, but none of the social workers confronted her, she said. ``No one ever intervened. No one ever said ... are you having a problem with drugs or alcohol?'' Dorris, who wrote a book about his experience with fetal alcohol syndrome, said his children have been arrested for shoplifting, sexual misconduct and violent behavior. ``They maintain no enduring friendships, set for themselves no realistic goals, can call upon no bedrock inner values to distinguish right from wrong, safe from dangerous,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Shevardnadze in Control at Space Center
With AM-US-Soviet Aid, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: ``I'm flying, I'm flying,'' Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze exulted Monday as he sat at the controls of a mock U.S. space shuttle. ``Let's take off.'' Alongside, Secretary of State James A. Baker III played the role of co-pilot with a wide grin on his face. ``He's the guest, I feel more secure that way, because I can't fly,'' Baker said, explaining why he had yielded the controls to the Soviet minister. Their visit to the Johnson Space Center reflected the new warmth in U.S.-Soviet relations. So did a pledge by Baker to consider providing food and other humanitarian assistance to the Soviets as they stagger at the brink of economic disintegration. ``We would appreciate it,'' Shevardnadze said softly, telling reporters that food supplies were ``the most acute problem'' facing his people. Baker assured him that ``the United States would want to be of assistance in ways that we can be.'' Baker and Shevardnadze are holding two days of talks on the crisis in the Persian Gulf, a still-unfinished treaty to trim U.S. and Soviet nuclear weapons and other tough issues. Among those issues is the lingering conflict in Afghanistan between the Soviet-backed central governeent and rebels armed by the United States, Pakistan and Saudi Arabia. U.S. and Soviet sources said the two sides were close to a decision to suspend their weapons shipments. An announcement would be made in a statement at the end of their meeting Tuesday. As part of the deal, the Bush administration would accept President Najibullah continuing in charge in Kabul during a transition to an elected government. The Soviets invaded Afghanistan in 1979 and withdrew last year. They provide the pro-Moscow government with about $500 million in military aid a year. The United States backs a coalition of rebels, some of them ardent Moslem fundamentalists, with about $430 million in annual assistance. Putting those issues aside temporarily, Baker and Shevardnadze toured the space center and spoke by telephone to the commander of the Columbia as the shuttle prepared to return to Earth. ``We are extremely proud of the work you are doing,'' Baker told the crew. Then Shevardnadze, speaking in Russian, picked up another phone and told the astronauts: ``You are paving new roads in space for the happiness of all of us here on earth.'' Astrophysicist Jeffrey A. Hoffman replied in Russian: ``We are very pleased.'' The United States and the Soviet Union have competed vigorously in space, both for prestige and for whatever military advantage could be gained. But the superpowers have also engaged in some cooperation. A dozen American astronauts and Soviet cosmonauts have been on joint missions. ``All of us would like to see less military application and more peace missions,'' Shevardnadze said. Before Baker and Shevardnadze arrived at the space center, a spirited German shepherd sniffed for explosives, slipping as it tried to maneuver on a shiny plexiglass floor in a mock space cabin. Baker gave the Soviet foreign minister a flag from a joint 1975 docking mission. In return, Shevardnadze presented Baker with American and Texas flags from an interplanetary probe. Shevardnadze said he was trying to persuade Baker to have their next meeting in space.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Lawmakers Approve Guarantees for Investment, Unions
DOC.TEXT: Lawmakers in the Supreme Soviet voted Monday to give investors and labor organizers more legal protection throughout the Soviet Union. The legislation dealt mainly with the principles of a market economy and did not address issues of currency convertibility or property ownership, nor the dismantling of a state bureaucracy that often saddles investors with red tape. The Supreme Soviet approved general principles of investment policy that guarantees ``equal rights for all investors, irrespective of property forms,'' Tass reported. ``The act is aimed at forming market-type investment relations and stepping up entrepreneurial activities in the country.'' The state news agency said investors under the new legislation must be reimbursed for any losses incurred by actions of ``state bodies ... violating their rights.'' The legislature later adopted a law on trade unions that ``provides for the independence of trade unions from government, economic and political bodies and their complete material and financial independence,'' Tass reported. It gave few other details. The law on labor unions comes two months after 900 Soviet coal miners, meeting in the Ukraine, established their own independent union and set up a governing structures that rejected state involvement. For most of the Soviet Union's 73-year history, labor unions were outlawed on the theory that the ruling Communist Party embodied interests of workers as the leading party of the workers' state.

DOC.HEAD: Libya Asks U.N. Meeting on U.S. Airlift of Libyans from Chad
DOC.TEXT: Libya's U.N. ambassador accused America on Monday of training Libyan POWs in hhad as guerrillas to undermine Col. Moammar Gadhafi's government. The Red Cross expressed concern over a U.S. airlift of the POWs. On Friday and Saturday, as victorious rebels consolidated their control of Chad, the United States flew out about 600 Libyan prisoners of war held by the former Chadian government to Nigeria. Libyan Ambassador Ali Treiki demanded an emergency Security Council meeting and said he would discuss scheduling one with council president Abdalla Saleh al-Ashtal, the Yemeni ambassador, on Monday. Treiki said was concerned about the well-being of the Libyans, and about the danger of a U.S.-organized plot against his government. ``There is no doubt that the United States has used them. They want to use them against our country,'' he said. ``We are worried about them. The Red Cross has not been allowed to interview them.'' The Libyan said it is against international law and the Geneva Convention on treatment of POWs ``to indoctrinate prisoners of war.'' The U.S. ambassador to Chad, Richard Bogosian, has declined to comment on reports that U.S. military advisers trained the captured soldiers for commando operations against Libya. Reports on Sunday said the airlifted Libyans' final destination was believed to be Zaire. The International Committee of the Red Cross complained Monday in a statement in Geneva that it was not allowed to supervise the airlift and said it wanted to interview the prisoners to make sure they left voluntarily. ``The ICRC has not been able to carry out protection work on their behalf as it would have wished,'' it said. A spokeswoman, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the ICRC was making representations to the United States and others in a bid to gain access to the prisoners. She said an ICRC delegate was at Chad's N'Djamena airport, but could not meet with prisoners privately to make sure they wanted to leave. The ICRC said it was never allowed to visit Libyan prisoners captured during the long conflict between Chad and Libya, despite repeated representations to Chad's former government led by President Hissene Habre. Idriss Deby's rebel forces toppled Habre this month. Deby is now interim president. Treiki said Monday that 17 Libyan POWs were slain during the rebel takeover of Chad, but that he did not know who killed them or under what circumstances. Libyan Foreign Minister Ibrahim Bashari said on Sunday the evacuated Libyan POWs ``are held against their will. They were taken hostage because they have a lot of information. They were trained and armed to destabilize the government of their own country or the political system of other nations.'' Bashari spoke after meeting with Nigerian President Gen. Ibrahim Babangida in efforts to repatriate the rest of the former POWs. A French news report said troops of Chad's new government on Sunday began dismantling a well-armed camp reputedly used by the Libyans. Agence France-Presse said the POWs' camp, about six miles north of N'Djamena, was well-stocked with arms and communications equipment. Other former POWs returned to Libya, which helped arm Deby's fighters. Chadian forces captured the Libyan fighters in clashes in 1983 and 1987. Chad and Libya have battled on and off in a border dispute for more than 20 years.

DOC.HEAD: North Carolina Sergeant Asks Return from Persian Gulf
DOC.TEXT: An attorney for an Army National Guard sergeant asked a federal judge Monday to order his return from the Persian Gulf until President Bush gets congressional permission to wage war on Iraq. Michael Ratner, a lawyer for the Center for Constitutional Rights, argued that Sgt. Michael R. Ange of Beaufort, N.C. should be returned from active duty in the Middle East because he faces ``the realistic threat he will be required to fight in an unconstitutional war.'' Ratner argued that President Bush has violated both the war powers clause of the Constitution and the 1973 War Powers Resolution by preparing for war with Iraq without obtaining permission from Congress. The lawyer asked U.S. District Judge Royce Lamberth to affirm ``what every school child knows: that Congress has the power to declare war.'' But Justice Department attorney John Tyler, urging the court to stay out of the dispute, said Bush has never ruled out the possibility that he would ask Congress to authorize the use of force to drive Iraqi forces from Kuwait. ``We don't know that the president will not seek authority from Congress; he has never so stated,'' Tyler said. Ratner, citing statements from Bush and other administration officials, said there is ``strong evidence'' that the president would launch an attack on Iraqi troops without seeking congressional approval. Ange, a police officer, was activated last month when his National Guard unit was mobilized and sent to Fort Lee, Va. He was unsuccessful in winning a temporary restraining order to block his deployment to the Persian Gulf. Now seeking an injunction ordering his removal from the Middle East, Ange contends that Bush violated the War Powers Resolution by failing to report to Congress that he had sent troops into a situation of imminent hostilities. Under the resolution, the president must end such a deployment in 60 days unless Congress authorizes its continuation. Lamberth noted that Bush told Congress after sending troops to Saudi Arabia that he didn't consider hostilities to be imminent. The judge expressed doubts over whether the requirement that Bush seek authority from Congress before waging war so clearly expressed by the Constitution. ``There have been a number of instances where presidents have proceeded without a declaration of war,'' Lamberth said, alluding to more than 200 occasions when U.S. troops fought or threatened to fight without congressiional approval. The nation has fought five wars declared by Congress. ``If you look at some of the early things that happened in the lifetime of the actual framers, the way these presidents acted would give you some pause as to whether the Constitution was that clear,'' Lamberth said in reference to early American military adventures that included combat with the Barbary pirates of North Africa in 1801-1805 and again in 1815. Tyler urged dismissal of Ange's lawsuit on the ground that the court was incapable of determining what were basically political questions best addressed by Congress and the president. ``The complexity of the Persian Gulf situation defies the court's ability to step in,'' Tyler said. Lamberth questioned whether he was in a position to judge whether Bush was really preparing for war or just trying to bluff Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein into removing his troops from Iraq. ``How do I decide this is a real threat of war by the president rather than something else to ensure that peace occurs?'' the judge asked. Lamberth did not indicate when he would rule. A lawsuit by 54 Democratic lawmakers that challenges Bush's power to wage war without congressional approval is pending before another judge in the same court.

DOC.HEAD: Cost of Living Soars in London but Tehran is Most Expensive
DOC.TEXT: The cost of living rose faster in London and Zurich than other major cities the past six months but Tehran easily remains the world's most expensive city. According to a survey released Monday, Tokyo was a distant second to the Iranian capital in the cost of living. The weaker dollar further widened the cost-of-living gap between the expensive cities of Europe and the major cities of North America, said the survey from Business International, a business information company. All Western European cities have become more expensive, but the sharpest increases came in Britain and Switzerland, the company said. However, the Scandinavian capitals remain Europe's costliest cities. Business International twice a year compares the cost of maintaining a Western standard of living in more than 100 cities. The surveys cover grocery items, alcoholic beverages, household supplies, personal care products, clothing and footwear, utility costs, domestic help, recreation and transportation. It calculated its index by comparing average prices from each city to prices in New York, which it used as a base city with a score of 100. New York ranked 24th in the latest survey. Here is Business International's listing of the 15 most expensive cities in the world, and how they scored on the index. Business International didn't provide the rankings or scores from six months ago. 1. Tehran, Iran, 225 2. Tokyo, 168 3. Abidjan, the Ivory Coast, 161 4. Osaka, Japan, 156 5. Brazzaville, Congo, 154 6. Libreville, Gabon, 149; Oslo, Norway, 149 7. Helsinki, Finland, 140; Stockholm, Sweden, 140 8. Zurich, Switzerland, 136 9. Paris, 132 10. Vienna, Austria, 128 11. Geneva, 125; London, 125 12. Copenhagen, Denmark, 122; Milan, Italy, 122 13. Lome, Togo, 121 14. Lyon, France, 115 15. Hamburg, Germany, 114; Madrid, Spain, 114

DOC.HEAD: Fort Harrison Residents Say Danger of Gas Leak Not Told Before Explosion
LaserPhoto NA3
DOC.TEXT: The body of a 5-year-old girl was found Monday in the wreckage of an Army base apartment building leveled in an explosion apparently caused by a natural gas leak. Seventeen people were injured, four critically, in the Sunday night blast. Fort Benjamin Harrison residents criticized the Army for failing to adequately warn them of the danger of the gas leak. The explosion ripped through a four-unit apartment building in Harrison Village, destroying it and heavily damaging a second building, base officials said. The blast occurred hours after fire authorities arrived to investigate a gas leak at another building in the complex, which housed enlisted personnel. That building was being evacuated when the blast went off several hundred feet away, said Major Ronald Downing. Marion County Deputy Coroner Charles W. Green said he could not conclusively identify the dead child discovered by rescue workers Monday morning until after dental records were checked. However, base officials said there was little doubt it was a 5-year-old girl who had been reported missing earlier. The girl's identity was not released. As fire officials investigated the leak, military police notified some residents that their gas was turned off and they might not have heat until Monday, said Sgt. Clayton R. Glass, who first reported the leak behind his quarters. ``We all knew what it was as soon as we heard it. ... We all smelled gas outside, it was so thick,'' said Victoria Glynn, a resident. She said military police asked residents if they wanted to be evacuated to a hotel or to stay in their homes. ``We thought it was for our convenience because we wouldn't have heat. We were never told there was possible danger.'' Joan Adams, another resident, said military police who knocked on her door told her ``there was no danger for us to stay here.'' Lt. Col. Bill Carey, provost marshal, said, ``We didn't feel the whole area needed to be evacuated.'' ``We don't know exactly what caused the explosion,'' said Dan O'Brien of Citizens Gas Co., which supplies gas to the base-operated system. ``What puzzled us was the fire continued,'' he said.``It was gas-fed, which surprised us because the gas was shut off.'' Residents of the 240-unit complex were allowed to return briefly Monday to gather belongings, but they were not told when they could move back. Six people remained hospitalized for treatment of severe burns, four in critical condition and two in serious condition, authorities at Riley and Wishard Memorial hospitals said Monday. Eleven rescue workers and military personnel were treated and released.

DOC.HEAD: Army Snipers, Curfew in Place Following Violence
DOC.TEXT: Army sharpshooters were posted at key intersections and a rare curfew was imposed in Bethlehem following the latest rash of violence and Arab unrest, authorities said Monday. Military snipers wounded at least four Palestinian rock-throwers in ambushes staged at road junctions in the West Bank, Israel television said. A military communique said the shootings were part of ``an increased special action against stone-throwing on civilian and army vehicles.'' Previously, soldiers have had orders to shoot stone-throwers in life-threatening situations, but rarely have sharpshooters been stationed on roads. In Bethlehem in the occupied West Bank, the streets were nearly deserted Monday under a curfew imposed after a Sunday bombing on the Jerusalem-Bethlehem highway that killed an Israeli soldier and wounded two others. Normally, Bethlehem is crowded during the Christmas season with visitors coming to the Church of the Nativity, built on the site where tradition says Christ was born. Israel radio said the bombing was claimed by the Jordan-based Moslem Fundamentalist Islamic Jihad. The national Itim news agency quoted military sources as saying they believed Force 17 of the Palestine Liberation Organization's mainstream Fatah movement was responsible. The report did not elaborate. In Bethelem, army chief of staff Lt. Gen. Dan Shomron vowed to take a hard-line approach against Palestinian assailants. ``We will continue with all the means at our disposal to fight and strike at this murderous, violent core,'' Shomron said. ``What is depressing and increasing tension is the absence of any prospect of peaceful dialogue,'' said Bethlehem's Mayor Elias Freij. In the occupied Gaza Strip, a Palestinian man was shot and stabbed to death by masked assailants on suspicion of collaborating with Israeli authorities, Arab reports said Monday. Sami Abdel Rahman abu Sabra, 34, of Deir el Balah refugee camp was the 317th Palestinian slain by fellow Arabs during the three-year-old uprising. Palestinian reports said 19 Arabs were wounded in scattered clashes with Israeli soldiers in the West Bank and Gaza. In another incident, an explosion went off Monday night near a civilian bus as it headed to the Jewish settlement of Elon Moreh near Nablus, about 35 miles north of Jerusalem, Israeli reports said. No casualties were reported. Four firebombs were thrown at Israeli vehicles in the Ramallah area, about 10 miles north of Jerusalem, causing no damage or injuries, the reports added. Fifty-four Israelis have died in the uprising. Israeli soldiers and civilians have killed 777 Palestinians during the period.

DOC.HEAD: Random Shootings at 9 Homes Terrorizes New Hampshire Residents
DOC.TEXT: Someone with a powerful shotgun has shot at nine homes in the dead of night in the past two weeks, and terrified residents have taken to sleeping on floors and removing Christmas lights. ``I just thank God it hit away from the part of the house where everyone was sleeping,'' Michele Michalides said after her sliding glass door was shattered by a slug. ``It's amazing people haven't gotten hurt.'' Michalides' home was one of four hit Saturday. The shootings, which began Nov. 27, occurred in different neighborhoods within a few miles of each other, and only one house has been hit twice - the home of Police Chief Thomas King. ``Chief was standing within 12 feet of where the bullet came through,'' Deputy Chief Paul Brodeur said. He said the first time King's home was hit police believed it was a coincidence but now they're not so sure. ``It's hard to believe it's not directed at him,'' he said. Brodeur said a man and his wife were showered with glass as they watched television and a little girl who got up from bed to use the bathroom was ``missed by just feet.'' The type of weapon, apparently a 12-gauge shotgun loaded with slugs, is particularly alarming. ``They have extreme penetrating power and can travel through walls like nothing,'' Detective Mark Putney said. ``These are the type of guns used for hunting large game.'' Police said they have no motive or suspects. They are telling people in the area to keep their blinds and drapes drawn at night and keep lights off. Authorities have beefed up patrols in the area and $2,000 has been offered for help in arresting and convicting the perpetrators. Hearing a news report that people might be arming themselves, Mayor Ray Wieczorek urged them not to do anything foolhardy. Michalides said she was dozing on the couch when the sound of her deck's glass door shattering made her bolt upright. ``I can't get the sound out of my head,'' she said. ``I was running around the house screaming. I didn't know it was a gunshot. If I had seen the holes in the wall, I would have been in a million pieces myself.'' The slugs went through the wood deck railing, burst the door, hit the back wall of the dining room and ricocheted into the living room. Now Michalides keeps her curtains drawn and her lights out after dark, and worries that her four children might get up in the middle of the night to get a drink. Across the street, Syvie Gosselin has her two daughters, 12 and 9, sleeping on the floor, but the youngest slept with her parents Sunday night. She said a friend down the street moved her children upstairs and took the lighted Christmas decorations out of the windows. ``Mine aren't going up this year either,'' Gosselin said. Roberta Veilleux, whose home was hit, also draws her curtains, but still plans to put up a Christmas tree with lights. ``We're trying to live as normal as possible,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: China To Buy More Wheat
DOC.TEXT: The Agriculture Department on Monday said it is allowing an additional 1.5 million metric tons to be sold to China under an export subsidy program. Under the Export Enhancement Program, the sales will be made through normal commercial channels at competitive world prices. A subsidy payment in the form of surplus commodities held by the Agriculture Department will make up for the lower global prices. An additional 10,005 metric tons remains available under the previous allocation. The new allocation is for one year.

DOC.HEAD: Mitchell to Lead Mideast Delegation
With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3rd graf to update with House delegation
DOC.TEXT: Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell will head a delegation of eight Democratic senators that will visit Saudi Arabia, Egypt and Israel later this week. ``It is important for members of Congress to have first-hand knowledge of the serious issues in the Persian Gulf,'' the Maine Democrat said in a statement announcing the seven-day trip. A 19-member House delegation, meanwhile, was leaving Tuesday for a trip to Saudi Arabia that also will include a stop in Israel. That group is led by Intelligence Committee Chairman Anthony Beilenson, D-Calif., and Rep. Henry Hyde, R-Ill., the senior GOP member of the panel. ``Through meetings with our allies, briefings with U.S. military commanders and discussions with our servicemen and women in Saudi Arabia, I am hopeful that this trip will increase our understanding of the issues in the Middle East,'' Mitchell said. Joining him on the Senate delegation leaving Thursday will be: Sens. Max Baucus, D-Mont.; Richard Bryan, D-Nev.; Bob Graham, D-Fla.; Herbert Kohl, D-Wis.; Charles Robb, D-Va.; Richard Shelby, D-Ala.; and Paul Simon, D-Ill. The members of the delegation will travel first to Jiddah, Saudi Arabia, where they are scheduled to meet with King Fahd. After military briefings and meetings with service personnel in Dhahran, they will go to Cairo for talks with Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak and other officials. The delegation also is scheduled to visit Jerusalem and meet there with Israeli officials.

DOC.HEAD: Albanian Capital Quiet after Police Disperse Protesters
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with state agency report on students' strike. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Communist leader Ramiz Alia agreed on Monday to meet with striking students, a day after police engaged in fist fights with student demonstrators. A diplomat in Tirana reached by telephone earlier in the day reported there some people were hurt and many were arrested in Sunday's rare show of public defiance against the Communist regime. ``The situation at Tirana University continues to be in disorder,'' the official ATA news agency said late Monday in reporting on what appeared a full-scale protest of university students in the Albanian capital. It said most students boycotted classes, gathering instead at dormitories to draw up a demand for a meeting with Alia ``to express to him their problems and troubles.'' Alia is both head of state and chief of the Communist Party. ATA said Sunday that the students were infuriated by a power outage that left dormitories without heat and light. It said demonstrators tried to exploit the situation for ``political ends.'' The brief dispatch appeared to be the first instance that official news media reported on a confrontation between police and demonstrators before foreign media. This was in line with recent moves to slowly open Albania to the outside world and ease controls on the country's 3.2 million citizens. Albanian leaders have rejected multiparty democracy of the kind that has replaced orthodox Marxist rule in other East European countries. ``It was learned that Comrade Ramiz Alia accepted ... (the students') request to meet and discuss with a students' representation, recommending the others to pursue regularly classes at the university,'' ATA said Monday. But it said that by Monday night no meeting with Alia had taken place - ``because the students have not yet chosen their representatives.'' ATA said Education Minister Skender Gjinushi transmitted Alia's message to striking students, a clear sign of how seriously the protest is being taken. The diplomat, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Sunday's demonstration started at 10 a.m. and lasted until police dispersed protesters at 1 p.m. He said ``a great many students'' took part but gave no estimates.

DOC.HEAD: Actor Corey Feldman Sentenced to Four Years Probation on Drug Charge
DOC.TEXT: Actor Corey Feldman was placed on four years probation and fined $5,000 Monday in a plea bargain related to two drug possession arrests. The teen-age star of such films as ``The Lost Boys'' and ``Stand by Me'' pleaded no contest to two charges of heroin possession and one of cocaine possession. In exchange, prosecutors agreed to dismiss felony charges of heroin possession for sale and transportation of heroin. As part of the plea bargain with Superior Court Judge Gordon Ringer, Feldman agreed to finish a seven-month drug rehabilitation program, which he entered in October. Ringer had issued a bench warrant for Feldman on Friday a day Feldman was arrested on a misdemeanor traffic warrant and for driving with a suspended license. He is to appear in traffic court on Jan. 2. Ringer issued the warrant after learning of the traffic arrest and Feldman's suspension from Cry Help, the live-in drug treatment program. Feldman was suspended forhhaving an unauthorized visitor. As part of the rehabilitation program, Feldman will be barred from working in the entertainment industry, said attorney Richard Hirsch. Feldman, 19, was arrested Sept. 20 in connection with unpaid traffic tickets. Officers said they found two packets of heroin in his sock during a search at a North Hollywood police station. He was arrested March 9 during a traffic stop when officers found 25 balloons containing heroin and cocaine in his car, police said. A short time after, he urged his fans to resist drugs. Feldman's publicist, MichaelLevine, said Monday that the actor would continue to do anti-drug work, even though it was not part of his sentence. He said Feldman believed the sentence was ``fair and equitable.''

DOC.HEAD: Military Brass Salutes Marines Going to Saudi Arabia
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
LaserPhotos JAKX2,3,4,7
DOC.TEXT: Twenty-four thousand Marines, the largest troop review the Corps has formed this century, received a ceremonial send-off Monday as they prepared to join U.S. troops in the Middle East. ``I want to salute my warriors today,'' Marine Corps Commandant Gen. Al Gray told the massed members of the 2nd Marine Expeditionary Force. Gray told the Marines and the 10,000 family members and supporters at the send-off that the U.S. response to the invasion is not about oil. ``We have built a very firm alliance in that region,'' he said.``Many different countries, nations ... and different religious beliefs have banded together to stop this terrorist aggression. ``Only the United States could take the lead to provide stability throughout the world and others have rallied to our cause,'' he said. The formation included about 8,000 Marine reservists from across the country. Adm. Powell Carter Jr., commander-in-chief of Marine Corps Fleet Atlantic, told the leathernecks that ``we all hope that this array of fighting forces along with the economic sanctions ... will convince Saddam Hussein to respect the will of the world and get out of Kuwait.'' ``If they don't, we know you'll do your job. You are Marines,'' he said. The Marines will join others already stationed in the Persian Gulf region, bringing the total number of Marines in active duty there to 60,000. About 400,000 American troops will be in the Middle East by year's end. Units of the force have been flying to Saudi Arabia since the last week of November in groups of up to 400. But the deployment will begin in earnest Wednesday, when the Marines are airlifted out of Cherry Point Air Station at a rate of about 1,000 a day, said base spokesman Maj. Jay Farrar. The imminent departure of the Marines is something most military families accept, said Paula Lawrence, whose 2-year-old son, Ralph Jr., sported camouflage pants and a Marine cap. ``You know they have to go, but you never get used to it,'' said Mrs. Lawrence, whose husband, Warrant Officer Ralph Lawrence, is among those scheduled to deploy this month.

DOC.HEAD: Kemp Pushes Capital-Gains Tax Cut With GOP Governors
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 9-10: ``In Washington,'' comments of Nunn's press aide
DOC.HEAD: With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle accused congressional Democrats on Monday of playing politics with the Persian Gulf crisis, saying some of them are ``portraying themselves as the party of peace'' and the Republican administration as bent on war. He did not name any Democrats as he asked Republican governors to help counter that message by speaking out for President Bush's policy. Quayle denounced Senate and House hearings on U.S. policy toward Iraq as a vehicle for criticism without accountability - although Bush had said those inquiries were all right with him. ``They felt compelled to have hearings but not compelled to allow the full Congress to vote on the actions taken by the president,'' Quayle told the Republican Governors Association. When a governor asked why the administration didn't seek a conditional declaration of war, Quayle said that had posed a dilemma because ``there is no perceived consensus in the Congress,'' and division or restrictive measures could undercut Bush policy. Despite his criticism, Quayle said he believes that ``when the chips are down, when America's vital interests are on the line, the majority of Congress can rise above partisan politics,'' and will support Bush. The vice president said solid congressional unity behind Bush ``would strengthen the chances for peace. ``But that would require Congress to resist the temptation to use the current hearings on the gulf for partisan political advantage,'' he said. ``Unfortunately, by portraying themselves as the party of peace and the administration as the party of war, some congressional Democrats - but by no means all congressional Democrats - seem to have placed partisanship above statesmanship.'' In Washington, Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Armed Services Committee, which held hearings on Persian Gulf policy, was not available for comment, according to his press aide, Scott Williams. Williams pointed to some of Nunn's appearance Saturday on the CNN ``Evans and Novak'' in which Nunn said, ``I think the hearings have been very responsible,'' and, ``When the guns start firing and when the troops are in war, I think you will find Sam Nunn and most other people behind the American flag and behind the men and women who are over there risking their lives.'' Earlier, another administration official had urged the governors to push for a capital gains tax cut as a step to get the economy moving and ease the dual pressures of slumping state revenues and increasing needs. ``It is time for, if you will, a Reagan-type tax cut,'' Secretary of Housing and Urban Development Jack Kemp told them. ``The revenues of the states are suffering from the high tax on capital gains, over which you have no control unless you join the debate,'' Kemp said. To the argument that a policy seeking to generate tax revenues by cutting tax rates is a free lunch dream, Kemp replied: ``There is a free lunch to governors. It is that if we get this economy moving again at the federal level, it will be felt at the state level.'' He said the capital gains tax rate should be cut to 15 percent as President Bush proposed this year, and eliminated entirely on assets held for longer than three years. ``It would unlock trillions of dollars,'' Kemp said, benefit all Americans and disprove Democratic assertions that Republicans want tax cuts that benefit only the rich. Opening the two-day conference, Gov. James G. Martin of North Carolina told his colleagues ``state governments in all parts of this great nation are being squeezed ... caught in that vise between declining revenues and pressing needs.'' He said it will take innovation and more productive use of dwindling tax resources to deal with the problem. But there were more speeches on the challenge than specific answers to the dilemma. William J. Bennett, the outgoing drug policy director who is to become chairman of the Republican National Committee next month, told the governors that politicians in both parties should ``stop talking past each other'' and find steps that will work to improve the lives of Americans who need help. He said his list includes protection against crime and violence, better education and equal opportunity. Bennett said equal opportunity doesn't require affirmative action that would involve ``preference by race'' in hiring or education. He said he thinks affirmative action should be an issue of political debate. Democratic leaders plan to try to reenact the civil rights bill President Bush vetoed earlier this year on grounds it would impose racial quotas. The administration plans to propose its own version once again. Republicans made the quota question an issue in this year's campaign, especially in North Carolina and California. Bennett said it is a debate that should continue. ``I do think this is an issue that we should talk about,'' he told reporters. He said he favors affirmative action if it means that minority Americans get equal word of opportunities for jobs or education, and an equal opportunity to fill them. Bennett said if minority applicants get an edge because schools or employers want to promote diversity on their rosters, that is okay with him. ``Diversity is not a bad end and aim in itself,'' he said. A dozen GOP governors, three governors-elect and one candidate were attending the conference. ``I'm a governor-elect in limbo,'' said Fife Symington of Arizona, who led narrowly in the Nov. 6 election but did not get a clear majority and faces a Feb. 26 runoff election.

DOC.HEAD: Unseasonable Warmth Stretches From Mid-Atlantic Coast to Plains
DOC.TEXT: A warm spell settled over much of the United States Monday, with temperatures 10 to 20 degrees warmer than normal for the second week in December. The unseasonable warmth stretched from the central Atlantic Coast across the Ohio and Mississippi valleys and into the northern two-thirds of the Plains region. Cheyenne, Wyo., reached 66 degrees to set a record high for the date. The previous mark of 64 had stood since 1939. Other cities with record highs Monday included Grand Island, Neb., with 66; Laramie, Wyo., 58; and Sioux Falls, S.D., 53. Light snow was scattered over north-central Minnesota, and from northern Vermont across northern Maine. Rain fell over northwest California, western and northern Oregon, eastern and northern Washington, northern Idaho and northwest Montana. There were no reports of measurable snowfall or heavy rainfall during the six hours ending at 1 p.m. EST. The nation's low was 7 below zero at Jackson, Wyo. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 24 degrees at Warroad, Minn. to 80 at Oceanside, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Greenland Premier Calls Election in Wake of Political Scandal
DOC.TEXT: Greenland Premier Jonathan Motzfeldt has called for March elections following a scandal arising from allegations that Cabinet ministers misused public funds, news reports said Monday. Opponents of Motzfeldt's socialist government claim to have documents to show that government members, including the premier, spent state money on lavish meals for the party faithful, the Greenland newspaper Atuagagdliutit said. Motzfeldt, a pastor of the Greenland Lutheran Church, has held the premiership since Greenland won partial independence from Denmark in 1979. About 53,000 people reside in Greenland, which has 840,000 square miles of territory, about 80 percent of it ice-covered. Motzfeldt allegedly used $9,000 of taxpayers' money on a luxurious dinner in support of his own re-election as party leader, the paper said. Bowing to opposition demands that his administration resign, Motzfeldt set the vote for March 5. In the last ballot, in May 1987, Motzfeldt's Siumut Party and the non-socialist opposition Atassut Party each won 11 mandates in the 16-seat Landsting, or homerule parliament.
