Siumut formed a coalition with the leftist Inuit Ataqatigiit party, which has one mandate. The conservative-leaning Issittup Party has four.

DOC.HEAD: Assembly Speaker Miller: I'll Be Indicted
DOC.TEXT: Assembly Speaker Mel Miller, the New York state Legislature's most powerful Democrat, said Monday that he expected to be indicted on federal felony charges. Miller said the indictment, expected later this week or next week from U.S. Attorney Andrew Maloney of Brooklyn, would charge him with some form of mail fraud for his role in a real estate transaction in 1983 and 1984. Miller denied any wrongdoing and said he would fight the charges. Such an indictment would make Miller the second Democratic legislative leader in Albany facing felony charges. State Senate Minority Leader Manfred Ohrenstein of Manhattan is to go on trial in February on state charges he hired ``no-show'' employees with public funds. The charges against Miller, 51, involve his private law practice and not his official duties as a state legislator, he said. Nonetheless, if he's convicted of a felony, Miller would be automatically removed from the Brooklyn Assembly seat he has held since 1970. ``The only thing I'm guilty of is being speaker of the New York state Assembly. I have done nothing,'' Miller told a state Capitol news conference Monday evening. ``We believe the crimes are being brought because I'm a very nice victim and it would be wonderful to put my scalp in someone's belt,'' he said. Maloney had no immediate comment. As speaker, Miller is one of the three most powerful officials in state government and he has virtual veto power over any legislation. He has been speaker since January 1987. Miller said he had informed Gov. Mario Cuomo and fellow legislative leaders of the pending indictment earlier in the day. The Democratic leader said he didn't believe the charges that would be brought against him represented a crime under state or federal law.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Accepts Nobel Peace Prize in Absentia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with acceptance speeches, banquet. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos MOSB6, STO4
DOC.TEXT: A stand-in for Mikhail Gorbachev, in accepting the 1990 Nobel Peace Prize for him Monday, read a statement by the Soviet president saying mankind has reached ``the moment of truth.'' Gorbachev said problems at home kept him from attending the Oslo ceremony. In Stockholm, Sweden, King Carl XVI Gustaf handed out gold Nobel Prize medallions and diplomas at a ceremony for the 10 laureates in medicine, literature, physics, chemistry and economics. Literature prize winner Octavio Paz of Mexico received the longest ovation from the crowd of 1,800 at Stockholm Concert Hall. He later told a glittering banquet in the Swedish capital, ``We are at the end of ideologies. We don't know what will be the face of the future. ``But we do know that the environment is in danger. We need to rediscover the feeling that the universe is a unity and that we are a part of it.'' The Swedish Academy cited Paz for ``impassioned writing with wide horizons, characterized by sensuous intelligence and humanistic integrity.'' Each prize this year is worth 4 million kronor (about $715,000). Sole winners get the whole amount. Multiple winners in one category divide it. Checks are deposited electronically into the laureates' bank accounts the day after the ceremony. The United States, which produced eight winners this year in economics, physics and medicine, is the only country that taxes the prize money. The winners at in Stockholm talked about the Earth's future and paid tribute to their patients, students and co-workers in accepting the awards for achievements that benefitted mankind. Gorbachev's acceptance speech was read by envoy Anatoly Kovalyov in Oslo City Hall. Referring to the past ``unnatural division of Europe'' and to Germany's recent unification, the Soviet leader wrote, ``We have begun to resolutely tear down the material foundations of a military, political and ideological confrontation.'' He quoted 18th century German philosopher Immanuel Kant: ``Kant prophesized that mankind would one day be faced with a dilemma: either to be joined in a true union of nations or to perish in a war of annihilation ending in the extinction of the human race. ``Now, as we move from the second to the third millennium, the clock has struck the moment of truth.'' In Moscow, Gorbachev said he regarded the 71st peace prize as ``a recognition of what we call perestroika and innovative political thinking, which is of vital significance for human destinies all over the world.'' Protesters in Oslo, Stockholm and Moscow denounced the Norwegian Nobel Committee's decision to award him the prize and complained about violence,human rights violations and political restrictions in the Soviet Union. Kovalyov said the $715,000 probably would be donated to worthy causes. Joseph E. Murray of Milford, Mass., accepted the medicine prize on behalf of himself and co-winner E. Donnall Thomas of Seattle, whose pioneering work in bone marrow transplants led to a cure for most childhood leukemia. Murray, who performed the first organ transplant, with kidneys, in 1954, said: ``The prize pays tribute to the hundreds of patients now living healthy lives. We are indebted to these patients who have been unselfishly involved in this research.'' Elias Corey of Cambridge, Mass., recipient of the chemistry prize for discovering how to simulate organic synthesis in the laboratory, made hundreds of medicines and other products easily available and affordable. ``Chemistry can be applied to improve the life of man and make life happier for all of us,'' Corey said. Richard E. Taylor of Medicine Hat, Alberta;, Jerome I. Friedman of Chicago and Henry W. Kendall of Boston shared the physics prize for experiments which helped prove the existence of subatomic particles called quarks and increased knowledge about the basic structure of the universe. ``There was great elation'' among financial economists over the recognition of their field by this year's Nobel Memorial Prize in Economics, said winner Harry M. Markowitz of New York. He spoke for co-recipients Merton H. Miller of Chicago and William F. Sharpe of Stanford University. The three were recognized for pioneering work in the theory of financial economics and how markets function. The Nobel Prizes are awarded on the anniversary of the death of Alfred Nobel, Swedish inventor of dynamite who established them in his 1896 will. Sweden's Central Bank established the economics prize in 1968. Gorbachev is the the third Eastern European who has not received his prize in person since 1975. Poland's Lech Walesa won in 1983 and Soviet human rights champion Andrei Sakharov, now dead, won in 1975.

DOC.HEAD: Fiji Says It Wants Back into the British Commonwealth
DOC.TEXT: Interim Prime Minister Ratu Sir Kamisese Mara said Tuesday he wants his island republic readmitted to the British Commonwealth. Fiji was excluded from the Commonwealth in 1987 after a newly elected, Indian-dominated government was overthrown by two military coups. The Queen was replaced as head of state and a republic declared. In an interview with the Fiji Times newspaper, Ratu Mara criticized the Commonwealth's veto rules that allow one member-state to determine whether others should be allowed to join or be barred. He called for a ruling saying the majority of Commonwealth countries should determine member applications. In a bitter diplomatic row, India has vowed to veto any re-entry application in protest over a new constitution that favors indigenous Fijians over other races, including ethnic Indians. Ratu Mara was quoted as saying that he would like to see Fiji back in the Commonwealth fold. ``But I don't know how we could return because I don't know how we were ousted from it,'' he said. ``I hope a system is devised whereby the views of the majority of members determine whether a new member is admitted or an old member returns.'' Ethnic Indians, originally brought to Fiji by the colonial British last century as indentured sugar plantation workers, comprised a majority of Fiji's 720,000 population. But emigration since then and two coups have left them a minority.

DOC.HEAD: New Evidence of Arizona Senatorial Conflict
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 13th graf: ``Before Stevens,'' to restore commissioner's name, William Von Raab
DOC.TEXT: Fresh conflicts between Arizona's two senators surfaced Monday at ethics hearings on the relationship between five senators and former S&L owner Charles H. Keating Jr. A former employee of Keating testified before the Senate Ethics Committee that Sen. Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz. called him and expressed keen interest in critical comments the executive made about Sen. John McCain, R-Ariz. The ex-employee, David E. Stevens, wrote the committee last October that McCain had never intended to reimburse Keating's company for his wife's cost of trips the couple took on Keating's corporate airplanes. Monday, Stevens said of this and other critical statements in his letter, ``I wish I had written these differently.'' Stevens, who handled tax matters for Keating's American Continental Corp., said DeConcini was sent a copy of the letter and called him at home on Nov. 26. DeConcini asked whether an affidavit could be prepared based on his letter. ``He said that he wasn't using my letter to hurt McCain and, in fact, he didn't think the letter would hurt him,'' Stevens said in an written account of his converstion with DeConcini released by the committee. Stevens also said, in his testimony Monday, that DeConcini asked, ``Would you mind if I released this to the press?'' The letter in fact did reach the press, although Stevens said the matter of public release was left unresolved in his conversation with Deconcini. The trips by McCain and his wife on Keating's planes from 1984-86 have not figured prominently so far in hearings on the five senators' assistance to Keating and interventions with S&L regulators on his behalf. McCain reimbursed Keating's American Continental Corp. for the trips in 1989 and was cleared of wrongdoing by the House and Senate ethics committees. The trips were made when McCain was a member of the House. Earlier in the hearings, aides to both senators gave much different accounts of conversations between the lawmakers just before they participated in crucial meetings with thrift regulator's on Keating's behalf in 1987. Other subjects of the ethics probe are Sens. Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich., John Glenn, D-Ohio and Alan Cranston, D-Calif. Before Stevens testified, former U.S. customs commissioner William Von Raab told the committee that senators often intervened with him on behalf of constituents. Von Raab testified for Sen. Dennis DeConcini, one of five senators under investigation for intervening with thrift regulators on behalf of Charles H. Keating Jr. Asked by committee member Warren Rudman, R-N.H. ``where you would draw that line'' of unacceptable conduct by senators, von Raab replied: ``If someone tried to bribe me.'' DeConcini was the only one of the five senators present as von Raab testified that lawmakers often asked him to grant waivers for constituents and to reconsider regulations. The committee held its 15th day of hearings on the relationship between the five senators and Keating, who with associates contributed $1.3 million to the lawmakers' campaigns and causes. The five senators asked thrift regulators in 1987 to reconsider a regulation limiting risky investments such as those undertaken by Keating's failing Lincoln Savings and Loan, of Irvine, Calif. Lincoln was seized in April 1989 at a potential cost to taxpayers of more than $2 billion. Regulators testified that DeConcini sought to negotiate a waiver of the rule for Lincoln and used the word ``we'' to indicate he was speaking for the other senators. Regulators contend that DeConcini improperly negotiated on Keating's behalf at that meeting. Von Raab said he had never been confronted by lawmakers under the exact circumstances as those faced by banking regulators when the five senators met with them in April 1987. Committee special counsel Robert S. Bennett noted that those meetings were held without aides, on behalf of a single constituent - Lincoln - which already had been found in violation of the rule on direct investments. ``All you have said is Sen. DeConcini is a friend f yours and all of your dealings with him have been honorable and appropriate,'' committee member Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., told von Raab. Von Raab said there were circumstances when lawmakers had intervened with him for constituents seeking reduction of fines and waiver of regulations for constituents. ``I never felt intervention ... seeking one of those results ... had been improper,'' he said. Other witnesses testified in DeConcini's defense, describing help he provided for law enforcement, drug-treatment projects and disabled veterans. They said he acted without regard to campaign contributions. ``I could not imagine how he could have done anything more,'' said Rod Mullin, who runs Amity Inc., a Tuscon-based assistance program for the poor.

DOC.HEAD: Pre-Columbus Site Discovered on St. Thomas
DOC.TEXT: Bulldozers at an island construction zone on St. Thomas have unearthed an achaeological site that could date to 900 years before Columbus first visited the Virgin Islands. Archaeologist Elizabeth Righter and volunteers from the National Park Service in Atlanta are carefully documenting the dig, and indications are it is about 1,400 years old. ``It's getting more extraordinary by the minute,'' Righter said Monday. ``We're finding much more than we ever dared to hope.'' Finds thus far have revealed two skeletons, food remains, a possible ball court and handicrafts. Preliminary examination of the skeletons indicates the man and woman were about 4-foot, 7-inches tall, and stocky with well-developed shoulders. Righter speculates they hiked the island's steep hills to and from the sea, carrying loads on their shoulders. Righter said the food remains are important because they contain charcoal and pottery. The charcoal can be carbon-dated to fix a more-precise time for each layer of the settlement. Food remains indicate a diet of crab, whelks, reef fish, turtle and cassava bread. The ball court is the first to be found on St. Thomas. Righter says pieces of what may be stone collars worn around the ballplayers' hips to hit the ball in a soccer-like game, have been found. Elaborately carved shell ornaments and finely crafted pottery, similar to what is now in Venezuela, are also among the ruins. Planning and Natural Resources Earth Change Inspector, Tom Linnio first discovered signs of the village during a routine inspection after inland property was cleared for the shopping area. Righter has been operating from donations, including those from the development owner, William Mahaffey, Virgin Islands Telephone Corp., Gassett Motors and St. Thomas Historic Trust. Labor has been donated by the Virgin Islands National Guard. National Park archaeologists are donating their time, as are members of the St. Thomas Historic Trust, the Explorer's Club and the St. Thomas-St. John Environmental Association. Meanwhile, the construction project is on hold until exploration is completed. Mahaffey said he will display a replica of the village in a 30-foot glass rotunda in the middle of the completed mall.

DOC.HEAD: Khartoum Government Sends Back Displaced Sudanese
DOC.TEXT: The government on Monday began transfering home hundreds of southern Sudanese who had been living in shantytowns around the capital, hoping to escape a civil war and food shortage. A train carrying 619 displaced people took off Monday for the western town of Babanousa, where the passengers will be transported by road to their homes in southern Sudan, the official Sudan News Agency said. The agency quoted Brig. Mohamed Osman, the governor of the capital Khartoum, as saying ``the reasons behind their displacement have now disappeared,'' and urged the returnees to go back home and start producing their own food. The displaced people poured in over the past few years, setting up shantytowns around Khartoum to escape the civil war in the south and the subsequent food shortages. The agency said the passengers all left on their own free will. It said the government has arranged for trains to move them out of Khartoum every two weeks. The government has denied earlier claims that it was forcing the displaced people to return to the war-torn south. In other parts of Sudan, authorities are discouraging the establishment of refugee camps where thousands have recently arrived, escaping a famine. The government is apparently trying to avoid a repetition of Sudan's 1984-85 tragedy when thousands died in camps from lack of adequate food and medicines. Thousands of people fleeing hunger in the western region of Kordofan arrived at a camp near the regional capital, el-Obeid. They are to be given a month's supply of food and sent home. A drought and consequent famine have struck most of the country, affecting up to 7 million of its 25 million people, and worse is expected within six months.

DOC.HEAD: 10,000 Teachers, Parents Protest Hungarian Budget Cuts
DOC.TEXT: More than 10,000 teachers and parents on Monday stood in pouring rain in front of the Home Affairs Ministry to protest what they called inadequate budget allocations for 1991. The rally was called by the Teachers' Federation to underline widespread anxiety about how budget cutbacks may threaten the quality of teaching. ``The teachers are demonstrating for the children,'' Mrs. Istvan Szoelloesi, general secretary of the Federation, told the Hungarian news agency MTI. She rejected charges that the teachers were only seeking pay raises. ``Teachers are only one component of teaching. But to keep kindergartens and schools open, you need heat and light, and in some places the money for these things will soon run out.'' Parliament on Tuesday is to begin debate on the 1991 budget. The draft budget calls for a $1.3 billion deficit.

DOC.HEAD: High Profile Week Begins for Daily News, Including Mediation in Washington
DOC.TEXT: The Daily News and its unions said Monday they will go to Washington this week for a federal effort to mediate a bitter 6-week-old strike. Both sides accepted the invitation of the director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service to meet with him. Negotiations have been going on since the beginning of the year on contracts that expired in March. The talks with the unions continued after the strike began Oct. 25 amid violence. James F. Power, a spokesman for the mediation service in Washington, said, ``Right now we feel quite happy we are getting them under the same roof. There's no way to say how these things are going to evolve.'' The Allied Printing Trades Council, the umbrella of the nine unions striking the paper, is to meet with the service's director, Bernard DeLury, Wednesday. DeLury will meet separately with management. The News says that by the end of this year its losses over the past decade will have mounted to about $200 million and that it must have major concessions to operate profitably. The unions say they might be able to grant some relief but that the ``management rights'' provisions sought by the paper are too broad. The board of the Tribune Co., the Daily News' parent company, was scheduled to meet Tuesday in Chicago to discuss the strike. Also Tuesday, a U.S. Senate hearing will be held in New York on the issue of hiring replacement workers during a strike, said Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio. On Monday afternoon, Gov. Mario Cuomo, the Rev. Jesse Jackson and Cardinal John O'Connor addressed a union rally of 6,500 across the street from the paper's offices. Police reported no incidents. ``The whole world is watching us ... as they watched Eastern. It has to come out better this time,'' Cuomo said, referring to the union struggle of the strikers at Eastern Airlines. The paper has printed daily since the strike began, although its circulation has dropped from 1.09 million to 552,000 as of last week. The use of more than 1,600 hawkers has helped the Daily News regain some of the circulation lost when large numbers of vendors refused to sell it. In another development Monday, unions representing transit workers said they would make sure the paper's hawkers complied with restrictions placed on them by a judge in allowing them to sell the Daily News on subway platforms. U.S. District Court Judge Miriam G. Cedarbaum ordered that there be no more than three hawkers at each station and that they remain within 10 feet of any existing newsstand, newspaper rack or newspaper vending machine not displaying or offering the News.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Recommends Life Sentence for Doctor Convicted of Identity-Switch Murder
DOC.TEXT: A jury recommended Monday that a doctor convicted of murder in an insurance fraud case serve life in prison without the possibility of parole. Dr. Richard Boggs, 57, was ordered back to court Feb. 1 for sentencing by Superior Court Judge Florence Marie Cooper. Boggs was convicted July 12 on nine felonies, including the 1988 slaying of Ellis Henry Greene. That jury deadlocked in the penalty phase and a new jury was empaneled to decide whether the doctor should serve life in prison or death in the gas chamber. Prosecutors claimed Boggs and the two owners of the troubled Just Sweats sports apparel company of Ohio, Melvin E. Hanson and John B. Hawkins, conspired to switch Greene's identity with Hanson's in an effort to collect life insurance. The prosecution said Boggs lured Greene from a bar to his medical office in April 1988 and suffocated him, although the cause of death was never conclusively proved through medical evidence. Boggs misdentified the body as Hanson and Hawkins had the body cremated the following day. Hanson's credit cards and birth certificate were found with the body. Hanson and Hawkins allegedly shared a $1.5 million insurance payoff and Boggs got $6,500, prosecutors said. Hanson, who had facial plastic surgery, fled to Mexico but was captured when he returned and is awaiting trial. Hawkins remains at large. Boggs insisted he didn't kill Greene. He claimed Hanson threatened to expose his homosexuality and ruin his practice in Glendale if he refused to sign a phony death certificate identifying the dead Greene as Hanson.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Journalist Returns to Earth Feeling Heavy But Hungry
DOC.TEXT: Toyohiro Akiyama's legs seemed like strangers to him when he returned to Earth on Monday after eight days as the first journalist and the first Japanese in space. He had not, however, not forgotten his fondness for beer. Akiyama, 48, told Japanese television viewers from his landing site in the Soviet Union, ``It seems like I came back as a mass of desire.'' Otherwise, he said, after the weightlessness of life in space, he felt ``heavy, heavy. I thought I could stand, but I felt I have no legs.'' Akiyama rode back to Earth in a Soyuz space capsule with Soviet cosmonauts Gennadi Manakov and Gennadi Strekalov, who were winding up a four-month stay aboard the Mir space station. Akiyama is a news director for Tokyo Broadcasting System, which paid the Soviets $12 million for his rocket ride and short stay at the space station, and spent an additional $25 million on the project. It expects to lose $7.4 million on the venture, even after firguring in advertising revenues and proceeds from documentaries and lectures by Akiyama. TBS showed exclusive live telecasts from their astro-reporter each night during his Odyssey, which enjoyed high ratings. He expressed concern about global pollution he viewed from orbit. He even recited Japanese haiku poetry. The newsman was mobbed by TBS reporters upon emerging, waving and smiling from the capsule. They sped to the landing site - the frozen tundra in Kazakstan republic in Central Asia - to beam live to Japan his thoughts upon arriving back on Earth. ``Yes, it's very beautiful,'' he said when asked how it felt to be back. TBS then arranged for Akiyama to speak to his wife Kyoko, who watched the landing from the company's Tokyo studios. ``I'm back,'' said Akiyama, wrapped in a parka and with his space helmet still in place. ``I worried a bit,'' replied his wife. ``Did the kids do all right on their exams?'' he asked. ``Why ask such things now?'' she said. ``I want to eat something good.'' ``I've prepared it,'' his wife reassured him. Akiyama told viewers, ``My body was in a state of weightlessness, say, about one hour ago. That is to say my body, including brain and stomach, was in a condition like floating. ``Now everything is being attracted downward. I think I can easily raise my legs, but I have a strange feeling that I must form an intention to do so.'' He said it seemed like he was feeling weight and air for the first time. TBS devoted the entire day to covering events surrounding his landing, which came at about 3:05 p.m. local time. The network rented four helicopters. When a reporter from one copter spotted the capsule plummeting to Earth, he yelled, ``I see it! I see it! It's there! It's there!'' Reporters were at the site less than 10 minutes after touchdown. His voyage began Dec. 2 with liftoff from Baikonur Cosmodrome, about 1,300 miles east of Moscow. He and two Soviet cosmonauts linked up with Mir Tuesday. He took with him six Japanese tree frogs, to test how they adapt to weightlessness. Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu told reporters the mission was ``significant for success in Soviet-Japanese cooperation. I expect this to a produce a very good influence.'' Having a paying passenger aboard was a major step in Soviet efforts to commercialize their space program. Japanese corporate sponsors, including a diaper maker and a toothpaste company, had their logos and names plastered on the rocket that launched Akiyama into space.

DOC.HEAD: Amid Hostage Homecomings, More Tough Talk from Both Sides
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 4th graf pvs `Defense Secretary' to ADD comments by Aziz. Picks up 5th grf pvs, `Even as...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos FRA7,9; DHR1-2; LON1,3; WX19-20,22
DOC.TEXT: More than 150 freed American hostages on Monday returned to joyful homecomings, but hopes of peace raised by their release were dimmed by tough statements frm both sides in the Persian Gulf crisis. Despite its decision to free the thousands of foreign captives, the Baghdad government made its most bellicose statement in weeks on Kuwait, saying it would ``not compromise one iota'' in its claim to the emirate it seized on Aug. 2. President Bush, in a Washington speech proclaiming Monday as Human Rights Day, denounced the Iraqi takeover of Kuwait as a ``systematic assault on the soul of a nation.'' Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, meanwhile, said Iraq's move to free the foreigners should not create unrealistic expectations about a resolution to the gulf crisis. He also said Iraqi President Saddam Hussein deserved no particular praise for deciding to end his ``abhorrent'' hostage holding. Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz, however, complained that Iraqis were confused by the hard-line statements from U.S. officials following the hostage release. ``We thought ... that this unanimous decision on the part of my president would create a positive atmosphere,'' said Aziz in an interview Monday with Cable News Network. Even as the freed hostages were streaming out of Iraq, more and more military forces converged on the gulf region. France announced it would increase its troops by an unspecified number, and Cheney said Saddam had been sending in reinforcements in recent days. Despite the continued talk of war, there was little that could dampen the hostages' joy at coming home. A Pan American flight from Frankfurt, Germany, arrived at Andrews Air Force Base outside Washington late Monday afternoon with 152 Americans and four Canadians. Those aboard the military-chartered flight had flown out of Baghdad the day before, the first Americans to go free under an Iraqi decree releasing all foreign hostages. Some in that group were taking later flights home. At the Frankfurt stopover, many appeared thin and tired after their 4{-month ordeal in captivity. ``It was like a gulag,'' said 58-year-old Robert Vinton of Santa Fe., N.M., who was held south of Baghdad at an oil refinery. Provisions on board the U.S.-bound flight included Big Macs and champagne, U.S. officials said. At Andrews, the former hostages appeared tired but most smiled as they left the plane. Relatives in the crowd held up signs, including one that said, ``Daddy, Daddy, I Need You.'' The group got on three buses to be taken to a processing area and made no public comments. Another 123 British, Australian and Irish citizens arrived in London aboard two flights from Rome and Frankfurt. ``I feel euphoric,'' said freed British hostage Harvey May. Australian Steve Hicking proposed to his girlfriend when she met him at London's Heathrow Airport. She said yes. Also, 384 Westerners, about 227 of them Britons, left Baghdad aboard a British-chartered flight on Monday. Diplomats said some Americans were aboard but were unable to give an immediate breakdown. U.S. officials said they planned to charter another flight from Baghdad in three or four days to evacuate the rest of the estimated 750 Americans in Iraq and Kuwait. Britain said it hoped to fly out another 320 Britons and others on Tuesday. Saddam said Thursday that all the foreign hostages could leave. About 8,000 Westerners had been trapped since the invasion of Kuwait, including about 600 held at strategic sites as ``human shields'' against possible attack by the U.S.-dominated multinational force. A rapid U.S. buildup of that force is in progress, aimed at bringing troop strength in the region to 400,000 by mid-January. That coincides with the Jan. 15 deadline the U.N. Security Council gave Saddam for getting out of Kuwait or facing possible military action. Word of the French decision to send in more troops came from Defense Minister Jean-Pierre Chevenement, who said the size of the increase would be announced later. France currently has about 6,200 army and air force troops in Saudi Arabia, where most of the multinational force is deployed. Iraq is building up its forces too, Cheney told a defense industry group in Washington. Even as Saddam freed hostages, Cheney said, ``he has simultaneously continued to build up his deployments in Kuwait, to enhance his fortifications and to add additional forces to the regions.'' The defense secretary said despite the release of the hostages, Saddam ``has given us absolutely no indication whatsoever of any intention'' of withdrawing from Kuwait. The latest show of Iraqi defiance on that point came from the Baghdad government's information minister Latif Jassim, who said any notion of an Iraqi withdrawal was ``nothing but dreams and wishful thinking.'' ``Kuwait is Iraqi, whether in the past, present or future,'' he said in a statement carried by the official Iraqi News Agency. ``We will not compromise one iota on Kuwaiti territory.'' Some weekend reports had said Iraq had redrawn its border with Kuwait in possible preparation for a partial pullout. The reports, in the Observer of London and the Al-Khaleej daily in Abu Dhabi, said Saddam's aim was to keep the entire Rumailah oilfield and two islands, Warba and Bubiyan, which would give it access to the Persian Gulf. The oilfield, which lies chiefly in Iraq, extends two miles into Kuwait and Saddam accused Kuwait of overexploiting it before he invaded. Also Monday, Coretta Scott King was at the United Nations with a coalition of peace activists trying to organize nationwide peace demonstrations on Jan. 15. That is the deadline in the U.N. resolution calling on Iraq to get out of Kuwait. It is also the birthdate of Mrs. King's husband, slain civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr. ``We will not tolerate making this a day of war and military aggression,'' she said. In other developments: -Crude oil prices rose 32 cents Monday to close at $26.90 per barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. -The Pentagon said it is sending more F-15 Eagle fighter planes to the gulf. Elements of the 36th Tactical Fighter Wing at Bitburg, Germany, will deploy starting Dec. 28. It did not say how many planes will go. A tactical fighter wing normally would include about 70 aircraft. An undisclosed number of F-15s was sent to the gulf in August. The Army on Monday also announced it was ordered to active duty 1,457 members of National Guard and Reserve units in 20 states. The activations brought to 120,281 the number of reservists called to active duty in all four services.

DOC.HEAD: Stasi Allegations Build Against Last East German Leader
DOC.TEXT: German news media on Monday reported links between a former East German secret police officer and Lothar de Maiziere, the nation's last leader and now a member of Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Cabinet. The reports identifying de Maiziere's ``control officer'' followed an earlier media allegation that de Maiziere worked for the now-disbanded secret police, known as the Stasi. Kohl spokesman Hans Klein said the chancellor was ``reserving judgment'' until a full probe is completed. De Maiziere now is a minister-without-portfolio in the Cabinet. De Maiziere has repeatedly denied the allegations. He guided East Germany to unity with West Germany on Oct. 3 and was his nation's only democratically elected leader. The scandal broke over the weekend after Der Spiegel magazine said an index card in Stasi files contained the ``cover name'' of a Stasi informer and de Maiziere's address in former East Berlin. Another news magazine, Stern, and the newspaper Bild reported Monday they had found de Maiziere's reputed ``control officer,'' identified as former Stasi Maj. Edgar Hasse. Bild quoted the man as saying, ``I was his (de Maiziere's) control officer. I met with de Maiziere regularly.'' Stern said it has found other former Stasi employees who also claim that de Maiziere had been an important informer. Stern quoted Hasse as saying he recruited de Maiziere, then an attorney, in 1982. Hasse claimed de Maiziere provided the Stasi with information about East German church leaders, the magazine reported. De Maiziere had close contacts with Lutheran Church officials. Stern telexed copies of its report to other news media in advance of Thursday's publication. Stern said Eberhard Jaekel, identified as another former Stasi officer, also claims that de Maiziere had been an informer. But the issue is complicated by Stasi files' being kept under lock and key in former East Berlin. Under the unification treaty, access to the files is tightly controlled because of their highly sensitive nature. Kohl's government has asked the official who safeguards the files, Joachim Gauck, to examine them as part of the probe. De Maiziere's friends and political allies on Monday said they believe his denials. ``I'll believe Mr. de Maiziere before I believe a former Stasi officer,'' said Otto Lambsdorff, head of the Free Democrats, junior partners in Kohl's coalition. Volker Ruehe, general secretary of Kohl's Christian Democrats, said the party believes de Maiziere ``until there is proof to the contrary.''

DOC.HEAD: Obscenity Charges Dropped Against Record Store Owner
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors dropped criminal charges Monday against a record store owner who sold the 2 Live Crew album ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be,'' saying they couldn't prove the sexually explicit lyrics were obscene. Dave Risher's trial was about to begin when Bexar County Court-At-Law Judge Tony Jimenez III dismissed the charges at the prosecutors' request. He also asked sternly why it took them six months to come up empty-handed. ``I think that the (district attorney's) office owes Mr. Risher an apology,'' he said. When he dismissed the court, spectators clapped and cheered. Risher was charged after Patrick Weaver, son of the president of Citizens Against Pornography, bought the album at Hogwild Records and Tapes in June and then complained to police it was obscene. The album includes references to oral and anal sex and sexual violence against women. The case apparently fell apart when Weaver listened to the album last Friday with the prosecutors and decided it didn't violate state obscenity laws. Expert witnesses also told prosecutors they weren't sure the rap album's contents met the state's test for obscenity. ``Taken as a whole, he (Weaver) did not feel that this album was obscene,'' Hancock said afterward. ``That is a weakness in our case. We obviously felt that trying the case would have been an injustice.'' Among other criteria, material can only be called obscene in Texas if it is found by a reasonable person to be without literary, artistic or political value. Weaver, 20, declined to be interviewed later. But his mother, Teresa Weaver, said in a call to their home that ``as much as he wanted to address was already addressed.'' ``I thought we were going to trial today. I'm pleasantly surprised,'' said Risher, who had been charged with promotion of pornography. The misdemeanor carries a maximum penalty of a year in prison and a $1,000 fine. ``I can't wait to get back to work,'' said Risher, owner of Hogwild Records and Tapes. Risher was charged after San Antonio vice officers visited record stores and told owners that a federal judge in Florida had found the album obscene. After that ruling, a Fort Lauderdale, Fla., record owner was convicted of a misdemeanor obscenity charge. Members of the Miami-based rap group were acquitted, however, of similar charges that followed a live performance in Hollywood, Fla. After the obscenity declaration in Florida, officers here asked store operators to sign statements saying they had been given the warning. Risher refused. Days after the warning, Patrick Weaver, whose mother is president of an anti-pornography group, bought the album at Risher's store and filed a complaint with police. ``I can't wait to get back to work,'' said Risher, owner of Hogwild Records and Tapes. There was no immediate reaction from 2 Live Crew to Monday's dismissal.

DOC.HEAD: Hostage Homecoming Flight Arrives in U.S.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf: ``The group,'' with nine grafs quotes
DOC.HEAD: With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: More than 150 Americans who had been trapped in Iraq and Kuwait arrived in the United States Monday for a holiday homecoming after four harrowing months spent as hostages or in hiding. The 152 American and four Canadians were greeted by a small but cheering crowd as they streamed off a charter flight at Andrews Air Force Base outside Washington. They appeared tired but most smiled as they left the plane, waving to the greeting party. Relatives in the crowd held up signs, including one that said, ``Daddy, Daddy, I Need You.'' Most of the group carried luggage; many wore casual clothes and were ill-prepared for the chilly evening weather. One woman was in a wheelchair. The group declined to speak with reporters at Andrews, but some individuals spoke freely at a hotel later. ``I was damned mad about the whole thing,'' said Jack Rinehart, 37, of Stover, Mo., an electrical engineer. Rinehart, a designer of air-conditioner motors, spent almost the entire time in the U.S. Embassy at Kuwait City where he said he was ``camp plumber'' and lost 25 pounds on a diet of tuna and rice. Dwight Durmon of Fayetteville, Tenn., said he was not mistreated in Iraq. But ``people are scared in Iraq,'' he said, clutching the hand of his wife, Kathy. ``Everybody has mental stress coming out of there,'' said Durmon, who declined to say what he did in Iraq. Both Durmon and Rinehart said President Bush was doing well in the crisis, Rinehart observing, ``I think George Bush and the administration have handled this beautifully.'' William Armbruster, a press officer for the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait who worked at the U.S. Embassy in Baghdad after Aug. 23, said one Iraqi citizen told him, ``Tell George Bush that whatever he is doing has got to be done. In an interview with CBS News, Ed Wener of Baltimore said he and four other people stayed indoors in Kuwait. ``We would have to travel from house to hoiuse once in a while, though, when we heard the Iraqis were in the neighborhood.'' Werner said he saw a Kuwaiti man fire at Iraqi soldiers and ``about 20 Iraqi soldiers just opened up on him,'' killing him. The jet carried hamburgers and champagne for the evacuees who had their first big breakfast in months on Monday. The Americans had flown from Frankfurt, Germany, where they had spent the night after arriving in Europe from Baghdad, Iraq. The State Department said 73 people remained in Frankfurt for medical treatment or because they wanted to make their own way home. U.S. officials said a second plane chartered by the Pentagon was to evacuate more Americans from Iraq and Kuwait on Tuesday. Ivan Selin, the undersecretary of State for management, along with Elizabeth Tamposi, the assistant secretary of state for consular affairs, greeted the evacuees. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater was cautiously optimistic about the release of more hostages, many of whom had been held as ``human shields'' at strategic locations in Iraq. Iraq's parliament approved the release of 8,000 American, European and Japanese hostages on Friday at the request of President SAddam Hussein. The hostages were trapped when Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. ``We've got one plane here and another on the way,'' Fitzwater said. But he did not know if any Americans were still being held against their will. ``The president's initial statement of `I'll believe it when I see it' still stands,'' Fitzwater said. The Iraqis, he added, were still ``totally in control.'' Fitzwater declined to give any precise numbers of how many Americans remain in Iraq and Kuwait. ``This is kind of a touchy question,'' he said. ``We'd prefer the Iraqis don't know exactly how many people we had there.'' In Frankfurt, the former hostages told reporters they were glad to be free. ``It was like a gulag,'' said Robert Vinton of Santa Fe, N.M. He was picked up on Aug. 18 on a street in Baghdad and held at an oil refinery. Vinton, 58, said he was held with eight other foreigners. ``We were mostly left alone,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Mayor Says New York City Faces New $250 Million Budget Gap
DOC.TEXT: Mayor David Dinkins said Monday the city has found yet another shortfall in its current budget, adding $250 million to the ever-growing shortage. He blamed cuts in state aid and the weakening economy. Dinkins just recently closed a $388 million gap inthe 1991 fiscal year budget, which ends June 30. Asked at a news conference in City Hall how he would close the new projected gap, the mayor answered that it will take ``more pain.'' He indicated he might have to turn to a contingency plan he developed while planning the earlier cut, but that totals only $40 million. The plan includes the closing of six firehouses and cutbacks in refuse collection, funding for senior citizen centers and food pantries, elimination of a nutrition program and some day care staff advisers, plus delays in bridge inspection and repair programs as well as maintenance at parks, playgrounds and beaches. Dinkins disclosed the possible new gap in the $28 billion budget after attending a meeting with the Standard & Poor's bond rating agency. The agency has already put the city on a credit watch and is to evaluate a municipal long-term bond issue of $1.3 billion Wednesday. Deputy Mayor Sally Hernandez Piniero said S&P currently rates city bonds as A-minus. She said Moody's rates them at A. Dinkins said he assured S&P executives that the city, which underwent a fiscal crisis in the mid-1970s, has acted responsibly in balancing its budget for years. He said that the city has closed $1.8 billion in holes in its budget during his term and that of former Mayor Edward I. Koch in the latter part of 1989. The mayor said he hoped that S&P would maintain the city's current rating at least until he presents his preliminary budget for the 1992 fiscal year, which starts July 1. That budget already has a $1.3 billion gap that the mayor said he plans to fill as well.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Urges Hanoi, Phomn Penh to Accept Settlement
DOC.TEXT: The United States warned Vietnam Monday that resisting the major-power formula for ending the Cambodian civil war endorsed by the United Nations would hurt its prospects for normal diplomatic relations with the United States. `Hanoi's own interests ... would be best served by supporting rather than resisting the progress made toward a Cambodian settlement,'' Assistant Secretary of State Richard Solomon told a subcommittee of the House Foreign Affairs Committee Although Vietnam has made some statements expressing willingness to support the U.N.-backed formula, ``other statements are at best ambiguous or put forward positions in basic opposition,'' Solomon told the subcommittee on Asian and Pacific affairs. Solomon said Hanoi should ``reexamine its position'' and influence the Vietnamese-installed government in Cambodia to accept the settlement drafted by the United States, Soviet Union, China, Britain and France, the five permament U.N. Security Council members, and recently endorsed by the Council and General Assembly. In answer to questions, Solomon said it was ``inconceivable'' that the Bush administration would normalize relations with Vietnam or the government in Phnom Penh, Cambodia, if the U.N. peace plan is scuttled. American business groups have been pressing for ending the U.S. trade embargo against Vietnam. Hanoi has sought normalization to bolster its weak economy. Solomon reaffirmed the U.S. ``long-standing policy that normalization of relations with Vietnam can occur only in the context of an acceptable comprehensive settlement of the Cambodian conflict.'' The hearing heard Solomon's assessments of a decline in the prospects for early peace and prevention of a return to power of the communist Khmer Rouge, blamed for more than one million Cambodian deaths in 1975-78. ``Unfortunately, the Phonm Penh regime has recently issued a series of statements opposing basic tenets of the current draft settlement ... only the Khmer Rouge are likely to benefit'' if the plan is scuttled, Solomon said. Solomon represented the United States in drafting the Big Five formula providing for a United Nations presence to organize free elections, temporarily oversee government and disarm the Southeast Asian country's warring factions. Phonm Penh leaders demanded that the U.N. presence last less than a year and be limited to organizing an election, leaving their powers unaffected, Solomon said. ``A fair and workable settlement cannot be achieved on this basis,'' he added. ``At worst ... once again in the control of the Khmer Rouge, Cambodia may yet again be transformed into an Asian Auschwitz,'' said subcommittee Chairman Rep. Stephen Solarz, D-NY, referring to the notorious Nazi extermination camp where millions perished in World War II. ``Unfortunately, there appears a very real reason to believe this (plan) may not be accepted,'' he added, referring to disagreement among the Cambodian factions and the recent statements from Phonm Penh. Even at best, Solarz said, Cambodia could ``end up like the Lebanon of Southeast Asia.'' Deputy Assistant Secretary of State Kenneth Quinn said the Khmer Rouge were ``regaining some popularity'' using Cambodian animosity against the Vietnamese as a guerrilla recruiting tool. With time on the side of the Khmer Rouge, Hanoi and Phomh Penh could serve their own interests by accepting a settlement providing for internationally enforced disarmament, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Security Council Again Delays Vote on Peace Conference
DOC.TEXT: The Security Council on Monday again postponed a meeting to discuss a resolution endorsing a Middle East peace conference. The council meeting, already delayed several times at U.S. request, was put off until Wednesday. Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir is scheduled to meet Tuesday with President Bush, and Western diplomats said the United States was seeking to avoid a vote until after Shamir leaves the country on Thursday. The United States seeks to water down reference to the conference, opposed by Israeli because it would emcompass the issue of Palestinians in Israeli-occupied lands. The United States wants mention of the proposed conference moved from the heart of a resolution to a non-binding preamble and presidential statement. The United States also opposed any language in the resolution that could suggest it is linked to Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's calls for a Mideast conference to help settle the Persian Gulf crisis. U.S. officials have indicated they may veto the draft resolution unless significant changes were made. The United States has been caught in a diplomatic dilemma. It is pressured by its Israeli ally to veto the measure any reference to a U.N. conference. But U.S. officials also fear a veto could weaken support from Arab nations that joined the coalition against Iraq following its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. The council voted 9-4 to adopt a Soviet motion to delay the session. The United States had pushed for postponement, while France and China abstained. Cuba, Colombia, Malaysia and Yemen opposed any delay and sought an immediate vote. Any of the five permanent Security Council members - the United States, France, Britain, Soviet Union and China - can veto a measure.

DOC.HEAD: Garbage Collections at 250,000 New York Businesses Curbed By Strike
DOC.TEXT: Small hills of bagged garbage began to crowd sidewalks in parts of Manhattan on Monday, the first day of a strike by workers employed by private haulers. Residential garbage collection is performed by the New York City Sanitation Department and was not affected by the strike. If accumulating garbage becomes a health or fire hazard, however, the agency will make emergency pickups. A 2,100-member Teamsters local called the strike after union members rejected a new contract raising wages $70 over three years. The workers now earn $600 to $700 a week and sought a $90 raise. Union leader Bernard Adelstein said the strike was generally effective in all five city boroughs, although in the Bronx ``a few trucks went out with scabs.'' Salvatore Spinelli, a spokesman for the private carters, said about 30 percent of trucks were operating throughout the city, staffed by management and non-striking crews. Some replacement workers might also have been hired, he said. About 400 private carters collect 10,000 tons of garbage daily from 250,000 business and commercial sites in New York City. At least one hauler hired security guards to follow his trucks on their route in case of trouble, but Police spokesman Detective Joseph McConville said no strike-related violence was reported. No talks were scheduled. Both sides said the next step was up to the city's labor negotiator, Eric Schmertz, who has been working on the dispute. On Monday the most conspicuous uncollected piles of garbage were in midtown Manhattan, mostly on side streets by fast-food outlets, large movie theaters and restaurants with high turnover. If health or fire inspectors decide the uncollected garbage is dangerous, city sanitation crews will pick it up and charge the customers $14.70 per cubic yard. That's the rate the city permits private carters to charge. Consumer Affairs Commissioner Mark Green, whose agency regulates hauling rates, has recommended that the current fee be cut by about $1 a cubic yard. Both the union and the private carters accused Green of helping precipitate the strike. Green said the workers and employers could ``search for scapegoats, but any failure in their negotiation is not due to my rate.'' New York City's private garbage collectors, a $1 billion service industry, were last struck for 17 days in 1981.

DOC.HEAD: North Korean Premier in South for Talks
DOC.TEXT: North Korean Prime Minister Yon Hyong Muk crossed the heavily armed border into South Korea on Tuesday for a third round of talks on easing four decades of confrontation. ``Welcome, welcome,'' the South's unification minister, Hong Sung-chul, said in greeting him at the border village of Panmunjom, 35 miles north of Seoul. ``How are you?'' replied Yon, smiling broadly. He bent down to allow a little girl to place a wreath of flowers over his head, then posed for pictures and waved at onlookers. Talks between Yon and South Korean Prime Minister Kang Young-hoon will take place Wednesday and Thursday. They are the third round in as many months of the highest level meetings ever held between the two Koreas. The talks are not expected to produce a major agreement, but are seen as a step in the lengthy process of drawing closer. The rival Koreas have been divided since 1945. ``Small, steady efforts and finally little gains ... will lead to quantitative change,'' said Limb Dong-won, a diplomat and spokesman for the South's delegation. The agenda, basically the same as in past talks, calls for exchanges and easing political and military tensions. The North wants a non-aggression pact and the South claims confidence building agreements are needed first. The South also will press for official recognition of each other's governments. The North has maintained formal recognition would perpetuate division of the peninsula. Midway in the prime ministers' talks, the South's President Roh Tae-woo says will fly to Moscow for a summit with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Roh says he will discuss ``ending the Cold War on the Korean peninsula and realizing a new order of reconciliation.'' China, Soviet Union and Japan, neighbors of the hostile Koreas, are seen as important behind-the-scene forces in the talks. All three, plus the United States, which maintains 43,000 troops in South Korea, would benefit from a lessening of tensions on the peninsula. Korea was divided in 1945 into Communist North and capitalist South, and fought a war from 1950 to 1953.

DOC.HEAD: Navy Planes Collide off USS Lexington
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES pilots still missing Monday night, details, background on planes and Lexington. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Two Navy aircraft practicing takeoffs from the carrier USS Lexington collided Monday over the Gulf of Mexico, and the two pilots were missing, the Navy said. The two TA-4 Skyhawk aircraft apparently collided in the air at 4:10 p.m. about 85 miles northwest of Key West, said Lt. Cmdr. Ray Kempisty, spokesman for Naval Education and Training in Pensacola, where the carrier is based. The Coast Guard joined the crew of the Lexington in searching for the pilots, but neither had been found by Monday night, Kempisty said. Each of the single-engine jets carried one occupant, the Navy said. At the time of the crash, the weather was fair except for a few low-lying clouds and winds of about 11 to 16 mph, said the National Weather Service in Key West. ``I don't think it would have an effect on the visibility,'' meteorologist Peter Mohlin said. The TA-4s, built by McDonnell Douglas Corp., are capable of carrying 10,000 pounds of ammunition and can travel at a top speed of 675 mph, according to Jane's ``All the World's Aircraft,'' an authoritative annual directory. The Lexington, a battle-scarred veteran of World War II, is the Navy's oldest carrier at 47 years and the only one used exclusively for training naval aviators. On Oct. 29, 1989, five people were killed when a T-2 Buckeye trainer from Meridian, Miss., Naval Air Station crashed into the ship's control island and cartwheeled across the flight deck in a fireball. The student pilot, Ensign Steven Pontell, 23, of Columbia, Md., was making his first attempt to land on a carrier. Navy safety investigators were unable to pinpoint a cause for the crash, concluding that pilot error or a throttle malfunction may have been to blame. The Lexington survived hits from a torpedo and kamika{e plane during World War II. It earned the nickname Blue Ghost because of its blue-gray paint job and repeated reports by Japanese propagandist ``Tokyo Rose'' that it had been sunk. The ship is scheduled to be decommissioned next November and efforts have begun to preserve it as a museum.

DOC.HEAD: `Belle of Amherst' Gets Publication Party 100 Years Late
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS four grafs after 4th graf: ``We kind ...,'' to UPDATE with quotes from celebration; pick up 5th graf pvs: The enigma ...
DOC.TEXT: A century after her poems were published, reclusive poet Emily Dickinson is getting the publication party she never had. And the kind of thing she probably would have hated. ``I guess we're safe in doing it at this time,'' observed Martha Ackmann, an organizer of Monday's celebration commemorating the publication of the bulk of Dickinson's poetry 100 years ago. The publication came four years after the poet's death. The poet might have deplored the fuss, but Ackmann said her old college is just making up for lost time. ``We kind of think of it as the publication party Mount Holyoke never gave Emily Dickinson. An acknowledgement of her achievement,'' said Ackmann, assistant professor of women's studies and English at the all-women school. About three dozen Dickinson devotees gathered Monday afternoon for a lecture and poetry accompanied by punch and gingerbread. Their reasons for attending varied. ``I always liked her poetry, for one thing,'' said Sarah Rusk, who has lived in South Hadley for 50 years. Amherst College senior Josh Jacobs, who came to brush up on the poet, said he thinks Dickinson would probably have lived an isolated life in any age. ``Even now, when you think about the industry which seeks so persistently to discover people, it seems to me that the way she lived ... there could be someone like her today who won't be published till 2130,'' he said. The enigma of Dickinson, how she could have been content to see only eight of her poems published during her lifetime - and those anonymosly - lies at the heart of the celebration. ``The question I've always wanted to ask Emily Dickinson herself is how did she keep going? What made (her) keep working, working, working at it? That must have been an enormous respect for art,'' Ackmann said. An inability to stop making revisions and a disdain for the vulgarities of fame are two possible explanations for Dickinson's reticence. ``In the 19th century a successful author was the equivalent of a 20th-century rock star,'' Ackmann said. ``That would have opened her life up to public consideration and scrutiny, and I don't think that she wanted that.'' ``She was ambivalent at best about publishing,'' said Jane Crosthwaite, an associate professor of religion and co-organizer of the commemoration at Mount Holyoke, which Dickinson attended from 1847 to 1848. Born 160 years ago Monday into a well-to-do family, Dickinson often sent poems to friends and family, but showed no inclination to publish, Ackmann said. Legend has it that she always wore white and toward the end of her life rarely left her house and garden. After her death in 1886, her sister Lavinia was clearing out Dickinson's rooms when she opened up a bottom drawer of a dresser and discovered ``sheet upon sheet upon sheet upon sheet of poems,'' Ackmann said. Lavinia showed the poems to some friends and family and then arranged for their publication on Nov. 12, 1890, by a Boston publishing firm called Roberts Bros., Ackmann said. The first 500 copies were well received and a second book was published the following year. Publication of the poems, often written in an unfinished form with perhaps six different adjectives stacked on top of one word, was not completed until the mid-1950s. Ackmann and Crosthwaite said they don't believe Dickinson would have regretted her lost celebrity. ``She said that if fame were to come to her it would come. She might be rather relieved that she didn't have to confront either the good or the bad readers of her poetry,'' Crosthwaite said. ``I don't think she wants to be part of the industry.''

DOC.HEAD: `The Big Funk' by John Patrick Shanley Opens Off-Broadway
DOC.TEXT: ``The Big Funk'' by John Patrick Shanley is a series of images, some provocative, some downright silly, in search of a play. The new stage work by the Academy Award-winning author of ``Moonstruck'' suffers from a bad case of lofty aspirations. The play foresakes story and character for heavy-duty messages about life, death, fear, love and other four-letter words. Oh yes, the playwright provides two nude scenes - one female, one male - for those not moved by words alone. You might call it Samuel Beckett meets ``Oh! Calcutta!'' Shanley is an accomplished writer whose best plays have a gritty, distinctive voice and a specific sense of place. ``Danny and the Deep Blue Sea'' was a brutal blue-collar Apache dance by two unlikely lovers in The Bronx. ``Italian-American Reconciliation'' was a looney romance about an inept go-between trying to save the marriage of a battling husband and wife in New York's Little Italy. There's nothing that concrete in ``The Big Funk,'' which opened Monday at off-Broadway's New York Shakespeare Festival Public Theater. In it, Shanley, who also directed his play, settles for the abstract. The place is here; the time now. The four main characters arrive one by oneto introduce themselves to the audience. The introductions don't help. First up is a beautiful young woman (Jeanne Tripplehorn) who calls herself the villain of the piece. She's actually the victim, put-upon by a sleazy guy who picks her up in a bar. Following her on stage is a tightrope walker (Jayne Haynes) named Fifi and her human cannonball of a husband Omar (Graham Beckel) who walks around with what looks like an old pot on his head. They are best friends with an unemployed actor named Austin (Jake Weber) who saves the girl after she is humiliated in the bar. She's tormented by that creep (Skip Suddut) who smears petroleum jelly on her head. She also has a thing for salad oil but that's not revealed until the second act. The first act ends with a bubble bath given to the girl by her rescuer. At least it quiets the audience. Act 2 is a Mad Hatter-style dinner for the four friends. During the meal, Austin waxes murkily about life. For some reason, also not entirely clear, the actor walks off-stage and then returns - naked - to lecture the audience on confronting their own fears. He certainly doesn't have any of his own, being able to stand there in the buff and remember all his lines. The actors are cheerful and enthusiastic in their portrayals of weirdness, and Tripplehorn and Weber deserve medals for baring more than their souls. But ``The Big Funk'' remains a collection of odd portraits and pictures rather than a play. It doesn't say much when the most arresting moment on stage is not anything the actors say but rather an oozing family-size jar of Vaseline spilling to the floor of the stage.

DOC.HEAD: Man's Self-Immolation Is Protest Of U.S. Mideast Policy
DOC.TEXT: A man who set himself on fire and died to protest U.S. policies in the Persian Gulf was a genial, upbeat person who lived alone on a houseboat and rarely discussed politics, according to his friends. Timothy T. Brown, 48, doused himself with a flammable liquid and then set it alight Sunday on the steps of a deserted cannery. He left behind a stack of fliers urging Americans to ``not repeat the mistake of Vietnam.'' Brown described himself as Vietnam veteran in the leaflets, but there was no immediate confirmation from Defense Department authorities. The eaflets were stacked in Brown's van about 100 yards from where Brown set himself on fire. ``I, Tim Brown, Vietnam veteran, declare that my act of self-immolation is a direct protest of American war policy in the Middle East,'' he said in the leaflets. ``America, do not go to war. America, do not repeat the mistake of Vietnam. Don't wait for the war to start and then protest. Protest now while there is still time.'' His death stunned his friends. ``We were real surprised and shocked,'' said Marie Carson, the owner of a florist's shop. Carson, who sold Brown a houseboat earlier this year, added that he ``seemed real upbeat and positive.'' Another neighbor, Diana Dickson, said she was baffled by Brown's suicide note ``because he never talked about anything political.'' ``I hate to invalidate what he said in his letter, but I find it hard to believe because he hadn't mentioned it before,'' she said. Brown, a knife-sharpener who served restaurants and other customers from his van, was a familiar figure in Isleton, a tiny fishing village in the rustic Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta, a lush network of levees, rivers and small towns about 50 miles east of San Francisco. Bob Brian, a spokesman for the Sacramento County coroner, confirmed that Brown's death was a suicide. A police officer who declined to be identified said investigators believe the liquid was gasoline.

DOC.HEAD: Gunmen Kill Policeman, Lawyer in Manila
DOC.TEXT: Gunmen killed a lawyer and a policeman Tuesday in separate attacks in the capital. The attacks appeared similar to tactics adopted by Communist assassination teams, but police mobile patrol dispatcher Cpl. Oscar Espino said investigators could not immediately rule out other possible motives such as personal grudges. Police said lawyer Franklin Farolan had just stepped out of his car near his office in the Ermita district when a man approached and shot him pointblank at about 7:30 a.m. The gunman escaped with four companions, Espino reported. Espino said that about 30 minutes later, a gunman - described by witnesses as appearing similar to Farolan's attacker - killed Patrolman Maximo Gaa as he was walking in another part of Ermita district. The killer and several companions fled on foot. On Monday, gunmen burst into a building in suburban Ateneo University and killed two union leaders and wounded a third as they were attending a seminar.

DOC.HEAD: Shamir: Don't Link Gulf With Our Conflict
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf: The Israeli ..., to UPDATE with remarks delivered; pick up 3rd graf pvs: ``We will ...''
DOC.TEXT: Israel is confident the United States will not permit Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein to link the Persian Gulf crisis to the Arab-Israeli conflict, Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said Monday. The Israeli government will not consent ``to any deal with enemies who wish to destroy us,'' Shamir said in a speech upon receiving the $100,000 Jabotinsky Prize as a ``Defender of Jerusalem.'' ``We will not be surprised if soon a number of states, not only Arab governments, will move to appease Saddam Hussein at the expense of Israel,'' Shamir said. ``The well-known argument will be that Israel should make a contribution, ostensibly for the sake of world peace. Let me, therefore, state at the very outset: Israel in 1990 is not Czechoslovakia of 1938,'' he said. ``We trust the American government's determined stand not to permit Saddam Hussein to link the gulf crisis with the Arab-Israel conflict and the Palestinian issue,'' Shamir said. The Iraqi leader ``knows that Israel will not remain passive if he tries to harm us,'' Shamir said. ``He is trying hard to fool the world into believing that he is defending the Arabs against what they call the Zionist enemy. He is fooling only himself and his blind supporters.'' A rapid U.S. buildup of the U.S.-dominated multinational force is in progress, aimed at bringing troop strength in the region to 400,000 by mid-January. That coincides with the Jan. 15 deadline the U.N. Security Council has given Saddam for getting out of Kuwait or facing possible military action. On another topic, Shamir said 1,000 to 2,000 Soviet Jews are arriving in Israel daily. ``In the month of November, 27,000 of our brethren arrived,'' with even more expected in December, he said. ``By the end of 1990, we could arrive at a figure of 180,000 for the year. That equals the number of Russian Jews who came to Israel ... from 1968 to 1988. There is now a realistic expectation that we may, indeed, increase our population by 1 million in the next three to five years. This is equivalent to the United States absorbing 60 million immigrants in three to five years,'' he said. It will cost some $40 billion to absorb the immigrants, he said, adding, ``To provide such a vast sum will require the joint effort, the aggregate strength, and the collective thinking and ingenuity of the entire Jewish people.'' Shamir was to leave for Washington after speaking Monday night. Outside the hotel, two small groups demonstrated, including about 25 people, led by Rabbi Avi Weiss, who held signs urging freedom for Jonathan Pollard. He was sentenced to life in prison in 1987 for spying for Israel. The other demonstrators represented a coalition of progressive Jewish groups.

DOC.HEAD: Saudis Fear if Saddam Keeps his Army He'll Be Arab Champion
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 8 `Most officials' to CORRECT first reference to Kuwait sted Iraq. Picks up 9th, `But after...'
DOC.TEXT: If Saddam Hussein were forced from Iraq but his military forces were left intact, he would claim the late Gamal Abdel Nasser's mantle as the champion of the Arab world, Saudis fear. Saudi officials, speaking Monday on condition of anonymity, echoed the concern voiced a day earlier by U.S. Secretary of State James Baker III. Baker said that even a peaceful solution to the gulf crisis would be followed by continued pressure on Saddam to curb his military power. ``He can't keep his military. He'll be a hero. He'll make Nasser in 1956 look like Mickey Mouse,'' said one Saudi source. Nasser, the populist Egyptian president who died in 1970, became an idol in the Arab world after standing up to the French and British forces backing Israel in the 1956 attempt to reverse his nationalization of the Suez Canal. He used his pan-Arab nationalism to appeal to public opinion across North Africa and the Middle East, destablizing many pro-Western governments in the process. His memory remains a potent force in the Arab world today. The Saudis see history repeating itself in Saddam's vast military arsenal and political ambitions. Saddam has the biggest and most powerful army in the Arab world, with a million troops, a missile armory and other weapons of mass destruction. Most officials expect he will find a way to extricate himself from Kuwait before being attacked by the 26-nation alliance that began deploying troops in Saudi Arabia soon after Kuwait was invaded Aug. 2. But even after a retreat, Saddam will ``say he stood up not just to the United States, but to the whole world,'' a Saudi source said. The future threat would be both political and military. Saddam's invasion of Kuwait, an emirate disliked by poor Arabs for its vast oil wealth and limited rights for foreign workers, struck a popular chord in many parts of the Arab world. It added to his claim of achieving a victory against Iran, a traditional Arab enemy, in the 1980-88 war, despite having gained nothing in the end. ``They just love this white stallion stuff, Saladin and all that,'' said an Asian diplomat, referring to the Arab general who in 1187 recaptured Jerusalem from the European crusaders. Saddam, who likens himself to the Kurdish Saladin, is often shown on Iraqi television heroically mounted on a white charger. ``Arabs will say, `He's tough, he can solve our problems, let's follow him,''' the diplomat added. Saddam has already tried to capitalize on that image with his attempt to link his withdrawal to an Israeli pullout from the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. ``Occupying another Arab land and torturing Arabs does not give hope that the Palestinians can be liberated,'' said a senior Saudi diplomat. The Saudis are concerned that what Saddam does not gain through charisma he can achieve through the threat of force, especially if he develops nuclear weapons within the next few years. They don't want U.N. economic sanctions against Iraq lifted unless Iraq reduces the size and power of his military, or at least makes U.N.-backed guarantees not to use its arms again on fellow Arabs. ``We can't just stop at the withdrawal. The Iraqi army has to be reduced to a degree that it won't threaten us,'' said the senior diplomat. The Saudis, despite buying billions of dollars' worth of advanced weaponry over the last decade, found themselves hopelessly unable to combat Saddam when he invaded Kuwait. The Saudis have embarked on a crash expansion of their military and are buying more weapons. But analysts say that even when that program is completed, they will still not be able to defend themselves without outside help.

DOC.HEAD: Joyous Homecoming for British
DOC.TEXT: More than 400 Britons held captive by Saddam Hussein returned home Monday to jubilant friends and family members. One former hostage became engaged on the spot. A plane carrying 384 former hostages, mostly British men, arrived late Monday at Gatwick airport on an Iraqi Airways flight from Baghdad. Earlier Monday, 101 freed Britons landed at London's Heathrow airport on a British Airways Boeing 767 from Frankfurt, Germany, where they arrived on Sunday from Baghdad. Twenty-two other hostages - including 13 Britons, five Irish and four Australians - arrived at Heathrow on a British Airways flight from Rome. They also left Iraq on Sunday. The former hostages at Gatwick were reunited with families and friends at a landing gate before clearing customs and passport control. ``As the plane came down, they (the relatives and friends) all rushed to the window and a huge cheer went up,'' said Gatwick airport spokeswoman Caroline Nicholls. Briton Raymond Washer said he had been held as a hostage at Kuwait City university and described how Iraqi troops looted the Kuwaiti capital. ``They had taken it to pieces brick by brick, just about everything,'' he said. ``They even took the little generators that were running the traffic lights. There was nothing left. Saddam Hussein will not move until he has taken everything out of Kuwait.'' Washer said the Iraqis captured him and others as they tried to escape across the desert in a convoy of vehicles a few days after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. ``They picked us up just five miles from the (Saudi Arabian) border,'' he said. Steve Hicking, a 30-year-old Australian oil worker who arrived on the flight from Rome, proposed marriage to his girlfriend, Lesley Campbell, when they met at the airport. She accepted. The British Foreign Office said two more charter planes will fly to Kuwait on Tuesday to pick up another 320 hostages.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Convicts Six L.A. Sheriff's Deputies of Stealing Drug Cash
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with details on convictions, charges jury deadlocked on, one incident captued on videotape, reax from sheriff and one defendant. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Six deputies were convicted Monday of conspiring to steal cash from suspected drug dealers in one of the worst scandals in the history of the Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department. A seventh deputy was convicted of money laundering, but the jury deadlocked on whether to convict him of conspiracy. The panel also deadlocked on numerous other charges against all the lawmen. The seven deputies, all former members of an elite narcotics unit in the nation's most populous county, were charged with stealing $1.4 million in drug cash. The case caused embarrassment and a major shakeup in the department. Prosecutors portrayed the defendants as corrupt individuals who abused the public trust and showed evidence that they stashed thousands of dollars in shoe boxes and bought boats, homes, cars and vacations and made numerous other purchases beyond their $40,000 to $60,000 salaries. They dismissed the defendants' arguments that they bought the items with cash earned through gambling, inheritance or baby-sitting. The defense criticized the prosecution's reliance on testimony by drug suspects and the deputies' ex-boss, former Sgt. Roger Sobel, who testified as part of a plea agreement. The deputies were part of a narcotics team called Major Violators Crew II, which made some of the department's biggest cocaine and money seizures. Authorities accused the men of seizing drug cash during raids, then obtaining statements from alleged traffickers disowning the cash. The deputies then allegedly stole a substantial portion of the money and divided it among themselves. The defense said the deputies were victims of their former boss, Sobel, who pleaded guilty in the case and testified about alleged money skimming operations. The trial lasted seven weeks and the federal jury deliberated just over six days before reaching its verdicts. U.S. District Judge Edward Rafeedie declared a mistrial on the deadlocked counts. ``I'm sure this jury did the best job they could,'' said one of the seven, Deputy James R. Bauder. ``But we're disappointed.'' ``The verdicts handed down today are not an occasion to celebrate,'' Sheriff Sherman Block said Monday. ``They are not a victory. They are the just conclusion to the unlawful actions of a few who sought to hide their crimes behind a badge of honor.'' The jury concluded that six of the deputies stole $48,000 in a 1989 incident captured by the FBI on videotape. But the panel deadlocked on other charges and reached not-guilty verdicts on charges related to the theft of $527,000 by three deputies. Convicted of conspiracy and stealing funds earmarked for the Sheriff's Department were Bauder, Daniel Garner, Terrell Amers, Eufrasio Cortez, John Dickenson and Ronald Daub. The jury also convicted Garner, Amers, Bauder, Cortez and Daub of filing false tax returns. A seventh deputy, Macario Duran, was convicted of structuring cash transactions to avoid federal reporting requirements of transactions of $10,000 or more. Cortez and Daub also were convicted of money laundering and structuring transactions. Cortez also was convicted of interstate transportation of unlawfully gained money. The deputies remained free on bail.

DOC.HEAD: Police Raid Yields Missing Mafia Boss
DOC.TEXT: An anonymous call to the ``Mafia hot line'' led to the arrest Monday of a convicted crime boss. Officials said Ignazio Pullara, 44, surrendered without a fight when police raided a house on the outskirts of Palermo. In 1987, he was sentenced in absentia to 10 years in prison for criminal association after police informers described him as the head of a Mafia family. Authorities were tipped to Pullara's whereabouts by a call to a special telephone number set up by a government high commissioner fighting the Sicilian underword.

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Student to Attend Friend's Pro-Democracy Trial
DOC.TEXT: A Chinese student returned from the United States on Monday saying he wants to attend the trial of pro-democracy activist Wang Juntao to see if it is fair. Ge Xun, 31, who was studying at Texas A&M University when last year's military crackdown occurred, said he heard that Wang will soon be tried for his involvement in the pro-democracy movement. ``I'd like to be a witness of the fairness of the court,'' said Ge, who described himself as Wang's friend. Chinese sources say Wang, editor of a now-banned economic studies weekly, and publisher Chen Zeming were charged with plotting to overthrow the government, a crime punishable by death. Both were arrested more than a year ago. The two were accused of manipulating the students who led protests urging democratic reforms. In June 1989, the army fired on protesters. Hundreds were reported killed. Thousands were arrested in a nationwide crackdown on dissent that followed.
