DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Star Watch: Out and About in West Virginia
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Nick Nolte lounges in the front row of benches in the Kanawha County courtroom, one arm thrown over the back of the seat, watching two lawyers debate a minor point in a preliminary hearing. People know Charleston's most famous resident is down at the courthouse today; even in West Virginia's biggest city, population 63,000, word spreads fast. But they leave him alone. Aside from the judge, the defendant, two court officers and the lawyers he's studying, the actor's got the room to himself. No fans demanding his attention. No producers demanding his time. No co-stars demanding he watch them strut their stuff. And, except briefly, no reporters demanding details of his life. And that's why Nolte, who works on the fringe of Hollywood's image-obsessed film industry and skirts the edge of stardom, finds himself more at home in the hills of West Virginia than in Los Angeles or New York. ``This whole business concept of stardom: It's a thing I find very entrapping, very limiting and not worth a damn,'' he said. ``I really don't function at all in my thinking on that level.'' Nolte was busy filming ``Cape Fear,'' Martin Scorsese's remake of the 1962 Gregory Peck-Robert Mitchum film in which an ex-convict blames a lawyer for his sentence and threatens the lawyer's wife. Nolte plays the lawyer who defends and betrays Robert De Niro. He researched much of the role in his adopted hometown, spending several days haunting the Kanawha County courthouse and jail to observe lawyers and judges at work. ``I want to see the demeanor (of a lawyer). I want to see how he behaves in the courtroom, how he behaves with a client, see how he's thinking. I want to figure out the points of law,'' Nolte said. He has researched roles in Charleston before, including his part as a homeless man in ``Down and Out in Beverly Hills,'' because he said he can do it without much distraction and get closer to those he's studying. ``Look, if I was trying to do this research up in New York City, say, or in L.A. in the court system ... it would be very difficult to approach it. It's just a much more complex city. It's impersonalized. It's complicated. It's fast-paced,'' Nolte said. ``And I certainly do need a certain kind of pace when I'm not in the actual process of doing a film. I need a pace where I can think a little.'' That's what he gets in West Virginia's capital, a compact city snuggled along the snaking Kanawha River and sheltered by the Appalachian foothills. Although he owns a house in Malibu, Calif., Nolte retreats to Charleston, where his wife, Becky, and a previous wife, Sharon Haddad, both grew up, and he can avoid hobnobbing with the film crowd. To Nolte, living in New York or Los Angeles inevitably forces actors to compete against each other to prove acting ability and commercial clout. ``One of the reasons I live in West Virginia is to stay away from that, rather than living in one of the film centers that constantly talk about this film succeeding and that film, and whether this guy was good and that guy was good,'' he said. ``I like to get away from that judgmental kind of thinking.'' The relaxed lifestyle of Charleston also suits Nolte, who grew up in a similar atmosphere in Omaha, Neb., and Ames, Iowa. ``I play golf and I hike and stuff like that,'' said Nolte, who played football while bouncing through five different colleges in the early 1960s. He also loves to fish. It's also easier for Nolte, the father, to get out in Charleston with his 4-year-old son, Brawley. ``I have my son up in New York City, and I get him outside the hotel for a walk in the park, and it's fairly intense,'' Nolte said. ``Here, I can take him out, let him run on the street, play in the backyard and the woods. ... In L.A., if I want to take him to the park, I have to get him in a car and go on a freeway that's the most traveled road in the world.'' Nolte, 49, has found himself on some less-traveled roads as an actor, which he became after abandoning college in 1962. He started hanging out at a Pasadena, Calif., theater with an actor friend - to meet girls, he says - and got hooked on the stage. A decade of touring the Midwest landed him back in Los Angeles in 1973, where he finally hit it big in 1976 with the TV miniseries ``Rich Man, Poor Man.''

DOC.NOTE: For release Weekend Editions, Dec. 21-23, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: CHARLESTON, W.Va.: Poor Man.''
DOC.TEXT: Working steadily since then, Nolte's had hits (``48 Hrs.,'' ``Down and Out in Beverly Hills''), misses (``Everybody Wins,'' ``Farewell to the King'') and films in between (``Q&A,'' ``Who'll Stop the Rain''). He recently finished ``The Prince of Tides,'' based on Pat Conroy's novel and directed by and co-starring Barbra Streisand. He plays a high school teacher and football coach coping with family problems in South Carolina. ``It's about a dysfunctional family,'' he said. ``It's a great Southern story.'' Nolte draws upon his experience as well as research to prepare for roles, although he keeps the personal parts private. Through it all, Nolte remains a modest box-office draw, and he prefers his low-key stardom to something on the level of a Tom Cruise. His biggest commercial successes have come when he's shared the marquee with Eddie Murphy in the two ``48 Hrs.'' movies, and with Richard Dreyfuss and Bette Midler in ``Down and Out.'' The films he carries tend to be offbeat and mildly successful at best. He's paid well for his mainstream movies (a reported $3 million for ``Farewell to the King''), but Nolte said he is ``constantly contradicting'' a Hollywood mentality that says ``an actor has a certain salary base, he shouldn't take less.'' ``That limits the film he can operate in,'' he said. ``When a film is operating the best, there is no star system. It is an ensemble. Consequently, if I can go to a film and see the film without seeing myself, then I think I've accomplished the task of fitting into the theme of the film.'' Amiable, joking and accommodating in an interview, Nolte on screen projects a gruffness and intensity that intimidates. But he uses variations on that persona to compile a diverse portfolio of characters: a noble drug runner in ``Who'll Stop the Rain,'' a beatnik in ``Heart Beat,'' a playwright convict in ``Weeds,'' an egocentric artist in ``New York Stories.'' ``The trouble with stardom is that it has a tendency to pigeonhole you. It has a tendency to classify you. It dictates a certain kind of popularity,'' Nolte said. ``Basically, you want to play characters and stories that intrigue you, and whether that man is a leading man or an evil man or whatever, you want to approach those roles that fulfill you and those stories that fulfill you.'' Once filming is over, Nolte moves on to the next role and does not look back. ``Those roles I did before, I wouldn't want to play them now,'' he said. ``It's chronological. As I grow old as a person, that story was the interest and the focus at that time. That's why I had to tell that story, that's why I got involved. ``Now, in no way could I now go back and do `Who'll Stop the Rain' and think in those terms. I don't quite think the same way,'' Nolte said. Laughing, he added, ``I'm probably a little more corrupt.''

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
The Artists: Ailey Lives Through Jamison
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Judith Jamison was the biggest star the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater had in its 32 years. She is now at the helm of the modern dance company as it twirls through its first New York season with an artistic director other than its founder. Jamison was named artistic director after Ailey's death last year on Dec. 1. The season had gone on that month, as planned, in a kind of shocked state for both dancers and audiences. Since Labor Day, the company has performed in the Soviet Union, France, England and Kansas City. In Denmark, it videotaped ``Episodes'' and ``For Bird With Love'' for showing by PBS next February. Two works Ailey choreographed, including ``Hidden Rites,'' are being revived for the current season, and five new dances are being added, ranging from ``Impinyuza,'' Pearl Primus' 1952 paean to the royal dancers of the Watusi in Ruanda, to ``Read Matthew 11:28'' by young Kris World, who danced and sang on a Stevie Wonder tour. There are also works by Donald McKayle, Lar Lubovitch for his own company and Jamison for the Jamison Project, the 12-member dance company she had before being called to head the Ailey. ``I'm excited about the season,'' she said in an interview. ``Sometimes the company is only known as a high-energy-burning, exciting company. `North Star' by Lar is a softer way of moving. They look beautiful doing that. ``The people dancing in the company now - who've been here on an average of four or five years - haven't danced Primus. Dudley Williams has; he is working on his 26th year here. I think she is one of our unsung heroines of dance as well as a great anthropologist. I wanted to present the men of the company in a piece that was Afro-centric. They're magnificent. ``Alvin's `Hidden Rites' is from the John Parks-Jamison era. It hasn't been done since then. It's part of Alvin's vocabulary these dancers had never visited. Dudley was the last person to dance Alvin's `Hermit Songs.' Three dancers will alternate it this season. It's about a monk.'' Next season Jamison plans to revive ``The Mooche,'' set to music by Duke Ellington. Jamison left the Ailey in 1980 to co-star in ``Duke Ellington's Sophisticated Ladies'' on Broadway. The hardest thing Jamison has to do as head of an established, respected company of 28 dancers, is delegate responsibility. ``When I joined in 1965, there were 10 dancers and everybody did everything. Alvin needed something, you did it. Now I have a staff, a development director, public relations and Masazumi Chaya, the miracle of this company, rehearsal director the last four years. He can remember details and dances like no other. ``I'm very good at molding the end result of rehearsals. I say: `You know the steps. Let me coerce you into dancing it. If you bring your entire being to this movement, you're going to take a step in a direction you haven't been in before.''' Jamison thinks it helps that she's a former dancer, as was Ailey. ``The dancers know that I remember what it's like to be in their shoes. They let me get on stage with them a couple of minutes in `Read Matthew.''' Six dancers from the Jamison Project have joined the Ailey company. ``It's a nice injection of energy,'' Jamison says, hastily adding, ``not that this company needs energy. It is nice to have some fresh blood. ``Alvin had the same idea I did; you want a Cecil B. DeMille cast of thousands. But the budget calls for 28.'' The six dancers from the Jamison Project learned 15 dances in six weeks. ``That's when you realize that `Revelations' isn't as easy as it looks,'' Jamison says. ``Revelations,'' which Ailey choreographed to spirituals in 1960, is called an American classic by Jamison. They loved it in Russia, she said. ``It does the same thing to everyone all over the world.'' ``We will always do Alvin's masterpieces, `Revelations,' `Cry' and `Blues Suite,' and the repertory is going to be fed,'' Jamison said. ``I think it is important the company does not sit as a museum piece. Alvin Ailey was to me a free spirit, a man who had extraordinary theatrical sense and a generosity beyond belief. There aren't other companies with men of his stature asg his peers to make dances for the company. ``I think one of his major contributions was that he made dance accessible. People who wouldn't naturally go to dance would come. They'd have their lives changed and how they feel about theater dance changed. Part of my goal is to continue touching the hearts and minds of people, especially young people.''

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Music Makers: Time's Not Up for Revived Minneapolis Rockers
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: When George Steinbrenner shared a guest star slot on ``Saturday Night Live'' with them this fall, the jokes were inevitable. Will the deposed New York Yankees owner manage The Time? ``He was looking for a new team,'' said Time keyboardist Jimmy ``Jam'' Harris. ``We told him we had a bass player and he thought we said first base. We're ready to go now. We told him we'd wear hats and stuff.'' Despite Steinbrenner's well-known habit of firing managers and coaches, lead singer Morris Day made it clear who'd be the Boss in any such business arrangement. ``Artists don't work for managers,'' Day said. ``Managers work for artists. If there's going to be any firing, we'll be doing it.'' Control is an important word in the Time's vocabulary, and not just because it was the title of the Janet Jackson album that brought Harris and partner Terry Lewis fame as producers. This reformed Minneapolis septet feels more on top of its career than ever before - for better and worse. The Time's return is a rarity in pop music circles. The reunion didn't take place because band members were desperate for money. And it resulted in an album, ``Pandemonium,'' that's clearly better than any of the three records the band recorded prior to its 1983 breakup. ``Pandemonium'' is a raucous funk-rock stew spiced by the slick comic sense of the sharp-dressed Day, who dubs himself the ``aristocratic black.'' The single ``Jerk Out'' has already hit the Top 20, and ``Chocolate'' is the second single. ``We left the ball lying on the field and nobody picked it up after we broke up,'' Harris said. ``We felt the ball was still there so we pumped a little air in it and we're back.'' The ballgame, to the Time's eyes, is an update of such old favorites as James Brown and Sly and the Famil Stone played by men who cut their teeth on real instruments - instead of the sampling wizards Harris and Day disdain. Harris said band members remained friendly following the 1983 dissolution and credited Lewis with badgering the group into a reunion. ``That took a little bit of time to get back together, because you're talking about brothers that are used to splitting money maybe one or two ways now splitting it seven ways,'' Harris said. ``It makes it a little more difficult. In the final analysis, I don't think this had anything to do with money.'' The Time's merger was like a high school reunion where everyone succeeded. Day, spurred by his role in Prince's ``Purple Rain,'' has moved into acting. Harris and Lewis can decorate their Minneapolis studio with Grammys won as producers. Guitarist Jesse Johnson has hit the top of the rhythm and blues chart and, like keyboardist Monte Moir, has his own production career. Percussionists Jerome Benton and Jellybean Johnson round out the band. Lurking behind the scenes is Prince, the band's unofficial eighth member. Individual success helped the band's technique and confidence and, Harris said, changed the relationship with Prince. Although Prince used the pseudonym Jamie Starr for credit on Time albums and members coyly denied his influence, the Time originally was little more than Prince's hired hands. Harris and Lewis, in fact, were both fired from the Time by Prince when bad weather prevented them from returning from a production date in time for a concert. ``There's really not any animosity,'' Harris said. ``It's nice to be able to come back into it and I guess have Prince's respect. He played an important part of us being in a position to do what we did.'' On ``Pandemonium,'' the Time avoided taking any individual credit for the songs. Prince's spokeswoman, Jill Willis, said Prince wrote five of the songs on the album, including ``Jerk Out'' and ``Chocolate.'' The Minneapolis Star Tribune reported that ``Jerk Out'' was originally recorded in 1986 for another band on Prince's Paisley Park Records. When Day was jokingly asked if he would be worried about being fired by Steinbrenner, he said it was Prince who should be concerned. But Harris said Prince didn't force himself on the band. ``Before, we didn't really have a choice - he was the one giving us the breaks and he was calling the shots,'' Harris said. ``We felt in order to have all of the elements that made the Time successful before he had to be involved. ``He came into it as an equal partner this time - as the eighth member of the group, so to speak - rather than as the boss. We were more like on equal footing. That was really nice.'' The Time returned their former boss' favors, performing on several songs on Prince's ``Graffiti Bridge'' soundtrack. They're in the movie, too, just as they were in Prince's breakthrough ``Purple Rain.'' While solo success frees band members from depending on the Time, it also has its downside. It leaves the band's future up in the air. The day before the ``Saturday Night Live'' appearance, band members held a summit to discuss going on tour. The conclusion? No conclusion. A tour is still a possibility, but nothing is planned and it won't happen until at least next year, said band spokesman Gene Shelton. It's a question of all seven members coordinating their schedules, he said.

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Books and Authors: Lawrence Block Takes a Darker Turn
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Not long ago Lawrence Block wrote a mystery series chronicling the travails of one Bernie Rhodenbarr, a burglar who constantly broke in somewhere only to stumble across a murder and implicate himself. Rhodenbarr, of course, had to solve the murders to protect his neck. The tone was amusing. Not so Block's books about ex-cop Matthew Scudder. The mood in those, including his eighth and newest one, ``A Ticket to the Boneyard,'' is decidedly different. ``Dark, I suppose, is the word,'' Block said in an interview. ``The one that is coming out next year, `Down on the Killing Floor,' is done and it's also a very dark book.'' Much of the darkness in ``Boneyard'' flows from the villain, James Leo Motley, a remorseless killer who relentlessly and cleverly hunts down his victims. ``People have said he is the most fully realized villain that I've done,'' Block said. ``He's not based on an acquaintance. I have not met this chap and do not want to.'' He wrote the first three Matt Scudder books in 1974. ``He and I had points in common,'' Block said. ``He lives in a hotel on West 57th Street. When the series began, he was recently separated from his wife and children and recently retired from the New York Police Department and drinking a lot in a saloon on Ninth Avenue. ``I was living on West 58th Street, recently separated from my wife and three daughters and spending a lot of my time in the very saloon that Scudder hung out in. ``In other ways, our background and nature were very different. I've married since then, seven years ago. Scudder has not. I quit drinking; I quit before he did. When I started writing the books it never occurred to me that either of us would ever stop.'' Block proudly recounts that policemen have told him they like the Scudder series. ``They say the way he acts and reacts and the way his mind works is very believable.'' Block briefly was an auxiliary policeman in New York. Scudder is interesting to write about because he evolves, his creator says. ``The books are as much about him as they are about the cases,'' Block said. ``That was not true of classic private detective fiction. (Raymond) Chandler wrote that a detective should be someone who exists as a window through which we see the world. I think that was fine when Chandler did it. I wouldn't be interested in writing that kind of book.'' He said he is pleased people often ask for more books on Bernie Rhodenbarr, who last appeared in 1983's ``The Burglar Who Painted Like Mondrian,'' his favorite. Block said he thinks he's done with Rhodenbarr, but he also thought that about Scudder after the sixth book in that series, noting: ``I don't have a lot of control over what I write next.'' ``My typical writing pattern is that I'll write a book in a month to six weeks and spend the rest of the year thinking about the next one. The enjoyable time is the two to three weeks between having finished writing a book and starting to agonize over the next one,'' he said. He started writing and selling stories while at Antioch College in Ohio. He dropped out for a year to work as an editor for a New York literary agency, and continued to write. Back at Antioch, he said, he couldn't focus on school work. ``My interest was writing and I grudged the time I had to spend on assignments and classes,'' he said. ``The school suggested I might be happier elsewhere. I've been writing ever since.'' He was always able to make a living. Hollywood made the Scudder novel ``Eight Million Ways To Die'' into a movie starring Jeff Bridges and changed the hero to a heroine to cast Whoopi Goldberg in ``Burglar,'' taken from ``The Burglar in the Closet.'' One of Block's early books, ``Deadly Honeymoon,'' was filmed as ``Nightmare Honeymoon.'' He also wrote seven books in the late 1960s and early '70s about Evan Tanner, a free-lance spy, and one of those may become a movie. He wrote four about Chip Harrison. ``Two are comic novels about a young man's coming of age. I liked writing that voice so much I put him to work for a private detective and wrote two mysterie.'' He also has written some books not in series. But publishers and bookstores like series, he said. ``It makes it a little closer to brand-name advertising. There's a pre-existing audience for each volume,'' he said. ``Readers like the same, only different. I find that myself as a reader. Sometimes if a writer will come out with a new series book, I'll read it. I want to spend time with those characters.''

DOC.HEAD: Nashville Sound: Misty Rowe Finds Solace on `Hee Haw'
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: When a joke falls flat on ``Hee Haw,'' the producers sometime look to a curvy, blond, Southern belle to squeal. More than once her squeaky voice has saved a laugh that otherwise would have been flat cornpone. Misty Rowe plays that perky role as if she was born to it. But behind the beautiful facade is a woman who has overcome some giant obstacles. The childhood lisp was conquered years ago, though a trace remains. The death of her unborn baby last spring, however, was a setback that took months and a cross-country move with which to come to terms. Oddly enough, she's found solace in ``Hee Haw'' from an understanding cast and crew. The baby would have been the first for Rowe and her husband, James DePaiva, an actor who portrayed Max Holden for three years on the soap opera ``One Life to Live.'' The couple dealt with their devastation by relocating from New York City to her original home in the Los Angeles area. DePaiva even gave up his role on daytime TV. And in June, Rowe returned to the ``Hee Haw'' set in Nashville. ``At first it was difficult,'' she recalled in an interview in her dressing room. ``But people encircled me and treated me so well and tried to make me happy. ``Sam Lovullo, the producer, kept playing jokes on me. It was a family-type atmosphere. It was very nurturing and healing. It was like having 12 sisters.'' As a child, Rowe was an unlikely candidate for an entertainment career that eventually made her a familiar face on TV. ``I quit talking for a year when I was 12 because people made fun of me,'' she said about her lisp. ``It was torture as a teen-ager.'' She took speech therapy and finally corrected the lisp, although a trace is still evident. ``Everybody is born with something, and it could have been much worse,'' she said. ``Everybody has something to overcome.'' With that problem behind her, she went on to ``Hee Haw'' and 200 other roles on TV, usually portraying carefree characters on such shows as ``Happy Days,'' ``Matt Houston,'' ``Airwolf,'' ``When Things Were Rotten,'' ``Fantasy Island'' and ``Love Boat.'' On ``Happy Days,'' she was Wendy the roller-skating car hop in 1974 and 1975, but few viewers knew it was her. ``A lot of people have seen it but don't recognize me because I wore a very short wig,'' she said. Rowe also has appeared in nine movies, including ``National Lampoon's Class Reunion'' and ``Meatballs II.'' She portrayed Marilyn Monroe in ``Goodbye, Norma Jean,'' 15 years ago. ``She was sweet and beautiful and she was the epitome of what is feminine for that time and for today,'' Rowe said about the fascination with the late sex symbol. ``She had a glow about her. When she was on camera, you wouldn't watch anyone else. ``In the '90s, we want women to be stronger and to take care of themselves, but she still represents the beautiful, vulnerable woman.'' On the long-running ``Hee Haw,'' Rowe is probably best known for a segment in which she sits in a brass bed telling fairy tales. This evolved into another spot showing her as a teen-age baby sitter telling the tales. ``It's nice when I do personal appearances and kids come up to me and ask for a bedtime story,'' she said. ``The show has given me freedom, and a home. People recognize me from `Hee Haw.' Films come and go, but `Hee Haw' is sort of eternal. It's been on so long.'' Her squeaky voice has become a trademark on the syndicated show, which is in its 23rd season. The hour-long program, with country music interspersed among the humor, is seen by millions on approximately 220 stations, usually early Saturday night. ``It's mine and I have to keep it,'' she said, laughing about her voice. ``It's high, a unique experience. Sometimes when jokes don't work, they write on the cue card, `Misty squeaks.' They think this saves it or something. ``I was once introduced to Stevie Wonder. He couldn't see me but he could hear me. He said my voice is like little bells. It was so nice.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Weekend Editions, Dec. 21-23

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Entertainment Briefs
DOC.TEXT: Filmmaker St. Clair Bourne will be story supervisor and artistic consultant for ``Bellevue Emergency!'', a new television cinema-verite series in production. The ``reality-based'' series, being filmed in the emergency ward of Bellevue Hospital and elsewhere in the New York area, will have a continuing story but will feature real people instead of actors. Bourne recently returned from Brazil where he was honored with a retrospective of his work at the Cineclube Estacao Festival in Rio De Janeiro. Twelve of Bourne's films were presented, including ``Making `Do the Right Thing','' ``Langston Hughes: The Dream Keeper'' and ``The Black and the Green.'' ``Bellevue Emergency!'' will premier later this month on ABC. --- NEW YORK (AP) - CTI, once an important record label for cross-over jazz artists in the 1970s, has been revived with the help of a Japanese conglomerate. Creed Taylor's comeback was made possible through a joint venture with CTI Wave, a subsidiary of the Saison Group, which owns the Wave Records chain. PolyGram will distribute. The first project for the revived label is an ambitious audio-visual work called ``Rhythmstick.'' It features 18 artists, including Art Farmer, Dizzy Gillespie, Flora Purim, Tito Puente and Phil Woods. During its heydey, CTI released records by such jazzmen as Chick Corea, Grover Washington, Ray Charles, Bob James, Herbie Hancock and Hubert Laws.

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, Dec. 13, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Migration Trends Changing for Retirees
DOC.TEXT: Rose Silverman is a Florida booster, no doubt about it. The 81-year-old exercise instructor offers morning aerobics classes and encouragement to seniors six days a week in the shade of a tile-roofed bathhouse on a beach that has drawn tourists for decades. ``The ocean, the climate, these were the biggest attractions,'' said Silverman, who retired here in 1967 from New York's Long Island. ``As you see, I'm very enthusiastic about Florida.'' But the face of retirement migration is changing, and old drawing cards like Miami Beach are no longer guaranteed to be flush with retirees. ``If you look at the destination of those who actually tend to move long distance, the Sunbelt is still the predominant destination,'' said University ofFlorida geography Professor Stephen Golant. But he believes regional migration patterns through 1985 indicate new retirees are becoming less likely to pack up and move south. Combine that with a Depression-era baby bust about to reach retirement age, and Golant sees change ahead in the Sunbelt's retirement image. Other experts on elderly migration see economic value in welcoming the retirees and predict greater competition among destinations. ``The fact that the retiring cohort is going to be somewhat smaller means that they're going to be fiercely competed for,'' said David Savageau, author of ``Retirement Places Rated'' and an employee relocation consultant based in Gloucester, Mass. ``The losers here, maybe they don't think of themselves as losers, would be archetypal retirement states such as Florida.'' Until recently, private enterprise dictated retirement destinations with developments and marketing tailored to seniors. But some states and communities are making retiree recruitment a public policy priority, convinced of the economic value of 65- to 75-year-old residents, Savageau said. Offering Hot Springs, Ark., as an example, Savageau said, ``Their identity lies in attracting retired people and attracting tourist business.'' ``The same thing can be said for Asheville, North Carolina, and Blacksburg, Virginia, places in the mountains that people would just fly over otherwise.'' Savageau disagrees with Golant's belief in a migration decline. ``I think retirement migration is going to increase even though there are fewer numbers of retirement persons,'' he said. But they both see economic consequences as one older person in 94 moves to another state, based on 1988 census figures. Researchers say that translates to 275,000 to 400,000 moves a year. Golant sees the primary impacts on housing, because the migrants need new places to live, and on recreation and leisure, ``everything from golfing to vacations,'' because they have the free time, the money and generally good health. Savageau added rankings on employment in the third edition of his book after finding a fourth of those who start claiming Social Security still work and an additional half would like to work. Job availability helped propel 12 Florida communities into his top 1990 rankings. Texas and Arizona have three slots and North Carolina two in the top 30. The aging population also will boost spending on ``everything having to do with health care and in-home nursing care,'' which could become a political liability by increasing demand on state budgets to support Medicaid, Golant said. Regionally, he said: ``The Northeast and Midwest will still, of course, be out-migration areas. ... There's nothing on the horizon that suggests more people will move into your New Yorks and your Chicagos.'' In the Sunbelt, Golant noted, ``There are an increasing number of retirement locales, such as the Carolinas, which would offer alternatives to people compared to Florida.'' Savageau believes Californians may be ready to jump ship to capitalize on their home equity, and he is seeing some backlash against established retirement havens. ``Look at these little places like Kalispell, Montana, or Blacksburg, Virginia,'' he said. ``They're very nice places. Sure, they don't have the year-round climate that San Diego might have, but they're still an alternative to Florida or Arizona or south Texas.'' But back at the beach, Mrs. Silverman's mind is made up. ``I feel those elderly people, if they have to go through those winters up north with the snow and frost and be indoors with the steam heat, it definitely shortens their lives,'' she said. ``Here, the pure air and the outdoor living and all the activities offered for elderly people, there isn't a person who wouldn't find something they are interested in. You name it, it's all here. It's here in Miami Beach.''

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, Dec. 13, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: State Plans Poll of Older Residents
DOC.TEXT: The Ohio Department of Aging wants to find out how the older residents are getting along and what the government should be doing to help them. The agency hired the Survey Research Center at the University of Akron to conduct a telephone poll of people 60 and older. About 4,200 residents will be questioned in 25-minute interviews in January, with an additional 1,500 polled in a second phase, said Susan Lewis, chief of the department's division of communications. Results are due in late February and March. ``We basically don't have any information beyond the 1980 census and it's not specific enough to our audience that we need to serve,'' Ms. Lewis said. Detailed information from the 1990 census will not be available until late 1991 or 1992. Information will be gathered from survey participants about health, living situation, and support they receive. Specific questions still are being drafted. But Ms. Lewis said respondents likely will be asked about whether they have to use a walker, or wheelchair, whether they can drive, and how well they see. Also subjects such as care received from children or friends. Federal funds will be used to pay the $145,637 cost of the poll. ``I see it basically as a planning tool. (Before) we go in and try to design systems of care for the future to serve the needs of the elderly, I think the first step is to listen,'' Ms. Lewis said.

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, Dec. 13, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Cranberries for Much More Than Sauce
DOC.TEXT:
What's ruby red, sparkles like a jewel and can appear in holiday cooking in everything from a punch to a glorious dessert? Cranberries. So often we limit these popping beauties to a sweet sauce for turkey. Yet cranberries with their sharp, bright taste combine with many ingredients. For example, when you combine cranberry cocktail juice with orange sherbert, ginger ale and club soda, and float oranges in the punch bowl, you have a not too tart, not too sweet punch for the whole family. Of course, you can also add spirits. Maybe you haven't thought of cranberries in soup before, but they are wonderful as cranberry borscht, a super entree for a holiday occasion. An unusual cranberry dish is a cranberry salsa to spice up any roast: turkey, ham, pork tenderloin. By the way, any cranberry sauce recipe can be spooned over a roast for the last half-hour of baking to make a lovely glaze. And for the crowning touch for dessert - cranberry jubilee, flambeed with brandy and served over ice cream. Don't forget to string cranberries along with popcorn for homemade decorations for the tree and store some packages in your freezer to enjoy all winter long. --- Cranberry Punch This punch can go with any party you are planning over the holidays. Use your punch bowl or pitchers. Serve ice in glasses so punch does not get watered down. 48 oz. cranberry cocktail juice 12 oz. frozen orange concentrate 2 quarts ginger ale 1 quart orange sherbet 2 navel oranges (sliced thinly) 1 bottle Burgundy wine (optional) 8 oz. vodka (optional)
In a seven-quart punch bowl pour cranberry cocktail juice, frozen orange concentrate and ginger ale. When ready to serve, add sherbet and orange slices. Add wine and vodka, if desired. --- Ruby-Red Cranberry Borscht Yield: 8 cups 8 cups water 2 12-ounce bags cranberries, picked over, rinsed, drained, and stems removed 4 tablespoons unsalted butter 3 medium-size red onions, sliced lengthwise into half-inch thick slices 3 cups red cabbage (about half a medium-size head), cored and finely sliced 1 16-ounce can small whole beets, undrained 6 tablespoons orange juice concentrate 2 tablespoons red wine vinegar Salt and freshly ground pepper, to taste Garnish: sour cream or plain yogurt, or 1 orange, thinly sliced
In a large casserole or kettle over medium heat, bring water to a boil. Add cranberries and cook until they pop and turn shiny. In a large skillet over medium heat, melt 2 tablespoons of the butter. Add the onions and saute until translucent, five to seven minutes. Add cranberries. Heat the remaining butter in another skillet. Add the cabbage and saute until limp. Add to the cranberry mixture. Stir in the beets with their juice, orange concentrate and vinegar. Cook until thick and the cabbage and onions are incorporated into the soup, about 15 minutes. Season with salt and pepper. Transfer soup to a tureen. Serve hot and garnish with sour cream, yogurt, or orange slices. --- Cranberry Salsa Yield: 1 cup 1 cup fresh cranberries, rinsed picked over, patted dry 1/2 small red onion peeled and cut in chunks 1 canned mild green chiles, rinsed and seeded 2 tablespoons cilantro, or fresh dill 2 tablespoons lime or orange juice 1 tablespoon sugar
In a food processor fitted with a metal blade, combine cranberries, onion and chile. Pulse on and off to make a coarse puree. Add lime or orange juice and sugar. Pulse on and off until it incorporates. --- Cranberry Jubilee= Yield: Serves 8 to 12 1 pound fresh or frozen cranberries 12 oz. red currant jelly 1/4 cup sugar 1 orange (peel and cut peel into 1/8-inch slivers) 1/2 cup rum 1/2 cup brandy 2 tablespoons brandy to ignite 3 pints vanilla ice cream In a four-quart saucepan, place fresh or defrosted cranberries. Add jelly, rum, brandy and orange rind. Bring to boil. Cook until berries pop, about eight minutes. Keep some berries whole. The sauce should thicken. Serve four ounces of ice cream in a goblet, wine glass or glass dessert dish. Put cranberry jubliee in a silver bowl, ignite with brandy. Serve 2 tablespoons over ice cream. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Jane Weston Wilson is the author of the lifestyle cookbook ``Eating Well When You Just Can't Eat the Way You Used To,'' Workman Publishing.

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, Dec. 13, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Seed-Swapping a Gardener's Art in Winter
DOC.TEXT: An Indiana woman is looking for a mild-tasting yellow tomato with red streaks. In Kentucky, a gardener wants tan-colored seeds of long, stringless bean her grandmother used to grow. A Missouri woman asks help in finding a Hungarian poppy with multiple heads. With luck, these people will find the seeds before another planting season comes around. All across America gardeners are engaged in a fruitful wintertime activity - swapping seeds through magazine columns or trying to rediscover the seeds of lost flowers and vegetables. At headquarters of the National Gardening Association in Burlington, Vt., editors are preparing a special seed-swap and search listing for their magazine this winter. They hope in this way to clear up a backlog of requests crowded out of regular bimonthly editions. Associate Editor Vicky Congdon says a staff horticulturist first tries to find the answer to a search inquiry in the association's library of hundreds of old catalogs and other sources. If he finds a source, he'll contact the inquirer; if not, the query gets printed in the magazine, National Gardening. ``People tend to use the swap column to meet other gardeners. They establish friendships. It's a way to get in touch with people who are interested in the same hobby,'' said Editorial Assistant Diane Walker, who prepares the popular feature. She said a woman mourning the death of her husband offered seeds of an Italian heirloom tomato he used to grow. ``I did not have a need to swap, but only a need to share,'' the woman said. Ms. Walker said the response was overwhelming, and this tomato flourished again in friendly gardens. The column provides glimpses into the lively diversity of things Americans are growing, some with names you might never see in the latest catalogs. An Oklahoman offered ``seeds of black long bean and purple pod pole snap bean, red peanut bush dry bean, black turtle bush dry bean, red calico pole lima bean (very prolific), scarlet runner bean, Clemson spineless okra, whippoorwill cowpea, and American flag leek.'' And a Californian said he had ``seeds of cinnamon, lemon, licorice and holy basil ... mixed aquilegia, cosmos, cornflower, bishop's lace, double larkspur, single and double hollyhock, single and double gloriosa daisy, sweet William, mixed amaranth and green tassel amaranth to trade for heirloom tomatoes, beans or any perennial good for cut flowers, or for any variety of goldenrod or a white-flowered variety.'' From Hawaii came an offer to swap coral tree seeds for canna seeds. The coral tree would grow in frost-free areas. Seed swapping has a venerable history in America. Thomas Jefferson's Garden Book is rich with references to seeds he received or offered. On Dec. 14, 1812, for example, he wrote to a friend, Charles Clay, ``I do not remember to have seen Salsafia (salsify) in your garden, and yet it is one of the best roots for the winter. ``Some call it oyster plant because fried in butter it can scarcely be distinguished from a fried oyster. I send you some seed. It is to be sowed and managed as carrots and to be taken up at the same time and put away for winter use. ...'' In our computer age, some gardeners use electronic ``bulletin boards'' to post their swapping or researching requests. Answers may pop up on their screens the next day or a month later, contributed by on-line gardeners using the same network. Much seed swapping, of course, goes on without recourse to magazines or modems, gardening being a neighborly pastime. A Frenchman who lives near me introduced me to shallots known as frogs' legs because of their shape and large size. Ten years ago, a barber gave me seeds of a luscious white eggplant he got in Sicily. That barber has since retired, but a new barber - also a gardener - promised me a container-grown, dwarf fig tree. For it, I swapped some advice on keeping weeds out of an asparagus bed by mulching with salt hay. --- EDITOR'S NOTE: George Bria retired from the AP in 1981 after 40 years that included coverage of World War II from Italy.

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, Dec. 13, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Jury Awards $15 Million in Nursing Home Death
DOC.TEXT: A nursing home has been ordered to pay $15 million to a patient's estate for failing to give him pain medication in the last days of his life. The family of the late Henry James charged that the staff at Guardian Care was negligent in reducing and withholding James' prescribed dosage of morphine to ease pain from terminal bone cancer. James, of Murfreesboro, was 75 when he died in June 1987. The nursing home is operated by Hillhaven Corp., with headquarters in Tacoma, Wash. Hillhaven spokesman Tim Carroll said last month that the Hertford County Superior Court jury's award ``bears no relationship to the facts presented and we believe it will be overturned on appeal.'' Carroll said the company operates 343 nursing homes in 38 states. Ron Manasco, one of the plaintiffs' attorneys, said the award was one of the largest in the country in the area of nursing home care. The family maintained that the home's nursing director told James he couldn't have his regular dose because he might get addicted. The court jury awarded $7.5 million in compensatory damages and $7.5 million in punitive damages. ---
DOC.HEAD: Older Workers May Reduce Employer's Health Insurance Costs
DOC.TEXT: Employing older workers does not cost much more in health insurance expenses than employing younger ones and may actually reduce an employer's health insurance costs, a study says. It concluded that differences in workers' health insurance costs among age groups were not great enough to be a major factor in employment decisions. The study, commissioned by the American Association of Retired Persons, compared insurance costs of younger and older workers, reviewed federal studies and examined data from Blue Cross-Blue Shield's Federal Employee Program. Health insurance costs for older workers compared favorably to younger workers in part because the older employees generally had fewer dependents. ``In addition, hospital admission rates and lengths of stay have been falling rapidly for older Americans,'' it said. The study found instances in which hiring older workers could actually reduce employer health costs, including: - Hiring older single workers. The study said the highest-expense single-worker group, those aged 60-64, costs less than the lowest expense family group, parents aged 25 or younger. - Hiring older workers eligible for Medicare which will pay most of the medical bills for those over 65. - Hiring older workers covered by another employer, including those workers covered in a spouse's or other household member's health care.

The worst two-month stretch of layoffs since the 1981-82 recession pushed civilian unemployment to a three-year high of 5.9 percent in November, the government said. Payrolls fell by 267,000 last month, the Labor Department said Friday, after a 180,000-job loss in October. Since June, when the unemployment rate was 5.2 percent, nearly 1 million Americans have joined the ranks of the unemployed. Following the grim news, the Federal Reserve and a handful of banks moved to cut interest rates. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Growth in consumer credit slowed to a seasonally adjusted $1.47 billion in October, the government reported. Analysts said it was another sign of a weakening economy. The Federal Reserve on Friday said consumer credit grew at an annual rate of 2.4 percent, down from a revised 4.6 percent rate posted in September. The September rate was even slower than the 4.9 percent advance originally reported. Revolving, or credit card, debt increased $1.56 billion, or an annual rate of 8.6 percent, down from a 12.9 percent gain in September and a 13.3 percent advance a month earlier. --- DETROIT (AP) - More than 30,000 auto workers, nearly all of them at General Motors Corp. plants, will have next week off as the auto industry wrestles with a recession. GM, Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. said Friday they plan to shut down all or parts of a dozen assembly plants for the week of Dec. 10, keeping 32,380 workers at home. The closures stem from slow dealer orders. GM also said it will lay off 50,470 workers when it shuts down 18 assembly factories in 14 states the week of Dec. 17, the last week before the industry's traditional shutdown between the Christmas and New Year's holidays. --- PHILADELPHIA (AP) - A jury Friday awarded $6 million to a state supreme court justice, saying The Philadelphia Inquirer defamed him in a reprint of a 1983 series about the court's conduct. The jury, which deliberated nine hours over two days following a seven-week trial, found the reprint was false and defamatory, but that the original series was not false. The award was the second libel judgment against the Inquirer this year. William Hangley, the Inquirer's lawyer, said the paper will appeal the verdict. --- NEW YORK (AP) - R.H. Macy Co. Inc. said it lost $56.5 million during its first quarter as the retailer's sales, hurt by the weakening economy and the Middle East crisis, tumbled nearly 10 percent. The closely held Macy, which is still paying the costs of a 1986 leveraged buyout, said its loss in the quarter ended Oct. 27 translated to $38.53 per share and compared with a shortfall of $33.1 million, or $23.92 per share, in the same period a year earlier. Macy's results in the latest quarter, reported Friday, reflected a $10.2 million gain related to a repurchase of some of the retailer's bonds. --- PROVIDENCE, R.I. (AP) - Fleet-Norstar Financial Group plans to cut about 500 jobs by the end of the month in an austerity plan designed to save about $100 million next year, a company official said. The layoffs will be scattered among Fleet's 1,000 offices in 40 states, but will affect primarily workers in New England and New York, said bank spokesman Robert W. Lougee Jr on Friday The Providence-based bank holding company pinned most of the layoffs on the recession plaguing the Northeast. --- CINCINNATI (AP) - Kroger Co. says it has received so few responses in a bond-exchange program to reduce its $1.4 billion bond debt that it will extend the deadline for replies until Dec. 20. The program was to have ended on Tuesday. The grocery giant offered Nov. 5 to let holders of bonds that begin paying 15.5 percent annual interest in October 1993 trade them in for bonds that pay 13 percent immediately. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole says he will introduce a bill early next month to grant some tax relief for military personnel serving in the Persian Gulf area. His bill would waive interest charges for failing to pay any taxes due by the April 15 deadline. The Kansas senator made the announcement Friday after the Internal Revenue Service noted that any member of the armed services serving in the Persian Gulf on April 15 would automatically have an additional 60 days to file a return and pay any tax due. --- BRUSSELS, Belgium (AP) - World trade negotiations collapsed when the United States and the European Community refused to back down and end a bitter dispute over reductions in farm subsidies. Uruguay's foreign minister, Hector Gros Espiell, halted five days of discussions on Friday after the EC rejected a compromise requiring deeper cuts in its extensive farm support program. Gros Espiell promised to restart the talks, possibly next month inGeneva, after further consultations to try to resolve the contentious farm issue. ---

The stock market drifted lower and bond prices hit six-month highs on Friday amid gloomy employment news. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 12.38 to 2,590.10. The dollar declined sharply and gold also lost ground. Grain and soybean futures prices were mostly lower, livestock and pork futures were higher and energy futures gained.

DOC.HEAD: Engine Makers Unite Against Common Enemy: High Cost of Doing Business
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report
DOC.TEXT: Pratt & Whitney forges an alliance with Germany's Daimler-Benz to develop a new generation of high-thrust jet engines. General Electric Co. sues, claiming the deal violates its agreement with Daimler-Benz. Then GE drops the suit, and announces this fall it is exploring a joint venture with Pratt & Whitney to develop a supersonic jet engine. Like countries forging alliances against a common foe, jet-engine makers are joining forces in ever-changing combinations, making it almost impossible to know which companies are rivals and which are partners. Joint ventures help engine-makers share astronomical development costs, which results in superior engines by combining the technological strengths of various companies, and even widen a company's customer base by giving it access to a rival's loyal customers, industry experts say. ``Things are happening very fast,'' said David Vadas, an economist with the Aerospace Industries Association, a Washington-based lobbying group. ``When you have the big boys - Pratt & Whitney, GE and Rolls-Royce - going into joint ventures, there is no turning back.'' Development of a new jet engine costs between $1 billion to $2 billion. The development costs for the supersonic engine that GE and Pratt & Whitney are contemplating could reach a staggering $4.5 billion. Perhaps 80 percent of jet engines built over the next two decades will be produced by international partnerships, said Mark A. Bobbi, an analyst with Forecast International in Newtown, Conn., which follows the aerospace industry. That eventually will increase to almost 100 percent, he said. ``The nature of new engines and new aircraft almost dictates it, because of the costs and risks,'' Bobbi said. Sales of commercial engines could amount to between $100 billion and $150 billion during the next 15 years, Bobbi said. Jet-engine makers form two basic kinds of alliances. The most common is known as a risk-sharing partnership, in which a number of companies contribute parts, technology and financing for an engine that bears one company's name. But several partners also may form an independent company that produces its own engines, like East Hartford-based International Aero Engines, created in 1983 by Pratt & Whitney, Rolls-Royce Ltd. of Great Britain and others. GE pioneered the trend in 1971 by teaming with Snecma, a French rival, to form CFM International. CFM produces the highly successful CFM56 series for short- to medium-range twin engine planes like the Boeing 737. East Hartford-based Pratt & Whitney launched its first civilian partnership in 1973, teaming with Daimler-Benz and Fiat Aviazione of Italy to build high thrust engines for wide-body jets. Volvo Flyg Motor of Sweden eventually joined the consortium, which builds the PW2000 series for planes like the Boeing 757. By 1988, Jane's All The World's Aircraft, an industry publication, listed six major jet engine manufacturing alliances. Pratt & Whitney, a division of United Technologies Corp., is involved in seven major partnership programs. GE is now working on at least five jointly produced engines. An alliance between Pratt & Whitney and GE would be the most surprising of all. The two companies have been slugging it out since the 1970s for primacy in the jet-engine market. Pratt & Whitney controlled 100 percent of the market until 1970, but GE is now regarded as the biggest jet-engine maker. Pratt & Witney logged $12 billion in orders and options last year, vs. GE's $15 billion. The companies announced in October they were exploring joint development of a supersonic jet engine to power planes faster and bigger than the French-British Concorde, powered by an engine built by Rolls-Royce and Snecma. ``There was no way either company could do it alone from a technological or financial viewpoint,'' said Donald Rudolph, managing director for development and planning at Pratt & Whitney. ``Everybody recognized it is so big that you need help.'' The companies informed the U.S. Justice Department of their plans, but said they don't anticipate antitrust problems. If the deal goes through, they will be working together on the supersonic engine only, and will compete in other areas. Generally, antitrust issues don't arise because the partners are from different countries. Joint ventures can breed superior engines by combining the best technology of the various partners, said Craig Hekking, another analyst with Forecast International. Take the V2500 engine built by International Aero Engines. Besides Pratt & Whitney and Rolls-Royce, IAE partners include Motoren und Turbinen Union, Daimler's aerospace division; Italy's Fiat Aviazione; and Japanese Aero Engines Corp. The V2500 engine, put into service in 1989, is built in modules - with each partner responsible for a specific section. The engines are then assembled at Pratt & Whitney and Rolls-Royce plants. Rolls-Royce builds the high-pressure compressor, Pratt the combustor and high-pressure turbine. Japanese Aero Engines Corp. contributes the low-pressure compressor system, while Motoren und Turbinen Union builds the low-pressure turbine. Fiat Aviazione builds the gearbox. Engine-makers also don't seem very worried about rivals' gaining access to their trade secrets. GE raised the issue in its $1.2 billion lawsuit against Pratt & Whitney, which it dropped after Daimler-Benz agreed to continue consulting with GE, but on smaller engines. But others say most engine-makers are roughly equal in terms of technology. Because engines like the V2500 are built in modules, a company contributing one piece wouldn't know how the other modules are put together, said Nick Tomassetti, the former IAE president who is now back at Pratt & Whitney. IAE has received $7.5 billion worth of orders for the V2500 so far, and expects orders to reach $20 billion by 2004.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Expected to Approve Eagle-Picher Class-Action
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge is expected to consolidate 65,000 asbestos claims against Eagle-Picher Industries Inc. in a controversial step toward settling the nation's biggest product liability issue, lawyers said. But victims' attorneys said Sunday they would move immediately to appeal a class-action order by U.S. District Judge Jack B. Weinstein and try to block a proposed settlement plan they say provides inadequate compensation. Under the proposal, Eagle-Picher would place $625 million over 20 years into a settlement trust fund that also would contain at least 25 percent of Eagle-Picher stock. Plaintiffs lawyers said it offers too little money and lacks protection should the company default or declare bankruptcy. The Cincinnati-based industrial products maker says it faces a Chapter 11 bankruptcy court filing if no solution to its asbestos liability is reached soon. Eagle-Picher has sold off millions of dollars in assets to pay claims, but says it no longer can meet its obligations. Kenneth Feinberg, a mediator in the case appointed by Weinstein, said he expected the judge to approve a class action as early as today and tentatively accept the settlement pending a series of hearings on its fairness. The hearings are to be held in New York, Cincinnati and another city and last from four to six weeks, he said. Individuals involved in the case said Weinstein also would freeze all litigation against Eagle-Picher and bar the company from paying out any asbestos claims pending approval of a final settlement. Weinstein wants to create a class action to settle all cases at once, which would eliminate costly trials that are diverting money that could be used to pay victims. Eagle-Picher's case likely would be used as a model for other companies with large asbestos liabilities. About 90,000 asbestos cases clog federal and state court dockets nationwide in what legal experts say is the biggest product liability issue in U.S. history. Another key step involves a reorganization of the Manville trust fund, which faces 130,000 claims but has run out of cash, that is pending before Weinstein. Several plaintiffs lawyers said victims would receive more money if Eagle-Picher reorganizes under federal bankruptcy laws than under the proposed settlement. They said they would fight Weinstein's class-action certification in the 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. ``The plan under any kind of objective scrutiny by anybody familiar with business or familiar with asbestos litigation is grossly unfair to the victims,'' said Gene Locks, a Philadelphia plaintiffs lawyer. ``Victims will come out multiples better through a (bankruptcy) reorganization,'' he said. Under the plan, Eagle-Picher would pay $460 million over 20 years, $120 million from operations and $45 million to meet already negotiated settlements. Payments would not begin until November 1993 at the soonest. The plan was negotiated and approved by only two of four attorneys appointed by Weinstein to negotiate with Eagle-Picher on behalf of victims. Plaintiffs attorneys nationwide met over the weekend to plan how to fight Weinstein, who they said appointed the two lawyers in an effort to force through a plan. Attorneys said they would challenge Weinstein's authority and handling of the case, as well as that of the two court-appointed victims' lawyers who negotiated the settlement, who have little experience in the 20-year-old asbestos litigation. ``There is a feeling among some plaintiffs lawyers that the judge is not objective and he is so much committed to finding a solution to the problem of asbestos litigation that the objective that should be there isn't,'' said Peter Angelos, a Baltimore lawyer who opposes the plan. Lawyers said the law firm of one of the attorneys, Stanley Chesley of Cincinnati, had a conflict of interest because it represented Owens-Illinois Inc., a major asbestos defendant company. Chesley said his firm represented Owens-Illinois more than 20 years ago on a non-asbestos matter and the company was not a current client. He said his lack of experience in asbestos was irrelevant. ``The issue is what's best for the claimants from an independent viewpoint,'' Chesley said. Current and future claims by victims of lung cancer and other respiratory ailments against Eagle-Picher are estimated at about 175,000. The company has spent $540 million in the last five years on asbestos obligations and its future claims are estimated at $600 million.

DOC.HEAD: Media Comapny Placed in Receivership
DOC.TEXT: John Fairfax Group Proprietary Ltd., which owns the Sydney Morning Herald and three other major Australian publications, was placed into receivership Monday after banks called in outstanding debts. John Fairfax, one of Australia's two major newspaper groups along with Rupert Murdoch's News Corp. Ltd., owes about 1.7 billion Australian dollars, or $1.31 billion, to its creditors. Company officials said directors asked for the appointment of a provisional liquidator for the group's finance division after banks refused to agree to a rollover of a debt of 850 million Australian dollars, or $654 million. The Deloitte Ross Tohmatsu accountancy firm was then appointed receiver and manager at the request of John Fairfax Group's banking syndicate. The ANZ Bank and Citibank are owed about 1.2 billion Australian dollars, or $850 million. The remaining debt is in the form of high-yield, high-risk bonds. John Fairfax, Australia's oldest media organization, also owns the Australian Financial Review, Business Review Weekly and The (Melbourne) Age as well as the Herald in Sydney. The Herald is the oldest English-language newspaper in the world continuously owned by the same family. In early October, the company reported a net loss of 59.08 million Australian dollars, or $45.49 million, for the year ending June 30. On Aug. 25, three top John Fairfax officials - Chief Executive Chris Anderson, Chairman Brian Kelman and director Bob Johnston - resigned amid continuing disputes on renegotiations of the debt. John Fairfax's problems have been mirrored at Murdoch's News Corp. Ltd. In early October, Murdoch merged four of his newspapers into two round-the-clock productions in Sydney and Melbourne. The moves came amidst a plunge in the value of News Corp. stock that wiped out more than 2 billion Australian dollars, or $1.66 billion, of the company's market capitalization. Murdoch has been talking in recent weeks with bank lenders about restructuring News Corp. debt and hopes to have a deal by early next year. Other media outlets in Australia have fared poorly as well. Two of the major private television stations are in receivership and have fired hundreds of staff. The third recently reported a loss of 618 million Australian dollars, or $511 million.

DOC.HEAD: China Announces Plans For Another Stock Market
DOC.TEXT: A third Chinese city announced plans Monday to open a securities exchange as interest in stock and bond markets rebounds from a period of official discouragement. Shanghai is scheduled to open China's first full-fledged securities market on Dec. 19, and the Shenzhen Special Economic Zone plans to open one next year. The newcomer is the Zhuhai Special Economic Zone, located near Shenzhen in southeastern China's Guangdong province. The zones are areas that have more freedom than most cities to experiment in economic reforms. Zhuhai Mayor Liang Guangda said a task force is preparing to open a securities market next year, the official China Daily reported. The report indicated the market will focus on stocks, unlike the upcoming Shanghai market that will handle mainly government bonds. The new markets will consolidate transactions, currently handled by dozens of small, unlinked counters in major cities. Liang's announcement reflects the new security market fever after more than a year of official coolness toward market-oriented reforms in general. After crushing a popular democracy movement last year, the conservative leaders who came to the fore denounced capitalist influences on society and the economy. In recent months, however, authorities have begun viewing securities markets as a useful tool for raising much-needed capital. They are most interested in using the markets to sell state treasury bonds to help cover a growing budget deficit. Last week, the government started up a nationwide computerized bonds trading system. There has been heavy publicity in the official media about the new system and the coming Shanghai market. Authorities are less enthusiastic about stocks because they transfer ownership of companies from state hands to the private sector. The government allowed the first stock issue under communist rule in 1985 and a brief period of stock fever followed, but most issues were made available only to employees of the companies involved and are not actively traded. Economists recently have revived interest in stocks by presenting them as a way of tapping private savings to aid industrial expansion and modernization. The official China Daily newspaper last week published an argument by a group of economists on behalf of stocks and markets. The newspaper boldly likened the new interest in all kinds of securities to ``a prairie fire spreading across the country - irresistable and irreversible.''

DOC.HEAD: Sharp Drop In Foreign Investments
DOC.TEXT: Foreign investments in the Philippines dropped more than 71 percent during the third quarter of this year, the Central Bank reported Monday. The bank said new foreign investments during the period amounted to $79 million, down from $282 million the same time last year. The figures were contained in a report submitted to President Corazon Aquino last week by Central Bank Governor Jose Cuisia. Portions of the report were released to reporters Monday. The report also said capital withdrawals surged 261.4 percent to $206 million during the first nine months of the year, up from $57 million a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Nissan, Volkswagen Suspend Plan For Passat Cars
DOC.TEXT: Sales of Volkswagen's new Passat model in Japan have been too low to proceed with plans for Nissan Motor Co. to begin assembling the cars here next year, spokesmen for the two companies said Monday. Current sales of about 200 a month make the start-up costs for Passat production unreasonable, a Nissan spokesman said. ``Unfortunately, the sales results aren't as high as expected. We think that if the current sales trend continues, there's no benefit in producing the car,'' the spokesman said. Through its dealer network, Nissan is to continue selling Passats imported from Germany. Volkswagen initially had expected sales of about 700 a month for the Passat, introduced in May as a successor to the Santana model. The two companies said their cooperation in other areas such as technology would continue. ``If in the future something comes up, we will be ready to negotiate with Volkswagen as ever,'' said the Nissan spokesman said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Nissan was to have begun assembling knockdown kits of the Passat next summer as it assembled and sold the Santana from 1983 to 1989. A Volkswagen spokesman confirmed low sales were the reason for suspending plans for Nissan to assemble the Passat. Volkswagen imports and markets its other models in Japan through an independent agent.

DOC.TEXT: For the past year, since the fall of the Berlin Wall, tourists have been rediscovering an older, more traditional Europe to the east. A reporter who recently took a cruise on the Black Sea from Bulgaria to the Soviet Crimea found a certain charm amid the chaos of a changing economy.

There's a small hotel - in fact, there are hundreds of them that only a year ago were private villas and holiday retreats for Communist commissars, privileged artists and favored trade union leaders. Now the vacancy sign is out for tourists from the West, or the Far East, since the yen is as welcome as the dollar, the pound and the mark. But, please, no levs - the locals disdain the local currency. And the high-rise Communist Party House, as much a fixture in every Bulgarian city and town as the hulking statue of Lenin, now has offices to rent to shipping firms, travel agents, exporters and all kinds of entrepreneurs pouring into Eastern Europe since the fall of the Berlin Wall. ``This is no longer a communist country; we are a developing democracy,'' says Dmitri, our guide from Balkantourist, the state travel agency, as he leads a band of tourists off a cruise ship through the ruins of Roman baths. In the second century, Varna, then called Odessos, was a rest center for the Roman emperors' legionnaires. A little later he leads us up a precarious trail to a cliff-hanging medieval monastery called Aladja. Suddenly last summer, all over Eastern Europe, monasteries and churches and palaces that had been held in ideological scorn for half a century came back in favor. Those that had been used to store grain or billet troops, or had been converted to museums of atheism, were being swept out and refurbished. And in beach resorts all along the Black Sea coast from Bulgaria's Turkish border to the Soviet Crimea, dreary high-rise hotels in stolid Stalinist gothic are scheduled for ``privatization.'' Ibusz, the Hungarian state tourist agency, is on the block to raise capital to launch capitalism. Dresden is trying to unload from its main square a 22-foot-high head of Karl Marx, but so far has found no takers. German golfer Bernhard Langer, the 1985 Masters champion, is prospecting for future course layouts in Hungary, Czechoslovakia and what was East Germany. The royal and ancient game, banned for decades in communist climes, already is in full back-swing on an island 21 miles up the Danube from Budapest at a 9-hole course named ``Szentendre'' - St. Andrews. ``Here in Varna,'' Dmitri says, ``we already have a German beer garden, an English pub, a Greek taverna and an Indian restaurant. We think many tourists will be coming. Our climate is much milder than the French Riviera. You can swim until mid-October.'' On a balmy fall day several bathers were slithering down water slides and landing splat in mud baths along the wide beach called Zlatri Piassatsi - Golden Sands. Hoping to match neighboring Romania's oil finds, drillers gushed up only mineral springs here. Some Austrian tourists happened by after World War II and insisted the waters cured rheumatism and baldness. A spa was born. Shepherding his flock into a shopping arcade where some lace, embroidery and leathercraft were displayed, Dmitri expresses the hope that Bulgaria's younger generation will ``hang in there'' (his newest English idiom) long enough to reap the rewards of a free-market economy. ``More than 100,000 left the country last year,'' he says. ``A million more may go next year.'' Outside, a young man was peddling ``rare icons'' that stained his jacket with their fresh coat of gilt. In a square near the Ethnographic Museum, the proprietor of a little van advertising ``beer, herring and brandy'' gave a sadder picture of the inflated local currency. He had no beer and no herring, but a plastic cup of slivova, strong plum brandy, netted you change from a one-lev note, valued at 14 cents. Arriving at Yalta in the Crimea, the cruise passengers wondered about the future of the 80 health resorts and sanitaria operated by various trade unions and government agencies. Nestled in the pine forests on the bluffs were villas and dachas of top-level commissars and apparatchniki. Our Intourist guide worried a little about privatization since individual Soviet republics now have been given control of their own tourism. But she doubts that foreign visitors will ever take over what she called ``the comrades' Coney Island.'' Last year, she said, 2 million vacationers came to Yalta, adding that ``our local joke is that they sunbathe standing up.'' She was eloquent on Yalta's health-giving climate: ``Winds off the Crimean Mountains filtering through the pine forests mingle with the Black Sea breezes to produce an atmosphere that has been scientifically proven to be beneficial in the treatment of stress, rheumatism, asthma and cardiovascular ailments.'' Russian playwright and short-story writer Anton Chekhov came for treatment of the tuberculosis he aggravated walking all night in the snowy streets of Moscow in despair over poor notices for ``The Seagull.'' Leo Tolstoy convalesced in a nursing home up on the bluffs and was read to under the pines by novelist Maxim Gorky.

DOC.HEAD: VARNA, Bulgaria: Maxim Gorky.
DOC.TEXT: In keeping with the new reverence for palaces, we had to don burlap mukluks to glide across the parquet floors of the Alupka Palace, the two-faced edifice that Count Vorontsov had his British architect dream up. It has a Tudor castle facade on the north side and a ripoff of the Moorish Alhambra overlooking the sea on the south. Leaving the grounds we were besieged by hordes of young black marketeers flogging caviar, champagne, amber jewelry, Russian army caps and more ``genuine antique'' icons. ``Hey Oncle Sam, you want hero medals?'' called out a boy barely in his teens, opening his coat like a prohibition bootlegger to display a lining resplendent with medals, ribbons and decorations. ``No? What about a meel-itary vatch?'' He pushed up his sleeve and revealed an armload reaching beyond the elbow. ``Maybe you give me choon-gum or a Marlboro cigarette.'' Our guide warned against ``pickpockets, money changers who will give you pre-revolution Ukrainian notes, and similar bad peoples.'' Since Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev lifted the lid on communism's pressure cooker all sorts of ``bad peoples'' have bubbled to the surface in the Soviet Union. Crime has risen nearly 40 per cent. In some larger cities, where burglaries are up 80 percent, the citizens are forming neighborhood crime patrols. The police, always despised but now ridiculed and rationed to 5 gallons of gas a day for their patrol cars, keep such a low profile that highway accidents have increased fourfold. Director Vladimir Malinin of Intourist recently reported that because of the crime situation bookings dropped 40 per cent in 1990, and American visitors were down to 100,000 from 180,000 the year before. Heavy morning fog at Odessa on the northern rim of the Black Sea delayed the docking of our ship, the Cunard liner Vistaford. Because we arrived late ``and the driver is not permitted overtime,'' our guide vetoed a photo opportunity at the foot of the famous Potemkin Steps. Twice as wide at the bottom as the top, the staircase projects a splendid optical illusion of even greater height than its 455 feet. Grigori Potemkin, Catherine the Great's favorite general, ushered in the golden age of tourism on the Black Sea in inaugurating the new harbor at Sevastapol in 1797. He floated foreign dignitaries down the Dnieper on 80 Roman galleys, painted red and gold, each with its own orchestra. Since some of the new towns planned for the Crimea were still on the drawing board, Potemkin had facades of fake buildings erected and transported in thousands of peasants to populate his ``Potemkin villages,'' a sort of Disneyland on the Dnieper. Our guide dismissed an enchanting Orthodox cathedral with golden onion domes as ``not important'' and attempted to hurry us into the hard-currency Beryozka shop, which sold vodka, fur hats, amber jewelry and other luxury items available only to foreigners. The way was blocked by a very drunken comrade being rushed along by two friends in almost as bad shape. He teetered from their grasp and fell on his face in the gutter, blood gushing from his cuts. ``Somogan!'' spat out our guide in disgust. The word means moonshine vodka, a popular black-market item in the wake of Gorbachev's temperance campaign. Saturday evidently was marrying day in Odessa. Dozens of wedding parties emerged from a government registry office to pose for pictures on the lawn and under the porticoes of the handsome opera house, one of Europe's finest. The brides in long white gowns, the grooms in formal wear, soee with top hats, arrived in horse-drawn carriages and vintage limousines, gaily decorated with flowers, streamers and silver bells. Some alighted from taxicabs and the tandem three-car trolleys. One bride was delivered by an ambulance driven by a friend or relative. Most bridal couples were in their 30s and beyond. ``They marry late because there is a long wait for an apartment, sometimes 10 years,'' a taxi driver told us. ``Many will move in with relatives.'' Downtown Odessa, with its broad boulevards, chestnut trees and the fading elegance of its hotels, museums, opera house and older apartments built in czarist baroque, retains the charm of an older Europe. But that vanishes as one proceeds past the university to the grim blocks of tower apartments in communist concrete. Gradually the clock is being turned back in Odessa. Rival political parties are beginning to emerge. Proletariat Street has changed its name back to French Boulevard. Before bidding us farewell, the lady from Intourist delivered one of those stupefying tour-guide statistics that trouble your sleep like the rumblings of an underdone blini: ``Unsurpassed in its curative qualities, the mud of Odessa has long been recognized as the world standard for mud.'' East of Berlin, local color is where you find it.
