That wariness was reinforced Monday by word from an Iraqi official that his country was not ready to compromise ``one iota'' on its position in Kuwait. Brokers also noted that investors were still digesting Friday's monthly report on the employment situation, which painted a gloomy picture of the outlook for growth and corporate profits. The Labor Department said the civilian unemployment rate jumped 0.2 percentage point to 5.9 percent in November, and that nonfarm payroll employment took a bigger-than-expected drop of 267,000. Gainers among the blue chips included Philip Morris, up } at 50}; International Business Machines, up ~ at 113]; General Motors, up \ at 36}; Exxon, up ] at 49|, and Procter & Gamble, up \ at 85\. On the downside, Boeing fell | to 44~ and General Electric was down { at 57. Lone Star Industries suffered the day's biggest percentage decline, falling 2[ to 2|. The company, which produces cement and deals in such other construction materials as sand and gravel, filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the federal bankruptcy law. Some bank stocks and other financial issues rose on expectations of further moves soon by the Federal Reserve toward easier credit. BankAmerica gained { to 24{; Manufacturers Hanover 1 to 24; Citicorp \ to 15; Federal National Mortgage ~ to 34}, and Household International 1[ to 31{. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market increased $7.27 billion, or 0.24 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose .51 to 179.58. Standard & Poor's industrial index gained 1.18 to 384.88, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was up 1.14 at 328.89. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market slipped .07 to 371.47. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 306.61, up .16.

DOC.HEAD: Privatization of Telephone Company Raises Hopes for Better Service
DOC.TEXT: The sale of the government-owned telephone monopoly to a consortium including French and American buyers raised the prospect Monday that it will get easier for Mexicans to get a phone and that when they do, it will work better. The Treasury Department on Sunday announced that St. Louis-based Southwestern Bell, France Cable & Radio and the Mexican Grupo Carso had submitted the winning bid of $1.76 billion for a controlling interest in Telefonos de Mexico. The sale means ``it will be possible to improve service notably, continue expanding the system, strengthen research and technological development...'' the government newspaper El Nacional said in an editorial. The sale was part of the government's program of selling an array of unprofitable or non-essential businesses and industries to the private sector. ``One of the purposes for the sale of Telefonos de Mexico was related to improvement of service,'' an editorial in El Universal said. ``There is a long road to travel, but there is no uncertainty about the new possibilities of making the advances that should occur in telephone modernization,'' it added. Alfredo Baranda, Telmex director, said the improvements would take time. The new owners hope that the wait for telephone service can be cut to two or three months within the next three or four years, he told the government news agency Notimex. There are now only 5.5 million telephone lines in Mexico serving a population of 81 million people. France Cable & Radio, in contrast, operates 28 million telephone lines in France. Shortages of lines, installation costs, line troubles and repair delays plague the Telmex system. Desperate customers occasionally publish newspaper ads or write letters the editor in last-ditch attempts to get repairs for lines that have been out for months. Although customers may be rejoicing at the prospect of better telephone service, some Telmex employees are unhappy at the privatization. The sale agreement also provides government financing of the sale of 4.4 percent of the stock to company employees over eight years. A dissident union leader said the privatization was carried out ``without consulting the workers.'' More than 500 employees have been fired over the past two years and the situation of 3,000 operators remains unresolved, Rigoberto Barba said. The government's privatization program is part of a revamping of the economy to cut the government debt and attract more foreign investment. Acciones y Valores de Mexico, GTE of the United States and Telefonica de Espana had offered $1.69 billion. Mexico's Grupo Gentor offered nearly $1.6 billion. The sale will return Telmex to the private sector. Formed in 1950 by the merger of companies owned by International Telephone and Telegraph of the United States and I.M. Ericsson of Sweden, majority ownership was sold to Mexicans in 1958. The government took over 51 percent ownership in 1972.

DOC.HEAD: Security Pacific Sets Aside $850 Million for Problems
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with closing stock price in 9th graf, Security Pacific.
DOC.TEXT: Security Pacific Corp. said Monday it would set aside $850 million for bad loans, foreclosed real estate and restructuring costs, a move that will result in a fourth-quarter loss of up to $360 million. The Los Angeles concern, the nation's fifth-largest bank holding company, said its profit for the 1990 fiscal year will decline to about $160 million, compared with $741 million in 1989. Security Pacific also said it will eliminate its merchant bank, which ran into trouble with lending in Britain and Australia. The company maintained that its core consumer and commercial banking operations in California and the Pacific Northwest remain strong. Taking losses now and focussing on core business will ``substantially strengthen'' future profits, said Chief Executive Robert Smith. The big debt-rating services, Moody's Investors Service Inc. and Standard & Poor's Corp., immediately began reviewing the company's debt ratings. S&P said major areas of concern were overseas operations and deteriorating domestic loans, while Moody's said its review would focus on commercial real estate lending and takeover loans. Security Pacific's announcement follows similar actions by big New York banks, in the face of loan defaults, a slowing economy and declining real estate values. California banks also face weakening residential and commercial real estate markets, as well as tougher government demands on lenders that have affected banks and thrifts nationwide. Management will recommend that Security Pacific maintain its quarterly dividend of 63 cents per share, Smith said. Security Pacific stock, which had fallen by $3 on Friday, rose $1 to $23 per share Monday on the New York Stock Exchange as investors apparently accepted Smith's take-your-medicine-now explanation. Less sanguine was Prudential Bache Securities analyst George Salem, who said he could not understand why the stock rose on the bad news. Compared to other California banks, Security Pacific's potential problems with real estate loans are high, Salem said in a telephone interview from New York. ``Their exposure is most heavily oriented to Southern California, which is the weaker part of the California economy,'' Salem said. Salem recommended that investors dump Security Pacific and other California bank stocks in a recent report that said California home resale prices could fall by 25 percent by 1992, new home sales are extremely weak, and commercial real estate is mired in rising vacancies, falling rents, a credit crunch and shrinking appraisals. ``The economic trends for California remain poor,'' Salem said Monday, noting that last week's unemployment figures showed the jobless rate for the state rose from 6 percent to 6.7 percnnt. Security Pacific, in the first three quarters, had increased its provisions for loan losses by 60 percent over last year, to $541 million. It said it would take $600 million in additional loan-loss reserves during the fourth quarter. It also set aside $50 million to cover a speeded-up program to sell off commercial real estate it has been stuck with through foreclosures. Security Pacific's merchant bank had handled commercial and investment banking and various securities and currency transactions in more than 20 countries. The company said it would take a charge of about $200 million in the fourth quarter to cover the costs of phasing out that bank. ``We expect to sell, downsize, or completely withdraw from many of our European and Australian activities, due to dramatic and continuing changes in economic and financial markets,'' Smith said.

DOC.HEAD: Former Shearson Executive Becomes Smith Barney Vice Chairman
DOC.TEXT: Jeffrey B. Lane, removed as the president of Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. during a management shuffle last year, has been named a vice chairman at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co., it was announced Monday. Lane, 48, currently an executive at Smith Barney's parent, Primerica Corp., will oversee the investment firm's asset management group and its futures division, Smith Barney said in a statement. Smith Barney said Lane would continue in his position at Primerica, where he is in charge of the recently formed Smith Barney Trust Co. In November 1989, Lane was removed as president and chief operating officer of Shearson and was reassigned to head the strugling investment firm's asset management business. He resigned a month later and joined Primerica early this year. Shearson, a subsidiary of American Express Co., underwent a shakeup and a $900 recapitalization last year after suffering a prolonged earnings decline. Turmoil at the company continued into 1990 with the resignation of Chairman Peter Cohen. Shearson has since renamed itself Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. Lane joined a Shearson predecessor, Cogan, Berlind, Weil & Levitt, in 1969 as a securities analyst and rose steadily through the ranks until last year.

DOC.HEAD: Gold Futures Rebound from 3-Day Slide on Mideast Jitters
DOC.TEXT: Gold futures prices rallied Monday on New York's Commodity Exchange, erasing almost half of last week's steep losses in reaction to tough talk from both sides in the Persian Gulf crisis. On other commodity markets, silver futures edged lower; oil futures rose; livestock and meat futures advanced; and grains and soybeans were mostly higher. Gold futures settled $3.50 to $3.90 higher with the contract for delivery in December at $374.20 a troy ounce; silver finished 0.5 cent to 0.9 cent lower with December at $4.05 a troy ounce. Gold's rally marked a turnaround for the market, which fell a total of $8.60 in the three previous sessions. Perceptions about the possibility of war in the Middle East dominated gold trading, said precious metals analyst Don Tierney of Fortune Commodities Inc. in New York. He said prices opened higher in New York following a rally on the London market after the Cable News Network aired an interview with Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz saying Baghdad does not recognize the United Nations' Jan. 15 deadline for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. The Iraqi government also issued a statement saying it would ``not compromise one iota'' in its claim to the emirate it seized more than four months ago. President Bush, in a speech in Washington, denounced the Iraqi takeover of Kuwait as a ``systematic assault on the soul of a nation.'' Higher energy prices and a weaker dollar also supported gold, Tierney said. ``At one point we were up $6.50, then some profit-taking came in,'' he said. In energy trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange, light sweet crude oil settled 26 cents to 35 cents higher with January at $26.90 a barrel; heating oil finished .24 cent lower to 1.8 cents higher with January at 80.97 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .99 cent to 1.7 cents higher with January at 67.73 cents a gallon; natural gas ended 0.5 cent lower to 4.5 cents higher with January at $2.355 per thousand cubic feet. Frozen pork belly futures soared the permitted daily limit of 2 cents a pound on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange as low cash belly prices and tight stocks of frozen bellies encouraged buying in the commercial sector. Charles K. Levitt, senior livestock analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc., estimated Dec. 1 frozen belly stocks at less than 23 million pounds compared with 67.5 million pounds a year ago. The Agriculture Department will release its estimate of Dec. 1 stocks on Dec. 21. Levitt said the market also was due for a rebound after dropping almost 12 cents from mid-November to early December. Hog prices rallied in sympathy with the bellies while cattle futures advanced to new record highs in line with record-high cash prices of up to 81.5 cents a pound, he said. Live cattle futures settled .35 cent to .78 cent higher with December at 80.70 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .13 cent to .50 cent higher with January at 89 cents a pound; live hogs were .25 cent to .70 cent higher with December at 49.95 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 2 cents higher across the board with February at 66.70 cents a pound. Grain and soybean futures prices finished mostly higher after a day of light trading on the Chicago Board of Trade amid hopes the United States will grant food assistance to the Soviet Union. The markets traded within narrow margins as traders awaited news from Houston, where Secretary of State James Baker and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze opened two days of talks that were to include a discussion of export credit guarantees. Wheat futures settled \ cent to 1\ cents higher with December at $2.53\ a bushel; corn was } cent to 2{ cents higher with December at $2.26} a bushel; oats were \ cent lower to { cent higher with December at $1.10\ a bushel; soybeans were { cent to 3 cents higher with January at $6.10{ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Delta Drops Request for Nonstop Atlanta-to-Moscow Flight
DOC.TEXT: Delta Air Lines on Monday asked to withdraw its proposal for a nonstop flight from Atlanta to Moscow, and filed instead for a route with one stop in Germany. The Atlanta-based airline previously had asked the Department of Transportation for permission to operate three weekly nonstop flights between Atlanta and Moscow-Leningrad in 1991, with daily flights beginning in 1992. Whit Hawkins, Delta's executive vice president for marketing and stations, cited increased uel costs and economic conditions in the United States and the Soviet Union as reasons for the decision not to pursue nonstop service. Delta, Hawkins said, is ``keenly interested'' in the one-stop route, however. Delta is the third U.S. airline to withdraw its application for nonstop service. Continental Airlines and United Airlines are the others.

DOC.HEAD: Lone Star Industries Seeks Bankruptcy Protection From Creditors
DOC.TEXT: Lone Star Industries Inc., a large cement company, filed Monday for reorganization under federal bankruptcy law. The corporation blamed its financial woes on the downturn in the construction industry and continued competition with subsidized imports. Lone Star's board considred two offers from foreign investors and other alternatives before concluding it would be best to seek bankruptcy protection, the company said. More than two-thirds of the cement industry in the United States has passed into the hands of foreign investors, the company noted. In its filing in U.S. Bankruptcy Court in White Plains, N.Y., the corporation listed assets of $1.066 billion and liabilities of $703 million as of Oct. 31, said company spokesman James A. Powers. Lone Star and a number of its subsidiaries filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act. Lone Star said the filing would enable it to continue a program begun in 1989 to sell off some assets and restructure the company around its core business operations of cement, aggregate and ready-mixed concrete. The company took a $250 million writeoff in November 1989 as part of its restructuring, which included a decision to sell marginal cement plants in Pryor, Okla., Sweetwater, Texas, and Bonner Springs, Kan. The plants are still up for sale. The remaining operations are located in the Northeast and Midwest. Lone Star said its profits have been hurt by foreign concerns selling cement in the United States at less than they charge at home, a practice known as dumping. The federal government recently found Mexican producers guilty of dumping. ``Unfortunately, this ruling is several years too late,'' Lone Star said. ``However, should other dumpers suffer the same fate, our business could improve its profitability.'' Even after restructuring, Lone Star and its affiliates retain a 9.8 million ton annual cement manufacturing capacity in the United States, the company said. For the nine-month period ending Sept. 30, Lone Star reported a net loss of $12.2 million, or 97 cents a share. Net sales for the period were $190.6 million, and exclude the operations held for sale.

DOC.HEAD: Wang Implements Holiday `Shutdown'
DOC.TEXT: In an effort to cut costs, Wang Laboratories Inc. will shut down much of its North American operations during the week between Christmas and New Year's Day, a company spokeswoman said Monday. Under the move, Wang employees in the United States and Canada will take vacations from Dec. 24 through Jan. 1, although ``skeleton crews'' will still staff the company's facilities, spokeswoman Gail Jackson said. This is the first time the company has taken such a move, she said. Jackson said Wang chose to take this step during a slow time of the year. It will make more employees available during higher peaks of demand. Wang, a Lowell-based computer maker, recently reported its first profitable quarter after a string of losses. But Jackson said the company is still looking for ways to cut expenses. While employees will take vacations from accumulated time-off with pay, the company will save money by scaling back its operations, Jackson said. Jackson could not estimate how much money Wang will save from the shutdown.

DOC.HEAD: Consumer Groups Target Ads
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 23rd graf pvs, The company, with 4 grafs to UPDATE with comment from Philip Morris. Picks up 24th graf pvs, Gus Buenz. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Cereal that cures flab, cigarettes that keep you slim and an airline fleet as new as its last overhaul are among the most deceptive advertising claims of the past year, consumer groups contended Monday. General Motors' depiction of itself as a safety pioneer and Philip Morris' new image as a champion of the Bill of Rights also won ``Harlan Page Hubbard Lemon Awards'' from assorted consumer, health and environmental groups. The annual awards are named for ``the first advertising executive to employ deceptive advertising techniques on a national scale,'' according to the Center for Science in the Public Interest. Hubbard is best known for his efforts on behalf of Lydia Pinkham's Vegetable Compound, a turn-of-the-century quack patent medicine touted as a cure for complaints ranging from fatigue to cancer. ``The Hubbard spirit is alive and well in the advertising community,'' said Bruce Silverglade, legal director of the center. Silverglade and others called on Congress to strengthen the Federal Trade Commission's power to regulate advertising. Sen. Joseph Lieberman, D-Conn., a consumer advocate when he served as Connecticut's attorney general, said consumer groups and state attorneys general need FTC help in their efforts to get deceptive ads off the air. ``As good as all those people are, they simply do not have the power to cleanse the marketplace of bad advertising,'' Lieberman said. The Hubbards have been awarded for the past six years to ad campaigns branded ``the most misleading, unfair or irresponsible'' by groups familiar with their products. The 1990 entry into the ``Hubbard Hall of Shame'' was a Volvo ad that showed a Volvo standing up to the crushing weight of a truck driven over its roof. The car had been specially reinforced to survive the weight. Robert Austin, a Volvo spokesman, said the company never intended to mislead the public and was not aware that the car in the ad had been reinforced until after the ad aired. ``A mistake was made during the production of the commercial which compromised its validity,'' Austin said. ``We went out and told the public that with our own corrective advertisement.'' Another ``winner' was Burger King, which advertised a ``Kid's Club'' as ``fun, non-stop'' and flashed images of children happily involved in what are presumably club activities. The real club offers only a membership card and some stickers, said Action for Children's Television. Burger King spokeswoman Cori Zywotow said the clubs have 2.7 million members who receive a newsletter five times a year and special meals at the restaurant. Asked if that counts as ``fun, non-stop,'' she replied: ``We stand behind our kid's club program and our kid's club advertising 100 percent. It's been wonderfully successful and lots of fun.'' Two major companies were cited twice by the watchdog groups. GM advertised its Cutlass Supreme model as ``fuel efficient'' even though it gets lower mileage than most of GM's other models, according to the Safe Energy Communication Council. In addition, the Center for Auto Safety said the company misrepresented itself by claiming in another ad that it ``pioneered the airbag.'' GM removed airbags from its cars after 1976 and fought government rules that would have required them. It now equips fewer models with airbags than Ford or Chrysler, the auto safety center said. Philip Morris, the cigarette maker, got a Hubbard for a Virginia Slims ad that, according to the National Women's Health Network, implies a brand called ``Superslims'' can help women stay thin. Philip Morris spokesman Les Zuke called that allegation ``absurd.'' Superslims, he said, ``makes two claims: Superslims emits 70 percent less smoke from the lit end and Superslims is an ultralight cigarette that tastes good.'' ``We have received no calls, no letters, no inquiries expressing confusion by any consumers over this clear and simple message,'' Zuke said. Philip Morris also was cited for its ads championing the Bill of Rights. The Coalition on Smoking Or Health dismissed the campaign as a PR effort to defeat government restrictions on tobacco promotion. Gus Buenz, a spokesman for Oldsmobile, said GM had airbags in cars in 1974 and has a strong tradition of safety research. He said the Cutlass ad was meant to highlight the car's roominess, price and responsiveness, as well as fuel economy. ``All we're doing is telling people you can get all those things plus 30 mpg'' on the highway, Buenz said. Other ``winners'' included: -Pan American Airlines for saying its transatlantic fleet is among the youngest - and, by implication, the safest - in the air. The airline counted recently overhauled planes as new to arrive at that conclusion, according to the Aviation Consumer Action Project. -Kellogg for saying that protein in Special K cereal can help women maintain healthy muscle tone while dieting. The Iowa attorney general has alleged in federal court that the ads are misleading, said the Center for Science in the Public Interest. Celeste Clark, vice president of nutrition marketing at Kellogg, said the company stands behind the factual content of its Special K advertising and has been saying it's a high-protein cereal for 35 years. ``We have tried to communicate the contribution Special K makes to a sensible weight loss plan involving diet and exercise,'' she said. ``The campaign is not meant to indicate that Special K alone can help you lose weight.'' -Coors Brewing Co. for Coors Light ads that feature a haunted house and the line that ``it isn't Halloween without the Silver Bullet.'' ``Its appeal to children is chilling,'' said the National Council on Alcoholism and Drug Dependence Inc. -A company sponsoring ``Fabulous Hawaiian Sweepstakes,'' a telephone ad delivered by an automatic dialing machine. The ad is really a pitch for a 900-toll call that costs $6 and repeats what you've already heard, said the Center for the Study of Commercialism. The center said it doesn't know the name of the contest sponsor. There was no immediate comment from other companies contacted for their reaction to the criticism.

DOC.HEAD: UPS Pilots Urged Not to Call in Sick
DOC.TEXT: United Parcel Service reported no increase in absenteeism Monday, the first day of a threatened sickout among UPS pilots. The Independent Pilots Association, which represents the company's 1,200 pilots, said anonymous letters were sent out telling members to call in sick Monday through Wednesday. The union responded by sending members a letter saying a sickout was illegal and asking pilots to ignore it. ``It appears that we may have been able to head this thing off,'' said Robert M. Miller, president of the union. ``But some of our pilots are stating that they don't think we should have stopped it.'' Miller said there was a great deal of frustration among the pilots about the slow progress of negotiations for a new contract. The pilots are working under terms of a Teamsters contract that expired July 31. UPS said operations were normal Monday and the rate of absenteeism was normal. ``There has been no sign of any job action, sickout, walkout or slowdown and none is expected,'' said UPS spokesman Bob Kenney said. Miller and UPS officials said they did not know who was encouraging pilots to call in sick. ``We've had hundreds of phone calls and we said to ignore the sickout,'' Miller said. ``Normally we don't respond to this type of thing, but we want our position known.'' UPS pilots transport almost 7 percent of the company's packages. A widespread sickout would only dent UPS' total volume but could cripple the company's overnight delivery service, its fastest growing and most profitable division. UPS, the world's largest package delivery service, employs about 237,000 people. Most deliveries are made by truck.

DOC.HEAD: AT&T Says It Received More Funding Offers for NCR Deal Than It Needs
DOC.TEXT: American Telephone & Telegraph Co. said Monday it received more offers of loans from banks than it needs to finance its hosile $6.1 billion takeover of NCR Corp. AT&T said more than 50 major U.S. and international banks have offered commitments for the $6 billion credit line the phone company is establishing in its bid to buy the nation's fifth-largest computer maker. AT&T said the credit line will back short-term notes the phone company plans to sell to finance part of the NCR bid. It also said it may draw directly on the credit line for the funding. AT&T met with bankers Thursday on the tender offer, which it announced Wednesday. NCR has said it is not interested in being bought by anyone and that it plans to fight the bid. Also Monday, a federal judge in Baltimore dismissed a suit by AT&T that sought to halt NCR from pursuing tactics to block the takeover. U.S. District Judge Frederic N. Smalkin ruled that his court does not have jurisdiction in the suit, filed Wednesday, because AT&T has not actually sought or obtained proxies from NCR stockholders. NCR, a Maryland-chartered corporation, is based in Dayton, Ohio. On Friday, NCR filed suit in Columbus, Ohio, asking a federal judge to declare valid a strengthened ``poison pill'' anti-takeover plan endorsed by NCR's board of directors. The existing poison pill would allow NCR to issue new stock to its shareholders at half the price if a company seeking a hostile takeover acquired 20 percent of its stock. The strengthened plan would lower the threshold to 15 percent. AT&T was seeking consolidation of the Ohio and Maryland suits and asking that NCR not be granted approval for its latest anti-takeover measure. AT&T also asked that NCR not be allowed to resort to two state anti-takeover measures, the Maryland Business Combination Act and the Control Shares Act. AT&T's lawyers said in court Monday that the phone giant is ``contemplating'' the use of proxies. In a proxy fight, a potential acquiring company seeks to unseat the board of directors of the target corporation. Smalkin said AT&T must first acquire enough NCR proxies to ignite the takeover fight before he could consider legal action.

DOC.HEAD: Chief of SEC's New York Office To Resign
DOC.TEXT: After nearly three years running the largest and busiest outpost of the federal agency that keeps Wall Street honest, Lawrence Iason said Monday he is stepping down. Iason, who took over as head of the Securities and Exchange Commission's New York Regional Office Jan. 25, 1988, told SEC Chairman Richard Breeden last week he planned to leave government service to return to his old law firm. Iason's last day with the SEC will be March 15. ``I've spent about half my career in government,'' said Iason, who clerked for a federal judge, served in the Watergate special prosecutor's office and at the U.S. attorney's office in New York during his legal career. ``Larry has made significant and substantial contributions to the New York regional office and to the commission since his appointment,'' Breeden said in a statement issued by his office. As head of the regional office, Iason, 45, oversaw a staff of 250. ``The time has come. I'm ready to go back to private practice,'' he said in a telephone interview from his office in lower Manhattan. Iason is leaving government to become a partner at the New York firm of Morvillo, Abramowitz and Grant. Otto Obermaier, the U.S. attorney in Manhattan, is a former partner in the firm. Iason conceded that money was a large factor in his decision. SEC regional chiefs make between $71,200 and $83,600, ``a significant difference from private practice,'' Iason said. Iason, who has three young children, said, ``I hate to make them sacrifice for my benefit.'' As head of the New York office, Iason presided over several key investigations. One involved the Business Week insider trading cases stemming from market-sensitive information leaked by employees of the magazine's printers. Another led to an administrative action against the brokerage firm Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corp. that concluded with a settlement of more than $5.6 million for alleged misuse of customer accounts. Iason took over an office in disarray after one regional administrator left suddenly in 1987 and officials at SEC headquarters virtually ran the New York office from Washington. William McLucas, who heads the SEC's Enforcement Division, remembers the low morale and heavy workload in New York during the three months he spent splitting his time between there and Washington before Iason came on board. ``I think what you saw was an office that needed some strong leadership. I thought Larry went in and really put the program back together,'' said McLucas, adding, ``I'm sorry to see him go. I think what he did with that office is remarkable.'' Iason, a 1967 Yale graduate, received his law degree in 1971 at New York University.

DOC.HEAD: Cray Receives First Order for CRAY-3
DOC.TEXT: Cray Computer Corp. announced Monday it has received its first order for a 16-processor Cray-3 supercomputer, which is in development and scheduled to be completed next year. The National Energy Research Supercomputer Center at the Lawrence Livermore Laboratory in California placed the order. The center already has an eight-processor Cray-2 that was installed last April. Cray Computer said the supercomputer center's order of both computers comes to $42 million. The company said the Cray-3 will be delivered to the center in phases beginning with a two-processor system scheduled for installation at the end of 1991. Installation of the 16-processor computer i expected to be completed by summer 1992, Cray Computer officials said. ``We are delighted to have received our first order from such an important supercomputer user as NERSC,'' said Neil Davenport, president and CEO of Cray Computer. Cray Computer was spun off last year from Cray Research Corp. of Minneapolis, a leading supercomputer maker, with the goal of developing the Cray 3. Supercomputers are advanced scientific machines used in weather forecasting, car design, simulation and other tasks that require great computational power.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Opens Sharply Higher, Share Prices Drop
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar opened sharply higher against the Japanese yen Tuesday morning, while the key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange sank. The dollar opened at 131.87 yen, up 1.32 yen from Monday's close of 130.55 yen. The dollar's recovery followed its advance in New York overnight as the U.S. Federal Reserve took no apparent steps to push interest rates lower, dealers said. Lower rates tend to reduce a currency's value. Market players have been expecting the Federal Reserve to ease monetary policy in an effort to revitalize the U.S. economy. ``The dollar in Tokyo is still rising gradually, but it will stay in a range somewhere between 131.60-132.30 yen,'' said Chizuko Satsukawa, a dealer with Chemical Bank. She said dollar-selling by exporters is preventing the currency from rising above the 132.50-yen line for now, but ``the yen is basically weakening, especially toward the end of the year, when there is a substantial increase in demand for the dollar from travelers and trading houses.'' More than a million Japanese are expected to travel overseas for the New Year holidays, and the majority of them buy dollars for the trip. Satsukawa said another factor accelerating the yen's decline was that Japanese investors were buying German marks in anticipation of an interest rate increase in Germany following a Thursday meeting of Germany's central bank. On the stock exchange, the 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average lost 304.13 points, or 1.28 percent, to move to 23,480.54 within the first 15 minutes of trading. Dealers attributed the slide to a weakening yen and profit-taking following consecutive gains in recent days. The index has gained nearly 2,000 points since Wednesday. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bond fell to 87.51 points in early trading from Monday's 87.72-point close. Its yield advanced to 7.165 percent, from 7.120 percent.

DOC.HEAD: National Semiconductor Profit Jumps 45 Percent in Second Quarter
DOC.TEXT: National Semiconductor Corp. said Monday its profit rose 45 percent in its second fiscal quarter, boosted by a credit stemming from the company's recent restructuring. For the three months ended Nov. 25, the company reported net income of $3.5 million, or 1 cent a share, compared with $2.4 million, or zero cents a share, for the same period a year ago. Sales for period, its second fiscal quarter of 1991, were $427.4 million, compared with $416.8 million for the same quarter a year ago, a gain of 2 percent. National Semiconductor said the quarter's results included a $2.4 million credit reflecting the reversal of restructuring charges stemming from the closure of its plant in Danbury, Conn. The company also announced during the quarter that it had signed a letter of intent to sell its plant in Puyallup, Wash., to Matsushita Electronics Corp. of Japan. The transaction is expected to be completed by April. Charles E. Sporck, National Semiconductor's president and chief executive officer, said the company had met financial goals it had set for the quarter. ``The significant improvement in operating performance in this quarter, compared to the first quarter of this fiscal year, reflects the benefits resulting from the restructuring activity which the company undertook this past August,'' he said. In the first quarter of its fiscal 1991, National Semiconductor reported a loss of $165.5 million, or $1.63 cents a share, compared with a loss of $21.9 million, or 24 cents share, in the first quarter of fiscal 1990. The first quarter's results included a pre-tax charge of $143.6 million in connection with the restructuring. In August, the company said it would lay off 2,000 employees and close two factories. Sporck also said the company reduced its debt by $18 million and its inventory by $20 million from the first quarter.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Approves Class Action Suit for Eagle-Picher
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with judge certifying a class action suit. Picks up 9th graf pvs, `The motion ...'.
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge on Monday formally consolidated 65,000 asbestos injury claims against Eagle-Picher Industries Inc. in a major step toward resolving a natiowide legal and medical crisis. U.S. District Judge Jack B. Weinstein certified a class action suit after a daylong hearing on a settlement proposal for Eagle-Picher that faces opposition from nearly all victims' attorneys involved in the case. Attorneys said they would fight Weinstein's consolidation of the cases, saying the company's $625 million long-term settlement plan provides too little money and too few safeguards for victims of lung cancer and other respiratory ailments. Weinstein faces an additional roadblock in the formoof a petition filed Monday in U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Cincinnati seeking to force Eagle-Picher involuntarily into bankruptcy proceedings. Under federal law, the bankruptcy petition puts all other court action involving the company on hold. But Weinstein said the involuntary bankruptcy filing was ``fradulent on its face'' and he was moving ahead immediately to certify the class action in spite of the bankruptcy petition. He also froze all litigation involving Eagle-Picher except to pay $45 million in previously settled claims. The Cincinnati-based industrial products manufacturer has said it would have to seek bankruptcy court refuge if no solution to its asbestos problems were reached soon. Eagle-Picher is liable for injuries caused by cement products containing asbestos it made from 1931 to 1971. The company has spent $540 million in the last five years on the issue and faces an estimated $600 million in future claims. New claims against the company are being filed at an average of 20,000 annually. Eagle-Picher Chairman Thomas Petry said he was pleased Weinstein moved to create the class action. He called the involuntary bankruptcy petition ``a desperate attempt ... to circumvent and derail these proceedings.'' The motion was filed by three asbestos victims who want Eagle-Picher placed under bankruptcy court supervision on grounds the company had failed to meet $19,200 in settlement payments. The company said it had met all obligations to the victims, creditors, lenders and other businesses. Plaintiffs lawyers acknowledged the filing was a strategic maneuver to try to block the settlement plan being considered by Weinstein. It would create a trust consisting of cash and company stock to compensate workers made sick inhlaing asbestos. Weinstein also appointed former federal judge Marvin Frankel to study whether Eagle-Picher claimants would receive more money in a bankruptcy or through the proposed settlement. He also said he planned to hold hearings on the fairness of the plan in New York, Cincinnati and Detroit. Lawyers complained the judge is forcing a national asbestos settlement without their endorsement. Weinstein wants a national plan to avoid long and costly trials that sap money for victims, some of whom have died before being compensated. Currently, more than 90,000 asbestos cases clog state and federal courts. A separate case involves the cash-strapped Manville trust fund, which faces 130,000 claims and is being reorganized under orders from Weinstein. ``The plaintiffs have been deprived of an opportunity to be heard,'' said Ron Motley, a Charleston, S.C., lawyer representing several thousand asbestos victims. ``We are resigned to the impossibility of getting a fair hearing in this court,'' said Steven Kazan, an attorney for the Asbestos Victims of America, which has about 18,000 members. Only one of three lawyers appointed by Weinstein to represent current Eagle-Picher victims has approved the plan, and he does not have any asbestos clients. More than 90 attorneys with 40,000 asbestos clients signed a petition Monday opposing the settlement plan. ``There is a massive lack of confidence in the settlement,'' Grant Hering, a New York plaintiffs lawyer, told the judge. ``For people who are victims, who have suffered what they have suffered, it is a gimmick they can't comprehend.'' Under the plan, Eagle-Picher would pay $460 million in annual payments over 20 years into the trust, plus $120 million from the company's cash flow. It also would contribute $45 million to pay settlements already negotiated. The trust would receive 25 percent of Eagle-Picher stock and 50 percent if the company failed to meet its annual payments after five years. In an apparent attempt to quell some of the criticism of the plan, which was presented to the court last week, Weinstein modified it to grant the trust voting control of Eagle-Picher if the company failed to meet annual payments during the plan's first five years. He also said payments should begin by Nov. 30, 1993, regardless of delays due to possible court appeals, and that victims should not lose any rights agreed to in a settlement if Eagle-Picher declared bankruptcy.

DOC.HEAD: Campbell Sells Freshbake and Seafood Operations
DOC.TEXT: Campbell Soup Co. has sold two of its European businesses as part of a major restructuring to improve the company's financial performance, the company said Monday. Campbell said it sold its ``Freshbake'' vegetable operations in the United Kingdom and seafood businesses in the U.K. and Belgium to Albert Fisher Group PLC for an undisclosed price. The units had annual sales of about $150 million, Campbell said. The food units were among five businesses Campbell put up for sale in May in a move to streamline the company's operations. Also put up for sale were D. Lazzaroni & C. SpA of Italy, and Campbell Irish Foods Ltd. and Mallow Foods Ltd. of Ireland. ``This sale results from our strategic decision to focus our European efforts on branded value-added prepared foods,'' Campbell Chief Executive Officer David W. Johnson said in a statement released by the Camden-based company.
